1 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria Gets Six New States


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - As part of its three-year transition programme to democracy, expected to end in october 1998, Nigeria's military regime has created six new states, making the west African country a 36-state federation of 100 million people.

"The exercise of state creation is not new to our nation," the military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, said Tuesday when announcing the creation of the new states in a broadcast to mark Nigeria's 36th anniversary of independence from Britain in 1960.

From a-three-regional structure at independence, a fourth region (The Mid- West Region) was carved out of the old Western Region in 1963. In May 1967, the Gowon administration, exploiting the political mood of the period, transformed Nigeria into a-12-state federation. 

The Murtala administration that overthrew the Gowon regime, restructured Nigeria into a federation of 19 states. The Babangida government increased the number to 30 with 593 local councils and the Federal capital territory, Abuja, before the latest addition.

Abacha also announced the creation of 183 additional local councils to bring the overall total to 776.

He conceded that "this rapid and enormous expansion of our political and administrative structure within less than four decades has continued to exert heavy pressure on our economy and system of governance."

But he said the latest exercise was "to ensure fair spread and balancing within the geo-political zones of the country applying such criteria as population and land mass, among others."

The new states include Bayelsa, carved out of the old southeastern state of Rivers with Yenegoa as its headquarters. Others are Ekiti from the former western state of Ondo, with Ado-Ekiti as capital, and Ebonyi, excised from the eastern states of Enugu and Abia, with Abakiliki as capital.

The three other states are Nasarawa, with headquarters in Lafia, carved out of the old middle-belt state of Plateau, while Gombe and Zamfara are the two new states from the north. Gombe, with capital in Gombe, is from the old Bauchi state and Zamfara with Gusau as capital is from the former Sokoto state.

The Abacha administration in December, 1995 set up a committee on the creation of states, local governments and boundary adjustment. The committee received a total of 72 requests for new states, 2,369 for local councils and 286 on boundary adjustment.

A new committee is to continue work on the boundary demarcation.

In an apparent move to assuage those whose requests were not met, Abacha warned against "festivities and jubilation among communities over the creation of new states and council areas."

Agitators often see state creation as passport to larger share of the national wealth and for bringing governance closer to their doorsteps.

But Abacha warned that the latest exercise should be seen in the light of " administrative convenience and necessity rather than the separation of peoples and communities."

On the transition programme, he called for "a disciplined and orderly conduct of partisan politics."

His government has registered as parties for the transition politics, five of the 15 political associations that applied for registration.

Abacha warned politicians to "avoid the pitfalls of the past, learn from the bitter experiences we have passed through and build a strong and virile democratic culture."

In his address, which also touched on socio-economic issues, he announced the setting up of a high-powered national committee on the education problem in the country.

The committee of "eminent professionals and well-meaning Nigerians," would examine past and present policies on eduction, study the problems that had retarded education growth and proffer solutions, he said.

Teachers of Nigeria's 38 federal and state-run universities have been on strike since April 9, demanding improved conditions of service and better funding of the universities.

Abacha also named businessman Ernest Shonekan, as chairman of another high- powered committee on Nigeria's economic development.

Shonekan was head of the interim civilian administration, which former military ruler Gen. Ibrahim Babangida installed when he stepped out of office in August 1993, after annulling the presidential election in June that year.

Abacha took over power from Shonekan on 17 Nov. 1993 in the heat of political crisis over the annulled presidential poll. Abacha charged the Shonekan committee with implementing the military government's new 'vision 2010' programme, to lay a solid economic foundation for national progress.

In the short run, he said his administration would consolidate the economic gains of the immediate past by putting in place "appropriate policy measures to bring down cost of food stuff, goods and services."

Families of political detainees were disappointed that Abacha's speech said nothing about those in detention.

There had been high public expectation that he would have addressed the issue, especially that of politician Moshood Abiola, the acclaimed winner of the annulled presidential election.

Abiola is awaiting trial for treason after declaring himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

Africa News


October 1, 1996


Cote d'Ivoire;
Cote d'Ivoire's Parliament Adopts Security Law


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire - The police in Cote d'Ivoire can now physically conduct searches on individuals, vehicles and homes and private places at any time of the day under a law adopted by parliament here Monday.

The law, whose objective is to curb the spiral of banditry in this West African country of about 14 million people, was approved by 155 votes while 13 voted against it. 

The searches would be conducted on any suspicion that there has been a breach of the law.

Before its adoption into law, the bill was vehemently criticized by certain politicians and humanitarian organizations, including the Ivorian Human Rights League.

The League argued the proposed legislation would be in violation of the universal declaration of human rights and the freedom of citizens.

But, at an earlier luncheon organized for the law makers, President Henri Konan Bedie had asked them to pass the law to give the security forces the means to combat the rise in organized crime.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


3 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


United States and Africa;
United States Official Meets President Rawlings


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana, - George Moose, U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Monday held discussions behind closed doors with President Jerry Rawlings believed to be on the proposed formation of an African crisis response force to deal with conflicts on the continent.

Later in an interview with journalists, Moose said the meeting was to help redefine joint notions between the two countries on conflict management and how best to rationalize them. 

"Ghana has a lot of experience to share with other countries through her distinguished role in peacekeeping efforts," he said.

Moose said the meeting is an ongoing process of dialogue between Ghana and the U.S, aimed at enhancing capacity to deal with conflicts on the continent.

Experiences from Liberia, Rwanda and Burundi, he said, call for the creation of lasting institutions and bodies that will manage them.

Sources at the meeting said no concrete decisions have been reached on the formation of such a force. "Ideas have been thrown about, nothing concrete has been reached. When this is done, the technicalities will be worked out and we will know what to do."

The sources said Ghana welcomed the idea, but wants to look at the details to enable the country know what exactly is expected of it.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 1, 1996


Business;
Zambia Railways' Money Stuck In Closed Bank


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia Railways and Zimbabwe's National Railways have 84 million British pounds sterling stuck in the liquidated Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI) in the United Kingdom.

Zambia's deputy communications and transport minister, Gilbert Mululu, disclosed in Lusaka Monday that the money was transferred into the failed bank's account from a Barclays Bank account three days before the bank ran into trouble. BCCI was closed in 1991.

"We are hopeful that the money may be recovered when the liquidators of the bank declare proceeds to various creditors... We shall receive our share of the money as soon as the liquidators of the bank declare how much we shall receive," Mululu said.

He said that the money was held in trust for the defunct Rhodesia Railways, whose assets were shared between Zimbabwe and Zambia.

Mululu explained that some assets could not be practically divided such as buildings and similar infrastructure, which was sold, from which the money locked up in the bank was realized.

A recent meeting between Zambian and Zimbabwean officials decided that a new company be formed to handle the sale of infrastructure.

The new company known as Emerged Railways Properties, will have offices registered both in Zambia and Zimbabwe, and would be handling non-divisible assets of the old railway company and the Victoria Falls Bridge in southern Zambia, which was also jointly owned.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996

5 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


Mozambique;
White In Mozambique, But Did He Assassinate Palme?


BYLINE: Paul Fauvet, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The man named by a South African police defector Dirk Coetzee as the assassin of Swedish Prime Minister Olof Palme is living in Beira and working for a company called Transport Commodity Trading (TCT).

Anthony James White's presence in Beira is far from clandestine: in 1994 he was among representatives of timber companies who protested loudly at attempts by the former rebel movement, Renamo, to extort money from businesses working in hardwood forests under Renamo control.

Tuesday's issue of the independent newsheet, Mediafax, cites anonymous South African sources as saying that White was involved in contraband operations in the 1980s, and was linked to both the South African and the Mozambican security services.

The paper says that its sources seemed afraid of White. The sources contacted by the well-informed Mediafax in Beira and in Pretoria warned:" Be careful with him". 

The notorious South African spy Craig Williamson, whom the apartheid regime boasted infiltrated the upper echelons of the liberation movement, the ANC, admits that he worked with White in a company called "Longreach".

But the word "Longreach" seems to have very sinister connotations. For Coetzee, and his successor at the head of the South African police Vlakplaas death squad, Eugene de Kock, what really existed was "Operation Longreach", a plan to assassinate the outspokenly anti-apartheid Swedish Premier (and perhaps other foreign leaders too - less than eight months after Palme's death in February 1986, Mozambican President Samora Machel died in a mysterious plane crash on South African soil).

Mediafax writes that Williamson had a "dual relationship" with Mozambique. He claimed to have acted as a channel between the Mozambican and South African governments in the late 1980s, but also had a business link with TCT, widely viewed as a company set up by the now defunct Mozambican Security Service, SNASP.

Former Security Minister Mariano Matsinhe, however, denied Williamson's boast. He told Mediafax that he never needed to use a lower level figure like Williamson when he could go directly to much higher figures in the apartheid military apparatus.

"I had a direct channel with the South African army", he said. 'I didn't need any liaison officer. My contact was Gen (Jannie) Geldenhuis".

Matsinhe claimed that he knew Willimason through TCT, and believed that he was also involved in the Mozambican fisheries sector. (Williamson has confirmed to the Swedish paper, Aftonbladet, that he had interests in lobster fishing south of Beira).

Asked whether he knew White, Matsinhe said "there's a White in Beira. I think he's managing a sector of TCT". He is. White runs a TCT sawmill on the outskirts of Beira.

Matsinhe denied that TCT was a company run by Mozambican security. But he admitted it was set up by Filipe Franco, a Mozambican with known security links.

Matsinhe said he believed that Franco is currently in Angola. That is also where Williamson is.

Apart from its Beira operations, TCT also has an office in Maputo. On Monday it was locked up with no sign of life.

The Mozambique news agency, AIM, has been unable to contact TCT in Beira, because many of Beira's phone numbers still have no contact with Maputo following the collapse of the telecommunication company's parabolic antenna at the Beira earth station in mid-September.

But the French news agency, AFP, managed to speak to White from Harare: He categorically denied any involvement in the Palme assassination.

Apparently de Kock, who started the latest round of investigations into the Palme murder by naming Williamson as the man who masterminded it, does not agree with Coetzee that it was White who pulled the trigger.

In the daily Johannesburg newspaper, The Star, of Monday, another South African death squad member, Peter Casselton, said he had spoken personally with de Kock in prison on Sunday, and de Kock excluded White from operation Longreach.

He did, however, link White and Williamson in the smuggling of 84 tons of ivory from Burundi in the early 1980s, and in the trafficking of rhinoceros horns in South Africa itself.

Meanwhile, it seems that the Swedish authorities themselves are not taking Coetzee's denunciation seriously enough to press the Mozambican government into taking any action. As of Monday afternoon there had been no official Swedish contact with the office of the Mozambican Prime Minister Pascoal Mocumbi.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

6 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


Nigeria;
Five Parties registered in Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Five political parties have been legalized in Nigeria out of the 15 that had applied to vie for power when the military-set transition period comes to a end in 1998.

The chairman of the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria, Summer Dagogo- Jack, Monday named the parties as the United Nigeria Congress Party (UNCP), the Committee for National Consensus (CNC), National Center Party of Nigeria (NCPN), the Democratic Party of Nigeria (DPN) and the Grassroots Democratic Movement (GDM). 

"All political associations that have not qualified for registration are hereby dissolved," he added.

Dagogo-Jack said members of the unregistered associations were free to join any of the five registered parties on individual basis.

Under the military government's three-year transition programme, the July- September period was set aside for party registration, delineation of constituencies and production of voters' register.

The political transition is expected to end 1 Oct. 1998.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

7 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


East Africa;
Weekly Roundup of Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2494 words


 

Nairobi - This is number 28 (23 - 29 September 1996) in a series of weekly reports from IRIN on general developments in the Great Lakes region. Sources for the information below include UN agencies, NGOs, other international organisations and media reports. IRIN issues these reports for the benefit of the humanitarian community, but accepts no responsibility as to the accuracy of the original sources.

* The Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee (RSCC) held its second meeting in Kigali, Rwanda on Wednesday and said that Pierre Buyoya, leader of Burundi's regime, should be "available" for the next regional summit. Noting the 'positive steps' taken by the regime towards meeting the conditions set out by the Arusha II summit, the Committee emphasized that the 'most important condition yet to be fully met is the immediate and unconditional negotiations with all groups.'

'Other leaders of parties to the conflict' may also be invited to to the next regional summit, according to the RSCC statement. This is thought to include Leonard Nyangoma, leader of the National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), whose armed wing, the FDD, is fighting within Burundi. The Committee decided that sanctions 'have so far been effective' and will stay in place, although fertilizer and vegetable seeds have been exempted from the embargo. 

No date has been set for the proposed third regional summit, but preparations for this will take place at a Ministerial meeting to be held on 10 October, and the summit, at the Heads of State level, is expected to follow soon afterwards. The next meeting of the RSCC will take place in Arusha, Tanzania, on 8 October. The full RSCC statement is available from IRIN.

The RSCC's decision to invite Major Buyoya to the next regional summit was welcomed by Jean-Luc Ndizeye, his spokesman, as "a very good step, but a small step." Ndizeye again called for the total lifting of the sanctions, saying that "the embargo is killing any chances of peace in Burundi". Buyoya's spokesman would not comment on the part of the statement inviting leaders of other parties to the conflict to attend the next summit, saying only "we will analyse the issue when the time comes." On 22 September Pierre Buyoya had said in an interview with the East African newspaper that he was " ready to start negotiations with armed factions" but that "on the other side they are not ready".

Pope John Paul II on Wednesday called for the sanctions to be eased, saying they are "creating a greater burden for the civilian population". His remarks came at the end of his weekly general audience when making a tribute to Burundian Archbishop Joachim Ruhuna, who died in an ambush on 9 September.

* The power struggle within FRODEBU intensified on Wednesday with 34 party activists in Nairobi declaring their support for Leonard Nyangoma, leader of the CNDD. Their declaration followed Mr Nyangoma's announcement on 19 September that he had taken over the party's presidency from former parliamentary speaker Jean Minani. This had been rejected by Mr Minani and by Augustin Nzojibwami, the secretary-general of FRODEBU.

Mr Nzojibwami was one of five FRODEBU officials reported last week to have left the German ambassador's residence in Bujumbura, where they had taken refuge. Mr Nzojibwami said that they had left their refuge to fill the vacuum in which Mr Nyangoma had made his announcement. He claimed FRODEBU would need to hold a party congress to turn its policy away from "non-violence and consensus".

* The town of Bukavu in South Kivu, Zaire, was reported calm at the end of the week after Zaire and Rwanda agreed on a ceasefire following exchanges of mortar fire on Sunday 22 September, Monday and Tuesday. Both Governments accused the other of having started the shelling, which killed at least one Zairean and injured five others on Tuesday night.

The Zairean version of events is that the exchange of fire first began on the Sunday after prisoners escaped from the central prison in Cyangugu, Rwanda. The Rwandese Patriotic Army was said to have shot at them as well as some Zairean soldiers near the border. The Zaireans claim that this was when they began firing at Rwanda. The Rwandans claim, however, that the shelling was started by Zaire. A ceasefire was negotiated on Tuesday, but on Wednesday the deputy governor of South Kivu, Lwabandji Lwasi, accused the Rwandans of breaking it by firing shots over the border. No further incidents have been reported since.

The insecurity prompted the United Nations to relocate 23 'non-essential' expatriate aid agency personnel to Nairobi on Tuesday. The International Federation of the Red Cross also evacuated three of its seven delegates in Bukavu after two shells landed in the garden of a hotel where IFRC staff were staying.

The shelling between Rwanda and Zaire reflects growing tension between the two countries following accusations by the Zairean authorities that the RPA have been training Banyamulenge near Uvira, South Kivu, and encouraging them to destabilise eastern Zaire, using Burundi as a rear base. This claim has been categorically rejected by the Governments of Rwanda and Burundi. Meanwhile, a UN Special Envoy of the Secretary- General, Ibrahima Fall, arrived in Kinshasa on 22 September to seek clarification on Zairean allegations that UNHCR had provided logistic support to armed groups infiltrating from Zaire and Rwanda. The charge was categorically rejected by the UN Secretary-General on 17 September.

The Banyamulenge are Zairean Tutsis who migrated from Rwanda into Zaire over several centuries and who say they have been targetted in recent months by the Zairean Army and authorities. According to reports from a Banyamulenge spokesman in exile, the Zairean authorities executed 40 Banyamulenge held in detention on Sunday 22 September. This was said to have been in retaliation for the killings of Zairean soldiers by Banyamulenge militia.

Correction: IRIN would like a correct a factual error in last week's Weekly Roundup (22.9.96). In a section on accusations against the local authorities in Uvira by Amnesty International the District Commissioner was named incorrectly. A subsequent Amnesty statement corrected this to Shweka Mutabazi. We apologize for any misunderstandings which may have arisen from this error.

* The United Nations International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR) agreed on Wednesday to postpone the trial of Georges Rutaganda, suspected of genocide and crimes against humanity, until 6 March 1997 on grounds of ill health. Mr Rutaganda is accused of being the second vice-president of the Interahamwe militia and of having played a leading role in the genocide. The court rejected, however, a request by Rutaganda's defence counsel that he be allowed to go to Europe for treatment of his illness, saying that he was receiving adequate care in a local civilian hospital in Arusha.

Neither Luc de Temmerman, the defence counsel, nor the court have revealed what illness he is suffering from, but Mr de Temmerman claimed that "if he is not treated in Europe, he won't be there in March to be tried". Meanwhile, the ICTR accepted on Friday a prosecution request that names of witnesses should not be disclosed to the public on security grounds. Yakob Haile Mariam, prosecting counsel, said one witness in Rwanda had already been told she would be killed if she went to Tanzania to testify against Mr Rutaganda.

The ICTR began the trial last week of Jean-Paul Akayesu, the former mayor of Taba in central Rwanda, also accused of having played a major role in the genocide. Before the trial got underway, African Rights, the London-based human rights organisation, released a report detailing Akayesu's actions during the genocide and showing that he 'went to extraordinary lengths to ensure the wholesale slaughter of Tutsis in his commune'. The full report is available from IRIN.

The trial of Akayesu, however, has also been postponed - this time for one month. Johan Scheers, his defence counsel, threatened on Friday to resign unless the court granted his request for a postponement of the case, saying that he had been given insufficient time to prepare his case. On Thursday the ICTR was also attacked by the Governments of Rwanda and Zimbabwe for slow progress since its establishment. They accused the UN of racial bias, saying that the Tribunal had acted more quickly to bring Bosnian war criminals to justice.

* The UNHCR announced on Tuesday that it was excluding from refugee status 20 Rwandans indicted by the International Tribunal in connection with the genocide. The list includes people who are currently being held in Arusha as well as others known to be in Europe and in refugee camps and elsewhere in Africa. The UNHCR is urging Governments not to provide those listed with asylum. They are: Ignace Bagilishema, Charles Sikubwabo, Aloys Ndimbati, Vincent Rutaganira, Mika Muhimana, Ryandikayo, Obed Ruzindana, Clement Kayishema, Jean-Paul Akayesu, Georges Rutaganda, Alfred Musema, Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, Gerard Ntakirutimana, Andre Ntagerura, Ladislas Ntaganzwa, Anatole Nsengiyumva, Elie Ndayambaje, Ferdinand Nahimana, Theoneste Bagosora and Eliezer Niyitegeka.

* The South African Government has been criticized by South African human rights groups, arms officials and politicians for its decision on Thursday to approve private sales of weapons to Rwanda. The decision has predictably been criticized by the RDR (Rally for the Return of Refugees and Democracy in Rwanda), the umbrella organisation representing Rwandan refugees.

* Rwanda's Ambassador to France, Christophe Mfizi, resigned from his post on Tuesday according to media reports. The embassy did not say why Mfizi, who was appointed to Paris in March 1995, had resigned. The first secretary, Modeste Rutabayiru, will temporarily replace him.

* Human Rights Watch and the Federation Internationale de Ligues des Droits de L'Homme called on Monday for the International Tribunal to investigate and prosecute rape and other gender-related crimes. The ICTR has to date issued no indictments for rape or other forms of sexual violence. The call followed the release of an HRW/FIDH report entitled, 'Shattered Lives: Sexual Violence During the Rwandan Genocide and its Aftermath', which details 'horrific' attacks on women and their families during the genocide. HRW/FIDH's recommendations included a call on donors to ensure that aid programmes meet women's needs, especially in the areas of criminal justice, health care, housing, credit, education, vocational training and trauma conselling, and on the Government of Rwanda to improve coordination between ministries seeking to issues relating to women.

* Some 284 people were killed in Rwanda in August according to a report by the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) released on Wednesday. HRFOR blamed the RPA for 159 of these deaths, while responsibility for the other killings lay with Hutu rebels who continued to target local officials and survivors of the genocide. The prison population reached 81,300 at the end of August, an increase of 2,800 since July.

* The peace agreement between the Ugandan and Sudanese Governments came under strain last week after the Sudanese Government all but admitted having bombed northern Uganda on Sunday 22 September. On Monday Amama Mbabazi, Uganda's Minister of Defence, had said that two Sudanese MiG planes dropped bombs aimed at the army barracks in Moyo on Sunday 22 September, but missed their target.

The Sudanese Government at first denied the claim, but later admitted that the attack had taken place. Iran's deputy foreign minister, Sheikul Islam Hessein, heading a five-member Iranian delegation to Uganda to investigate the incident, said that the attack could have been the result of a navigational error or an intelligence failure. The Iranians have recently mediated a normalisation of relations between Uganda and Sudan, and in a recent peace agreement the two countries committed themselves to preventing attacks from their territories against each other.

The agreement was further thrown into doubt, however, following reports on Friday that 30 people, including 28 civilians, were killed when rebels from the Lord's Resistance Army attacked Kitgum town on Wednesday. The civilians were caught in the cross fire during fighting between the army and the rebels. The Ugandan Government claims that the LRA fighters entered the country last week from bases in Sudan.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

Africa News


October 1, 1996


Burundi;
U.S. Bishops Mourn Deaths of Bishop and Others in Burundi


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is a letter dated September 20, 1996 to His Excellency Bernard Bududira Bishop of Bururi, president, Conference des Eveques du Burundi, from the president of the National Catholic Bishops Conference in the United States,

Your Excellency:

It is with great sadness that I have learned of the tragic death of our brother bishop Joachim Ruhuna, Archbishop of Gitega, Sister Concessa of the Sisters of Charity, and the other individuals who were caught in the ambush. I offer my heartfelt condolences to you, the brother bishops of your Conference, to the families of the victims and to the faithful of the diocese. I join with the Holy Father in deploring this heinous murder "which joins a chain of unheard of violence."

Archbishop Ruhuna's death is a heartbreaking reminder of the urgent need for the continued pursuit of reconciliation and justice in Burundi. I pledge our Conference's continued solidarity with the Burundian bishops, and the continued support of your Conference's efforts to bring God's peace to your troubled land. I have attached, for your information, a statement which I issued in response to the archbishop's death.

With a prayerful hope that we may never be witness to such an act of cruelty again, and that the archbishop's sacrifice may lead to dialogue and mutual understanding, I remain,

Fraternally your in Christ, Most Reverend Anthony M. Pilla, Bishop of Cleveland, President, NCCB/USCC


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

9 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Bank Head Says Africa at Crossroads


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3534 words


 

Washington DC - Following is the text of an address by Omar Kabbaj, president of the African Development Bank (AfDB), to the Overseas Development Council on September 30.

It is for me a pleasure and welcome opportunity to join you, President Sewell and distinguished guests, this afternoon in exchanging views on the role of the AfDB Group in African development. Our special thanks go to the Overseas Development Council not only for hosting this event, but also for the important role it plays in seeking to inform and improve the multilateral approaches and institutions that promote international development. In line with this basic objective of ODC, I will therefore take the next few minutes to share with you some ideas about the African Development Bank -- by taking up aspects of its past, present and future.

The AfDB Group

As you may know, the African Development Bank Group comprises mainly the Bank itself, established in 1964, which is the non-concessional window with a capital base of about US$24 billion 20($24,000 million); and the African Development Fund, the principal concessional resource affiliate, with total subscriptions of over $11 billion ($11,000 million) (before the latest Seventh Replenishment). 

The Agreement establishing the Bank stipulates that it shall contribute to the economic development and social progress of its regional member countries, individually and jointly. At the beginning, the membership was composed only of African countries, but today total membership stands at 77 regional and non-regional countries, with the United States as the leading non-regional shareholder, having 5.7 percent of the total voting power. Additionally, the United States accounts for some 13 percent of subscriptions to the African Development Fund (before the latest Seventh Replenishment).

These contributions have enabled the United States to work in concert with other donors in the provision of finance and technical assistance supporting development programmes in Africa. This is reinforced by the representation of the United States in the governing bodies of the Institution, which gives it a strong voice in the policies and management of the Bank Group. U.S. participation has also enabled firms in this country to compete in the provision of goods and services for projects and programmes financed by the Bank Group. Thus, at the end of 1995, cumulative Bank Group disbursements for procurement of goods and services to non-regional country suppliers amounted to US$10.8 billion ($10,800 million); of this total, about US$765 million was made to U.S. suppliers. Clearly, therefore, the participation of the United States in the Bank Group has not only been supportive of Africa but also beneficial to U.S. business.

The Bank Group has, over the years, pursued the traditional functions of MDBs by mobilizing and deploying resources to finance projects and programmes. In these areas, the Bank has made major strides from its modest beginnings in the 1960s so that by the end of 1995, the Bank Group had cumulatively approved over 1900 loans and grants amounting to nearly $30 billion ($30,000 million). While financing projects has constituted the primary preoccupation, the institution has, in response to the crisis of the 1980s, also been substantially engaged in policy-based operations to support reform and adjustment programmes, in close cooperation with the World Bank. For the period 1987 to date, policy-based operations have accounted for some 20 percent of Bank Group commitments.

Recent Institutional Reforms

The Bank Group, like other MDBs, has been seeking ways to enhance the quality of its operations and to foster overall development effectiveness. For the past one year or so, specific reforms have been implemented in respect of operational quality, financial management, institutional management and organization, and overall governance and related matters. With regard to operations, the main thrust has been the implementation of an Action Plan for improving the quality of operations centering on issues of portfolio performance and lending policies and practices.

Country assistance strategies are now systematically guiding all lending operations which (have) fully taken into account country risk and country performance. Along with these, there has been active work to complete an overall review of the Bank Group's Portfolio. The first Annual Portfolio Performance Review Report has been considered by our Boards of Directors this month -- revealing reasonable overall performance so far, although more remains to be done. Attention has also been given to strengthening post- evaluation activities as a means of organizing and using lessons of experience in designing new projects. Consultations with other MDBs are also going on for exchanging experiences and advancing on technical methodologies.

With respect to procurement of goods and services for projects funded by the Bank Group, a revamped system has been put in place to ensure complete transparency and unambiguous implementation procedures. Efforts have also been sustained to cancel non-performing loans and grants. In this regard, a major cancellation of loans and grants -- adding up to over US$2 billion ($2, 000 million) for the Bank Group over September 1995 to July 1996 -- has been concluded after extensive consultations with the borrowers. The resources so freed will be returned to the appropriate common pools for reallocation.

In the area of financial management, emphasis has been placed on controlling loan arrears by tightening the policy on sanctions, by systematically applying directives on cancellations, and by increasing coordination with the Bretton Woods Institutions. Beyond these, recent internal studies and Board Discussions have addressed the Bank's lending rate, currency management, and net income management.

On the organizational side, the Bank's leaner structure put in place early this year, is now well in place. The new structure entailed the compression of supervisory posts by well over a third of the previous size; and separation, with compensation of about 20 percent of staff members. More recent efforts have been focused on efficient and transparent recruitment as well as on determination of training requirements. A number of training programmes, for example, in macro-economic analysis and environmental management, have already commenced. We are also proceeding with plans to relaunch the Young Professionals Programme to ensure renewal of staff.

On overall institutional governance, a Special Study on Governance and Related Issues is being considered by the Bank's Ad-Hoc Committee of Governors on the Fifth General Capital Increase. Aspects of the Study that do not require actions by Governors are already being addressed by Management and the Boards of Directors. There are other ongoing exercises relating to the review of policies and operations as well as to financial control and management.

The programme of reforms has come a long way and received the endorsement of our shareholders, regional and non-regional -- as partly reflected in the conclusion this year, of consultations on the Seventh General Replenishment of the African Development Fund. As a result, total concessional resources amounting to about US$3.0 billion ($3,000 million) will be available to fund projects and programmes over the period 1996-98 in the low-income regional member countries. On this basis, we should be able to support a combined -- concessional and non-concessional -- annual lending programme of about US$2.5 billion ($2,500 million) over the same period. To supplement our own resources, we will step up our catalytic role by intensifying Bank Group collaboration and co-financing activities with bilateral and other multilateral development institutions.

Development and Operational Policies

Permit me to address next some issues in development policy and operations. The current development policy priorities of the Bank Group emanate from Africa's over-arching development objectives in the 1990s. These focus on accelerating production growth, promoting human resource development, poverty reduction, and attending to the foundations of longer-term development. In furtherance of these objectives, the Bank Group would also provide support for critical cross-sectoral concerns, such as women in development, environmental management, and private sector promotion.

The Bank Group accords high recognition to the central role that should be accorded to poverty reduction in the continent. Estimates by international institutions, for instance, indicate that, on current trends, while the number of poor people elsewhere in the developing world would decrease by 300 million over the fifteen years to the turn of the century, the number in low- income Africa is projected to increase by 85 million. And this situation is being exacerbated by the AIDS pandemic threatening a rising share of the population. Consequently, therefore, the Bank is evolving deliberate approaches to supporting the attack on poverty. A substantial share of Bank Group interventions (as much as 65 percent in the case of concessional resources) would be directed to projects and programmes in agriculture and the social sectors; and some programmes would be direct and targeted at poverty reduction.

In our overall approach to poverty reduction and related issues -- like the environment -- we have been seeking cooperation with non-governmental organizations (NGOs). For as you know, NGOs have often made the greatest impact in areas like grassroot activities, gender issues, and community participation, which have eluded official development assistance. We have a policy in place to increase collaboration with NGOs. Already, the Bank has held several consultations with regional and non-regional NGOs, and a major conference is scheduled for November 1996.

The preparatory discussions have focused on issues of enhancing collaboration between the Bank and NGOs on policy concerns and other activities, especially the Bank's poverty reduction programme. We will be making further strides in this area, with the finalization of a new micro- enterprise assistance strategy which will set the framework for extending micro-credit to the poorest groups, using NGOs and other grassroot organizations. In working with NGOs and with others in the development community, we intend to systematically provide information on all relevant activities of the Bank Group -- to encourage transparency and dialogue. The Bank Group's Policy on Disclosure of Information -- including a proposal to establish an Information Centre -- is under consideration of our Boards of Directors.

I should also mention, in the context of poverty reduction and social development, a major issue -- the debt of the poor countries -- currently on the active agenda of the international community. We in the Bank have supported and participated in the international consultations on the issue. Internal reflections are, therefore, under way in consultations with the Bretton Woods Institutions, on the possible options and modalities that may be applied by the Bank Group for participating in the debt initiative -- of course, subject to our own financial constraints.

To be sustainable, the goal of poverty reduction should be linked with the pursuit of broad-based economic growth, partly through raising the investment rate. In many of the low-income countries, the investment rate is inadequate to meet replacement needs, let alone supporting new production capacity. The goal should be to lift the investment rate not only through increased mobilization of official flows, but also by tapping potentials from domestic sources, especially that coming from the private sector. Indeed, it would not at all be an exaggeration to say that achieving sustained growth would critically depend on the extent to which the private sector succeeds in mobilizing the requisite resources for investment.

Given this importance of private investment, we have in the Bank recently revamped our private-sector strategy to emphasize the aspect of leveraging our financing by acting as catalyst and mobilizer of private capital, both domestic and international. In all these efforts, we will work closely with other financing institutions such as IFC, the World Bank, and bilateral agencies.

Five main areas of action, that are more or less being pursued also in other MDBs, will underpin our interventions. First, the Bank will assist more actively in the creation of an enabling environment beyond macroeconomic management -- participating in building up supporting institutions such as land registries, security exchanges and legal regimes that are vital for private enterprise development.

Second, we will consolidate areas of past support by using loans and equity instruments in a more selective manner. And the Bank will seek investment opportunities in countries where enabling environments exist, as well as promote interaction between foreign and local investors so as to create enduring and profitable business relations.

Third, the Bank will seek to play a significant role in the private financing of infrastructure, including Build, Operate and Transfer (BOT) schemes; and will also provide technical advice to governments on the development of the necessary legal and regulatory framework to attract private financiers for such projects.

Fourth, the Bank will also play an enhanced role in assisting with privatization. In this field, too, there is need for technical assistance which we could provide. The Bank may also invest directly in the privatized companies.

Finally, the Bank will provide a more focused and enhanced assistance to small and medium-scale enterprises, through lines of credit to performing commercial banks and other financial institutions.

Mr. Chairman, private capital has a major role to play in the growth process, and we all welcome the recent encouraging trends in flows to the developing world. But as we also know, these flows have been concentrated in a few countries and have mostly shied away from the low-income ones, partly because of the weak creditworthiness and infrastructural base of such countries. For some time to come, the low-income countries would continue to rely substantially on concessional resources to finance their development programmes.

In the context of the African Development Bank Group, consideration of country creditworthiness has entailed that no less than 39 regional member countries, out of a total of 53, remain without access to our non- concessional window for sovereign loans. This means that apart from IDA and other concessional sources, support for these countries will have to come from the African Development Fund.

As we speak now, however, the contribution of the United States to the ADF- VII, although pledged, has not been approved by Congress for the coming fiscal year. We are, of course, grateful for the leadership role that has been taken by the U.S. as well as for the pledge, and are sensitive to the constraints facing the U.S. and other donors. But, given the conditions in low-income Africa, it would not be fully practical to engage in accelerating economic development, if concessional resources would not be available in magnitudes that would significantly support the attack on poverty and finance social overhead investments -- that would otherwise remain unattended. And, as we know, improvements in the economic conditions of these countries generate increased demand for the goods and services produced in U.S. and other industrial countries.

Conclusion

Africa's development prospects today stand at crossroads. The process of economic reforms is gaining momentum by the year as the majority of governments are embracing widening dimensions of these reforms and as domestic consensus is growing. Africa's development partners, on their part, have invested both financially and in terms of widening international consensus in what should be done to sustain recovery and development. Yet, we still face major obstacles like the inadequate external capital flows, especially to the poorer countries. These problems, however, are certainly within the abilities of the international community to resolve -- if we could all continue pulling together in the desired direction.

The African Development Bank, as the continent's own institution, has grown to enjoy a unique confidence and trust with government and non-government bodies throughout Africa; and has generated support from development partners beyond the continent. The Bank will, of course, work closely with the World Bank and other multilateral institutions operating in Africa. It will use its locational advantage in the continent, its mostly African staff, and its Africa-specific technical and cultural knowledge to promote socioeconomic development.

It will also use its political proximity and closeness to advance policy dialogue with member governments on matters which may be sensitive but yet important for development management. And, it will as well address and assist in important developmental approaches -- like regional cooperation and integration -- that are often so important for faster growth. As a financing institution, the Bank contributes to the additionality of development resources by providing diversity and therefore the spreading of financial risk. The additional financing channel, in turn, could be used and has been used beneficially for co-financing with bilateral and multilateral institutions.

The ongoing institutional reforms I outlined earlier are placing the Bank Group on a much stronger footing to meet its mandate of supporting the development and integration of African economies. Importantly, the reforms should go a long way in efforts to ensure the development effectiveness of our operations. Recognizing the positive role of the Overseas Development Council and its friends in promoting international development, I do hope that we can count on your influence and support for Africa and the African Development Bank.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


10 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


United States and Africa;
Administration Has Positive Record on Africa


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4934 words


 

Washington DC - Following is the text of remarks on September 26 by David F. Gordon, director of U.S. policy programs at the Overseas Development Council, before the House Subcommittee on Africa, during hearings on the Clinton administrations Africa policy.

I would like to thank the Subcommittee Chair, Representative Ros-Lehtinen, and members of the Committee for inviting me to testify on the topic of the Clinton Administration's performance in Africa. This is an important topic and I commend the Chair for calling this hearing today. I am particularly pleased to be sharing the table with Ambassador Hempstone, with whom I had the great privilege to serve when he was U.S. Ambassador to Kenya. I also want to commend the Chair, the Ranking Member, Mr. Ackerman, and other members of the Committee for the diligent work of their very talented and hard-working staffs.

The views that I express this afternoon are my own and do not necessarily reflect those of my colleagues at the Overseas Development Council or its Board of Directors. 

GENERAL ASSESSMENT OF U.S. AFRICA POLICY

In a recent issue of the journal Foreign Policy, as an exception to his generally favorable assessment of the Clinton Administration's conduct of foreign affairs, Richard Ullman, a relatively liberal analyst, gave the Administration a failing grade for its Africa policy, with the tart comment: " No Cold War = No Policy." This afternoon, my colleagues around this table, none of whom will take umbrage at the label conservative, are presenting their own critical comments concerning the Clinton Administration's Africa policy. So, the Administration's Africa policy has come under criticism from both sides of the spectrum.

I believe that, while not without weaknesses, the Administration's performance in Africa has been basically sound. Before moving on to the details of my assessment, let me comment briefly on the context within which U.S. Africa policy operates. Several elements of the political context have been major determinants of that policy.

First is the peculiar limbo status of Africa in post-Cold War foreign policy. Stuck between ill-defined, but real, American interests and Africa's peripherality to U.S. strategic or vital concerns, Africa policy is inherently very tricky. Absent the Cold War framework where all regions were part of the chess board of the great game of superpower competition, determination of U.S. interests for several regions has been under dispute, but nowhere has this been more difficult than in Africa.

In this context, continuing U.S. engagement in Africa has often been justified by an ever-expanding litany of "new" issues and threats that demand immediate American attention. Approaches to Africa by advocates of many political stripes tend to veer among absolutes -- either complete handwashing, domination by a single theme (be it the environment, democracy, or trade promotion), or massive overextension. The Administration has been generally successful in balancing disparate views and moderating extreme pressures from all camps.

Second, the Administration has been inundated with immediate crises and disasters in Africa. Assistant Secretary Moose has expressed, on several occasions, frustration at his inability to focus on the larger goals of U.S. policy because of the day-to-day crush of responding to Africa's multiple crises. The proliferation of crises has complicated efforts to articulate and implement broader conceptual themes for policy. Hopefully, Secretary Christopher's impending trip to Africa will help address this issue.

Third, anti-internationalism in general and anti-Africa sentiment in particular has reared its head in the Congress. In the aftermath of the loss of U.S. lives on the streets of Mogadishu in October 1993, and especially after the 1994 election, U.S. Africa policy has been under something of a " state of siege." Somalia was a watershed in encouraging congressional and public hostility toward the U.N. and toward active U.S. engagement in Africa. A barrage of anti-internationalist pressures from the public and Congress, specific calls from Senators Helms and McConnell to substantially cut U.S. assistance to Africa, and large cuts in the international affairs budget have left Africa policymakers on the defensive, scrambling to justify continued American involvement and to find the resources needed to support that engagement.

Despite this very challenging political context, on the whole the Clinton Administration record on Africa is positive. Moreover, in Africa policy, as in other areas of foreign policy, the Administration is settling onto a more steady tack after some initial rough waters.

-- The Administration worked effectively for change in South Africa, supporting the long negotiating process, providing an ample aid package for the transition period, and working to build a broad relationship with the new South Africa based on the principle of mutual benefit and respect.

-- It played a crucial role in reinvigorating the peace process in Angola, where we now stand on the verge of a decisive breakthrough that holds the promise of ending Africa's longest war.

-- It has increased pressure on the terrorist-supporting Islamic fundamentalist regime in Sudan.

-- It has provided strong international leadership on humanitarian relief, especially in the Horn of Africa, and has been in the driver's seat on multilateral efforts to promote Africa's own capacities for conflict resolution and peacekeeping.

-- It has utilized new policy instruments to foster improved human rights, the consolidation of democracy, and more effective governance.

-- Finally, the Administration has made Africa a priority within the U.S. foreign aid program, protecting the African account from the draconian cuts taken from programs to Asia and Latin America.

The Administration has been somewhat less successful in some other areas:

-- It has had difficulty in generating consensus and action in response to the derailing of the democratic transition in Nigeria, Africa's most populous state.

-- Chastened by Somalia and allowing its skepticism towards the U.N. and Secretary-General Boutros-Ghali to overcome fundamental humanitarian considerations, the U.S. (as well as other countries) failed to take preventive action that might have mitigated the tragedy in Rwanda in 1994.

-- While successfully defending bilateral aid, the Administration has been less successful in defending the U.S. contribution to the International Development Association, the soft-loan window of the World Bank, nearly one- half of whose resources are lent to Africa.

AFRICA POLICY: THEMES AND IMPLEMENTATION

Support for democratization, facilitation of conflict resolution, and promotion of economic reform and sustainable development comprise the tripod of the Clinton Administration's Africa policy. These themes reflect the essential continuity of U.S. Africa policy in the post-Cold War era. The Clinton Administration has built upon efforts begun in the Bush Administration to shift U.S. Africa policy away from the negative elements of the Cold War legacy toward more positive ends. It is unfortunate that the bipartisan continuity in U.S. policy towards Africa has not been better recognized since it is a positive sign of consensus in U.S. foreign policy.

The U.S. has stopped supporting dictators and military regimes in Africa. Instead, there has been a substantial shift in American aid and attention toward countries undertaking transitions to more open political systems and freer economies. In the 1980s, much U.S. aid was wasted in Mobutu's Zaire, Sergeant Doe's Liberia, and Siad Barre's Somalia. But today, U.S. aid resources are directed to those African countries most dedicated to reform and with the best prospects for trade and investment. Among our leading recipients are South Africa, Uganda, Ghana, Ethiopia, and Mali, all of which are going through difficult "dual transitions" to democracy and a market economy.

U.S. aid is playing an important role in facilitating the return to economic growth and stability that is occurring in most African countries. Our assistance promotes development by facilitating better economic policies, helping to entrench democratic governance, and supporting basic human resource investments in child survival and girls' education. Partially as a result of these efforts, most African countries have growth rates of over three percent per year and U.S. exports to Africa have been growing at a rate of more than twenty percent annually for the last two years.

Taking into account the inherent difficulties involved in promoting democracy in Africa, the Clinton Administration's record is strong. As one of Africa's most astute observers, Professor Ali Mazrui, noted in testimony before this Subcommittee, "the U.S. must recognize the paradox of a strong African desire for democracy combined with a fragile African capability for it." An oft-heard critique, from democracy advocates and some human rights groups, is that the Administration has failed to live up to the promises concerning democratization made in the 1992 presidential campaign. But the fact that the Administration has not made democracy promotion the be-all and end-all of its Africa policy is a sign of flexibility and maturity rather than failure.

The Administration has signaled U.S. support for democratization by increasing aid programs in new democracies and closing down programs in countries like Cameroon and Togo, where autocrats hijacked democratic transitions. U.S. support, through training and monitoring, has been crucial in the success of "transitional elections" in nearly twenty African countries. The U.S. has played an important role in all of southern Africa's democratic transitions and, as a result, has an influence in the region far in excess of the still limited formal U.S. presence and economic ties. This influence is already paying dividends for the United States. In the debate on the extension of the Non-Proliferation Treaty, South Africa lent its considerable moral stature to the U.S. effort to achieve an extension of the Treaty, and was a significant factor in our success.

The Administration has also worked to advance conflict-resolution and conflict-prevention activities in Africa. Working with members of this Committee from both parties, the Administration supported, and helped shape, the Africa Conflict Resolution Act of 1994. It has supported the efforts of the Organization of African Unity to build an indigenous capacity for conflict resolution, and is now undertaking an intense effort, along with a number of European states, to develop a strategy for enhancing the military capacity of African peacekeeping forces.

Again working with a bipartisan group of members of Congress, the Administration is currently developing a more coordinated approach to facilitating U.S. trade and investment in Africa. The U.S. has played a significant role in promoting economic reform in Africa, and has an interest in maximizing the impact of those reforms on U.S. trade and investment. The Administration has been in intense consultations with the Africa Trade and Investment Caucus, led by Representatives Phil Crane and Jim McDermott, on a set of legislative and executive branch initiatives.

GUIDEPOSTS FOR THE FUTURE: U.S. INTERESTS

Madam Chair, you asked the panelists today for suggestions on how the U.S. should approach various issues affecting the African continent. In looking at future U.S. engagement in Africa, it is useful to begin by laying out U.S. interests. Here we must distinguish among actual threats to national security, significant national interests, and mere aspirations. Any hard-headed analysis of Africa must conclude that, with the exception of Sudan's ties to international terrorist organizations, U.S. security concerns in Africa are marginal by any measure. But America does have real interests in Africa.

First and foremost is a humanitarian interest. Fifty years ago, in announcing post-World War II reconstruction plans, Secretary of State George Marshall committed U.S. foreign policy to a fight "against hunger, poverty, desperation, and chaos." The geographical focus of that fight shifted over the years, from Europe in the late 1940s, to Latin America, and then to Asia. Today, the focal point for America's spirit of generosity must be Africa. Although famine and the dire crises Americans readily associate with Africa are in fact rare, Africa remains the world's poorest, least educated, and least healthy region. Indeed, recent polls suggest that public support is strongest for American aid and intervention abroad for humanitarian reasons.

We also have economic interests in Africa. Despite the low level of existing commerce, Africa remains a huge potential untapped market for U.S. trade and investment. Economic opportunities in Africa have improved dramatically in the past several years. The ideological climate in Africa has shifted to a remarkable degree with almost every country at least moving in the right direction of economic reform. Africa boasts more than a dozen active stock markets (with at least five more in the works) and many countries have liberalized their investment codes and begun to attract substantial investment, most notably Ghana, Kenya, Zimbabwe, and Uganda.

In 1995, U.S. exports to Africa increased by over twenty percent, and recently released Commerce Department figures show that this expansion has continued in the first half of this year. South Africa, because of its sheer economic size and regional domination, is already an important economic partner. On the investment side, numerous Africa-related funds, touting the continent as the "final frontier," have sprung up in some of the world's biggest investment houses, including Morgan Stanley, Baring Brothers, and Alliance Capital. We need to keep in mind that it was not so long ago that countries in Latin America and Asia that are now lucrative markets for U.S. trade and investment were considered hopeless, much of the way that Africa is perceived today.

Several transnational issues directly affect the United States and can only be adequately addressed through bilateral and multilateral cooperation with African partners. The lesson from the battle against smallpox and AIDS is that global efforts are necessary to wipe out some public health threats. International drug trafficking and crime syndicates are a rising problem that can only effectively be dealt with through cooperative efforts. The U.S. also has a substantial interest in preventing the further expansion of drug and crime networks in Africa.

Finally, the African-American community wants the U.S. to be engaged in Africa. The end of the Cold War has made regional and issue-specific constituencies increasingly influential in U.S. foreign policy. Such ethnic influence in foreign policy has a long history in American politics and is certainly well within the American tradition. A successful foreign policy must reflect and incorporate the views, values, and concerns of all segments of American society.

PROMOTING U.S. INTERESTS: SHORT-TERM AND LONG-TERM APPROACHES

During the Cold War, the central policy debate concerning Africa was between those who favored a short-term approach based on Cold War calculations and those who proposed a long-term strategy based on fostering more rapid economic growth and development. In 1987, Congress put its weight decisively behind the latter approach by creating the Development Fund for Africa (DFA). But, as long as the Cold War continued, a long-term approach based on the development paradigm could never prevail.

In the past few years a new, and largely unaddressed, tension has emerged between long-term and short-term involvement. On the one hand, the underlying logic of the DFA legislation remains valid. Encouraging and supporting " development" -- social, political, and especially economic -- is the basic long-term strategy for attaining many, indeed most, of the United States' goals in Africa. On the other hand, events on the ground in Africa and political pressures at home have pushed U.S. Africa policy into a much more short-term mode. To some extent, this is unavoidable and appropriate. Yet, the increasing pressures for immediate response, combined with the insistence by NGOs and many in the Congress that U.S. development assistance efforts focus on child-survival and other immediate social expenditures, threaten to take the U.S. "out of the game" of long-term development. We need to restore a balance between short-term and long-term approaches in order to effectively promote U.S. interests in Africa.

A: The Short Term: Criteria for Crisis Intervention

For many African countries, it clearly makes little sense to think long- term as they face political, economic, or social crises. The U.S. clearly has a role in these situations in providing humanitarian and emergency assistance, but the question is how can the U.S. decide where and when to act, beyond emergency relief, in crisis or potential-crisis situations? The cold realities are that in most instances the U.S. will not be able to successfully engage or intervene. But there are a number of cases where the U. S. will not be able (to), and should not, disengage. What specific criteria justify intervention?

-- The first is large states that hold the key to regional stability. This would only include a few countries, most notably Nigeria and Zaire (as well as Kenya and South Africa, should a major crisis arise). While the disintegration of the Togolese state would be a tragedy for Togo, it would have no regional implications and pressure for external assistance would fall into the lap of the intimately engaged French. But the collapse of Nigeria into chaos or civil war would likely have regional repercussions that could unleash waves of instability and mass migration throughout West Africa.

-- Second are countries where the U.S. has significant economic interests. Again, this would involve only a very limited number of countries, with Angola and Nigeria being the two obvious cases due to the vast quantities of oil we import from them. The United States annually purchases over $5 billion ($5,000 million) of Nigerian oil and $2 billion ($2,000 million) from Angola. Major American companies, including Mobil, Chevron, Exxon, and Texaco, have significant production and exploration interests in those two countries, with total U.S. private investment topping $6 billion ($6,000 million).

-- Third are countries with close historic ties to the United States, in which there is a broad consensus within the international community and in Africa that the U.S. is the relevant dominant external power. Only Liberia and Ethiopia fall into this category. Decisive American engagement in Ethiopia in 1991 was crucial in facilitating the stable political transition following that country's civil war. Unfortunately, the failure of the U.S. to take decisive action at several key moments has been one reason why the Liberian conflict has been so difficult to end.

-- Finally, given the American humanitarian tradition, the U.S. should not ignore crises where, barring international action, large numbers of people face imminent death. While the defining lines would necessarily be fuzzy, in instances of impending mass starvation (Somalia in 1992) or genocide (Rwanda in 1994 and Burundi today), policymakers should be prepared for such contingencies. Simply reacting to emotional public outbursts is no basis for policy. It must be recognized that massive intervention can be dangerous, costly, and fraught with unforeseen complications. But, despite the risks, there will sometimes be no alternative to intervention.

In countries that fall within one of these four categories, the U.S. must be willing to undertake serious diplomatic efforts and to commit both real resources and/or impose real costs in order to invigorate such diplomacy. In this regard, often the U.S. will need to work with other major powers and shape and support United Nations initiatives.

B: The Long Term: Focused Support for Development

Successful development will be the long-term key for preventing crises, addressing humanitarian concerns, and taking advantage of economic opportunities. While most of the important challenges and problems facing Africa -- managing ethnic diversity, controlling the population explosion, creating effective and stable polities, promoting higher rates of economic growth -- do not threaten the U.S. directly, there will be costs to the United States should they fail to be successfully addressed. In that context, the interests that the United States does have in Africa -- avoiding human suffering and the need for large-scale emergency relief, developing markets for American products, addressing global health, drug, and crime problems, preventing breeding grounds for international terrorism -- will be much harder, and probably impossible, to achieve.

The good news is that the prospects for development in Africa, and the ability of international assistance to facilitate development, have never been better. A number of long-standing conflicts have been resolved, misguided experiments with socialism have been abandoned, and a new generation of highly competent political and economic managers now occupy senior roles in most countries. Some twenty-five Africa countries are moving forward, if in many cases slowly, on economic reform and democratization and/or national reconciliation.

Moreover, within Africa a broad consensus has emerged on a strategy for development that is consistent with U.S. interests. This strategy emphasizes the following themes: first, the importance of effective macro-economic management; second, the need to promote the market and private sector as the engine of economic growth; third, the centrality of sustainable investment in basic education and health; fourth, the continuing need to reduce the rate of population growth; and fifth, the importance of strengthening the institutional underpinnings for development, both within the government and in the non-governmental sectors. At the center of the new consensus is the belief that while external assistance can be helpful, the primary impetus for development can only come from within.

How can the United States best support this agenda?

First, by continuing to support the International Development Association (IDA), the soft-loan window of the World Bank. IDA resources remain central to both the ongoing process of economic policy reform and to the vast bulk of major investment activities ranging from human resource development through improved basic health and education, the expansion of the financial systems, and the rehabilitation and construction of basic infrastructure needed for economic growth.

Second, by ensuring that as African countries recover economically and begin to increase their exports, they do not run into restrictive trade barriers. Particularly problematic are the rules of the Multi-Fiber Arrangement, in which a percentage increase in a country's exports to the U.S. within each category of textile goods automatically triggers a quota response. African countries are starting from such a low base that even modest success can provoke such a quota, as the U.S. recently slapped on Kenyan textile exports. Although such incidents are rare and relatively minor today, as Africa grows, these barriers may become more onerous in the future.

Third, by better concentrating bilateral assistance both substantively and geographically. American bilateral programs should be concentrated in those countries showing strong commitments to private-sector-based development, effective human resource investments, improved governance, liberalization of their political sphere, and respect for international human rights norms.

Substantively, U.S. assistance programs should focus on key areas in which the U.S. has a comparative advantage, which are high priorities within the African development consensus, and which will serve to create a broader range of economic linkages between the U.S. and Africa. Existing U.S. aid programs are spread too thin and in some ways lag behind the current African consensus. They often pay too little attention to the opportunities that exist for promoting expanded trade and investment ties between the U.S. and Africa, and are increasingly looking away from programs aimed at improving governmental performance.

A reformed U.S. bilateral aid program in Africa should focus in four areas: first, reducing population growth rates through provision of family planning services and better child and maternal health care; second, improving governance by strengthening the capacity of African governments and enhancing non-governmental voices; third, promoting more dynamic microenterprise development to unleash the latent talents of Africa's hidden entrepreneurs and create expanded employment opportunities; and fourth, developing an African trade and investment partnership that will both provide a stimulus for economic growth in Africa and deepen the trade linkages between U.S. firms and 600 million potential consumers of American goods in Africa.

Given the crisis-ridden political context within which it has had to operate, the Clinton team's overall record in Africa is positive. By emphasizing the areas that I have highlighted, the next Administration, whether led by President Clinton or Senator Dole, can do even a better job of focusing policy in more deliberate ways and best serve U.S. interests in Africa into the next century.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
