Africa News


October 1, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S.-Africa Trade Growth Should Be Encouraged


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Washington DC - Following is testimony by Walter Kansteiner, senior associate at The Forum for International Policy, in a September 26 hearing before the House Subcommittee on Africa, during hearings on the Clinton administrations Africa policy.

In the past 10 years, U.S. policy towards Africa has focused on a few core issues -- conflict resolution, political reform, and economic and commercial development being the dominant concerns. The Clinton Administration has not differed from previous administrations. It too has articulated its policies based upon these three central issues. Resolving conflict, encouraging democratic political institutions, and building a strong economy are interlinked, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. This testimony is a very brief attempt at examining the Administration's policies and performance on economic and commercial issues. 

After a somewhat slow start, the Clinton Administration realized that Africa has commercial potential. With U.S.-Africa trade increasing and direct foreign investment growing substantially, the Administration began searching for ways to promote U.S.-Africa commercial activity. Last year trade with Africa grew 12 percent to $18 billion ($18,000 million). U.S. exports to Africa were about on the same level as our exports to Eastern Europe.

Direct equity investment has also been expanding. U.S. companies now have as much invested in South Africa alone as they have in Turkey, Israel, or India. (It is interesting to note that the average return on investment in African holdings is 28 percent -- far higher than the 8.5 percent worldwide average.)

These impressive economic statistics helped encourage the Clinton Administration to organize a White House Conference on Africa in June 1994. The message from this conference was on target as senior officials discussed the importance of supporting a strong private-sector throughout Africa. And U. S. corporations were encouraged to seek out African trading partners, and to look for investment opportunities.

The conference, however, was followed by very little concrete support, but for one important exception, the late Secretary of Commerce Ron Brown. In his three years in office Ron Brown averaged two trips per year to Africa. He led commercial missions, he pushed for greater trade, he encouraged U.S. companies to invest in Africa. But most importantly he diplomatically but forcefully explained to African leaders that they had to get their economic houses in order if they wanted to succeed in attracting investment dollars. Ron Brown's voice was heard, and he helped both the African states as well as American companies.

Unfortunately, since his death, the Commerce Department does not seem to have the same level of interest or energy in pursuing his initiatives.

The Clinton Administration has also attempted to encourage business contacts with programs such as the U.S.-South Africa Binational Commission, which has a business council component.

These limited efforts at supporting commercial activity between the U.S. and Africa have been quite helpful. But the next administration, whether Democrat or Republican, should begin to consider how the U.S. can influence, persuade, cajole, and push African states towards more aggressive free market economic policies. The U.S. voice in Africa carries far, and we need to demonstrate our commitment to a strong private sector throughout the continent. African governments have long dominated their own economies and their country's commercial activity. But if Africa is to prosper, governments must give up the reins of economic power and release the private sector from excessive regulations and restrictions.

Privatizing state-owned companies is an important first step in taking governments out of critical commercial sectors. Often, African political leaders are reluctant to carry out privatization programs. But privatization of state assets is the most efficient way of transforming equity structures and making these companies preform on a commercial basis. The U.S. government must support privatization efforts, bilaterally, as well as through the international financial institutions like the World Bank, IMF, and African Development Bank.

The next Administration must also focus on the region's most likely economic success story -- southern Africa. Along with the rest of the world, the current Administration has thoroughly enjoyed the success of Nelson Mandela's new South African government. But the honeymoon is over, South Africa and the southern African region must make some tough economic decisions.

Southern Africa has a population of about 125 million; it is a region that has excellent resources and commercial infrastructure. It could develop internal trading patterns that would benefit all of the countries in the region. What is desperately needed is some type of free-trade agreement or structure. The U.S. government should be actively encouraging the region's political and commercial leaders in discussing and building plans for a Southern Africa Free Trade Zone. Perhaps the nucleus institutions already exist with the South African Customs Union and SADC (Southern African Development Community). But the next administration could assist in building an African economic institution that would have long-term commercial benefits.

The next administration needs to continue the hands-on type commercial activity that Ron Brown actively pursued. But it also must become engaged in helping African countries take the right steps toward building private-sector- dominated economies. Our active participation in privatization processes, either bilaterally or via international financial institutions, is critical. We must also become involved in helping Africans formulate economic strategies that appear overwhelming, like a Southern African Free Trade Zone, yet are absolutely necessary if Africa is to become economically viable in the next century.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 1, 1996


Business;
Tourism Award Handed To Zambian Government


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Hotels and Catering Association of Zambia (HCAZ) chairman, Gaudenzio Rossi today said Zambia should create a proper information system that would provide the much needed information to tourists and boost the tourism industry in Zambia.

Mr Rossi was speaking in Lusaka today when he presented to Tourism Minister Gabriel Maka, the Africa Travels Association (ATA) award given to Zambia for outstanding leadership in the tourism industry. 

"Zambia lacked a proper information system that would provide information to tourists within and outside Zambia. There was need to create an information system that would include some magazines," he said.

He said the private sector in the tourism industry should also cooperate with government to strengthen the industry.

Mr Rossi who received the prize on behalf of Zambia recently in Namibia said the award showed that Zambia's tourism industry was recognised by many internationally.

He said ATA is based in New York and deals with tourists travelling to Africa.

And Mr Maka paid tribute to ATA and concurred with Mr Rossi that tourism enterprises should cooperate among themselves and government ministries to boost tourism.

He said tour operators should present their personal complaints to the ministry of tourism through their respective associations and not individually as was the case at present.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Africa News


October 1, 1996


Business;
Zambian Sugar Shares Are Over Subscribed


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - The public over subscribed for the Zambia Sugar Plc shares forcing the Zambia Priva- tisation Trust Fund (ZPTF) to re-issue an additional 57 million shares to meet demand.

ZPTF fund manager, Abdul Munshi, in an interview yesterday, said they had re-issued more shares to the public in addition to the 328 million shares. 

Munshi said a further 56.6 million shares were offered in addition to those offered by ZPTF and Zambia Sugar's major shareholder, Commonwealth Development Corporation, during the public floatation in a bid to enable all Zambians who applied to acquire shares.

And Stanbic Bank of Zambia Limited, in a statement yesterday, said the public floatation had experienced a 25 per cent oversubscription.

Foreign applications had to be scaled down by 80 per cent to give Zambians first priority.

In the share allocation, a total of 56.4 million shares have been secured by individual Zambians while local institutional investors acquired 104.5 million shares. Off-shore investors - institutional and individuals - secured 185.5 million shares.

Munshi further disclosed that the remaining three per cent Zambia Sugar Plc shares in the custody of ZPTF would released on the secondary market later, depending on favourable market conditions.

Africa News


October 1, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Panic Grips Mozambican Squad


BYLINE: Goodson Machona and Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - Panic-stricken Mozambique Football Association (MFA) officials have warned their new coaching staff that they will be fired should Mozambique lose to Zambia in this Sunday's Africa Cup of Nations match.

The "endangered" new coaching staff took over after MFA fired Portugues Rui Casador only months after he replaced Ukranian Viktor Bonderenko.

"The coaching staff has been told in no uncertain terms that they will be fired should Mozambique lose against Zambia," a reliable source said in an interview yesterday, advising: "Zambia should be careful as they (Mozambique) will take the game very seriously." 

The panic in the Moza-mbiquan camp was further heightened when the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) disclosed last week that all Zambia's professional players, including inspirational skipper Kalusha Bwalya, would be available for the weekend game.

According to the source, the news sent stand-in coach, Arnaldo Salvado, scuttling around for the services of aging Chiquino Conde, currently plying his trade with Portugal's Sporting Lisbon, Mateus Tchaka Tchaka of Boavista in Portugal and another player identified only as Jojo.

"There was total panic when they heard that Kalusha Bwalya and the other professionals were coming for this weekend's game," the source disclosed.

But things seem not to be working for the Mamba's as they are reportedly having difficulties in getting their European-based players as they are said to be tied down with their club programmes.

But Second Secretary at the Mozambique High Commission in Lusaka, Jose Antonio Matsinha, said in an interview yesterday that all the professionals will be available.

"We are expecting a delegation comprising 25 people," Matsinha said. "All the professionals are coming. From Portugal we are expecting Chiquinho, Jojo, Tchaka Tchaka and from South Africa, we are expecting Tico Tico, Cashela and Nuro.

He, however, declined to be drawn into discussing the outcome of the game opting instead to say: "let's wait until after the game".

Matsina, who comfirmed that the Mamba's will be arriving today, disclosed that the team has just returned from Oman where they had a series of friendlies against that country's national team.

Salvado is coach for Ferraoviario de Maputo, the team that eliminated Zamsure in the CAF cup last year via a 2-1 defeat in the second round after a one-all draw.

Africa News


October 1, 1996


Zambia;
Opposision Says Voters' Cards Being Sold In Zaire


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) yesterday claimed that the Nikuv voters cards are being sold in neighbouring Zaire.

"We have information that these cards are being sold in Lubumbashi and we feel government must move to stop this because at the end of the day, we may not have free and fair elections," ZDC general secretary, Derrick Chitala, claimed without proof. "Some people are making the cards at their homes."

Chitala said his party had made proposals on how to make the elections free and fair but it is like no effort is being done on the part of the government. "We need to have fair elections not with these voters cards which some people are making with their backward machines," Chitala said.

Africa News


October 1, 1996


Business;
Zambian Meat Processing Plant Sought


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - Zambeef and Colcom, two Zambian businesses engaged in the beef industry, have approached the Zambia National Farmers' Union(ZNFU) with the intention of setting up a modern meat processing plant in Zambia.

The two companies are targeting the quality processed meat market held by South Africa and Zimbabwe. 

Currently, Zambia is importing quality processed beef sold in supermarkets.

According to the latest issue of ZNFU publication, The Zambian Farmer, the two companies are considering importing carcasses or live animals from Zimbabwe for processing and slaughtering here in the initial stages of the project.

But the union is still weighing the advantages of a declining import quota system.

Meanwhile, the Zambian beef producers will soon be able to benefit from exports to Mozambique, arranged by the Beef Cattle Producers Association.

According to the union, the BCPAZ has been talking to the Red Meat Producers Association of South Africa and it is hoped that a bilateral trade agreement will be reached that would allow at least a limited amount of Zambian beef onto the South Africa market.

The association is also looking into the supply of long weaners to Mozambique, having managed to negotiate higher prices than the local market would pay. They expect to export more than 100 heifers a month.

LANGUAGE: English

17 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


Zambia;
Law Group Continues To Expose Constitution Flaws


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Lusaka - The new Republican Constitution is riddled with a lot of flaws and should be sent back to Parliament for re-amendment, Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) chairman, George Kunda, advised on Friday.

Addressing the Kitwe Press Club, Kunda said "the flaws, as well as other contentious issues in the Constitution, should be dealt with and redressed by the government together with the opposition parties and other concerned citizens".

"The current Constitution, as amended, is not a good piece of legislation and therefore needs substantial amendments," Kunda said. "We need a Constitution and laws which are good and can ensure justice." 

However, Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda, on Thursaday told parliament that the new Constitution has already been enacted into law and "the matter is closed".

Kunda, however, contends that under the current Constitution, "the presidential term is tied up with the life of the National Assembly", meaning President Frederick Chiluba may continue ruling up to November 29, 1996 when Parliament is scheduled to dissolve by operation of law and effluxion of time.

This, according to Kunda, is a departure from the old Article 38 (1) in the 1991 Constitution, which required that presidential elections are held before the expiry of the five year presidential term.

Kunda also pointed out that another major flaw in the new Constitution is the provision in Article 88 (9) which presupposes that after Parliament is dissolved, the president can still recall a dissolved National Assembly owing to a state of war.

"The question is, if the presidential term comes to an end by virtue of Article 38 ( by reason of the dissolution of the National Assembly), how can such a President ( who is no longer president) recall a dissolved National Assembly?" Kunda asked.

Kunda is also not happy with Article 38 (2) in the new Constitution which provides for the vice-president, or a member of the cabinet elected by the cabinet, to take over the performance of presidential functions.

"This provision, would appear to contradict Article 45 (2) of the same Constitution in that the vice-president in terms of Article 45 (2) is appointed by the President from among members of the National Assembly. Members of cabinet are also appointed from members of the National Assembly (Article 46 (1) ). Hence if the National Assembly is dissolved, where does the vice-president or any cabinet member, who is part of the same dissolved National Assembly, get his legitimacy to rule the country?

"Again, how can the vice-president or member of cabinet, take over the performance of presidential functions, if the appointer (the President) has ceased to hold office by virtue of the dissolution of the National Assembly?"

The LAZ chairman also contends that in view of Article 45 (3) which provides that the vice-president shall vacate that office upon the assumption by any person of the office of the President, there is no justification for the vice-president to perform presidential functions after the dissolution of the National Assembly, since such dissolution also terminates the presidential term.

"Again how can you refer to a member of cabinet, when there is no cabinet? From which cabinet will such a minister be elected from, to perform presidential functions and which cabinet members will elect him?" Kunda asked.

On Sunday, opposition UNIP's publicity secretary, Bweendo Mulengela, stres- sed that "come October 31, Chiluba should not be at State House" while Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) President, Alfred Zulu, said "Midnight of November 2, 1996 is the maximum period" for President Chiluba to stay at State House.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

18 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


Zambia;
Land Act Torn To Pieces


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Chuulu Kalima, Zambia Democratic Congress chairman of the Lands Committee, on Sunday tore up a pamphlet used by the lands ministry in explaining the Land Act, calling it "a mere piece of propaganda".

Kalima was speaking on ZNBC's Open Fire , television programme on Sunday evening which was discussing the 1995 Land Act.

"It is shameful to see senior civil servants, government officers, using this piece of party propaganda to explain the Land Act," Kalima charged, adding that the information was not worth the paper it was written on. 

Participants from the opposition, who included Michael Chileshe from UNIP, Leslie Zulu from the Liberal Progressive Front, Ludwig Sondashi from the National Party, criticised the MMD for not consulting the people - especially - the chiefs before enacting it into law.

Kalima, a former lands minister in the MMD government, explained that at the time he went around the country to introduce the bill, majority of the people in rural areas were opposed to it because it was bad law.

Sondashi said that if his party came to power it would, within a short time, repeal the Act and bring back to what it was before so that chiefs could have a bigger say in customary land affairs.

Sondashi said that negotiations over land sales should be between the buyer and the seller and there should be little interference from the government.

"If I want to sell land to my neighbour, we should be able to agree between the two of us instead of going to ask for consent which opens loopholes for bribing government officers," he said.

Sondashi explained that land was a very sensitive issue which needed to be handled with care unlike in the present case where villagers holding traditional land had now been turned into squatters on their own land.

But MMD deputy national secretary, deputy minister without portifolio Paul Tembo, defended his party, saying it had provided for customary land under the new Land Act.

Tembo said chiefs had been given the rights to administer their land and maintained that the ruling party had delivered what it had promised in their manifesto.

But Kalima accused Tembo of having not read the Land Act.

"I don't think Tembo has read this document. The President has got all title to land. It belongs to him and it is up to him to grant it to whosoever he wishes. That is what we are talking about," Kalima said.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


Zambia;
Elections in 2001?


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, Column, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

Lusaka - Strange as it may sound, President Chiluba and the current National Assembly have constitutional mandate to stay in office for the next five years. And there may not be elections in Zambia this year, after all. Wait, before you cut me off.

In the furore of the citizenship clauses arguments, some clauses may have slipped past our legal minds. 

Let's reason from the following questions:

1. When and how does this National Assembly's term end?

2. When and how does President Chiluba's term end?

3. Can the President or Parliament do anything to prolong their terms?

4. How soon can elections be held after dissolution of National Assembly?

The current National Assembly was elected October 31, 1991 under the 1991 Constitution which stated that their term of office was five years. By the 1991 Constitution, the current National Assembly's term ends on or about October 31, 1996.

However, the 1991 Constitution is no longer in effect. On May 28, 1996, when President Chiluba assented, the 1996 Constitution became the law.

In enacting the 1996 Constitution, the National Assembly made provision for continuity of the office bearers. While Article 9 states that any person who, under the law amended, would have been required to vacate his office at the expiration of any period or on the attainment of any age shall vacate his office at the expiration of that period or upon the attainment of that age, Article 10 of 1996 Constitution provides different notion for the National Assembly: It states that " the existing National Assembly shall be the National Assembly during the period beginning on the commencement of this Act and ending on the date set for the holding of elections to the office of President and the National Assembly under the Constitution as amended".

And so when is this date set for elections? The 1996 Constitution is not clear. Article 88 states that the National Assembly: "(a) shall, unless sooner dissolved, continue for five years from the date of its first sitting after the commencement of this Constitution or after any dissolution."

Does this mean that the current National Assembly has five more years, since its first sitting after commencement of the 1996 Constitution was a few weeks ago? From a layman's assumption, I believe it to be so. And I fear this was either a genuine error or a deliberate loophole for a reason.

On the President, Article 34 of the 1996 Constitution states that: (2) An election to the office of President shall be held whenever the National Assembly is dissolved and otherwise as provided by Article 38. Article 38 says: (1) If the office of the President becomes vacant by reason of his death or resignation or by reason of his ceasing to hold office by virtue of Article 36, 37, or 88, an election to the office of President shall be held in accordance with Article 34 within ninety days from the date of the office becoming vacant.

Article 36 deals with Removal of President on grounds of incapacity while Article 37 deals with impeachment of President for violation of Constitution.

President Chiluba is not in danger of losing office due to grounds of incapacity or impeachment for violation of constitution. He also does not look like he wants to resign.

So the only reason, his office would become vacant would be by dissolution of Parliament or at the end of his term.

Article 35 deals with Tenure of office of President and says every President shall hold office for a period of five years unless he resigns, dissolves Parliament or is incapacitated. But when did Chiluba's five-year mandate start and when will it end?

He took office on November 2, 1991 for a five-year term but did the1996 Constitution change that? It appears so. Article 8 which provides for Continuation in office of President states that: "The person holding the office of President immediately before the commencement of this Act shall, unless he ceases to hold office by virtue of the provisions of Article 34 or 35 of the Constitution or resigns, continue in office and shall exercise the executive powers of the President under the Constitution as amended until the person elected at the first election to the office of President under the Constitution as amended assumes office."

Can President Chiluba hold on to power past this year? Yes, so long the National Assembly has not been dissolved. This bring us to the question No. 3. - prolonging the terms of office.

The 1996 Constitution gives the President option to prolong his term in office by extending the term of the current National Assembly. Article 88 (5) states that "The President may at any time prorogue Parliament." This section does not give a limit on how long he can prorogue (discontinue or prolong) the meetings of parliament without dissolving it.

The Constitution does not also state under which conditions he can use this power. It's all up to the President.

The President can also postpone elections under a state of emergency. The brewing tensions between UNIP and MMD may be reason enough for him to declare a state of emergency. Also if there's an uproar over the treason trial outcome, the President can use that to declare a state of emergency and delay elections.

But even if the current National Assembly's term ends on October 31, and it is dissolved, there will not be enough time to hold elections in 1996. The three-months requirement would mean that elections are held during the rainy season and that would compound the situation.

Also, since only Parliament can change the constitution, President Chiluba can delay elections by conceding to demands to change the constitution and it will take National Assembly several sessions and months to change the 1996 Constitution.

Either way, don't hold your breath about elections this year.

There might not be any. And the sad thing is it might not be unconstitutional.

God, I pray, my conclusions are wrong!


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1996


East Africa;
Weekly Roundup of Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2494 words


 

Nairobi - This is number 28 (23 - 29 September 1996) in a series of weekly reports from IRIN on general developments in the Great Lakes region. Sources for the information below include UN agencies, NGOs, other international organisations and media reports. IRIN issues these reports for the benefit of the humanitarian community, but accepts no responsibility as to the accuracy of the original sources.

# The Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee (RSCC) held its second meeting in Kigali, Rwanda on Wednesday and said that Pierre Buyoya, leader of Burundi's regime, should be "available" for the next regional summit. Noting the 'positive steps' taken by the regime towards meeting the conditions set out by the Arusha II summit, the Committee emphasized that the 'most important condition yet to be fully met is the immediate and unconditional negotiations with all groups.'

'Other leaders of parties to the conflict' may also be invited to to the next regional summit, according to the RSCC statement. This is thought to include Leonard Nyangoma, leader of the National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), whose armed wing, the FDD, is fighting within Burundi. The Committee decided that sanctions 'have so far been effective' and will stay in place, although fertilizer and vegetable seeds have been exempted from the embargo. 

No date has been set for the proposed third regional summit, but preparations for this will take place at a Ministerial meeting to be held on 10 October, and the summit, at the Heads of State level, is expected to follow soon afterwards. The next meeting of the RSCC will take place in Arusha, Tanzania, on 8 October. The full RSCC statement is available from IRIN.

The RSCC's decision to invite Major Buyoya to the next regional summit was welcomed by Jean-Luc Ndizeye, his spokesman, as "a very good step, but a small step." Ndizeye again called for the total lifting of the sanctions, saying that "the embargo is killing any chances of peace in Burundi". Buyoya's spokesman would not comment on the part of the statement inviting leaders of other parties to the conflict to attend the next summit, saying only "we will analyse the issue when the time comes." On 22 September Pierre Buyoya had said in an interview with the East African newspaper that he was " ready to start negotiations with armed factions" but that "on the other side they are not ready".

Pope John Paul II on Wednesday called for the sanctions to be eased, saying they are "creating a greater burden for the civilian population". His remarks came at the end of his weekly general audience when making a tribute to Burundian Archbishop Joachim Ruhuna, who died in an ambush on 9 September.

# The power struggle within FRODEBU intensified on Wednesday with 34 party activists in Nairobi declaring their support for Leonard Nyangoma, leader of the CNDD. Their declaration followed Mr Nyangoma's announcement on 19 September that he had taken over the party's presidency from former parliamentary speaker Jean Minani. This had been rejected by Mr Minani and by Augustin Nzojibwami, the secretary-general of FRODEBU.

Mr Nzojibwami was one of five FRODEBU officials reported last week to have left the German ambassador's residence in Bujumbura, where they had taken refuge. Mr Nzojibwami said that they had left their refuge to fill the vacuum in which Mr Nyangoma had made his announcement. He claimed FRODEBU would need to hold a party congress to turn its policy away from "non-violence and consensus".

# The town of Bukavu in South Kivu, Zaire, was reported calm at the end of the week after Zaire and Rwanda agreed on a ceasefire following exchanges of mortar fire on Sunday 22 September, Monday and Tuesday. Both Governments accused the other of having started the shelling, which killed at least one Zairean and injured five others on Tuesday night.

The Zairean version of events is that the exchange of fire first began on the Sunday after prisoners escaped from the central prison in Cyangugu, Rwanda. The Rwandese Patriotic Army was said to have shot at them as well as some Zairean soldiers near the border. The Zaireans claim that this was when they began firing at Rwanda. The Rwandans claim, however, that the shelling was started by Zaire. A ceasefire was negotiated on Tuesday, but on Wednesday the deputy governor of South Kivu, Lwabandji Lwasi, accused the Rwandans of breaking it by firing shots over the border. No further incidents have been reported since.

The insecurity prompted the United Nations to relocate 23 'non-essential' expatriate aid agency personnel to Nairobi on Tuesday. The International Federation of the Red Cross also evacuated three of its seven delegates in Bukavu after two shells landed in the garden of a hotel where IFRC staff were staying.

The shelling between Rwanda and Zaire reflects growing tension between the two countries following accusations by the Zairean authorities that the RPA have been training Banyamulenge near Uvira, South Kivu, and encouraging them to destabilise eastern Zaire, using Burundi as a rear base. This claim has been categorically rejected by the Governments of Rwanda and Burundi. Meanwhile, a UN Special Envoy of the Secretary- General, Ibrahima Fall, arrived in Kinshasa on 22 September to seek clarification on Zairean allegations that UNHCR had provided logistic support to armed groups infiltrating from Zaire and Rwanda. The charge was categorically rejected by the UN Secretary-General on 17 September.

The Banyamulenge are Zairean Tutsis who migrated from Rwanda into Zaire over several centuries and who say they have been targetted in recent months by the Zairean Army and authorities. According to reports from a Banyamulenge spokesman in exile, the Zairean authorities executed 40 Banyamulenge held in detention on Sunday 22 September. This was said to have been in retaliation for the killings of Zairean soldiers by Banyamulenge militia.

Correction: IRIN would like a correct a factual error in last week's Weekly Roundup (22.9.96). In a section on accusations against the local authorities in Uvira by Amnesty International the District Commissioner was named incorrectly. A subsequent Amnesty statement corrected this to Shweka Mutabazi. We apologize for any misunderstandings which may have arisen from this error.

# The United Nations International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR) agreed on Wednesday to postpone the trial of Georges Rutaganda, suspected of genocide and crimes against humanity, until 6 March 1997 on grounds of ill health. Mr Rutaganda is accused of being the second vice-president of the Interahamwe militia and of having played a leading role in the genocide. The court rejected, however, a request by Rutaganda's defence counsel that he be allowed to go to Europe for treatment of his illness, saying that he was receiving adequate care in a local civilian hospital in Arusha.

Neither Luc de Temmerman, the defence counsel, nor the court have revealed what illness he is suffering from, but Mr de Temmerman claimed that "if he is not treated in Europe, he won't be there in March to be tried". Meanwhile, the ICTR accepted on Friday a prosecution request that names of witnesses should not be disclosed to the public on security grounds. Yakob Haile Mariam, prosecting counsel, said one witness in Rwanda had already been told she would be killed if she went to Tanzania to testify against Mr Rutaganda.

The ICTR began the trial last week of Jean-Paul Akayesu, the former mayor of Taba in central Rwanda, also accused of having played a major role in the genocide. Before the trial got underway, African Rights, the London-based human rights organisation, released a report detailing Akayesu's actions during the genocide and showing that he 'went to extraordinary lengths to ensure the wholesale slaughter of Tutsis in his commune'. The full report is available from IRIN.

The trial of Akayesu, however, has also been postponed - this time for one month. Johan Scheers, his defence counsel, threatened on Friday to resign unless the court granted his request for a postponement of the case, saying that he had been given insufficient time to prepare his case. On Thursday the ICTR was also attacked by the Governments of Rwanda and Zimbabwe for slow progress since its establishment. They accused the UN of racial bias, saying that the Tribunal had acted more quickly to bring Bosnian war criminals to justice.

# The UNHCR announced on Tuesday that it was excluding from refugee status 20 Rwandans indicted by the International Tribunal in connection with the genocide. The list includes people who are currently being held in Arusha as well as others known to be in Europe and in refugee camps and elsewhere in Africa. The UNHCR is urging Governments not to provide those listed with asylum. They are: Ignace Bagilishema, Charles Sikubwabo, Aloys Ndimbati, Vincent Rutaganira, Mika Muhimana, Ryandikayo, Obed Ruzindana, Clement Kayishema, Jean-Paul Akayesu, Georges Rutaganda, Alfred Musema, Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, Gerard Ntakirutimana, Andre Ntagerura, Ladislas Ntaganzwa, Anatole Nsengiyumva, Elie Ndayambaje, Ferdinand Nahimana, Theoneste Bagosora and Eliezer Niyitegeka.

# The South African Government has been criticized by South African human rights groups, arms officials and politicians for its decision on Thursday to approve private sales of weapons to Rwanda. The decision has predictably been criticized by the RDR (Rally for the Return of Refugees and Democracy in Rwanda), the umbrella organisation representing Rwandan refugees.

# Rwanda's Ambassador to France, Christophe Mfizi, resigned from his post on Tuesday according to media reports. The embassy did not say why Mfizi, who was appointed to Paris in March 1995, had resigned. The first secretary, Modeste Rutabayiru, will temporarily replace him.

# Human Rights Watch and the Federation Internationale de Ligues des Droits de L'Homme called on Monday for the International Tribunal to investigate and prosecute rape and other gender-related crimes. The ICTR has to date issued no indictments for rape or other forms of sexual violence. The call followed the release of an HRW/FIDH report entitled, 'Shattered Lives: Sexual Violence During the Rwandan Genocide and its Aftermath', which details 'horrific' attacks on women and their families during the genocide. HRW/FIDH's recommendations included a call on donors to ensure that aid programmes meet women's needs, especially in the areas of criminal justice, health care, housing, credit, education, vocational training and trauma conselling, and on the Government of Rwanda to improve coordination between ministries seeking to issues relating to women.

# Some 284 people were killed in Rwanda in August according to a report by the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) released on Wednesday. HRFOR blamed the RPA for 159 of these deaths, while responsibility for the other killings lay with Hutu rebels who continued to target local officials and survivors of the genocide. The prison population reached 81,300 at the end of August, an increase of 2,800 since July.

# The peace agreement between the Ugandan and Sudanese Governments came under strain last week after the Sudanese Government all but admitted having bombed northern Uganda on Sunday 22 September. On Monday Amama Mbabazi, Uganda's Minister of Defence, had said that two Sudanese MiG planes dropped bombs aimed at the army barracks in Moyo on Sunday 22 September, but missed their target.

The Sudanese Government at first denied the claim, but later admitted that the attack had taken place. Iran's deputy foreign minister, Sheikul Islam Hessein, heading a five-member Iranian delegation to Uganda to investigate the incident, said that the attack could have been the result of a navigational error or an intelligence failure. The Iranians have recently mediated a normalisation of relations between Uganda and Sudan, and in a recent peace agreement the two countries committed themselves to preventing attacks from their territories against each other.

The agreement was further thrown into doubt, however, following reports on Friday that 30 people, including 28 civilians, were killed when rebels from the Lord's Resistance Army attacked Kitgum town on Wednesday. The civilians were caught in the cross fire during fighting between the army and the rebels. The Ugandan Government claims that the LRA fighters entered the country last week from bases in Sudan.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
