Africa News


October 2, 1996


Congo;
Mysterious Disease Kills Congo's Pygmies


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - At least 41 people have died of a mysterious disease within one week in Epena district, some 1,500 km (936 miles) north-east of Brazzaville, the Congolese capital.

An official source said here that the victims were mainly pygmies, who live on hunting and gathering of fruits in the forests. No further details were given about the nature of the disease.

Apart from the mysterious disease, several villages in the district have been flooded with water from the area's rivers. The floods have destroyed huts and crops, officials said.

Epena district authorities have launched an appeal to the government to provide emergency assistance to the affected population.

The district is often prone to floods, the most serious of which occurred in 1981 when many children suffered from measles in the wake of heavy flooding.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Burundi;
Former Burundian Speaker Leaves German Embassy


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The former speaker of the Burundi parliament, Leonce Ngendakumana, on Wednesday left the German Embassy in Bujumbura, where he had sought protection since the July 25 coup against President Sylivestre Ntibantunganya.

"I am urging all Burundians to remain calm and talk to each other in an effort to solve the country's problems," he said. 

Ngendakumana told PANA Wednesday in Bujumbura that he would make a public announcement Thursday on his reasons for leaving the embassy.

Only former President Ntibantunganya, who was ousted by Maj. Pierre Buyoya, is still hiding in the United States Embassy. On taking power, Buyoya immediately suspended political parties and the National Assembly. However, facing a strong economic embargo imposed by the neighboring countries, he relented and announced the first parliamentary session would open on Oct. 7.

The Burundian parliament, elected in June 1993, was dominated by the majority Hutu party, the Burundi Democratic Front or FRODEBU. It had 65 members in parliament. The Tutsi-dominated Unity for National Progress, or UPRONA, had 16 representatives.

However, FRODEBU now has less than 10 parliamentarians. Others were killed together with the first democratically elected president, Melchior Ndadaye, in an abortive coup d'etat on Oct.21, 1993.

Following the July coup, the majority of FRODEBU members of parliament joined the main Hutu rebel group, the National Council for Defence and Democracy, headed by Ndadaye's former interior minister, Leonard Nyangoma.

Some 150,000 Burundians are estimated to have died in revenge killings between the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi ethnic groups, following Ndadaye's death.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Set To Host World Tobacco Leaders


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - World tobacco leaders meet in Zimbabwe in November, to discuss the growing contribution of tobacco to development in poor countries and the threat of the anti-smoking lobby.

Zimbabwe Tobacco Association (ZTA) public relations director, Lal Taylor, said the week-long meeting of the International Tobacco Growers' Association from November 1 to 7 would also celebrate the importance of Africa in global tobacco production. 

Zimbabwe is a founder member of the association and one of the world's top three producers of flue-cured tobacco which brings in more than 700 million U. S. dollars into the country annually.

Taylor said for many African countries, revenue from tobacco exports was playing a major role in their social and economic development, and it was evident that Africa's contribution to world tobacco output was increasing.

One of the largest growth rates in production of more than two percent was expected in Zimbabwe.

Local tobacco farmers are this year expected to increase the area planted to tobacco to produce a crop of about 230 million kg compared with just over 202 million kg grown in the 1995/96 season.

The ITGA was founded in 1984 by six of the world's major tobacco producing countries-Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Malawi, the United States and Zimbabwe- and its main mission is to "be the active voice and representative of tobacco growers throughout the world".


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Liberia;
U.N. Condemns Liberian Massacre


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi; PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

NEW YORK - The United Nations Wednesday condemned the killing of several civilians in Sinje, Liberia, on Saturday, calling it a serious violation of human rights and the rights of children.

The U.N. secretary-general's special representative to Liberia, Anthony Nyakyi, said in New York that the U.N. Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) was making urgent arrangements to investigate the incident. 

Quoting reports from U.N. agency and relief workers, he said the massacre left at least 17 civilians dead, mostly women and children, and many more wounded. It caused about 1,000 people to flee Sinje, in Grand Cape Mount County.

"Other reports put the figure of the dead at between 25 and 42," Nyakyi said.

The incident, he said, demonstrated the serious consequences in implementing the Abuja peace process whereby the warring factions are to disengage and be disarmed.

"I call on all armed factions to disengage their fighters without any further delay," he said.

He said that the massacre was a setback to the efforts to deliver food to the needy in the interior of the country. It has also hurt efforts by the West African peace Monitoring Group (ECOMOG) and the mediating team to facilitate the opening up of roads to the interior.

"The callousness of the attack is demonstrated by the savage hacking of the leg of an eight-month-old girl who was evacuated by relief workers to Monrovia," Nyakyi said.

The perpetrators are yet to be established. The massacre is the latest in a series of incidents which have marred numerous attempts to end Liberia's more than six-year-old civil war, in which an estimated 150,000 people have been killed.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


31 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Senegal;
The Spectre Of AIDS Hangs Over Ourossogui Town


BYLINE: Cheikh Tidiane Ndiaye; PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

OUROSSOGUI, Senegal - The township of Ourossogui, 673 km north of Dakar, the Senegalese capital, has witnessed an upsurge in the number of people living with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which leads to the incurable AIDS.

Ourossogui hospital's chief laboratory technician, Djegane Sarr, who is in charge of AIDS tests, says an average of three people are diagnosed with the virus per month.

He said in a recent interview that 48 HIV-positive individuals had been diagnosed as of Sept. 25. Out of these, 42 had already developed full-blown AIDS. Six blood donors were also found to be HIV-positive. 

If the trend continues, he added, the 1996 figure of infected people could surpass the previous year's, which was at least 59, 10 of whom were blood donors.

According to Sarr, AIDS cases are on the rise in Ourossogui because its menfolk are great travellers. After living for long periods in Central Africa, Europe or the United States, some of them get infected.

Sarr claimed these returnees were responsible for the propagation of the HIV in Ourossogui. To prove his point, he cited the 1996 statistics which indicated that two thirds of the carriers were men while the remainder were women and children.

Due to the high infection rates, he added, Ourossogui hospital is increasingly finding it difficult to get uncontaminated blood for needy patients.

Paradoxically, even when one tries to obtain blood from accompanying relatives, most of them are also found to be seropositive when their blood is sent for diagnosis at the provincial hospital in Saint-Louis.

Sarr cited the example of a pregnant woman who gave birth under very difficult conditions after waiting in vain for her husband's blood. The blood was found to be contaminated with the HIV.

For ethical reasons, Sarr did not reveal the sad news to the woman but said he intended to conduct a blood test on her and her child to check whether they were infected.

What happened to the father? "He disappeared and has not shown up again after vowing that he has never left his village for any place where he might have caught the disease," the laboratory technician added.

Such disappearances, to avoid shame, are common among Ourossogui's Fulani community. AIDS victims in this ethnic group only return for hospitalisation at the terminal stage.

Hence, nearly all the AIDS patients who were diagnosed at Ourossogui hospital went home to die quietly, except for two brothers aged 17 and 19, who report to hospital for the required tests every three months.

The two were found with the virus when they donated blood together with three other brothers, who have not shown up.

According to Sarr, women, who remain behind when their husbands travel, appear to be better informed about the disease's danger.

He cited the example of a young woman, who, after observing her husband's failing health, refused to have anything to do with him unless he went to see a doctor.

When the husband tested positive, the woman only agreed to return to conjugal home after conciliation efforts. She nonetheless refused to have sex with him until his death, two months later.

Sarr is so affected by blood scarcity that sometimes he has to donate his own to save a patient. He has now embarked on a sensitization programme among the population, which is however not having an impact due to language barrier and lack of teaching materials.

To remedy the situation, Sarr has suggested to his superiors to make arrangements for blood donations among school children in Matam and Bakel districts.

Children in these districts are believed to be less infected by the HIV virus.

Senegalese anti-AIDS programme officials estimate that only 1 percent of the country's population is HIV-positive.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Angola and Zambia;
Savimbi Jilts Zambia?


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Luanda - President Chiluba said here last night that he was very disappointed with UNITA leader Dr Jonas Savimbi's decision to boycott the Southern African Development Community heads of state summit which opens today.

Mr Chiluba was speaking when United Nations Secretary-General Boutrus Boutrus-Ghali's special envoy to Angola, Dr Allion Blondin Beye called on him at his presidential suite at Meredien hotel here.

Mr Chiluba said he had been assured as late as Sunday afternoon by the UNITA leader that he would attend the summit which had been called by SADC leaders to try to put the Angola peace process back on track.

The President, who had personally invited Dr. Savimbi to the summit, said he was very disappointed with the guerrila leader's action. 

Mr Chiluba disclosed that he had earlier sent two envoys -- former Foreign Affairs Minister Vernon Mwaanga and Lusaka business tycoon Enock Kavindele - to extend his invitation to Dr. Savimbi to attend the summit. He said Dr. Savimbi assured the two envoys that he would attend the summit.

Mr Chiluba who has expressed concern about lack of progress in implementing the 1994 Lusaka peace protocol between the MPLA government and UNITA, said he wanted to give chance to Dr. Savimbi to tell SADC leaders and the world at large about the problems he was facing in implementing the peace pact.

Zambia hosted peace talks between the Angolan government and rival UNITA in November 1994 to end two decades of civil war that erupted soon after independence from portugal in 1975.

The two parties eventually signed the Lusaka agreement on November 20, 1994 and are currently in the process of implementing the time table.

Despite the current setback, Mr Chiluba said he and other leaders would continue to persue efforts that would bring lasting peace to the war torn SADC member country.

He said it is only through peace that the people of Angola would improve their quality of life.

Meanwhile President Chiluba said here last night that Zambia will go to the polls this year using the controversial 1996 republican constitution.

Mr Chiluba also ticked off outsiders who are meddling in the country's affairs that " the matter of the constitution are not for outsiders but for the Zambians themselves".

He was addressing Zambian military and police observers seconded to the United Nations peace keeping forces and Zambian nationals at the residence of Zambia's ambassador to Angola Major-General Benua Bulaya in Luanda.

Mr Chiluba stated that elections will take place this year and will be based on the 1996 republican constitution.

He said no group of people can claim to be competent in making laws than parliament.

The president who conceded that there has been pressure from certain quarters who have threatened to cut aid" if we do not withdraw the new constitution," reiterated that the new law was not targeted against a particular individual.

He maintained that there was no crisis in Zambia. In another development, Mr Chiluba paid tribute to Zambian peace keepers whom he said had brought honour to the country.

As Commander of the Zambia Armed Forces, he was proud of their contribution to international peace.

"There is no nobler assignment than the one you are doing," he told military and police observers assigned to the UN peacekeeping forces in Angola.

He urged them to continue rendering professional service whenever they are called upon to do so.

Earlier , Zambia's ambassador to Angola, Major-General Bulaya told the President not to listen to " old and spent" forces who are trying to detract him from the course he was taking.

He told the President to stick to the path he had taken so that Zambians can continue to enjoy the fruits of independence. He said all the servicemen serving in Angola were solidily behind his leadership.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Business;
State Disposes Of Energy Shares in Zambia


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Privatisation Agency (ZPA) has announced the privatisation of two major companies in the energy sector, BP Zambia Limited and AGIP Zambia.

Making the announcement at the ZPA monthly press briefing yesterday, the agency's chief executive, Valentine Chitalu, said the government has sold its 25 per cent of shareholding in BP to BP Africa. 

The government has sold its 50 per cent shareholding in Agip Zambia Limited to Agip Petroli International BV.

The BP shareholding was sold at US$3.3 million while the AGIP shareholding went at $850,000.

Giving an overview of the pace of privation, Chitalu said out of 118 companies dealt with so far, 88 have been sold to Zambians.

Of the trading sector's 178 shops or properties, 92 per cent have been sold to Zambians, Chitalu said.

"Out of 30 companies sold to foreigners, 14 companies were outside ZPA control due to the B' shareholders having pre-emptive rights," Chitalu said.

Chitalu also announced the sale of Lyambai Hotel in Mongu to J.S Songolo and two others at K55 million. Zambia Pork Products has been sold to Webster Musukwa at K500 million. This includes accrued employee benefits amounting to K200 million.

Concerning some tourist lodges which are due for re-advertisement by the state, Chitalu said the process of finding new bidders for the tourist lodges would be undertaken by the tourism ministry.

"The lodges no longer fall under the ZPA," Chitalu said.

Meanwhile, the agency hopes to cash in $20 million from company sales this year.

"But it will obviously be more, seeing that last year we made $33 million," Chitalu said.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Zambia;
(Editorial) Our view - Human Rights Violations


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Lusaka - The disclosure by the Munyama Human Rights Commission that the inhuman treatment of citizens that characterised UNIP's Second Republic has continued into MMD's Third Republic is sad but expected.

Human Rights violations are not committed in a vacuum. Just as there are political set-ups that help promote democratic rule and respect for the humanity of all citizens, some political systems and practices can only survive through repressive constitutional and legal arrangements and deeds. 

And repression knows no religion or ideology. Repression under Cuba's communist rule is not different from that of Iraqi's Islamic regime. It is also not different from that of UNIP's humanist society or that of MMD's capitalist and Christian nation. Repression is repression. Period.

And the question of whether UNIP's repressive regime existed for 17 years while that of the MMD has been for a much shorter period is neither here nor there. Repression cannot be measured by longevity or intensity.

And with MMD's leadership's exhibited desire to stay in office at all costs we are headed for more human rights violations.

The constitutional and legal framework the MMD government has put in place will inevitably lead to a clash with citizens who hold liberties dear. And the government is very much aware of the fact that it will not be possible for President Frederick Chiluba and the MMD to govern without resorting to the use of force to crush dissent and opposition in the country.

And this is why the government has amended the country's constitution to give President Chiluba powers to be the prime mover and controller of every activity in Zambia.

This also explains the introduction of the Intelligence Bill whose effect will be to turn the country into a police state, with the President as chief constable.

The introduction of a permanent Human Rights Commission, given the myriad of laws whose enforcement automatically result in violation of human rights, is a ploy to deceive the international community and retain some respectability.

The future, unless the current trend is quickly reversed, does not hold much for human rights protection and promotion as it does for the entrenchment of their violations.

As the Commonwealth Human rights Initiative that visited the country last month observed, the political situation in Zambia merits attention from its friends and the international community at large as the country's fragile experiment in democracy building is under threat in a situation where the shortage of time is a critical factor.

The direction in which the country is headed is clear. The time to start the fight and defend our dignity is now, tomorrow may be too late.

Opposing view: Government Is Committed To Human Rights

By Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, chief government spokesman and information minister

The government has decided to establish a permanent Human Rights Commission with a view to preventing further violations of human rights in Zambia.

Government has decided to, among other measures, establish a permanent Human Rights Commission which is enshrined in the amended Republican Constitution.

This action is being followed up by the enactment of an enabling Human Rights Commission Act during the current sitting of the National Assembly.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Zambia;
Munyama Human Rights Report Officially Released


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Lusaka - The government yesterday released the report of the Munyama Human Rights Commission of Inquiry which was unofficially published by The Post in January this year.

But the accompanying government's reactions to the commission's recommendations contained in a white paper has thrown out most of the "touchy" recommendations, especially those on the judiciary, prison service and the immigration department.

The government has, for instance, rejected the recommendations which would have provided for speedy trials and that in those cases where trial does not commence within thirty days, the accused if in custody must be set free unconditionally and another which would have empowered the Chief Justice to require fellow judges to provide an up-date on the status of cases under their charge. 

"This is not accepted because the provisions of Article 13 (3) of the Constitution are adequate. Moreover, the judiciary is currently working on amendments of the rules of regulating adjournment," read the government's reaction in part.

The white paper has also rejected the recommendations which would have amended Section 7 of the Zambia Security Intelligence Services Act to withdraw ordinary police powers from security officers.

"This is not accepted. Section 7 of the Act gives police powers to intelligence officers only in a State of Emergency," government's reaction reads.

On the recommendation which called for the establishment of separate wards for prisoners and remandees in hospitals to avoid the illegal practice of shackling them to beds in the ordinary wards, the government reacted thus: " This is not accepted. The solution lies in the improvement of medical facilities within prison premises."

The government also rejected the recommendation which sought to have prisoners incarcerated in prisons situated near their homes.

The overnment has also thrown out a recommendation for the defence force not to be involved in activities which are clearly for the police.

"This is not accepted. The defence forces may be involved in such activities at the invitation of the police force," reacted the government.

And, in a tail spin of things, the report does not have names of people detained between 1989 and 1993.

But when challenged, information minister, chief government spokesman, Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, who released the report, claimed "there were no detentions during that period".

Mwanamwambwa conceded that the findings have taken long to be released but claimed "assignments involving any Commission of inquiry need to be handled systematically and carefully".

But when asked what was happening to the Gabon Report, which has been long standing than the Munyama Report, Mwanamwambwa retorted: "That falls under the baby of the ministry of defence. It could be it's not ready yet...and I know its not ready, I could have seen it."

Meanwhile, Mwanamwa-mbwa also disclosed at the same press briefing that the government has decided to establish a permanent Human Rights Commission.

"With a view to preventing further violations of human rights in Zambia, the government has decided to, among other measures, establish a permanent Human Rights Commission which is enshrined in the amended Republican Constitution,"

Mwanamwambwa said. "This action is being followed up by the enactment of an enabling Human Rights Commission Act during the current sitting of the National Assembly."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Mozambican Squad Jets In To Lusaka


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga and Shiekh Chifuwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - A fear-gripped Mozambican national soccer team arrived in the country yesterday with their Portuguese-based wing terror, Jojo Fernandes admitting: "Zambia is surely the favourite".

Jojo, who plays his club football for Portuguese second division side, Penafiel, observed that playing Africa's highly-rated team, the Mozambicans are under pressure to secure a win.

"Zambia seems to have the advantage of being the best team in Africa and I think we may have a little problems but this is football, we can still do something," said Jojo in an interview shortly after the arrival. 

But skipper of the side, Francisco Canonde could only say; "We shall wait for the day."

And trainer of the side, Arnalo Salvao, whose 18-player-squad has brought only four professinals, said although he rates Zambia highly, he could not predict the outcome of the match as both teams were prepared .

Apart from Jojo , Chiwinho Conje is another player playing in Portugal, while two other professionals-Nuw Tuauwsine and Cachola Jwene play in South Africa.

"We are aware that Zambia is a very good team in Africa, but I think since we have all trained, it would be match that will be interesting. But I can not say if we will play attacking or defending football," said Salvao.

But it was the Mozambican high commissioner in Zambia, Cristopa Jamo, who appeared rather overzealous, urging the players to win at all costs.

Said Jamo, rather diplomatic after seeing that Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) general secretary, Julio Chiluba, was present.

"We always play to win, we don't play to draw and lose but if we draw it is always by accident. Even this game , we can win, I hope it will happen,"

And embattled FAZ boss, Michael Chiti, yesterday announced a slash of the gate fees for the Zambia-Mozambique match following pressure from fans.

But those wishing to watch the match at the VIP stand will still have to pay through the nose as nothing has been done to the K50,000. charge, but it will be K1, 000. for children, K5,000. and K3,000. Open wings.

LANGUAGE: English

37 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Mozambique: Mambas' Track Record Traced


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Lusaka - The date was January 25, 1996 and the giant Free State Stadium in Bloemfontein, South Africa, was alive with excitement and hurrah which Ghanian and Mozambican fans had brought to the African Nations Cup finals.

Fans for both sides had good reason to be excited: Ghana, a messy first round their team were determined to stay in the race for the cup they have won a record four times while Mozambique were gunning for their first ever quarter final berth.

After kick-off, Mozambique looked like they would upset Ghana and, for 45 minutes, it appeared their self-assurance was fully justified. Comfortable on the ball, ticking smoothly and covering with speed and commitment which sealed the central approach to their danger zone. They even managed to nod in one goal. 

Then something snapped. Ghana blasted in two goals and Mozambique's dreams were shattered.

On Sunday, the Mamba's (as Mozambique national soccer team is known) are back in Africa's premier soccer cup against the awesome power of Zambia's Chipolopolo eleven.

Can they do the unthinkable, beat Zambia right in it's own backyard?

The answer is definitely an emphatic NO, especially when you analyse their track record from their debut in the Nations Cup in 1982.

They have lost crucial matches, earning them the nickname "traditional losers".

In their maiden game, they made a false start beating Lesotho 6-0 but in the return match, Lesotho licked them 2-1 and weeks later, they lost 2-1 to Zaire and they managed a 3-all draw in the return game.

In the 1984 qualifying games, they surprised when they whacked an ill- equipped Cameroon 3-0 in Maputo but lost the return match with a resounding 4- 0 rout in Yaonde.

Mozambique finally managed a berth at the finals in 1986 after finishing top of the group that comprised Mauritius, Libya and Malawi. Unfortunately they were kicked out in the preliminaries of their group matches.

They did not qualify for the 1988 finals as they were kicked out in the preliminaries, drawing 1-1 with Zimbabwe and losing the return match 2-3.

They met Zambia for the first time during the 1990 qualifying games. They lost 0-1 in Maputo and were bloodied 3-0 at Independence stadium.

Two years later, they finished second in the qualifying matches after they beat Sudan 1-0, whacked Kenya 2-1 and repeated the routing of Sudan by a lone goal. Their run was, however, stopped by Kenya who beat them 1-0.

During the 1994 qualifying games, they lost 2-0 to Zaire, beat Lesotho 3-0 and drew 0-0 with Kenya. They again drew 0-0 with Zaire, 1-1 with Lesotho but lost 4-1 against Kenya. They finished third in the group and did not qualify for the finals.

But perhaps their greatest achievement was during the qualifying matches for last year's African Nations Cup finals in South Africa.

They beat Botswana 3-1, nudged Guinea 2-1 but lost to unfancied Angola 0-1. But they managed to qualify to the next round by beating Namibia 4-2, Mali 1- 0 and Botswana by three goals to nothing.

They drew with Guinea 0-0, beat Angola 2-1 and drew 0-0 with Namibia. They finished second and qualified to the finals. They, however, bowed out in the quarter finals suffering a 2-1 defeat against Ghana. But do the Mozambicans know what they are up against?


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


38 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 2, 1996


Zambia;
Goverment Dismisses Election Fears


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lusaka - Chief government spokesman, information and broadcasting minister Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, in a press release yesterday dismissed fears of a possible vacuum in the office of the president as unfounded and unjustified.

Mwanamwambwa charged that comments made by the Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) and other quarters expressing concerns on matters relating to the election of the President and dissolution of the National Assembly are misleading the public.

Mwanamwambwa was reacting to the concerns raised by the Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) of possible presidential crisis due to the ambiguities introduced by the Constitution (Amendment) Act of 1996. 

ZIMT president Alfred Zulu charged that if President Frederick Chiluba continues his stay at State House after October 31, he shall be doing it illegally.

"Midnight of November 2, 1996 is the maximum period, beyond that, he will be extending his rule illegally," Zulu warned on Sunday.

But Mwanamwambwa said "such comments have the potential of confusing the members of the public, as they tend to create the erroneous impressions that a vacuum may arise in the governance of the country".

He said the current Constitution, as amended by Act number 18 of 1996, provides under Article 34 (2) that; "An election to the office of the president shall be held whenever the National Assembly is dissolved and otherwise as provided by Article 38".

Article 38 provides that; "If the office of the president becomes vacant by reason of his death or resignation or by reason of his ceasing to hold office by virtue of Article 36, 37 or 88, an election to office of the president shall be held in accordance with Article 34 within 90 days from the date of the office becoming vacant".

Mwanamwambwa said the provisions of the law are such that there can be no vacuum at any one time in the office of the President nor the President occupy office illegally in between elections.

"In correcting these unfounded fears and incorrect interpretations of the 1996 Constitution, government wishes to state that the constitutional provisions with regard to these matters are quite clear," he said. "If the President's tenure ends - regardless of how it ends, whether by death, resignation, impeachment - the constitution provides that there shall be an election within 90 days upon the office becoming vacant."

Mwanamwambwa said when the National Assembly is dissolved, general elections have to be held after 90 days, regardless of how that dissolution occurs.

"The President remains in office over a period of 90 days, until he succeeds himself in the event of being re-elected, or another person is elected to the office," he said, "There is no question therefore of any vacuum occuring in the office of the president and creating a crisis, as it is being claimed, and Article 38 gives powers to the president to act for 90 days and he may do so after he has dissolved the National Assembly."


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 2, 1996


Science and Health;
WHO Reports Yellow Fever in Benin


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Geneva - An outbreak of yellow fever has been reported in the Department of Atakora in the northeast region of the country. The area affected is Kerou Sous Prefecture (population 44,329) where 48 cases and 37 deaths have been recorded. These cases occurred between July and September 1996. Urgent control measures were put into place following a meeting with the Minister of Health:

i) an immediate epidemiological investigation to be carried out in the areas affected;

ii) strengthening of surveillance including declaration of all cases of haemorrhagic fever with jaundice;

iii) immediate vaccination of the exposed population and informing the population to use impregnated mosquito nets;

iv) informing countries with common borders of the situation;

v) an entomological investigation into the density of the Aedes population in certain urban areas was also foreseen.

A team led by the Minister of Health accompanied by the WR visited the area on 17 and 18 September to assess the situation. A vaccination campaign was started immediately with the stock of 13 000 vaccines already available provided by the French Fonds d'Aide et d'Action Culturelle and WHO. Two further donations of 50,000 doses of vaccine were made by the government of the Netherlands and (by) the European Union. The health authorities plan to vaccinate the whole population of Kerou and surrounding areas (population more than 350,000), and therefore need more than 200,000 further doses for this purpose. An appeal has been made for financial support.

Travellers are reminded that yellow fever vaccination is obligatory for entry into the country.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 3, 1996


East Africa;
Humanitarian Situation Report (Sep 25 to Oct 1)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs (Burundi)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2120 words


 

Nairobi - Humanitarian activities in Burundi continue to be limited by the regional sanctions imposed on the country. The September 25 meeting of the Regional Sanctions Coordination Committee (RSCC) in Kigali concentrated on the political stalemate in Burundi. The RSCC did, however, publicly confirm that it had agreed earlier in the week to allow FAO to import limited quantities of fertilizer for non-cash crops and vegetable seeds. A six percent drop in the January 1997 pulse harvest is forecast by FAO as a result of the non-delivery of fertilizer that had earlier been blocked by the embargo. It is already too late to use the fertilizer this season.

Security throughout Burundi remains precarious with ambushes continuing on the main roads and with most of Bujumbura once again without electricity. Fuel supplies held by the humanitarian community continue to be alarmingly low, and while an order has been made, no new stocks have been received.

While there have been few reports of new fighting in Burundi over the last week, reports of continued fighting in eastern Zaire have raised concern about the possibility of a new inflow of refugees into Burundi. To date, however, only small numbers of people have crossed into Burundi to escape the fighting in Uvira and Bukavu. 

1. General

*Burundi's neighboring states enforcing sanctions against the Buyoya regime hinted last week that they would allow Buyoya to meet with political leaders of neighboring country's at the next regional summit, effectively reducing the Burundian leader's political isolation. In recommendations issued after the September 25 meeting of the RSCC in Kigali, committee members advised that "Buyoya be invited to be available" for the next regional summit to discuss developments in Burundi. The text added that "other leaders of parties to the conflict (are) also invited to be available." Buyoya had tried for some time to win an audience with those responsible for imposing the economic sanctions but had been rebuffed until last week. No firm date has yet been set for the regional summit, but it could be as soon as the second week in October.

Member's of the Buyoya government welcomed the opening even though the wording of the recommendations appeared to give President Buyoya's rule the same degree of legitimacy as that of rebel leaders such as Leonard Nyangoma. " We consider that it is a good thing to be able to explain the situation to our neighbors," said Minister of Information Pierre-Claver Ndayicariye. "It is never too late to make peace, but while people hesitate about lifting sanctions, the embargo claims innocent victims," he added in an interview with reporters.

*The power struggle within the Hutu-dominated Frodebu party intensified September 25 with 34 more members backing CNDD leader Leonard Nyangoma's claim to be the new party chief. Nyangoma had announced the previous week that he had wrested the party's presidency away from Jean Minani, the former speaker of the national assembly. Minani continues to contest Nyangoma's claim.

*In a speech during the September 27 ceremony in which the Burundian Supreme Court swore in Buyoya as head of state, Buyoya reiterated his claim that the coup was necessary to avoid the disintegration of the Burundian state and promised once again to organize a national debate on the country's political future. He added that preparations for the debate were already underway.

*Howard Wolpe, President Clinton's special envoy to Burundi arrived in Bujumbura September 29 to once again argue for a negotiated settlement of the conflict and a return to constitutional rule. This was his first trip to Burundi since early August, shortly after the July 25 coup. After his September 30 meeting, Wolpe told reporters that he and Buyoya had discussed ways of restoring peace, but gave no other details. Wolpe is expected to leave Burundi October 3 to meet with political leaders of other countries in the region imposing sanctions against Burundi

For the first time since this summer, Burundian authorities have opened their side of the border with Zaire. Although the border was somewhat porous even when it was officially closed, the action by Burundian authorities has made it easier for those supplying the parallel market for fuel in Burundi to bring supplies into the country. The price on the parallel market for fuel is now said to be between 500 FrBu to 700 FrBu, a reduction of several hundred FrBu per liter. Officially, Zaire has kept its side of the border closed.

2. Security

The Burundian army reports that five civilians, ten rebels and two soldiers were killed last week near Rutegama in Muramvya province. Thirteen people were injured in separate attacks in the province over the week but additional details were not available.

Rebel ambushes continue along major roads throughout the country, although UN security officials report somewhat fewer ambushes than previous weeks. Rebels continue to target minibuses transporting passengers and food to markets, as well as other soft, commercial targets. Direct attacks against military units have become infrequent.

While attacks along Route 2 between Gitega and Murumvya continue, rebels have now begun to target vehicles travelling along Route 3 between Bujumbura and Rumonge. This week, rebels attacked at least three vehicles traveling on that route with at least one person killed, three injured and three vehicles destroyed. The attacks were in the vicinity of Kabezi, about 25km south of Bujumbura.

According to WFP, there are unconfirmed reports of serious clashes in Kayanza province, including an attack on a health center and hospital in Butaganzwa commune.

Rebels have once again destroyed electric pylons in Bubanza province. At least one more pylon was toppled Sunday, once again plunging most parts of the city into darkness and forcing UN agencies and NGOs to divert fuel stocks to run generators.

WFP has had to remove its Twin Otter plane from service in order for it to undergo maintenance in Johannesburg. Without the use of the plane, members of the humanitarian community who need to travel between Bujumbura and other regional towns will be forced to risk travel by road. Use of the plane would be essential should an evacuation of UN staff be necessary. It is expected to be at least a week until the plane is back in service.

3. Affected Populations

UNHCR reports that refugees continue to cross into Burundi from eastern Zaire. Over 400 have crossed the border since the conflict between Zairian Tutsis and elements of the Zairian miliary erupted last month. Many of those escaping the fighting who have crossed into Burundi are in the troubled Cibitoke province, and will be transported by the Burundian government to a UNHCR camp now being prepared in Gihanga, about 15 km north of the Bujumbura airport.

ACF is exploring the possibility of enlarging its nutritional programs in Gitega, rural Bujumbura and northern Kayanza.

The International Rescue Committee has begun operations in Muyinga province. In conjunction with the Ministry of Health, IRC will work to improve sanitation in IDP camps and rehabilitate local water systems.

According to WFP, the governor of Ngozi province is discussing with relief agencies, including WFP, the possibility of resettling internally displaced Burundians on the sites of the two former refugee camps in the province.

4. Humanitarian Coordination

The Rwandan Sanctions Committee has granted a joint request from the humanitarian community for a bulk shipment of diesel and petrol for UN and NGO humanitarian operations and basic administration. WFP and the UN Resident Coordinator in Tanzania are exploring procedures for importing fuel from that country. On the assumption that the Rwandan shipment will arrive shortly, no order has been placed with Tanzanian suppliers.

On September 30, UNICEF, with the logistical support of WFP, organized an airlift to Burundi of 500 kg of vaccines to prevent the spread of measles and polio. The quantity is sufficient to immunize 150,000 children.

UNICEF has sent essential drug kits to Rutana and Muyinga provinces through its operational partner IMC, to Cankuzo through MSF-Switzerland and to Bururi through WFP in collaboration with provincial health authorities.

Final touches are being completed on the new draft of the Joint Operations Plan for Humanitarian Assistance in Burundi.

Preparations for a joint-agency assessment mission to examine the state of IDPs in the Gitega region are underway. 5. Impact of Sanctions on the Delivery of Humanitarian Assistance

The recent RSCC exemptions granted for medicine have not prevented serious shortfalls in the providing of essential services in the health sector. A major concern continues to be the severe shortage of BCG (tuberculosis) vaccines. UNICEF-donated government stocks of the vaccine are virtually depleted. New supplies have been ordered, but unless they are received within days, the vaccination chain will be broken.

The lack of fuel continues to limit the ability of all agencies to undertake field activities. It has become increasingly difficult to deliver essential drugs, vaccines and food used in supplementary feeding programs. Lack of fuel, for example, has prevented UNICEF from supervising the delivery of materials for the repair of water catchment sites and gravity flow systems in Kirundo and Ngozi provinces, as well as the distribution of emergency water and sanitation materials for recently displaced persons in Kayanza and Ngozi provinces.

Materials ordered from suppliers outside the country for the provision of emergency water and sanitation facilities, as well as other humanitarian needs, have been blocked from delivery. Obtaining humanitarian materials locally has become increasingly difficult as supplies have run out and can not be replenished.

HUMANITARIAN COORDINATION UNIT/DHA P.B. 1490 Bujumbura, BURUNDI tel: 257 22 31 35 fax: 257 22 58 50.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


41 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA)- Commission to give grades to tourist class hotels

The Ethiopian Tourism commission announced that it has planned to give grades to tourist-class hotels in various regional states.

Preliminary preparations have been finalized in all of the regional tourism bureaux to give a 1.5 stars grades to hotels which can fulfil the criteria set for the grades, according to Ato Matewos Gebre Mariam, department head of standardization and trade licence.

He said there are hotels which fulfil the necessary criteria in Nazareth, Jimma, Goba, Awassa, Harar, and Dire Dawa towns.

Ato Matewos said grades would also be given to restaurants which prepare foreign dishes in Addis Ababa in the near future and added it has given a two- five star grades to 13 government owned and private hotels until early this year. 

He said the awarding of the grades is not an ever lasting as the hotels can be upgraded or degraded depending on the timely quality of services they render and features of each of the hotels.

The department head said if the quality of the services of any hotel is declining, its standard will be lowered, if it increases, the number of stars will be increased.

The commission has also issued trade licences to about 40 tour operators which are active in more than one regions.

New education curriculum goes on trial

DESSIE (ENA) - The Amhara Regional Education Bureau said the new curriculum is to be tried for grade three and seven in 14 selected sample schools in Amhara Region.

Speaking at a five day workshop organized to introduce professionals about the new curriculum, Ato Yilma Tirsit, senior curriculum expert in the bureau said the curriculum has been prepared for the different subjects taught in the two grades.

The new curriculum will be implemented in all schools in the region after amendments are made and text books prepared based on this year's trial, he said.

The trial on the new curriculum for grades two and six has proved effective and text books were prepared to launch formally the curriculum in all the schools in the region the expert said.

The previous curriculum had shortfalls in solving the problems of the society and has not encouraged the students for research and creativity, Ato Yilma said adding, the new curriculum was designed in such a way that it encourages and invites students for research and creative works.

The five day workshop reviews the new curriculum for grades two and six and discusses the one for grade three and seven.

Premier's press statement

In a press statement he gave to the local newsmen on Saturday, Prime Minister Miles Zenawi said that the recent measures on banning Franco Valuta, price adjustment on petrol and petroleum products as well as the recently imposed rates on shops and other business centres in Region 14 were all taken to break the subsidy-syndrome and promote the principles of market economy.

"Whether we like it or not the only path to sustainable development in today's world is pursuing the market economy. The hard fact is this: if we succeed in the world market competition we develop; if we lose we wither. And this is attained not by government subsidy but by creating a robust market- oriented economy," Prime Minister Meles pointed out.

Price hike effect: minimal

The recent increase in the price of petroleum products will not have significant repercussion on the economic status of the consumer because the resulting effect will be cushioned by the better performance of the national economy, Minister of Trade and Industry, Ato Kassahun Ayele said.

Meanwhile, Ato Ayenew Betwelegne, Vice Minister of Transport and communications, on his part said that since petroleum and derivatives account for less than 18 per cent of the cost of running a car, the effect of the price change on the transport sector is minimal and any change on transportation fares is superfluous.

In the meantime, the Agricultural Input Supply Corporation said the increase in fertilizer price, resulted from the rise in fuel price, is less than 50 cents per quintal. The increment in full price is so insignificant that it would not discourage farmers from buying fertilizers, it is noted.

Economic registration

Addressing the 51st General Assembly of the United Nations recently, Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin said in New York the only durable solution to the political crisis in Africa is the economic regeneration and development of the continent, the only reliable preventive means for ensuring and maintaining peace and stability in the region.

The development of Africa would continue to be a distant dream unless the known obstacles such as debt burden are removed, he said, indicating that Ethiopia is one of the least developed and most indebted countries whose wide ranging and thorough going economic reform programme could easily be adversely affected by the heavy and unbearable debt burden and servicing obligations.

Inter-parliamentary meet

In a statement he made recently on arrival at Bole International air Port after attending the meeting held from September 12-17, House Speaker Dawit Yohannes said important decisions believed to alleviate poverty in Africa and minimize the problem of instability in some parts of the continent were made by the sixth inter-parliamentary meeting in Beijing, China.

Ato Dawit said the Ethiopian delegation has not chances of voicing various political and economic problems existing in the African continent, to which solutions were suggested by the participants of the meeting.

'Demera' celebrated

'Demera', the finding of the True Cross was colourfully celebrated on Thursday here at the Maskel Square in the presence of hundreds of thousands of the Christian laity.

On the occasion, His Holiness Abune Paulos, Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, said 'Demera' is both religious and historical and called upon followers of the Christian religion to preserve it for generations to come. The bonfire was lit by the representative of Region 14 Administration after the blessings of the Patriarch.

Dam construction

The 120-million birr Alwero Dam Project, whose construction was delayed for more than a decade for various reasons is now completed, the Water Works Construction Enterprise said.

Located about 850 kms away from Addis and 50 kms from Gambella town, the dam has a capacity to hold 75 million cubic metres of water and develop 10, 000 hectares of land, it was learnt.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
Trial of Derg officials resumes today


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 120 words


 

ADDIS ABABA(ENA) - The Federal High court resumes today the trial of former government officials. 

The Federal High Court has heard 39 witnesses of the Special Prosecutor in 34 proceedings since criminal cases were filed on December 13, 1994 against the Derg officials who it said had committed genocide.

The court is to continue hearing the witnesses of the Special Prosecutor against the officials at its 35th session.

The court has been in recess since September 6 to 28.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
'Errecha' Thanks Giving Day Celebrated


BYLINE: Getachew Kejela, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

DEBREZEIT - The traditional Oromo thanksgiving day known as 'Errecha' was celebrated in the familiarly colourful fashion at Lake Hora, some 50 k.m East of Addis Ababa, on Sunday.

Thousands of the residents of Debre Zeit town and its environs attended the annual event celebrated every second Suday after Maskel-- the Day of the finding of the True Cross. The occasion was marked by throngs of people paying sacrificial tributes to their gods(adbar) of the lake and of the Oda(Oak tree) near Hora under which they sand and danced in chorus- the elders and spiritual leaders taking turns in blessing the ceremony. 

Ato Mengesha Gudata, 72, who was accorded the honour of opening the ceremony by blessing the devout said that 'Errecha' was a blend of both the religion and culture of the Oromo people passed and down from generation to generation. "It is an occasion whereby the people give thanks to god for its benevolence in enabiliting them realize their wishes, getting good rains and collecting good harvest, living in peace etc." the septuagenarian observed.

The pilgrims from as far as Addis Ababa, Nazareth and even beyond carry with them coffee, perfume, incense, alcohol and even precious metals like gold which they leave at the place as token sacrifice in accordance with their previous year's solemn promise to do so for fulfilment of their wishes.

W/ro Askale Desta, who was making coffee along with a dozen colleagues amidst a dancing and singing crowd under the old sprawling Oda tree, said: " Right at this place last year I vowed to make coffee on the spot in honour of the gods if my prayers about my dislodged children coming back home from abroad in peace were answered; and has so happened" , she told this reporter in high glee and her broad faces suffused by sweat caused by the mid-day heat as well as the extreme suffocation of the crowed.

Observers consider it amazing that Christians, Moslems and animists alike from the various nations and nationalities take part in the ceremony by offering sacrifices, dancing and singing to the tune of their respective languages and cultures.

Many people were also observed taking bath while others swam in the crater lake as a sign of cleansing which they describe as "doing away with the evils of the older Ethiopian year and welcoming the new one in good spirit."

Debre Zeit, traditionally known as Bishoftu among the Oromos, is a popular weekend resort. The "Errecha" has added to its tourist appeal.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
End of Franco Valuta Boosts Business


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The abolition of franco valuta and the availability in the required amount of foreign currency would encourage not only big business ventures but also small retail trade.

The remark came yesterday from representatives of Customs Authority, Addis Ababa Chamber of Commerce, the National Bank and Inland Revenue in an interview with the press in the Ethiopian Television studio.

Ato Fisha Dejene, vice chairman of the operation sector of the customs authority said the coming to an end of franco valuta may affect illegal trade but there is no doubt that it would encourage legal businessmen who are entitled to get foreign currency they require from the banks. 

Woizero Yematawork Haile, board member of directors, Addis Ababa Chamber of Commerce, said entrepreneurs operating in the legal frame work do not want to do business with franco valuta in place and called for the existence of banking system free of bureaucratic bottlenecks as well as an effective banks service.

Ato Kinfe-Michael WoldeTensay, manager of the foreign exchange department of the National Bank of Ethiopia indicated that the exchange rate in the black market was very high as compared to that to be provided by the banks adding this could facilitate business and make businessmen more active in the sector.

If there is no franco valuta, there will be no contraband trade in gold and precious stones, he added.

According to Ato Mohammed Abrar Yassin, Inland Revenue Collection Division head, equal amount of interest is demanded for franco valuta which comes to an end today and legal business therefore he said nothing special would happen to businessmen in the absence of the former.

The business system being introduced in Ethiopia would also encourage wholesale trade which enables the importation of commodities at very low prices, he added.

Representative of the Chamber of Commerce said the chamber could give every possible support to businessmen to encourage them to import additional goods in a bid to prevent the soaring of prices and the scarcity of commodities.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 3, 1996


United States and Africa;
Congregations Commit to Nigerian Democracy


BYLINE: American Committee on Africa (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

New York - Congregations from coast to coast will dedicate themselves to seeking the restoration of freedom and democracy in Nigeria on October 6 by observing Nigerian Freedom Sunday. Nigeria, which marks the 36th anniversary of its independence this month is now suffering under a brutal military dictatorship. Military dictator Sani Abacha has jailed over 7,000 religious, political, labor and human rights activists, including Moshood Abiola, the winner of the 1993 Presidential election. 

Nigerian Freedom Sunday was established in a Declaration of Conscience on Nigeria endorsed by over 40 prominent religious leaders at a national conference of the Religious Action Network of the American Committee on Africa this May. Declaring that Nigeria, "once a beacon of hope and pride for African people throughout the world ... has been brought low by the brutality and injustice of a military dictatorship." the signatories pledged to lift their voices in the U.S. on behalf of Nigerian freedom and democracy. They called on all people of good will to join them in this effort.

The U.S. is deeply involved in perpetuating the system of violence and fear. It buys nearly half of Nigeria's oil exports which provide the ruling military dictatorship with 85% of its annual revenue. Declaring that U.S. and "multi-national corporations exploit Nigeria's vast oil wealth, extracting billions of dollars in profits while Nigerian children go hungry" signatories are marking October 6th as a day of prayer for the victims of oppression and dictatorship and for the peaceful return of freedom and democracy. Hafsat Abiola, daughter of the imprisoned president, will speak at Canaan Baptist Church of Christ in Harlem. "It is important to support this struggle for freedom in Africa's largest country" said Wyatt Tee Walker, Senior Pastor at Canaan Baptist Church and President of the American Committee on Africa.

The Religious Action Network is a project of the American Committee on Africa, which was founded in 1953 to support struggles for independence, democracy and economic justice in Africa.

For further information, contact Rev. Paul Harris at (212) 962-1210.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 3, 1996


United States and Africa;
Statement On Presidential Election in The Gambia


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Washington DC - Following is a statement by Nick Burns, U.S. Department of State spokesman, issued October 2, 1996, on the Presidential Election in The Gambia.

The United States deeply regrets that the September 26 presidential election denied The Gambian people the right to choose their leaders in a free and fair manner. The two-week run-up to the presidential election did not provide a level playing field. The Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council (AFPRC) restricted political participation by banning some former politicians and parties, allowed only a brief campaign period for registered parties, limited television and radio access to certain candidates, and continued to detain political prisoners.

Throughout the two-year transition program the AFPRC detained political prisoners, arrested journalists, and banned political activity. These activities created a climate which was not conducive to holding a free and fair election.

We deplore the pre-election violence and resulting arrests. We call on the Government of The Gambia to ensure the safety of all Gambians and other residents in the country, including those who express views different from those of the Government.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 3, 1996


United States and Africa;
Text: Remarks by Christopher and Tunisian FM


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Washington DC - Following are the remarks by Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Tunisian Foreign Minister Habib Ben Yahia prior to their meeting on October 3, as provided by the State Department.

SECRETARY CHRISTOPHER: Good morning. It's always a special pleasure to welcome my friend, Foreign Minister Habib Ben Yahia, back to Washington D.C., You know, it's really striking when I think of it: we're almost on the 200th anniversary of U.S.-Tunisian relationships. I guess you could say it has stood the test of time, hasn't it? We've been close partners, and I particularly want to acknowledge the strong support that Tunisia has given over the years to the peace process. 

Naturally, today we'll be discussing the state of the peace process, the concern that we all have for it. I'll be having an opportunity to brief the Foreign Minister on some of the elements of yesterday's discussion. I know we share the view that the parties must do everything they can to find areas of agreement; the only alternative, a return to violence, is simply not acceptable to any of us. Both sides reject such a course, as does the international community. I believe that both sides are committed to making the negotiations that will commence at Erez succeed, and I hope in the very shortest time possible.

We're very grateful to the role that Tunisia has always played in the peace process. Most recently, and I think only a couple of weeks ago, Tunisia hosted the meeting to launch the new Middle East and Mediterranean Travel and Tourism Association, one of the things that came out of the Amman summit. I am confident that we'll continue to work together on the peace process, as we have on so many other issues. It's a very great pleasure to welcome you back, Habib, to have an opportunity to exchange views with you once again.

FOREIGN MINISTER BEN YAHIA: Thank you, Mr. Secretary; good morning, ladies and gentlemen. It's nice to be back to Washington as usual, to do this pilgrimage every year back to Washington. This particular time is of certain importance to both of us, Mr. Secretary, to give back vigor to the peace process. That peace process we cherished, we built piece by piece, with patience, with a lot of good work, and it's for the last five years we have been together embarked on a very important, risky and difficult business, of making peace in the Middle East. I hope that with yesterday's summit, a new departure, new momentum is being gained, and we hope that Dennis Ross going back to the region this Sunday will help us put back the peace process on track, in order to reach the implementation of the agreements signed in Oslo and Washington and Cairo. Tunisia has always been committed to peace. Peace has its own dividend for everybody, but we insist that we should see concrete results, and the sooner the better, in order to avoid any (inaudible). We are always committed to peace. President Ben Ali has been instrumental in working very hard to maintain the momentum with all parties concerned. We hope that this will be the case this time, in order for us to face next year, the next century, with plenty of hope for peace in the region. Thank you, Mr. Secretary.

QUESTION: Mr. Secretary, are you making any plans yourself to travel to the Middle East prior to your Africa trip? Will you be in Erez on Sunday?

SECRETARY CHRISTOPHER: Let me say this about that. I've always held myself ready to go to the region when it would be helpful in moving the process forward. I think I feel particularly a responsibility to do that in connection with the talks about to begin at Erez, and so when it seems that I might be useful, when my presence there would be helpful in moving the process forward I'll certainly be prepared to go. I don't have any plans to do so at the present time, but I'm going to be watching the situation closely to see if things develop in a way that might make a trip by myself a constructive and positive step.

QUESTION: Wouldn't you be making that decision today, sir?

SECRETARY CHRISTOPHER: I'm probably making it every day over the next several weeks as we watch the situation develop. The situation is very fresh, and really just unfolding.

QUESTION: Mr. Secretary, the Israelis and the Palestinians seem to agree on one thing, which is that the Israelis won out at the summit this week, and the Palestinians lost out because they didn't feel they gained anything from the Israelis. How do you react to that?

SECRETARY CHRISTOPHER: I don't think it ought to be evaluated in terms of winners and losers. We have no illusions about the situation, but there was conversation between the two leaders, which had not been possible to have. If you think back to a week ago today, we had the bloodiest day on the West Bank within anybody's memory. Things are somewhat better now. I think the conversation that took place, the recommitment to a nonviolent future, the commitment to have intensive and indeed continuous negotiation, is a step forward. In that sense, everyone comes out a winner. But we've got a long way to go, there are difficult times ahead, and I think we need to see some results flowing from those negotiations.

Thanks very much.

Africa News


October 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

NAZARETH (ENA) - Ethiopian Women Lawyers' Association organizes symposium: A symposium organised by the Ethiopian Women Lawyers' Association opened Tuesday in Nazareth town aiming at reasserting the need for organizng women and making them understand basic family laws.

The two day symposium is being attended by 20 women drawn from governmental organizations, and political parties active in various zones and woredas.

Speaking at the opening of the symposium, Woizero Lomi Ejersa, chief secretary of the East Shewa zone council indicated the need for women to organize themselves into associations so the they could secure their equal rights come out from the influence of harmful traditions and participate in the making and implementation of development policies and create job opportunities. 

 

166 New city buses to be imported this Ethiopian year

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Addis Ababa city Bus Service Enterprise said 166 additional city buses will be imported in two rounds this Ethiopian year.

Ato Kebede Weldu, manager of the enterprise told ENA that the first fleet of 100 buses are planned to arrive after four months while the rest 66 at the end of this Ethiopian fiscal year.

The plan for the importation of 166 new city buses bring the number of additional buses to 266 in a period of less than two years with the importation of 100 DAF buses imported since last March.

Ato Kebede said city bus service has grown by 90 per cent with the importation of 100 new buses already in service.

Ato Kebede said the resentful price increment would not affect bus fares as the city bus service is subsidised by Region 14 Administration.

The students will be charged 15 cents while other passengers 25 cents for a single trip as usual, Ato kebede said.

Bumper harvest

NEKMPTE (ENA) - Farmers embraced by the agricultural extension programme in East Wellega Zone said they have begun harvesting 80 quintals of crop from just a hectare of land.

The farmers approached by ENA said the extension programme launched a year ago was instrumental in boosting production.

The farmers said they are expecting to harvest about 250 quintals of sorghum this production season.

According to reports some 1,800 farmers are actively participating in the extension programme in the zone.

"Girgir" Wins Film Award

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - A film entitled "Girgir" produced by Ato Yemane Demissie and played by Ethiopians has won special award at the Harare South African Film Festival, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said here yesterday.

The ministry said quoting Ethiopian embassy in the Zimbabwean capital that the film stood first out of 20 other films all produced by Africans.

The film depicts socio-political conditions during the aborted coup d'etat led by Mengistu Neway against the Haile Selassie regime. The coup was locally known as the "Tahisas Girgir", the December movement.

Arts & Entertainment;
Ethiopian Film Wins Award In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - A film entitled "Girgir" produced by Ato Yemane Demissie and played by Ethiopians has won special award at the Harare South African Film Festival, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said here yesterday. 

The ministry said quoting Ethiopian embassy in the Zimbabwean capital that the film stood first out of 20 other films all produced by Africans.

The film depicts socio-political conditions during the aborted coup d'etat led by Mengistu Neway against the Haile Selassie regime. The coup was locally known as the "Tahisas Girgir", the December movement.

Africa News


October 3, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Air Acquires One Fokker 50 Aircraft;
News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Ethiopian airlines(EAL) yesterday took delivery of one of the five Fokker 50 aircraft it had ordered from the Dutch manufacturer which went bankrupt as one of its major share-holders withheld funding.

EAL will acquire the remaining four passenger aircraft before the end of this Ethiopian year, according to Dr. Ahmed Kello, chief executive officer of the EAL. 

The acquisition of the aircraft will enable EAL to meet 90 per cent of the current demand for domestic air transportation, and at the same time will serve as an important support to the airlines' international network, Dr. Ahmed said.

The development of EAL's domestic capacity "will allow ETHIOPIAN' to fully cater for international visitors to the country enabling the airline to develop Ethiopia's tourism potential and strengthen the airline's competitive position, " a press release by the airline stated.

The Fokker 50 purchase order has been cause for much concern and speculation as Fokker went bankrupt following an advance payment of 6.8 million dollars by EAl, of the total 66 million dollars cost of the five aircraft.

The Fokker 50 is a sturdy aircraft suitable for Ethiopian conditions and can carry 50 persons at a time, airline sources said.
