89 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 7, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Senate To Discuss Bill On African Trade


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - The United States senate will soon discuss a bill which calls for affirmative action on African trade and the removal of the quota rule imposed on Kenya textiles, Kenya's Finance Minister, Musalia Mudavadi, has said.

"The proposed bill was drafted by three U.S. senators, who want the U.S. congress to lift the quota rule imposed on textiles imported from Kenya and Mauritius," said Mudavadi. 

He was addressing journalists at the Jomo Kenyatta international airport, Nairobi, Sunday evening on arrival from a World Bank/IMF meeting in Washington.

The proposed bill, Mudavadi said, was aimed at reducing trade imbalances between Kenya and the United States.

It comes in the wake of a report that more than 10,000 Kenyan textile workers had lost jobs following cuts in the quota.

At a meeting in the U.S., Mudavadi said the quota on woven shirts and pillow cases had resulted in the closure of several factories in Kenya.

He said it was gratifying that the U.S. was now trying to make Kenya an equal trading partner.

"It did not make sense to subject Kenyan goods to a quota system when the entire globe is fostering liberalized trade," said the minister.

Mudavadi also announced that the World Bank and the IMF had come up with a new initiative aimed at allowing development countries to negotiate for debt relief at multi-lateral level.

"Previously, countries could only negotiate at bilateral level but the resolution means that they can now directly negotiate with the World Bank, the IMF and other such institutions for the reduction of their burden," he noted.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


90 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 7, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Reserve Bank Criticizes Government On Borrowing


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe charged Monday that the government was crowding out the private sector from domestic credit sources, saying this was limiting the ability of local companies to invest and create much-needed employment.

The bank, in a harsh comment on what it termed state profligacy, said the projected government borrowing from local sources of some 500 million U.S. dollars was too high to sustain economic growth. 

The bank also warned that efforts to cut inflation, which in August fell to a three-year low of 18 percent, would be frustrated by excessive growth in money supply as government continues to rely more on borrowed funds.

Government's 3-billion-dollar budget released July 25 showed a fiscal deficit of 682 million dollars, excluding grants.

The bank said the fact that at least 527 million dollars of the total deficit of 562 million dollars would be come from domestic sources was evidence enough that the government was crowding out the private sector.

"The public sector, therefore, continues to account for a disproportionate share of domestic financial resources. This, at the expense of productive sector borrowing, will limit the capacity of the private sector to generate much-needed employment and economic growth," the bank said.

Furthermore, it said that the envisaged recourse to domestic financing of at least 500 million dollars threatened expansion of the money supply, which would dampen the anticipated slowdown of inflationary pressures.

The bank had forecast inflation to fall to 20 percent by December but indications are that it could reach 23 percent following a spate of administered price increases in the past two months, among them fuel, rail and energy.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


91 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 7, 1996


Uganda;
Traders Reopen Shops As Government Sticks With VAT


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda - Striking Ugandan traders have reopened their businesses despite vows by President Yoweri Museveni that the Value Added Tax, or VAT, regime would be maintained.

Museveni, in his nationwide address on state radio and television Saturday, said the controversial tax was necessary because it would turn Uganda into an export orientated economy. 

The traders want VAT scrapped or reduced to at least 17 percent. When government refused, the traders shut their shops at the end of September.

Although the strike has not been officially called off, businesses reopened in major shopping centers in the capital, Kampala on Monday.

Many traders said there was no point insisting on the strike when there was no hope of government scrapping VAT, which has replaced the Commercial Transaction Levy and Sales Tax.

However, striking leaders held a closed door meeting Sunday in Kampala to adopt new positions with which to confront the government over the controversial tax.

The meeting, called by the Uganda Importers, Exporters and Traders Association, was convened to react to Museveni's address. At the end of the meeting, the association's treasurer, Godfrey Mugalu, said they would try to meet with Museveni.

In his address, Museveni blamed officials of the Uganda Revenue Authority for corruption and incompetence which generated controversy over VAT. He also attacked what he said were "opportunistic politicians" for hijacking the traders' strike to further their own interests.

Twelve people, including a member of parliament, Ken Lukyamuzi, were arrested last week for inciting the public against paying VAT. But they have been released on a presidential prerogative.

Multilateral institutions consider the Uganda liberal economy to be among the most buoyant on the continent.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


92 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 7, 1996


United States and Africa;
Moose Briefs on Christopher's Africa Trip


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 8627 words


 

Washington DC - Following is the transcript of an October 3 U.S. Information Agency Worldnet "Dialogue" with George Moose, assistant

secretary of state for African affairs on Secretary of State Warren Christopher's October 7-15 trip to Africa,

Q: Hello, welcome to Worldnet's "Dialogue," I'm Jim Harriott.

From October the 7th through the 15th, the U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher plans to make a five-nation trip to Africa. During this trip the secretary intends to underscore the United States' firm commitment to help further democracy, economic development and trade, regional integration and conflict resolution on the African continent.

Today we are pleased to have Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs George Moose, joining us live from the U.S. Department of State, to answer questions regarding Secretary Christopher's trip. Welcome, Ambassador Moose. 

A: Ambassador Moose. Thank you very much, Jim. It's good to be here.

Q: Any opening thoughts for us?

A: Well, Jim, let me just say by way of introduction you mentioned that the secretary is about to depart this weekend on a trip to five African nations, and I am delighted to be accompanying him. And the purpose of that trip is to, broadly speaking, to reinforce the efforts that the administration has been making to support African initiatives in the area of democratic transition, economic development, sustainable development, and conflict prevention and conflict resolution. He is going to be using his stops both to highlight the tremendous progress that is being made across the continent, but also to contribute to our ongoing efforts to deal with crisis situations, whether they be in Liberia or in Burundi or in Angola.

We very much look forward to the opportunity to hear from our partners in Africa as to how, looking to the future, the United States can continue to assist them in building the capacity to deal with their problems on the continent, in partnership with the United States and with others.

So we very much look forward to the trip, and look forward to the opportunity today to get a preview of some of the issues that are likely to be raised on the secretary's various stops. Thank you.

Q: Thank you, Mr. Ambassador. Having said that, I would also like to welcome our overseas panel that is in South Africa, Tanzania, and Mali and Angola -- all countries Secretary Christopher will visit.

We will start our discussion today in Addis Ababa. Welcome to Worldnet, and please go ahead in Ethiopia with your questions.

Q: Mr. Ambassador, we are trying to establish our communications with Addis Ababa. But in the meantime, a question for you. The timing of this particular trip -- I am sure there are those who will question it and whether it has anything to do with the U.S. presidential election campaign. Let's take that one first off.

A: This is a trip for which, frankly, Secretary Christopher has been hoping and wanting to make for some time. And he has held tenaciously to his commitment to making this trip notwithstanding the exigencies of other events taking place in the world. It is in no way related to our own elections here in the United States.

He has over the last four years been one of our staunchest supporters, in our efforts with the Congress and with others, to make sure that the United States has the wherewithal, the resources, to honor our obligations and our commitments to the international community broadly speaking, but specifically to Africa. I think he sees this as a way just to underscore his own personal commitment as well as that of the administration to our continued engagement in Africa. And, as I indicated earlier, to highlight the untold story, the unwritten story, about the substantial, tremendous progress and advances that are being made across the continent. That is the fundamental inspiration -- motivation -- for this trip.

Q: All right, thank you. Now let's establish with Mali, if we can. Go ahead in Bamako with your questions for the ambassador.

Q: I am... deputy general director of the political section of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. As you know, Madam Regina Brown, deputy assistant secretary for African affairs, on August 2, 1996, said that there was a need for an integral approach by the United States in order for African problems to be tackled. And you, Mr. Moose, you said, on September 11, in a letter called "Democracy and U.S. Foreign Policy Towards Africa" -- you said that democracy and development are inseparable and interdependent, and that U.S. aid -- and the U.S. administration would try to find the resources necessary to support democracy and development in Africa. In the light of these two statements, how do you envisage this participation of the United States in our development and democratization, especially since you said that U.S. assistance has been cut by 25 percent to Africa on the one hand, and on the other hand, you also said that USAID assistance would also be cut back? Thank you.

A: Well, thank you for your question. It's an indication that one should be careful what one said, because one's words can come back to haunt one.

We did indeed say, first and foremost, that there has to be an integral approach to Africa's problems -- and that's not any different from our approach to other parts of the world as well. We know that there must be simultaneous efforts with respect to different aspects of the African agenda. We know that it is important -- it is critically important to build the institutional underpinnings of democracy in order to sustain the more longer- term effort toward rational responsible use of resources in Africa.

We also know the importance of dealing with conflict situations and potential conflict situations which if not dealt with threaten to overwhelm the substantial progress that is already being made.

But we also know that you cannot sustain democracy or peace without a substantial improvement in the welfare, the livelihood, of individuals and people across the continent. And that is why (a) continuing partnership, in terms of a foreign assistance, but also increasingly in terms of trade and investment and the role of the private sector, is important.

We are -- we have faced a difficult time in our own country, as have some of our partners elsewhere, in sustaining the levels of our commitment for foreign assistance. But that level still is there. And in the waning days of this recent Congress, the secretary, the president and others have managed to ensure that the United States will have the sufficient means to continue our engagement in Africa, as elsewhere.

But I think there are some important things we need to draw from our current experience, and one is the necessity of working even more closely with our partners, European and other, in ensuring the most effective use of the assistance that we do make available. But, beyond that, working directly with our partners in Africa to help create that environment that is going to in fact increase investment and trade and commercial opportunity. In the future it is evident that that has to be the driving force behind economic growth, economic development. That was the message that Secretary Brown took to Africa in February; that is the message that Secretary Christopher will be bringing to Africa with him on this trip.

Q: Bamako, let's return to you for another question for Ambassador Moose.

Q: African countries constantly need assistance, especially material aid. There is a phenomenon that we don't understand, which many people perhaps are not aware of. What does decentralized cooperation with the United States really involve? We don't understand what kind of decentralized cooperation we should actually be establishing with the United States, and what that actually means.

A: I am not sure I fully understand your question, but let me say a couple of things perhaps in response.

There is a concern generally in the development community, and indeed in the United States, about the phenomenon that we call aid dependency, because ultimately that dependency can be damaging to the self-esteem of African countries and African nations, but also to their long-term efforts to build their own capabilities and capacities.

I think it is important to know that last year and the year before, '94 and '95, Africa grew by over 3 percent. African economic growth exceeded 3 percent across the continent, and that that growth was widespread -- more than 30 countries of Africa participated in that growth. In some cases those growth rates were substantially above that. That is our hope, and I believe Africa's hope, for the future.

We need to do more to encourage the role of the private sector, the growth that can only come through the private sector, as the means to ending aid dependency. Now, let me stress here we know that for the foreseeable future in specific areas -- whether it be in population or in environmental protection, or in the effort to deal with diseases and in education -- there are going to be continuing requirements on the African continent for support from the outside. But the long-term hope has to be in helping Africa's own dynamic entrepreneurs assume their rightful role in generating the growth, the sustainable growth in the long term that will improve the living conditions for Africa's people.

Q: My second question is this: As you know, peacekeeping and humanitarian intervention are very expensive operations, very difficult ones which require enormous logistical, technical and financial resources. Ruth Perry, president of the Council of State of Liberia, called upon the international community to respect its ECOMOG commitments to stop the war and to restore peace and democracy in Liberia. Within this framework, the United States committed itself to providing aid to strengthen ECOMOG up to 18,000 troops. We've heard from the media that President Clinton gave his agreement for the creation of an African intervention force, a rapid intervention force, made up of 10,000 troops. My question is: What is the role that you see for regional and subregional organizations, and in the settling of disputes and calming of conflicts? What is your new concept of this whole area? Thank you.

A: Well, thank you for your question. As you know, I was just recently in Bamako discussing with President Konare and with others this very important issue.

Let me say one thing first. We understand just how expensive and difficult it is to respond to crises after the fact, to put together peacekeeping operations in order to deal with conflict situations. And that is why we have (placed), and will continue to place a strong emphasis on our collective capacity to prevent crises. That is why we have invested and supported the OAU in the creation, the standing up of its own conflict prevention mechanism. That must continue to be, I believe, the major emphasis of our effort.

But we also know, frankly, that there are times when our best diplomacy and our best efforts fail us. And in those situations we know that we need a collective capacity to respond; otherwise conflict situations can spread, they can affect the neighboring countries, the can damage the stability and the prospects for prosperity throughout subregions. That is why we have worked with our partners in Europe as well as in Africa in trying to develop an approach to build the capacity of African nations to more effectively respond to crises and situations, whether they be humanitarian crises, conflict situations or natural disasters.

We believe that in that there are several things that are important. Clearly, there is a need for outside support from the United States and from others in order to help build that capacity. But we also know that there are a number of African countries with a demonstrated capacity and with experience in international and regional peacekeeping across the continent. Some countries, such as Ghana, for example, and Senegal, have as much as 30 years' experience in international and regional peacekeeping. We want to build on that capacity and help to create a capability within Africa to, if necessary and as appropriate, create -- come together in international regional forces that can respond to certain kinds of crisis situations, or forces and elements that can participate in broader international peacekeeping or humanitarian response efforts. We think that is entirely consistent with what the OAU has been trying to do in its efforts in Addis Ababa, and also what some subregional organizations -- ECOWAS on the one hand, SADC on the other -- have been seeking to do. We think there is a complementary role, a contribution that the United States and other outside partners can make to that effort.

Q: I want to make my question clear regarding decentralized cooperation. You know quite well that the prime minister visited the United States at the invitation of President Clinton during the Democratic convention. When he got to Pennsylvania, he heard about decentralized cooperation as a phenomenon which was really becoming more common. I just wanted to know what this concept means. What is it?

A: Well, I think, as I understand the concept, it is something that we have been developing for some time. It is a recognition that the -- all of the expertise, knowledge does not reside in our own federal government when it comes to dealing with particular kinds of problems, and that there are many other organizations out there, whether they be non-governmental organizations, or indeed our own state and local governments which have important contributions that they can bring to bear in helping nations around the world deal with their problems.

I would cite but one example. In the case of South Africa right now, we have a number of our own state governments which are dealing directly with the new provincial governments in South Africa to help them establish the procedures, the structures needed to effectively manage their local governmental issues. I think that is a perfect example of how we can expand the expertise, expand the resources that can be made available, that can be brought to bear in dealing with Africans' development issues and development problems.

Q: Thank you, Bamako. Let's join our guests now in Addis Ababa. Please go ahead with your questions for Ambassador Moose.

Q: I am... the managing editor of a business and financial private paper. My question is that you mentioned about African dependency problems, and there are two U.S. Congress members -- namely, Mr. McDermott and Mr. Fred -- (inaudible) -- that they brought a new initiative to Africa to change aid through trade, and they had planned to ship 300 million U.S. dollars from USAID to a sort of private management fund. My question is they have also planned to create a trade area, a U.S.-African free trade area by the year 2000. What is the -- first of all, I would like to know the developments, because last month, in September, they had a plan to develop...

A: Well, we seem to have lost you. But let me -- I think I understand the thrust of your question, and let me try to respond. The initiative that Congressmen McDermott and Crane have put forward is an extremely important one and a very timely one. It is a recognition of what I said earlier, namely, a recognition of the need that increasingly in the future we need to build on the capacity of the private sector as the engine, as the primary engine of economic growth and economic development in Africa. It is very consistent with the message that Secretary Ron Brown brought with him to Africa during his historic mission in February. It is the same mission and message which Secretary Christopher will be taking with him on this trip.

The proposals in the Crane amendment I think are proposals that around which a great deal of debate is now taking place. We regret that in this particular session of Congress there was not adequate time to complete that debate in order to put a specific piece of legislation into effect. But we are confident that in the new year, with the return of Congress, that Congressmen McDermott and Crane have already laid a very solid foundation for us to build on in the new session of Congress.

I will say to you, very importantly, one of the concerns we have is that people not fall into a trap of thinking that this is a debate (about) aid on the one side and trade on the other, because for the foreseeable future those two things must go hand in hand. Much of what we have been trying to do -- and indeed other partners have been trying to do with their aid -- is indeed to create the kind of environment, as Secretary Brown used to say, "enabling environment," that would make it possible for the private sector to operate effectively and freely. That assistance is going to continue to be needed. So what we are talking about is not aid versus trade; we are talking about aid and trade in a partnership as to how they together can overcome the obstacles to economic growth and sustainable development in Africa. That is an important initiative, and I am confident that it will move ahead in the Congress next year.

Q: My question will be concerned with the McDermott-Crane trade initiative, which I believe calls for something like a stronger and a closer economic tie between the United States and Africa in the years ahead. Concerning this initiative, you say you may take exceptions to some specific aspects of the proposal. Which specific aspects did you mean, and why?

A: Well, to amplify on my previous answer, I think one of the things that concerned us was the suggestion that we should -- we could deplete our already limited foreign assistance aid programs in order to build this new initiative for investment and trade in Africa. And I think those of us who know the importance of maintaining those levels of aid were concerned that some in the Congress -- some in the Congress -- might exploit that as a means of further cutting our foreign assistance budget. So that was one thing that we took exception to.

But let me stress again that the important point that Congressmen McDermott and Crane have made is the absolute necessity for us to focus much more attention on the role of the private sector. In that regard, they have suggested that we seriously consider the notion of the kind of free trade area between Africa and the United States. I think realistically the experts - - and I don't profess to be one -- say that that's not something that can be accomplished in the short term. But the important point again is that we all agree that there are things that can be done in the short run, particularly to improve and enhance African access to international markets.

As Africa develops, as it begins to create new industries, those industries will not be able to prosper and survive unless there are outlets for their products. And so one of the things we would like to focus very much on in the next year is how we can give added, enhanced access to African producers, African industries, to the global marketplace. That is, I think, one of the most important contributions that we in the United States could make.

The second important contribution is that we need to figure out more effective ways of financing our projects and project development in Africa. This is something that we have heard not only from our African partners, but, frankly, increasingly from our own American businesses, that they feel a need to have some additional mechanisms for financing their exports as well as their projects in Africa. Those are key elements that I think have emerged from the debate over the Crane-McDermott amendment, and which will be central to our discussion in the new year.

Q: Last year before you made a visit to three African countries you made a statement that U.S. key focus in 1996 will be getting together with African private sector, or -- I would like -- what your achievements or what you have done in 1996 regarding this major focus or major concern of the United States to work with the private sector of Africa.

And my second question is: Do you have any plan to talk to the people in the private sector on this visit of yours? Thank you.

A: Indeed. I am delighted with the emphasis that you are placing on our activities in the private sector, because again I think they are extremely critical, both to the contribution I believe the United States -- not only the government of the United States, but the American private sector -- can make to Africa's development, but also extremely important to the partnerships that are already developing between American businesses and African businesses in order to realize that potential.

Let me mention simply two things. As an outgrowth of Secretary Brown's visit in February of this year, a number of initiatives were taken. For example, there is the proposal for a reverse trade mission from the states of East Africa to the United States. That is, I think, a direct outgrowth of our efforts to improve and enhance the discussion, the dialogue, and indeed the partnerships, between Africa and the United States.

I'd also mention that very similarly to that we have worked closely with our colleagues in the private sector here in the United States. I would mention specifically the Corporate Council on Africa, which earlier this year led a very important mission of American business people to Ethiopia and to Eritrea. That too, which we supported from the U.S. government, our Department of Commerce and others, is another illustration of how we hope to bring some added impetus to our efforts to promote the role of the U.S. private sector in Africa, and indeed the role of the African private sector.

Q: Obviously, among the Africa's ... one type or set of problems that hinder progress towards sustained economic growth, a severe... absence of relatively skilled labor forces (inaudible). In this connection, doesn't the recent immigration of thousands of Africans to the United States adapt to the already existing problem of human resource impoverishment?

A: The problem that you highlight is indeed a critical element in the efforts to build Africa's own capacity to deal with its own and social development problems.

The answer to that is not, I think, for the United States to impose restrictions on the movements of people from Africa or elsewhere to the United States; it is indeed to continue the efforts to create conditions in Africa which make economic growth possible, and which thereby create the opportunity that will attract people with talents to remain in their own countries.

I think it's important to note that since 1991, with the transition in Ethiopia, we are increasingly seeing members of the Ethiopian community here in the United States returning home in order to make their contribution to Ethiopia's development. I've seen a similar phenomenon with respect to Eritrea -- with respect to Ghana, for example, where over the last 10 years Ghana has achieved economic growth rates of as much as 7 or 8 or 9 percent. What that has meant is new opportunities for those people with skills and talents, and so that many of those people are now beginning to return home in order to contribute to the development of their own countries. I think one of the universals here is -- that I have found in my conversations with Africans resident here in the United States -- is their universal desire to find ways to make their skills and their talents contribute to the development of their own nations. That's the natural tendency on the part of all of us. But the solution, once again, is to continue the efforts of economic reform, which are beginning to turn around the decline in growth rates, and beginning therefore to create the opportunities which will attract and hold those skilled people, those very talented Africans.

The other point I simply would make is the obvious one, and that is that we need to continuous -- this is why we need to continue with assistance programs. There are certain things that are essential underpinnings of private sector development, and one of those is the training of a skilled labor force. In various ways our investments, those of the United States and others, in education are key critical elements in building that human potential so that in fact the skills will be there to take advantage of the new emerging economic opportunities.

Q: How do you see your new initiative to trade with Africa with the fact that American exports to Africa (are) less in 1995 from 1994 by 23 percent? And the second thing is that you didn't answer my question whether you have a plan to talk to people in the private sector in this trip.

A: I didn't answer your question. Yes, indeed we do. The secretary -- we have sought several opportunities, including one in Ethiopia, for the secretary to meet with members of our private sector as well as with the indigenous private sector. And that's the case on other stops as well.

On your question about the importance of the African market to the American business community, I would correct you in one sense. In fact, American exports to Africa grew over the past year by about a billion dollars. It was - - if I recall correctly, and please don't hold me to this figure -- about $5, 400 million. I would also point out that that value of U.S. exports to Africa exceeds the value of U.S. exports to the former Soviet Union, the newly independent states of the Soviet Union, or to Eastern Europe, which suggests again how important the African market is for America. And that is not counting what we regard as the important future potential of that marketplace.

On the reverse side of that, I would simply say that America is the largest purchaser of goods and products from Africa. It is -- we are in global terms the country that purchases the most goods and services from Africa. But we are not satisfied with that, because as I said earlier, Africa currently is only -- only participates to the extent of 1 or 2 percent in the total trade of the global economy. That is insufficient and unsatisfactory. We need to find ways to enhance Africa's ability to access international markets.

We think that the World Trade Organization's framework gives us an opportunity both to improve African producers' ability to make their goods available on the market, but also to provide incentives for production in African countries. We think that Africans need to be much more heavily engaged in the discussions and debates of the WTO to make sure that that potential is in fact being realized.

Q: We thank you, Addis Ababa. We will now join our guests in Dar es Salaam. Welcome. Please go ahead there in Tanzania.

Q: Your ambassador to the U.N., Madeleine Albright, is quoted to have said that the U.S. would like a new U.N. secretary-general elected who will steer the organization to the 21st century, the qualities which according to you Boutros-Ghali does not possess. But, on the contrary, most Third World countries, and some of your closest allies, support Boutros-Ghali for another term. Why do you continue to block Boutros-Ghali's reelection, in view of the eminent majority support he appears to command? And do you think you are trampling on democracy, which your country so much cherishes, by suppressing the wishes of the majority U.N. member states?

A: Well, Ambassador Albright's statement is indeed a reflection, an accurate reflection, of the view of this administration, including President Clinton. And this is without any negative criticism of anyone about what has happened in the past. What we are looking at here is in fact an opportunity for a democratic solution to a problem. What we are looking for is an opportunity for the international community to choose the person who is best qualified in order to lead our organization, the United Nations, into the 21st century. It is no secret that our organization, the United Nations, is in serious difficulty, that it is not currently able to meet its challenges, its obligations to assume the role we would all wish it to assume in the international community, whether it is in terms of its ability to organize missions for peacekeeping or international security, or whether it is in terms of its capacity to respond to the development challenges in Africa and elsewhere. It is critically important for all of us that our organization, the United Nations, be effective, be capable of assuming that role and that responsibility.

But in order to do that, that organization, our organization, is going to require major restructuring and reform in the years to come. If that doesn't happen, I fear personally that the United Nations will cease to be a meaningful or effective organization for any of us. I think that is particularly true for Africa. Nowhere is the development challenge greater than it is for Africa.

I would simply say that I have found in my discussions an openness to the question of how we together come to a consensus about who is best qualified to lead our organization in the future. We in the United States are anxious to engage in that consultation.

Q: Dar es Salaam, we will be returning to you in just a moment. Mr. Ambassador, a question if I may: Is it not true that Mr. Boutros Boutros- Ghali, when he accepted the position, agreed to serve only one five-year term?

A: Indeed. Secretary-General Boutros-Ghali at the time of his first term did indicate publicly and to us and to others his intention to serve for only one term. I think we had all based our considerations and our calculations on that statement. By the same token, we are aware -- we are certainly sensitive to the desire on the part of African countries to see an African continue to lead the United Nations. I personally know and believe that there are many Africans qualified and capable to assume that leadership role. I would hope that Africa itself would quickly undertake the search, the consultation, that would help us all make a decision on how to select a person capable of leading the organization into the next century.

Q: Thank you. Let's return to Dar es Salaam for more questions for the ambassador.

Q: I work for the East African regional newspaper in East Africa. I have one question for Ambassador Moose. Two months before Pierre Buyoya of Burundi took power by force, President Clinton's adviser Anthony Lake warned, and I quote, "If any group seizes power by force, you should know that the U.S. will see to it that they are isolated by the international community and feel the full weight of international law." But what we are seeing now is Buyoya took power by force, and the United States is giving Buyoya a chance. What has shaped the U.S. (favorable approach ?) to Buyoya now?

A: I was on that trip with National Security Adviser Lake, and let me say that nothing he said there has changed since he said it.

We have worked as hard and as closely with the states of the subregion, particularly with Tanzania, as anyone, to try to ensure that there is both a successful diplomacy leading to a political solution in Burundi -- that has not changed our objectives -- and I had a chance to talk with President Mkapa when I was just there last week -- our objectives are identical -- identical - - to those of the states of the region. We think it is extremely important that pressure be maintained on President Buyoya because his regime is not legal -- it is the result of a coup -- and because it is critically important that he understand the need to move towards a successful political settlement.

We think it is also important that the other players, the other parties to this terrible tragedy in Burundi, also understand the necessity on their part, their obligation, to behave in a way that contributes to a political solution. That is a view which is I think consistent among the members of the Great Lakes region. We know that there is a very important summit meeting that will be coming up in Arusha on the 11th and 12th of October. Indeed, Secretary Christopher plans to be in Arusha at that time. We see that as an important opportunity to further consolidate our collective effort to try to bring about a solution to the Burundi crisis.

Q: Dar es Salaam, we thank you for your questions and your comments.

Now we go to Cape Town. Please go ahead in Cape Town, South Africa.

Q: Mr. Ambassador, it seems rather curious that the State Secretary is making his first trip to Africa during the last weeks of the first Clinton administration, and perhaps during his own last weeks as secretary of state. Given the fact that he is widely believed to be due to retire within a few months, why is Secretary Christopher planning to come to Africa at this time? Is this not something -- an afterthought for the administration, perhaps aimed at the elections of November?

A: As I said earlier, and frankly, the secretary, had he had his druthers, would have made this trip some time ago. I think the opposite of your question is that since it is the waning days of the first administration, why go at all? Well, I think it's because that the issues and the concerns of this administration remain as they have been. We believe that there is an ongoing requirement for U.S. engagement in Africa. That doesn't change because we happen to have an election coming up in a few weeks time. We think it's important that we build on what we have been -- what we have tried to accomplish over the last four years as we look to the next four years, regardless of what happens in those elections here in the United States.

The secretary has made a particular commitment this year, which will be reflected in the course of his trip, and in the aftermath of his trip, that matters to try to reverse the terrible trend that we have seen over the last several years with regard to the -- our ability, our capacity to support development broadly speaking in Africa. He feels strongly that we have reached a critical point in our own budgeting process, our ability to provide the resources necessary to sustain our engagement.

One of the things that I know he intends to get out of this trip is the example of positive progress in South Africa and elsewhere that he can bring back and bring to bear on the public debate here in the United States about our role, our engagement, our commitment -- internationally, but specifically in Africa. That -- I mean, I do think that this trip more than anything else reflects the secretary's own personal sense of responsibility and obligation to making sure that in the broader scheme of international policy Africa is not lost.

Q: Mr. Secretary, there is some danger some believe that political crisis in the Middle East, and Secretary Christopher's particular attention to that problem, that this African trip may be called off at the last moment. Can you give us any assurance that that won't take place?

A: I can't give you an absolutely hard assurance, but I can tell you that we met with the secretary again this morning, and the trip is still on, and his commitment to making that trip is still firm.

Q: Secretary Christopher will be making a major policy address to the South African Institute of International Affairs on Saturday of his trip. Can you give us any indication or broad outline of the themes of that talk?

A: Well, I am certainly not going to try to steal the secretary's thunder here, but I think you can well imagine the themes that he will be stressing. He will be stressing our fundamental belief in the importance of the continued development of democratic institutions and processes and practices in Africa. If anything, our experience and our modest contribution and support for South Africa's transition has reinforced us in the belief that it is important for us to continue that kind of effort elsewhere across the African continent.

As you know, Secretary Christopher was instrumental in the creation here in the State Department of a Bureau of Human Rights, and I have no doubt that in his various stops he will be emphasizing the importance we continue to attach to that. His stop in Arusha and his visit to the international tribunal will be an important highlighting of the role of that institution in preventing -- or certainly punishing those responsible for crimes against humanity.

He will be stressing, as we have throughout, our efforts to support African nations and African institutions to respond to crises; but, more importantly, to try to prevent crises.

And last, but not least, he will be making a special appeal on the importance of dealing with those key elements of sustainable development, including the environment and population. As you may know -- you may recall in his speech in Stanford a few months ago, back in the spring, he launched a special initiative from the State Department on issues of the environment. He has followed up on that in several visits -- trips he has made to other parts of the world. And I am confident that in his trip to Africa, and especially in South Africa, he will want to stress the importance that the United States attaches to assisting Africa deal with and manage its incredibly rich environmental heritage.

So those are the things I expect you might hear. But, again, I think he may have something other -- something perhaps a little new and fresh to offer on all of those subjects.

Q: Mr. Ambassador, I think the African continent feels that although America does pay attention, a great deal of attention to the problem of conflict resolution here in Africa, it doesn't always put its money where its mouth is. Why is there so much reluctance on the part of America to commit its own troops to helping the resolution of conflicts in Africa?

A: Well, I think, frankly, that if you look at (it) historically that that doesn't hold up. We have committed troops to Somalia, we have committed troops to major humanitarian response to a crisis in Rwanda, and variously we have contributed troops to other African peacekeeping initiatives.

But let me also say that in any given year, over the past few years -- the past three years of this administration -- at any one time there have been upwards of 20,000 American troops committed to international peacekeeping efforts around the world. And the administration has made quite clear its continuing commitment to participate in international peacekeeping and humanitarian response. But it is also quite obvious that no country -- not the United States, not anyone else -- can be everywhere all the time in response to every crisis. That is why the president sent us on our recent mission to talk with partners in Africa and in Europe about how we enlarge the collective capacity of all of us to deal with crises, whether they be in Africa or elsewhere.

We have been doing things around the world to help build the ability, the capacity of national militaries to participate more effectively and more rapidly in crisis response and international peacekeeping. We have done that in Europe in our Partnership for Peace program; we have done it in helping the Balkan states create a battalion which is now participating in Bosnia; we have done it in Latin America with our exercises with our Latin American partners to improve their peacekeeping capabilities. We think it's time to do the same in Africa, to build a collective capacity to respond to crises.

I think it is clear that we -- all of us need to look at how we can more rapidly and more effectively deal with crisis situations, whether they occur in Africa or elsewhere. We believe -- we know that there are African countries that have both the tradition, the capacity and

the experience to make an important contribution there.

Q: Two questions. First, is the secretary going to be seeing opposition figures as well as ANC figures on his trip to South Africa? And, secondly, I understand there is a possibility that he might be making some contribution from the United States to Desmond Tutu's Truth and Reconciliation Commission - - I wonder if that might not go further into opening up the CIA and other intelligence files from the years -- intelligence agencies -- to help the TRC in its work?

A: Well, I frankly can't -- I am not sure that there is much I can say about your second question. But on your first, yes, indeed. In virtually all of the stops the secretary does hope to meet not only with members of government, but with members of the opposition and other elements of civil society that we believe play an important role in building the democratic process and building civil society -- making an important contribution. That's certainly the case in South Africa.

We do -- I know also the secretary does hope to have a chance to meet with Bishop Tutu, because we value the role of the contributions that the Truth and Reconciliation Commission has been making to South Africa's own efforts at reconciliation and consolidating its democratic transition.

Q: We thank you, Cape Town. While Luanda, Angola, cannot participate live, they sent in some questions by fax. Ambassador Moose, let me read one or two of them to you, if I may. Luanda asks: What do you think of the peace process in Angola? Are you optimistic about it?

A: We know that this is indeed a very critical phase in this peace process. It is the moment at which a lot of things need to come together, and we believe need to come together promptly, in order to ensure continued momentum and the consolidation of the significant progress that has already been made. I think it is important to acknowledge what has already been accomplished. The United States was instrumental in reinitiating the negotiations in and around Angola back in 1993. It was one of the first initiatives that we took. There were a lot of people at the time who believed that we were wasting our time, that given the experience of October 1992 there was nothing that could be accomplished in Angola.

The record, I think, speaks for itself. Not only was there the successful conclusion of the Lusaka negotiations, the Lusaka Protocol, but now we are well into the implementation of that agreement, with some 60,000 UNITA troops quartered, with a number of other key elements of that process already under way.

But we are mindful that unless the momentum can be sustained that the process is still subject to setback and to jeopardy. That is why the secretary has decided to lend his further weight to the effort to move the process forward. We think it's important for the government's side to exercise maximum restraint and patience, just as we think it's critically important that UNITA honor its commitments and its obligations under the Lusaka Protocol. Those are the two messages that the secretary will bring with him, and that are part of our ongoing efforts to ensure the successful implementation of the Lusaka agreements.

Q: Mr. Ambassador, you have in part answered the next question that Luanda had -- but I'll ask it anyway.

A: Surely.

Q: What will the U.S. do further to move the peace process forward? Would you like to elaborate on that?

A: Well, I think there are several important contributions that we can make, and not necessarily alone, but in partnership with others who share our concern and attach the same importance to this process -- our troika partners for example, Russia and Portugal, as well as the members of the Southern African Development Community who only this week hosted an important summit meeting in Luanda to underscore their commitment to the peace process in Angola. But beyond that we have made I think an important contribution along with others to the consolidation of peace, to the process of demobilization, to the process of repatriating refugees and displaced persons from outside the country, to the critically important de-mining effort in Angola, which is key to enabling people to return to their homes. All of these are contributions which we in the United States and others can make.

I would underscore one final area, and that is we know that the process of reconciliation in Angola, given the history of tension, of conflict, of mistrust, must continue, and indeed must deepen. We are prepared -- we stand ready -- we have committed to working with UNITA as well as the government in helping to strengthen those institutions -- the parliament, the judiciary, the press -- which are key to that ongoing process of reconciliation.

Q: Mr. Ambassador, that's all the time we have for today's dialogue. I would like to thank Assistant Secretary George Moose for taking time out to discuss U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher's upcoming trip to Africa. Thank you.

A: Thank you, Jim.

Q: Good to have you here. And our thanks to our panelists in South Africa, in Ethiopia, Tanzania, and Mali, and questions from Angola. Thank you for your participation. For Worldnet's "Dialogue," I am Jim Harriott. Have a good day.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


93 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 7, 1996


Nigeria;
Communique: World Congress of Free Nigerians


BYLINE: Africa Policy Information Center (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

WASHINGTON, D.C. - During a four-day World Congress of Free Nigerians (WCFN) in Washington, DC, USA, (September 26- 29, 1996) attended by delegates from Africa, Europe and the Americas, members of the Congress deliberated on the problems created for their country by successions of military dictatorships in general and by the current military dictatorship in particular.

The Congress salutes the courage of the leadership of the National Democratic Coalition (NADECO), the United Democratic Front of Nigeria, (UDFN) and other pro-democracy organizations inside and outside Nigeria who have since the annulment of the June 12th 1993 elections been championing the struggle for the restoration of democracy in Nigeria.

The Congress expressed solidarity with the strike action of the Academic Staff Union of Universities (ASUU), now in its eighth month and called upon parallel organisations of university academics in the international community to express their solidarity by coming to the aid of their beleaguered colleagues in Nigeria.

The Congress expresses its deepest gratitude to the governments of Canada, Jamaica, New Zealand and others, and nongovernmental organizations who have helped to sustain the struggle so far. 

The Congress agreed on the following resolutions:

1. That the mandate expressed by the Nigerian people on June 12th, 1993 expressed the sovereignty of the people and that this sovereignty cannot be surrendered.

2. That the political class must not participate in the ongoing transition programme of the Abacha regime, as participation in this sham is tantamount to surrender of that popular mandate.

3. That the general civil disobedience by Nigerians already in place should be continued and widened. This includes acts of noncooperation with the regime on all matters.

4. That a Parliament-In-Exile (PIE) be established immediately and that the inaugural meeting of the PIE shall be held within three months.

5. That the PIE should draw up proposals for a Sovereign National Conference in Nigeria and a model civilian constitution for Nigeria to replace unitary constitutions that have, since 1966, been foisted on Nigeria by military dictatorships.

6. That Nigeria should return to the parliamentary system of government when democracy is restored to the country.

7. That the PIE will be a unified legislative organ of all Nigerian pro- democracy groups and will serve as the primary voice of the alternative to General Abacha and military dictatorship.

8. That the PIE shall set up an all-civilian constitution- drafting committee to prepare a model draft of a constitution that restores genuine federalism to Nigeria, for approval by Congress.

9. That the PIE shall examine in detail the following proposals: a) restructuring of the Nigerian federation into viable selfsustaining regions which shall not be less than six nor more than ten in number; b) allocation of functions among federal, regional, and local governments, including provisions for autonomous areas; and c) revenue allocation and other constitutional matters.

10. That the PIE shall enshrine in our constitution that the minimum rights of all Nigerians shall be in accordance with the rights enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, and other human rights charters to which Nigeria is a party.

11. That there should be enshrined in our constitution, drastic deterrents against planned or accomplished overthrow of democratic government. The statute of limitation would not be applicable to such crimes.

12. That the PIE shall examine the total restructuring and reorientation of the military to ensure they return to constitutional role of defending the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Nigeria, acting under orders of a democratic civil authority.

13. That the PIE shall set up an international panel of jurists to draw up an indictment against Generals Ibrahim Babangida and Sani Abacha, for crimes against humanity by past and present military regimes under their command.

14. That the PIE shall prepare model bills on human rights, the political and economic empowerment of women, the environment, education, science and technology, and the preservation of our culture and heritage.

15. That the PIE shall set up a committee to prepare model draft bills on corruption and on drug trafficking.

16. That General Abacha must release immediately all political detainees, including MKO Abiola, Beko RansomeKuti, Frank Kokori, Shehu Sani, A. A. Adesanya, Ganiyu Dawodu, Ayo Adebanjo, and hundreds of others.

17. In view of persistent reports that Ayo Opadokun has been killed by agents of the Abacha regime and not released as claimed by the regime, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) should be called upon to investigate the matter.

18. Congress resolves that the Planning Committee of the Congress together with such persons as it may coopt (a) to submit proposals to Head of delegations on the composition of the PIE and (b) to maintain continuity and sustain contact among pro-democracy groups and individuals between congresses.

19. As a symbol of our rejection of the military regime, we henceforth cease to recognise the current Nigerian national anthem. Henceforth, whenever Nigerians congregate at nonofficial functions, they should sing the old democratic anthem, Nigeria We Hail Thee.

20. That, recognizing education as the bedrock of a democratic society and the key to successful development of a nation, compulsory and free secondary education, both grammar and technical, should be provided in all parts of Nigeria.

Adopted 29th September 1996

Participating Organisations: NADECO Abroad, United Democratic Front of Nigeria (UDFN,) Nigerian Democratic Movement (NDM, USA), Nigerian Democratic Movement (NDM, UK), Oduduwa Movement (UK), New Nigeria Forum (NNF, UK), Action Group for Democracy (AGFD, USA), Egbe Isokan Yoruba (USA), Canadian Organisation for Human Rights and Democracy in Nigeria (COHDN), Canadian Association for Democratic Movement in Nigeria (CADMN), Organisation of Nigerians in the Americas (ONA, USA), Nigerian Democratic Alliance Inc. (NDA, USA), Nigerian People's Forum (NPF, USA), Call2Action (USA), Egbe Omo Yoruba (USA), Movement for the Reformation of Nigeria (MNR, UK), Nigerian Democratic Task Force (NDTF, USA), The Cocoons (USA), Solidarity Movement for Southern Minorities (SMSM, UK), Oduduwa Youth Movement (OYM, USA), Democratic Alliance of Nigerians in Canada (DANIC).

(Distributed by the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), the educational affiliate of the Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E- mail: apic@igc.apc.org. Web: www.igc.apc.org/apic/index.shtml.)


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


94 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 7, 1996


Zaire;
Conflict In South Kivu, Zaire & Regional Implications


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3694 words


 

Nairobi - Following is a revised briefing issued October 9 by the United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs Integrated Regional Information Network on the conflict in South Kivu, Zaire & its regional implications.

During September 1996 a growing number of reports testified to human rights abuses against Zairean Tutsis, known as Banyamulenge, by the army and local people in and around Uvira in South Kivu, Zaire. It soon became clear that at the same time a conflict between the Banyamulenge and the army was taking place, and as refugees began to arrive in Rwanda and Burundi, the Governments of Zaire and Rwanda traded accusations over responsibilities for the escalating crisis. As tensions between the two countries mounted, mortar fire was exchanged between Bukavu, Zaire and Cyangugu in Rwanda over several days.

This briefing describes developments in September and seeks to put them in their historical context. It gives an account of the immigration of Banyamulenge into Zaire, examines their claims to Zairean nationality and describes how they have been stripped of their nationality and targetted by the local authorities, army and local people since April 1995. Drawing parallels between this crisis and developments in Masisi and Rutshuru over the past year, it examines the accusations of both Zaire and Rwanda, as well as the humanitarian and regional implications of the crisis. 

DEVELOPMENTS DURING SEPTEMBER 1996

On 9 September local people in Uvira town mounted a demonstration against Banyamulenge, declaring Uvira a 'ville morte', calling on the 'foreigners' to leave the country and attacking their homes and property. The demonstration followed a weekend in which soldiers from the Zairean Army had broken into several religious establishments in the town, arresting local church members and missionaries and seizing vehicles, documents and communications equipment. The events prompted the German arm of Caritas to announce it had suspended its activities in the town.

Reports soon emerged that during the weekend of 6 - 8 September, five Banyamulenge had been killed by Zairean soldiers. One man, Bolingo Karema, was allegedly beaten and stoned to death in Uvira town, while four others were killed in surrounding villages. The offices of a local Banyamulenge NGO, Groupe Milima, had allegedly been looted by soldiers, while its director, Muller Ruhimbika, was in hiding after a warrant had been issued for his arrest. Mr Ruhimbika had played a prominent role in drawing attention to the situation in Uvira during 1995 and the first half of 1996 (see the following section), and is currently living in exile.

Over subsequent days the army sought out Banyamulenge, arresting men while allowing women and children to go free. The arrests were reportedly carried out at the instruction of the District Commissioner of Uvira, Shweka Mutabazi. Amnesty International singled Mr Mutabazi out for criticism, citing reports that he had encouraged the takeover of Tutsi property and authorized the enrolment of youths into the armed forces to fight the 'Tutsi armed group'. Amnesty also undertook to investigate reports that more than 35 Banyamulenge had been 'extrajudicially executed' by the Zairean authorities and more than 50 others 'disappeared' at the start of the month.(1)

Reports of fighting between Banyamulenge militia and Zairean soldiers also began to emerge, with three soldiers reported killed during the week beginning 9 September. The Zairean Army declared the Uvira area a 'military zone' and was reported to be reinforcing its presence with troops from Goma, Bukavu, Shaba and Kinshasa. On 13 September the Zairean Government accused Rwanda of having enrolled 3,000 Banyamulenge in its army and of training and infiltrating them to destabilize eastern Zaire, with Burundi providing them with rear bases. Both Governments categorically rejected the charges.

At the same time Banyamulenge, some of whom had been held in detention, were refouled or fled the country and began entering Rwanda and Burundi. Several hundred refugees were reported as having reached Cyangugu in Rwanda and others as having gone to Cibitoke and Bubanza provinces in Burundi. At the end of the month UNHCR estimates put the number of recent Banyamulenge arrivals at over 500 in Rwanda and over 400 in Burundi. Of this number 535 people had been 'refouled' by the Zairean authorities and the rest had left Zaire spontaneously.

During the weekend of 14 and 15 September Zairean television reported accusations by the authorities that the UNHCR and IOM (International Organisation of Migration) had been assisting armed groups to infiltrate Zaire from Rwanda and Burundi with the aim of destabilizing Kivu. Following these accusations two UNHCR staff were beaten up by Zairean soldiers. On 17 September the claims were dismissed by the UN Secretary-General, as being 'completely unfounded'. The Secretary-General subsequently sent Ibrahima Fall as a UN Special Envoy to Zaire to seek clarification on the allegations. The Zairean authorities, meanwhile, confirmed that the activities of IOM throughout Zaire had been suspended.

On Sunday 22 September the growing tension between Rwanda and Zaire manifested itself in an exchange of mortar fire between the two countries. This was repeated during the following two days, killing one Zairean and injuring five others. It also prompted the United Nations to relocate 23 'non- essential' expatriate aid agency personnel to Nairobi and the International Federation of the Red Cross to evacuate three of its delegates, after two shells landed in the garden of a hotel where IFRCS staff had been staying.

Rwanda and Zaire accused each other of having started the exchanges of fire. On 23 September the Government of Rwanda released a statement detailing its version of events. It accused the Government of Zaire of targetting Kabembe town in Cyangugu prefecture with automatic weapons fire and artillery shelling between 6pm and 11pm on 22 September. These attacks were said to have caused neither injuries nor material damage.

The Rwandan Government linked this alleged 'act of aggression' with an attack in mid-September on the prison in the neighbouring commune of Gishoma, in which a group of infiltrators had sought to free prisoners. According to the statement, the RPA 'repulsed the attackers, who fled under cover of automatic weapons fire from the Panzi camp in Zairean territory.'(2) The dispute over who had started the attacks continued, however, although a ceasefire was agreed on 25 September. Zaire alleged that Rwanda broke the ceasefire on 26 and 29 September, a claim denied by Rwanda.

At the same time a Banyamulenge spokesman in exile reported that on 22 September the Zairean authorities had executed 40 Banyamulenge being held in detention. They had been arrested by the authorities the previous week at Baraka in Fizi zone. The summary executions were said to have been in retaliation for the killings of Zairean soldiers by Banyamulenge militia. Independent confirmation of this incident has yet to be obtained.

On 22 September the Zairean authorities also repeated allegations that soldiers were infiltrating into Kivu from Rwanda and Burundi in order to support the Banyamulenge militia. Government spokesman Oscar Lugendo was quoted in the press as saying that Zairean troops killed three 'Rwandan' soldiers and captured five others at Kiringye in Uvira region on 31 August. He claimed that the infiltrators were being commanded by Banyamulenge who had been officers in the Zairean Army but had gone to Rwanda after the victory of the RPA in July 1994. (3) The authorities said the soldiers had infiltrated Uvira via Cyangugu in Rwanda and Cibitoke in Burundi. BACKGROUND

Different historians give different dates for the migrations of Tutsi pastoralists from the historic kingdom of Rwanda to what is now Zaire. All of the estimates, however, date the migrations between the 16th and 19th centuries (4). The atlas of the Republic of Zaire produced by Jeune Afrique in 1978 provides a map showing the routes of the major historical population movements into and within what is now Zaire, and dates the movement of pastoralists from Rwanda into Kivu between the 17th and 18th centuries. This was part of the migration which also brought Rwandan Tutsis to Masisi and Rutshuru zones in what is now North Kivu.

The United Nations Special Rapporteur on human rights in Zaire states with confidence that 'ever since 1797, under the rule of Yuhi IV Gahindiro, Rwandan Tutsis have emigrated to the Congo, settling in Kakamba, in the plain of Ruzizi and in the higher regions (Mulenge Hills), because of the climate and to feed their cattle.' (5)

These Tutsis established their first settlement at Mulenge and became known as Banyamulenge (people of Mulenge). They settled in Uvira, Mwenga and Fizi zones, where they are to be found to this day (although there are now Banyamulenge living further south, in Shaba, and in major towns around the country). Establishing their own settlements they lived side-by-side with indigenous Bantu ethnic groups - the Babembe, Bafulero, Banyindu, Barega, Barundi and Bashi. They speak a variant of Kinyarwanda (the language of Rwanda), recognized as a separate dialect by linguistic authorities (6). Today estimates of their number range from 250,000 to 400,000 people, roughly comparable with other ethnic groups in the area (the Barega have been estimated at 400,000, the Babembe at 252,000 and the Bafulero at 275,000).(7)

The Banyamulenge lived in relative peace and harmony with their neighbours for most of this century. It was not until the Mulele rebellion in Kivu in 1964 that Banyamulenge found themselves in opposition to other local people. The Mulelists, espousing a variant of communist philosophy in which property, land and cattle were to be shared among local people, drew support from other ethnic groups in South Kivu. The Banyamulenge, however, did not share their neighbour's enthusiasm for these goals and helped the then Congolese National Army to crush the movement in South Kivu. This episode instilled a deep and lingering resentment against the Banyamulenge within other ethnic groups in the area.

The Banyamulenge, however, continued to prosper economically and also succeeded in securing political representation at both the local and national levels. In 1980 however, Mr Gisaro, the sole Banyamulenge MP in the Zairean Parliament, died in a car crash. In 1981 the Zairean Parliament passed new legislation relating to Zairean nationality. This sought to nullify the 1972 legislation under which all persons of Rwandese origin who established their residence in the Kivu province before 1 January 1950 and who had continued to reside in Zaire were collectively granted Zairean nationality as of 30 June 1961.

Henceforth nationality would be acquired on an individual basis only and any other mode of acquisition of Zairean nationality was null and void. In effect, people of Rwandese origin in Zaire were rendered stateless persons. According to informed legal opinion, however, the 1981 law was arbitrary and discriminatory and therefore unlawful under international conventions to which Zaire is a party. If this analysis is accepted, the Banyamulenge retained a strong claim to Zairean citizenship.

They were, however, refused permission to stand as candidates or to vote in the 1982 Parliamentary elections. Banyamulenge in Mwenga zone protested against the decision by burning ballot boxes being used in the elections. The same was true for the 1987 Parliamentary elections, when again the Banyamulenge could neither stand for office nor cast a vote. This time there were protests in Uvira and Fizi and again ballot boxes were burnt.

The tensions aroused by these disputes were further exacerbated by the refugee crises of 1993 and 1994, when Hutu refugees first from Burundi and then from Rwanda, flooded into the area. Local people are said to identify themselves with Hutus and to hold Tutsis responsible for heaping the refugee problem upon them through the coup of October 1993 in Burundi and their struggle for power in Rwanda after the RPF invasion of 1990. In this analysis the genocide of 1994 was characterized as the culmination of a war rather than the planned and purposeful extermination of Rwanda's Tutsi minority.

On 28 April 1995 the High Council of the Transitional Parliament passed a Resolution in order, ostensibly, to prevent Rwandan and Burundian refugees from acquiring Zairean nationality. The Resolution followed a visit to Kivu by the Vangu commission of inquiry, which had been established to look into these questions. The most surprising aspect of the Resolution was that it treated the Banyamulenge as recent refugees. The Resolution included a list of people to be arrested and expelled, the cancellation of any sale or transfer of assets which benefited 'immigrants who have acquired Zairean nationality fraudulently', the replacement of existing governors and commanders with new officials, and the banning of Tutsis from all administrative and other posts. (8) The Resolution was signed by the Speaker of the Parliament, Anzuluni Bembe Isilonyonyi, who claims to come from Uvira and have Babembe ancestry.

It wasn't long before the Resolution was put into action. On 19 September the District Commissioner of Uvira, Shweka Mutabazi, wrote to the official responsible for urban planning in Uvira telling him to make a list of the properties and land owned by Banyamulenge, that all building work by Banyamulenge was to be brought to a halt and that all abandoned Banyamulenge houses should be identified and itemized. He also charged the same official with informing the head of the Banyamulenge community about these developments.

During late 1995 and early 1996 acts of harrassment as well as evictions of Banyamulenge were an increasingly common occurence. On November 21 1995 the authors of a petition to the authorities were detained, shortly after one of their number, Muller Ruhimbika, had been interviewed by the UN Special Rapporteur on human rights in Zaire, Roberto Garreton. During his January 1996 report Mr Garreton noted that some Banyamulenge had already been expelled from Zaire while others were under an expulsion order. The Special Rapporteur also reported that he had been informed that 'local tribes were arming in readiness for a struggle against the Banyamulenge, forcing the latter to do the same.'(9)

The immediate precursor to the events of September was the banning of Groupe Milima, the non-governmental organization run by Mr Ruhimbika, on 9 August, again at the instigation of the District Commissioner for Uvira. Groupe Milima, a rural development organization which had lobbied for the nationality rights of Banyamulenge to be recognized, was clearly proving to be a thorn in the side for the authorities. The letter announcing the ban accused Mr Ruhimbika of political lobbying, travelling without the permission of the authorities and drawing the nationality issue to the attention of the Carter Centre. It also alleged that Mr Ruhimbika had been trafficking arms to the Banyamulenge.

CONCLUSION

In many respects recent developments in Uvira bear an uncanny resemblance to developments in Masisi since November 1995. There too, Zairean Tutsis have been targetted by the local authorities, army and local people and forced to flee their country. In the case of Masisi there is substantial evidence that Rwandan Hutu refugees, in particular members of the interahamwe militia and the former Rwandan Army, have fuelled the conflict by bringing arms and hatred to an already volatile situation (10). In the case of Uvira the alleged involvement of Hutu refugees in targetting the Banyamulenge remains just that - an allegation. With Masisi as with Uvira, the conflicts have resulted in mutual recriminations between Zaire and Rwanda.

Yet the obvious difference between the two conflicts is that in the case of Masisi the Tutsis were forced out of their country without putting up a fight. This is not proving to be the case in Uvira, where the Banyamulenge have been arming and preparing themselves for the current confrontation. As one Banyamulenge spokesman in exile explained, "They have seen what has happened in Shaba with the Kasai who were unarmed. They saw what happened to their 'brothers' in Masisi and Rutshuru, who were defenceless and were killed and evicted. The Zairean authorities say the Banyamulenge must go. The only option they had was to get arms. They are saying, 'we're not going to allow this to happen to us'."

How the conflict will evolve is a matter of speculation. While reports from the area do support claims that Rwandan Hutu refugees are assisting the Zairean Army, it is unclear to what extent local people from other ethnic groups in South Kivu are willing to take up arms against their neighbours. In the case of Masisi, it was the involvement of local Hutus in league with refugees and occasionally the army that really made the position of the Tutsis untenable and forced them to flee.

What is abundantly clear is that unless the legitimate claims of the Banyamulenge are recognized and the differences between Zaire and Rwanda resolved, the region faces yet another escalation in its crisis of insecurity. This will be unwelcome to the international community, as it counts the cost of assisting yet more internally displaced people and refugees. It will be bad for the countries of the region, whose development can only be hindered by worsening relations and violent disruption. And it will be a disaster for local people, who will be condemned to further deaths, displacement and flight from their own country.

REFERENCES

1. Amnesty International, 'Zaire: Amnesty International condemns Human Rights Violations against Tutsi', 20 September 1996.

2. Statement by the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation of Rwanda, 23 September 1996.

3. Arthur Malu-Malu, Reuters News Service, 'Zaire hits out at aid groups, neighbours, 22 September 1996.

4. Kagame Alexis (1972), Maquet, J and Hiernaux, J (1954), Weis (1959), Depelchin (1974), cited in 'Memorandum on the Tragedy of the Rwandaphone Zaireans with some Proposals and Recommendations', June 1996.

5. Mr Roberto Garreton, 'Report on the situation of human rights in Zaire', 29 January 1996.

6. Barbara F. Grimes, Ed., 'Ethnologue: Languages of the World', Summer Institute of Linguistics, Inc., Dallas, Texas, 1992.

7. As for 6.

8. Le Haut Conseil de la Republique - Parlement de Transition, 'Resolution sur la Nationalite', Kinshasa, 28 April 1995.

9. As for 5.

10. UN DHA IRIN, Situation Report on Masisi and Rutshuru, 10 May 1996 and Update on Masisi, Rutshuru and Lubero Zones, 15 August 1996.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)
