125 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 7, 1996


Malawi;
The Women of Blantyre's Hannover Street


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Blantyre - Hannover is the name of a city in a Germany. But next time you are in Blantyre, Malawi's commercial city and hear about the Hannover trade, do not be mistaken into thinking that Malawi has notched a trade agreement with any country.

They are talking about women who hang out along Hannover Street in Blantyre at night and indeed enter into trade agreements in which the commodities are nothing but their bodies. They are referring to the world's oldest profession which some young girls in Blantyre make no secret about as their source of bread and butter - prostitution. 

Malawi has for ages been trade marked 'The warm heart of Africa' and indeed, many a visitor to this tropical-weathered, but poverty-stricken country has gone back home nursing a holiday hangover due to the memorable time spent on holiday in the warm heart of Africa. Ask any of these visitors what qualifies Malawi to be so appraised, apart from the magical waters of Lake Malawi, and they will talk of the friendly smiles and hospitality of Malawians.

The hospitality, however, has nothing to do with the commercial sex offered by the woman who stands in dark corners, in the middle of the road and under the roofs of corridors along Hannover Street plying her trade. The warm heart of these girls is of a different kind. This type of trade is the pure trade of lust and risks. Ironically, those involved in it claim that it has benefited many in this poverty stricken country.

Ask Hawa Mbewe for example. She has all the answers to questions you can ask her about Hannover and what goes on along the street - the good and the bad part of it. At 22, Hawa has done what the majority of university graduates in Malawi cannot do after working for five years. She has built herself a semi-executive house valued at over K80,000 (US$5,340) in the sprawling shanty, Mbayani, a stone's-throw away from the hustle and bustle of Blantyre from trading her body to various clients who cannot resist her looks upon seeing her on Hannover Street.

Occasionally, Hawa changes her trading posts to other entertainment joints in the country. "entertaining clients is a special art. If you do it right, the customer will come back, as memories of the good times will haunt him even after flying thousands of kilometres overseas to Europe or America," says Hawa.

She says that although she prefers the 'up-market' class of foreigners and expatriates as her special clients, sometimes she gets hooked by some locals just for the fun of it to alleviate what she calls "worries of some disgruntled husbands with their family problems." But she says locals are a problem in that they like abusing the women by sometimes just using them without paying for the services they render.

To prevent falling prey to such "scoundrels of customers", Hawa says - and most of her friends - they engage the services of personal body guards. These range from thugs in the shanties around Blantyre to security watchmen guarding the premises and offices along Hannover Street and the other streets nearby.

Stella Banda,18, who has been a prostitute for over five years says apart from providing protection in times of need, security guards also provide rooms in and around premises they guard where the prostitutes can take their " short time" customers, for a small fee. "The watchmen are usually bribed, amounts ranging from K10 upwards, for providing us with shelter to entertain customers who cannot afford our full-time rate at a rest house or hotel, or are in a hurry to spend a long time with us."

Stella considers herself one of the reasonable prostitutes, charging K200 for short time service and any amount over K350 for the whole night, excluding the costs of beer and accommodation. She says some trustworthy watchmen, who find it easy to provide accommodation and protection, are given an allowance of K200 as retainers every month. Several watchmen confirmed they are hired by night raiders to do some errands for them ranging from protection, hiding the more discrete customers and alarming them of any impending danger, more especially when rogue and vagabond patrol police are approaching.

"Ndi pa tauni pano amwene ndingatani? (This is town my brother, what else can I do to supplement my meagre salary apart from playing to the tunes of these prostitutes?)" said one security guard. He says the scenes they see at night are very nasty and they only accept to give room just because of poverty. Another watchman lamented that when the going gets tough for the prostitutes, for instance when they are running away from police and other angry clients, they are compelled to hide them until they are of danger.

"We do this but are risking our jobs. What if our bosses decide to come at night and find out we entertain these acts taking place around premises that look decent during day time?" he questioned. The guard, however, "questioned the sense of other respectably looking gentlemen who leave the comfort of their homes and their wives to come to Hannover Street and indulge in adultery around stinking alleys".

He also expressed concern that contrary to the numerous warnings, bill boards, radio and press advertisements on the dangers of AIDS, people, both local and foreign, still preferred to have sex with high risk groups such as these 'Hannover girls'. Authorities, of course do not condone prostitution and neither do tourism officials who clearly state that tourists do not come to come to this country for sex. The tourism ministry abhors the tendency of some owners of rest houses and motels who use their facilities as brothels.

Willie Chingaru, police spokesman on the issue of girls hanging around entertainment joints and public places at night says: "The police have the power and the authority to arrest any woman found loitering at night and they can lock them up any time." Others feel that the starting point would be for the police to curb this increasing trend in prostitution by rounding up the watchmen and security guards.

Recent statistics show that Malawi and Zimbabwe remain in the lead in HIV/AIDS occurrences in the SADC region.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 7, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia Left Out Of Warren Christopher's Africa Tour


BYLINE: Maidstone Mulenga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Washington, DC - When United States Secretary of State Warren Christopher begins his first trip to Africa today, he will not be stopping in Zambia.

Although Christopher's visit is being promoted as part of the United States efforts to showcase democracy, economic progress and peace in Africa, apparently Zambia is not among the African countries showing these three traits.

State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said Christopher "felt it is very important for him to go there so that he can work with these leaders directly on their turf and visit some important countries". 

Christopher is scheduled to stop in Mali, Ethiopia, Tanzania, South Africa and Angola.

Bill Twaddell, deputy assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said Christopher's visits with President Oumar Konare in Mali and Prime Minister Meles Zenawi in Ethiopia would reward those two leaders for guiding their countries to democracy.

In Tanzania, Christopher will speak with President Benjamin Mkapa, former President Julius Nyerere and other regional leaders on topics including how to deal with tribal warfare that has left hundreds of thousands dead in nearby Burundi and Rwanda.

Christopher will also visit the headquarters of the United Nations International Tribunal on war crimes in Rwanda, which is set to begin its first prosecutions for the 1994 massacres in Tanzania.

Among the topics Christopher will discuss with African leaders at those stops is an administration proposal for an Africa Crisis Response Force - composed of troops from African nations - to provide safe havens for civilians during conflicts or natural disasters.

In Angola, Twaddell said, Christopher's aim will be to shore up a

process of national reconciliation between President Jose Eduard Dos Santos and Jonas Savimbi, his major opponent in the civil war that raged in that oil- rich nation for years.

The secretary's stop in South Africa, Twaddell said, will remind the world of that nation's peaceful transition to black-majority rule and, US officials hope, to stimulate business interest in investing there.

"I would say it's good that the secretary is personally involving himself in those areas: political reform, economic development and conflict resolution efforts," Twaddell said.

Although this is Christopher's first visit to Africa, the Clinton administration has been active on the continent.

In 1994, the administration organized the first-ever White House Conference on Africa.

Before he perished in a plane crash in Croatia last spring, Ron Brown was doing a good job in trying to promote trade and investment in Africa.

The administration also deserves credit for appointing a special envoy to help warring factions make peace in Angola and for finding funds to help the OAU and individual African nations take on peacekeeping duties in some of the continent's various trouble spots.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 7, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia 'Darts: Mambas


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - A second-minute rebound hit by inspirational Kenneth "Bubble" Malitoli yesterday saw Zambia collect three vital points against the Mambas of Mozambique in an African Nations Cup qualifier at Lusaka's Independence Stadium.

Malitoli, who was playing deep in the midfield, hit the back of the Mozambican net after the Mambas goalie, Basillio Luis, was completely beaten by the ball.

But while Zambia increased the pace of the attacks after the clincher, the Mambas playing a 4-4-2 formation in the first half as compared to Zambia's 3- 5-2, also summoned a lot of players in the backline to frustrate the Zambians. 

But it was Mwape Miti, playing as a twin striker with Dennis Lota upfront, that was a threat to the Mambas as his mere hold on the ball resulted in a lot of panic for the visitors that had only one serious attempt at the Zambian goalie, Davies Phiri.

While the Mozambicans, with skipper, Conde Francisco, doing much of the attack, were no push-over, it was the Zambian striking force of Mwape Miti, Dennis Lota and the midfield comprising Vincent Mutale, playing a defensive midfield role, Joel Bwalya, very outstanding in attacks and Bubble Malitoli, that was a delight.

A sixtieth minute attempt by Lota, who was very well assisted by the wingers-Andrew Tembo and Jonson Bwalya, was thwarted by the Mambas who seemed determined for at least a draw.

And national team trainer, Roald Poulsen, in a post-match interview, said he was not bitter with the narrow victory as the three points counted most.

"We had a very good match and I think players like Mwape Miti, and others played a very good game. I am not bitter because in such competitions, the important thing is simply to win, and since we have won, I think we are safe," he said.

But the Mambas coach, Arnaldo Salvado, bragged that his team stands a chance of reversing the scores in the return match.

"The game was tough and Zambia has proved that it is a good side, but still, I think we will win when Zambia comes to Mozambique. We will have the same chances of playing at home just like Zambia had," the coach said.

Sports - General;
Auto Racing: Zambian Is Tail-Ender In Equator Rally


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - Celebrated Zambian motor rally giant, Satwant Singh failed to tick in the Caltex Equator Rally finishing sixth in the event in which he was the sole Zambian driver.

According to a fax message from the Kenya Motor Sports Club, Satwant, who was driving a Subaru Impreza finished 1 hour 38 minutes 29 seconds in the rally in which he was navigated by Suringder Thatthi. 

Emmanuel Kato, of Uganda, with co-driver, Opoka who started number five, has been holding the lead in a Toyota Celica, having lost 1hour 29 minutes 53 seconds.

Second position went to Rob Hellier, while last year's winner and defending champion, a Kenyan driver who was driving a Subaru Impreza, was third. The number four slot went to Nazir Virjee and Peter Stone , with Mark Tilbury and Bill Kirk in a Nissan Pulsar, emerged fifth.

Four other drivers-Sammy Aslam, Jimmy Wahome, Martin Evans and Chris Mwaura were out of the race due to either accidents or minor breakdowns.

Africa News


October 7, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: Lone Goal Victory Angers Fans


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - Dejection and down cast eyes characterised soccer fans yesterday after the Zambia national team struggled to beat unfancied Mozambique 1-0 in the opening African Nations Cup qualifier which was played at Lusaka's Independence stadium.

For most, if not all, the game was the lousiest ever since Roald Poulsen took over as coach of the Chipolopolo Eleven.

"The game was lousy," observed Chipolopolo Fan Club chairman, Elijah Chisanga. "The system we used, 2-5-3, failed. We should go back to our usual system of 2-4-4." 

According to Chisanga, "the midfield was crowded and players kept running out of ideas".

This view was shared by Mozambican coach, Arnaldo Salvado, who pointed out that "Zambia did not play well".

"We deserve to have won. It's just that there was no justice on the pitch," Salvado said without elaborating.

Most of the fans interviewed expressed similar sentiments with some calling for Poulsen's blood.

"He should be fired," remarked a fan who travelled all the way from Chipata for the game.

But perhaps, no one could have put it more succinctly than stand-in captain, Johnson Bwalya.

"We should have won this game by a large margin," Johnson said. "But we fumbled a lot of chances. Anyway that is the name of the game."

Midfielder, Andrew Tembo, who perhaps was the biggest culprit added: "It happens in football. Sometimes you play well and other times you fail to tick. "

But coach Roald Poulsen seems content with the result.

"At least we got three points," Poulsen said in a post-match interview, adding: "The biggest problem was the pitch. It's too bumpy."

He was supported by his erstwhile pal, Danmark's Brondby FC team manager, Emil Baekenhoff, who is in the country on a player buying spree.

"The field is not good, something must be done about it," Baekenhoff said.


LOAD-DATE: October 10, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


130 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1996


Science & Health;
Africa Loses 1.3 million Hectares Of Forest Yearly


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 851 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Africa loses some 1.3 million hectares of forest each year, a Nigerian environmentalist, Luka Achi, has said.

"Everyday, about six thousand five hundred hectares of African savanna are being cleared," he said. "Annual rituals of bush-burning during the dry season is taking its toll on the forest reserves."

Achi, the general manager of the Environmental Protection Authority in Nigeria's northern state of Kaduna, was speaking Monday at the opening of a three-day sub-Saharan Africa Forum for Environmental Journalists.

He said the over-exploitation of African forests had resulted in droughts, land degradation and the "concomitant spread of arid and desert lands."

In Kaduna State alone, he said "no fewer than ten lorry loads of firewood" were carried to other states everyday.

Another dangerous trend, he added, industrial pollution coming from the dumping of toxic wastes in some African countries.

He said that the trend pointed to "a deepening environmental crisis," especially for developing countries.

In his welcome address, the secretary-general of the sub-Saharan Africa Forum for Environmental Journalists, Sani Malumfashi, said there was need for the active participation of the mass media in the crusade for a cleaner environment for all.

He urged the workshop participants to help educate society on how to prevent lead poisoning, which he said was on the increase worldwide.

Journalists from Cote D'Ivoire, Ghana, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Zambia are attending the workshop.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


131 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1996


South Africa;
South African Strikes Cost More


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Industrial action in South Africa during the first nine months of 1996 cost the country a total of 1.35 million man-days -- an increase of more than 50 percent on the 870,000 man-days lost through strikes in the corresponding period of 1995.

This was revealed here Monday in a report by labor analyst, Andrew Levy and Associates, which showed that after a slow start, the number of man-days lost in industrial action rose sharply in the third quarter of 1996. 

But, the report adds, "although quite a jump on last year's figure, it is still well below that of the previous three years and is not expected to exceed the two-million mark by the end of the year."

In 1994, South African strikes cost the country 2.5 million man-days in the first nine months of the year; the figure for 1993 was 2.4 million; and in 1992 a total of 3.1 million man-days was lost in industrial action.

The third quarter of 1996 was dominated by two major strikes which resulted in a combined loss of 784,000 man-days.

These were the illegal strikes at the Rustenburg Platinum Mine involving 28, 000 workers, and the seven-day strike by 80,000 South African clothing and textile workers' union members in the clothing industry.

The major reason for strikes in South Africa in this period was wages, (59 percent), followed by grievances, (39 percent).


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


132 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1996


Business;
Breweries In Nigeria Face Hard Times


BYLINE: Chike Okocha, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The fortunes of the brewery industry in Nigeria are on the decline as alcoholic beverages, the sub-sector's main money earner, now attract low patronage from consumers.

"In 1993, we used to sell more than five cartons of beer daily but now two cartons of beer sometimes last for two days or more before the drinks are sold out," says Biola Fagbemi, a bartender at a popular restaurant in Lagos.

Fagbemi says the current trend in the sale of lager beer is general. According to him, more people are trying to reduce their alcohol intake, while others are opting for the non-alcoholic drinks. 

The public affairs director of Guinness Nigeria Plc, Ulu Mba, confirms the problem facing the industry.

The industry, which produced over 15 million hectoliters of assorted beverages from its installed capacity of 18.3 million in 1993, has declined to less than five million in 1996.

Mba claims that only two breweries, (Nigerian Breweries Plc and Guinness Nigeria Plc), out of 13 currently producing, could be said to be doing so conveniently.

But the Managing Director of Nigerian Breweries Plc, Felix Ohiwerei, says his company is not faring any better.

For example, he said, in 1991, 180 million cartons of his company's products were sold, but the production was halved in 1992 and dropped to 86 million in 1993. The figure has further plummeted in 1996.

In the case of Guinness Nigeria Plc, although its turnover appreciated to 8. 074 billion naira from 5.201 billion in 1994, its pre-tax profit fell to 786. 076 million naira from 898.512 million in 1995 (80 naira = 1 USD).

The decline was attributed to economic depression which has resulted in many factories operating below their installed capacities.

Ohiwerei, who is also the chairman of the beer group of the Manufacturers Association of Nigeria, has described the current production level of the beer industry as the worst ever in the country.

The spill-over effect is also felt on the Nigerian Stock Exchange, where securities of the listed breweries have failed to attract investors.

This has adversely affected the price movement of their securities, resulting in losses with brokers, in response to the market trend, marking down the sub-sector's share prices.

Capital market operators attribute the poor performance of the industry to high rate of inflation, officially estimated at 72.8 percent, and which has continued to erode the consumers' purchasing power.

Economists believe that most Nigerians now restrict themselves to their basic needs, resulting in the accumulation of products of the brewery industry in warehouses across the country.

In the same vein, Ohiwerei attributes the lowered production capacity of the brewery industry to the consumers' weak purchasing power.

He said because of the depressed economy and weak purchasing power of consumers, tied to the level of inflation, many shareholders and consumers now resort to selling their financial commitments.

"Beer is no more on my priority list. Before, I used to buy beer in cartons but now, I consider it a luxury I can hardly afford," says John Uche, a businessman in Lagos. "I only drink beer at social functions where it is offered free of charge."

For Okey Okeke, a civil servant, the high cost of beer has forced him to become a teetotaller -- the minimum price of a bottle of beer in Nigeria is 35 naira.

According to industry sources, other reasons for the malaise in the brewery industry include scarcity of foreign exchange in the last five years, which has prevented companies from procuring foreign input like machinery for production.

Brewers also cite religious reasons for the decline in their business, with many former beer parlors turned into churches, and former drinkers transformed into "born again" christians, preaching against alcohol consumption.

Meanwhile, the breweries are trimming their labor force to remain afloat. Sources at the Nigerian Breweries Plc, for instance, reveal that about 48 managers and 500 junior workers in the company's four plants located in Lagos, Ibadan, Enugu and Aba have been relieved of their jobs.

Premier Breweries, Consolidated Breweries, Guinness Nigeria Plc, among others, have similarly laid off some of their workers earlier in the year.

Vigorous sales promotion campaigns aimed at boosting beer consumption are currently being mounted by the beleaguered breweries. Their effect remains to be seen.

Ohiwerei suggests that the only viable option for the industry is to broaden its operational capacity and concentrate on the production of non- alcoholic beverages.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


133 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1996


Mozambique;
Crime Threatens Swiss-Mozambican Relationships


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The killing of the Swiss anthropologist,

Nicole Bezencon, on the outskirts of Maputo September 30, and the apparent inability in solving the crime, are threatening to undermine bilateral cooperation between Mozambique and Switzerland.

The deputy general-director of the Swiss Cooperation Office, Rudolf Dannecker, arrived in Maputo Sunday to discuss the Bezencon killing and its implications with the Mozambican government, and with the rest of the donor community.

The Swiss Embassy said Monday said that Danneker was "perplexed and dismayed" by the murder. 

"He is also worried at the general deterioration in the security situation in Mozambique and is demanding a rapid and convincing explanation," the embassy said.

It said that the future of Swiss aid to Mozambique would depend on Dannecker's discussions in Maputo.

Bezencon was killed at Tsalala, about 15 kilometres from central Maputo, in broad daylight as she was returning from a school belonging to the National Water Board where she taught. The motive was car theft and the two armed assailants seized her four-wheel drive vehicle.

A Mozambican colleague travelling with Bezencon, Carlos Munguambe, escaped but was seriously wounded. He is still undergoing treatment in Maputo Central Hospital.

On Monday, the heads of diplomatic missions in Maputo met at the Swedish Embassy to discuss the sharp rise in violent crime and the government reaction to it.

One of its aims was to ask the government for "a political signal" indicating its commitment to the fight against crime.

The charge d'affaires at the Swiss Embassy, Gregor Binkert, told reporters that donor representatives in Maputo were "very worried" at the situation.

"It could have negative effects on the country's economic recovery, and on development cooperation programmes," he said. He added that the donors want concrete and speedy results from the investigation into the killing. A week has passed and the police has made no public statement on the investigation.

Yet, the Swiss Embassy has found that there were clues that should be followed up. Binkert said that the two assassins had been by the roadside " for many hours waiting." Many people in the area knew who they were, he added.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


134 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Abacha Urges Front Against Information Imbalance


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Nigerian head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha, Tuesday urged African countries to present a common front in the crusade to correct the imbalance in the world communication and information order.

"We must not give up our desire to take greater control of our destiny and reverse our peripheral system in global information system," he said in a message to the opening of a conference of the World Association of Press Councils in Abuja, the Nigerian capital. 

"We have for too long allowed ourselves to be heavily buffeted by unrestrained misinformation from external mass media to the detriment of our national interests," Abacha said in the message delivered by his deputy, Lt. Gen. Oladipo Diya.

Stressing the power of information and Africa's remarkable disadvantage in information gathering and management, the Nigerian leader charged the conference to address the "repercussions" of Africa's continued disadvantaged position in the world communication and information order.

The participants are also to proffer solutions to this "unacceptable situation" and strive for the enhancement of journalistic practice and intrinsic relationship between responsible journalism and Africa's developmental goal.

He said the discussion of rights and privileges of the press must take account of the socio-cultural environment in which the press must render service.

"There cannot," he said, "be any demand for rights without responsibilities or freedom without a corresponding obligation."

He urged the association to give guidelines on press performance worldwide.

This is to enable journalists and other bodies charged with national security to "advise themselves on the limitations that what the world accepts should be placed on the exercise of the freedom of the press."


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1996


Nigeria;
Gas Trade On The Cards In Nigeria-Turkey Talks


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The plan for the purchase of Nigeria's liquefied natural gas by Turkey marked the high point of economic talks between the two countries, Nigerian officials said Tuesday.

According to the officials, Turkey is proposing to buy at least 100-million- U.S.-dollar worth of Nigerian gas a year, to boost trade between both countries currently amounting to less than 100 million dollars per annum. 

The bilateral talks form the highlights of a two-day visit by Turkish Prime Minister, Neometin Erbakan, who arrived in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, Monday.

Erbakan met Monday with Nigerian head of state Gen. Sani Abacha, while their officials held separate talks under the two nations' joint economic commission.

The prime minister, due to leave Abuja later Tuesday, was accompanied by a 250-member delegation of private sector representatives and officials, including four ministers.

During preliminary talks that preceded Erbakan's visit, Nigeria proposed 14 areas of cooperation with Turkey, aimed at boosting the level of bilateral economic undertakings.

These included commerce, tourism, construction and consultancy services.

Others were technical and scientific cooperation, agriculture, banking, health matters, free trade zones, telecommunications and transport.

Also covered by the proposals were the liquefied natural gas project, education, housing and petro-chemicals.

The two countries signed an agreement on economic, scientific and technical cooperation in 1986.

Africa News


October 8, 1996


Sports - General;
Chess: Zambian Women Chess Players Are Africa's Best


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - A Zambian team of women chess players that went for the 32nd Chess Olympiad in the former Soviet republic of Armenia returned smiling, after emerging as Africa's best team in the Women's category.

According to Zambia Chess Federation (ZCF) president, David Hamoonga, who led the Zambian delegation, the all-woman Zambian side came out top ahead of twelve other African countries including South Africa, Zimbabwe, Malawi, Kenya, Tanzania, Lesotho, Mauritius, Reunion Island, Uganda, Swaziland, Angola and Mozambique. 

"It was overall a very impressive performance by our team, and although we did not bring any physical honours, the fact that we came out as the top team in Africa speaks a lot," said Hamoonga in an interview on Friday.

But the ZCF boss, who had travelled with national ladies champion, Brenda Mumba of Zamsure Lusaka, Mercy Banda of Four Knights Lusaka, Dessy Mwanza of Nkana and Joy Mtine of Zamsure Ndola, claimed that much better results could have come out had Mumba competed in other boards.

"Brenda, being the Zambian champion was made to compete in Board One, which was the toughest. But had she competed in other boards, something could have been done," Hamoonga said of the tournament held from September 15 to October 2.

And the poor performance by the Zambian champion saw her drop on the World rankings from position 2265 to 2206, while another Zambian , Joy Mtine moved up to number 2265.

Zambia could not send a men's team because of lack of money.

Africa News


October 8, 1996


Sports - General;
Auto Racing: The 1996 Africa Rally Standings


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - Four time African champion, Satwant Singh, has opened up a twenty point lead on the 1996 African Rally Championship drivers' standings after finishing first at the just ended Caltex Equator Rally in Kenya.

Driving a Subaru Impreza, Satwant scored twenty points in the highly competitive 1,000 km race to bring his total tally to seventy.

An excited Zambia Motor Sports Association (ZMSA) treasurer, Aaron Chungu, said at a press briefing yesterday that this win puts Satwant in good stead to scoop the 1996 African title. 

"Satwant has proved that he is a hero. He finished first out of forty-two cars," Chungu said, explaining: "With this win, he has opened up a twenty point lead and with only one more rally to go-the Total rally of South Africa- it's most likely that he will win the 1996 African title."

Satwant's closest rival on the log is Kenyan Azar Anwar, who finished sixth and collected a paltry eight points. He now has 50 points.

On third position is Peter Lansdell of South Africa who has accumulated 24 points thus far.

"I am very happy with the result," enthused Satwant, who is populary known as the "Flying Sikh", in a telephone interview from Nairobi, Kenya, yesterday. "It (the rally) was very fast and very rough and clearly the level of competition was very high. The Kenya Open (as the rally is normally referred to) is one of the toughest in the whole series."

He, however, could not immediately indicate whether he will take part in the deciding Total rally slated for October 17 to 19, in South Africa.

"It's too early to make a decision on whether I will take part or not," Satwant said. "I want to fix my car first as I have damaged the left front suspension and the cross member very badly."

ZMSA president, who is also Satwant's wife, Lee-Anne, expressed relief at the result.

"There was very strong opposition, especially from the Ugandan, Emmanuel Kato," Lee-Ann said in a telephone interview from Kenya.

This is the first time that Satwant has won this elusive round of the African championship. In his two previous attempts ( 1993 and 1994) he finished third after damaging his car.

Meanwhile, on the navigators standings, Satwant's navigator Surinder Thatthi of Kenya, is leading the pack with 50 points after collecting 20 points in the Equator rally.

On second position is Shammi Khan of Kenya who has amassed 42 points while on third position is Eddie Verlaque of South Africa with 24 points.

And, according to the final results faxed by the Clerk of Course, Andy Najee, the Zambian clocked 08:01 hours and 33 seconds. Hard on Satwant's " wheels" was Glen Edmunds who clocked 08:23 hours and 55 seconds. Nazir Verjee of Kenya finished third.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 8, 1996


Zambia;
Intelligence Bill Denounced


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - It is criminal and immoral for the government to confer more powers on the Zambia Security Intelligence Service (ZSIS), an institution guilty of abusing its citizens and subjecting them to inhuman and degrading treatment, charged Civil Society chairman, Lusaka lawyer John Sangwa, on Friday.

Sangwa, at a press briefing at Lusaka's Pamodzi Hotel last Friday, said the proposed legislation, through the amendment of the Zambia Security Intelligence Service Act, was counter to the recommendations of the Human Rights Commission. 

"It is insane for the government to confer police powers on the ZSIS when recommendations of the Commission, after listening to horrifying stories from citizens who suffered at the hands of this institution, was that such powers should be taken away," Sangwa said.

The ZSIS Bill No 34 of 1996, among other things, has broadened the circumstances in which intelligence officers are expected to use firearms. It also confers power on the officers to obtain search warrants and search premises, persons and intercept telecommunications.

Contributing to a debate on the Bill last week in Parliament, National Party president Humphrey Mulemba charged that the government was creating " elimination squads and merchants of death" through the legislation.

"I find it unacceptable that our intelligence service should be transformed into what is being proposed," Mulemba, who is also Solwezi Central National Party member of parliament, charged. "They (intelligence officers) are supposed to be collectors of information. It will be dangerous to arm them. We will turn the intelligence service into elimination squads and merchants of death."

Sangwa implored the government to consider recommendations of the Commission which say the role of the ZSIS be confined to intelligence gathering in matters relating to state security and that ordinary police powers be withdrawn from intelligence officers.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 8, 1996


Business;
Grain Traders In Zambia May Shun Inventory Credit Scheme


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) executive director, George Grey, yesterday said the recently launched Inventory Credit Scheme (ICS) may be shunned by grain traders due to the prevailing high interest rates.

Gray, in an interview yesterday, feared that although the scheme had not yet "kicked-off", the ICS was not likely to be fully subscribed to by grain traders as maize prices had remained low while the current interest rates were very high. 

"We wouldn't be surprised if the scheme doesn't kick-off this year as very few people are interested because of high interest rates while the maize prices are flat," Gray said.

The government abandoned the initial Maize Marketing Revolving Fund in preference to the ICS, citing operational modalities and the "mischanneling of funds"meant for the maize marketing.

Agriculture minister Suresh Desai announced in April, this year when the scheme was launched, that ICS would be allocated about K52 billion from which farmers would source funds for the purchase of maize after depositing grain in the scheme's reserves.

October 8, 1996


Business;
Zambian Government Agrees To Review Liberalisation Policies


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - The government has responded favourably to the advice for a review of the liberalisation policies in a bid to check the collapse of companies in the manufacturing sector due to unfair competition from cheaper imported goods.

Commerce, trade and industry deputy minister Alfred Lienda, making the announcement last Wednesday at the official launching of Gillette range of products, revealed that the government would review the liberalisation policies. 

Lienda admitted that from the time the country had opened its doors to the outside world, several companies in the manufacturing sector had collapsed.

"The government is addressing this problem to resuscitate the falling manufacturing sector," Lienda said.

He noted that as a result of cheaper imports, Zambia was slowly turning into a trading nation as the manufacturing companies were subjected to unfair competition from traders.

Economics Association of Zambia chairman, Griffin Nyirongo, on Thursday called on the government to consider protecting the manufacturing sector by not fully liberalising the economy as most companies had no capacity to compete with rival companies in the region.

Nyirongo was commenting on the decline in the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) which he partly attributed to the almost collapsed manufacturing sector.

October 8, 1996


Business;
Fuel Crisis In Zambia Likely To Last Longer


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The current fuel crisis in the country is likely to last until the end of the year unless government gathers resources to repair the oil pipes at the Indeni Oil Refinery in Ndola.

According to sources on the Indeni board of directors, the plant needs extensive rehabilitation costing millions of dollars which neither the company nor the government seems to have. 

"The problem at Indeni seems to be more financial than technical," said Transporters Association of Zambia chairman, Charles Madondo, in an interview yesterday. "I think the statement from the Minister of Energy Edith Nawakwi was not true. We have reservations that it is only leaking pipes and bad weather that are causing this grave shortage. What manner of bad weather is it that has continued for this long?"

He revealed that truckers were feeling the pinch already when they had to park trucks for over two days in search of fuel. He lamented that this was the peak period of the transport business in Zambia when the agro industry had to take their crop to markets.

Zambia Chambers of Commerce and Industry (ZACCI) chairman, Gerry Chabwera, condemned the escalating costs of business in Zambia and asked the government to seriously tackle the issue.

"We cannot begin to imagine what increased costs will do to us," Chabwera said.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


143 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 8, 1996


Zambia;
President's Plans For UNIP Detainees Revealed


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba wants the UNIP treason detainees convicted so he can exercise his presidential powers to grant them amnesty and make political capital out of it, claims a South African intelligence report.

The report also reveals that it is President Chiluba who instructed Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) Gregory Phiri to prosecute the eight UNIP treason detainees.

President Chiluba, who invited Rhema Church pastor, Ray McCauley, to attend the Ndola Trade Fair in July this year, made his intentions known in private discussions with the South African clergyman who was also on a mission for the South African ministry of foreign affairs.

"After the due process of the law had been followed and that the eight individuals had been convicted, he Chiluba under his presidential powers would grant amnesty to the convicted individuals and this would happen before the next election," the intelligence report claims this is what President Chiluba had told pastor McCauley. 

The South African intelligence document, which contains debriefing notes of the trip undertaken by pastor McCauley and the church's press officer, Ron Steele, in July this year, also says President Chiluba told pastor McCauley he would "give instructions to speed up the prosecution of the eight individuals concerned in the treason and murder trial".

And presidential press aide Richard Sakala, who complained about The Post coverage of his recent South African trip, on August 19 demanded for a written press query which was promptly faxed to him on the same day but has remained unanswered.

But reacting to the South

African intelligence document, Steele in a fax dated August 8, confirms both the meeting in Ndola between President Chiluba and pastor McCauley and the subject of discussion.

Steele, however, disputes some details of the discussion while confirming that President Chiluba referred to the amnesty for the detainees once convicted.

"Pastor McCauley did say they had discussed the question of amnesty for the treason trial eight and he (McCauley) got the impression that President Chiluba might be looking at this possibility," Steele says.

Steele also confirms a number of points in the intelligence report as having been subjects of discussion between President Chiluba and pastor McCauley but differs on some details.

According to the intelligence document the South African foreign ministry was involved in pastor McCauley's visit when they asked the clergyman to discuss with President Chiluba "the current situation in Zambia with specific regard to the Constitution and its withdrawal thereby allowing a level playing field in the next elections and the UNIP detainees."

But Steele denies this, claiming an American missionary, a Reverend David Newberry invited McCauley and that the South African government had nothing to do with it.

"South African foreign affairs department never once contacted pastor McCauley or myself," Steele says.

And, unlike the intelligence report, Steele says that pastor McCauley accepted the invitation because Newberry assured him that President Chiluba would attend and that "it would be a good opportunity to speak to President Chiluba in view of the concerns we have about his image in the South African media".

"On this basis pastor McCauley accepted the invitation because he thought it would be a good opportunity to speak to President Chiluba in view of the concerns we have about his image portrayed in the South African media," Steele says, adding: "Because of President Chiluba's Christian confession Pastor McCauley was interested to hear Chiluba's side of the story and to encourage him to maintain democracy in Zambia, which had been his platform of success."

Steele, however, accepts as correct a paragraph in the intelligence report which says President Chiluba told the pastor that "elections would be free and fair with the participation of UNIP but Kaunda would not under any circumstances be allowed to stand".

Steele also accepts the general comments in the intelligence document where it says "the shops are full and the situation in the country looks to be very good, things are working well".

"This is a remark of mine made whilst in Ndola and later in South Africa and was made in the context of comparing my last visit to Zambia about six years ago," Steele says.

Steele further admits as correct the intelligence document's entry that " after discussions with various and random individuals during this visit it was concluded that Chiluba was still very popular with the people of Zambia".

"This was the general impression gained from one day in Ndola and from speaking to the general public at the crusade and to dignitaries at a banquet in the evening," Steele says in reply.

However, Steele disputes the document's entry that President Chiluba " admitted to have been deceived by some members of his cabinet who were not Christians" and he instead says: "President Chiluba never told pastor McCauley he had been deceived by some cabinet members. He had willingly confessed he had been over zealous to see Christian participation in government. Subsequently he had corrected this to ensure that only the best qualified person got the job, irrespective of religious belief."


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

October 9, 1996


Mozambique;
Mozambique Increases Port Charges


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Mozambique Port and Railways has increased tariffs for the Beira port and rail from the beginning of October, to cater for increasing maintenance costs.

The commercial representative of the company, Gabriel Mabunda, said in an interview rail tariffs had gone up slightly, but port tariffs had not yet been changed. 

"The increases are relative to the types of goods carried," he said.

The increases would affect the volume of Zimbabwe's exports through the porta as the tariffs were still competitive and the Beira port was an economic route for Zimbabwe.

Mabunda said Mozambique railways had not increased tariffs for the past 10 years, but had started to make adjustments from last year to try to cover maintenance costs.

He said the Beira port last year handled about 1,712,000 tons of cargo and until September this year, had handled 1,519,000 tons of cargo and 17,000 containers from Zimbabwe.

"The line has the capacity to move more cargo....", he added.

Africa News


October 9, 1996


Science and Health;
ICIPE Gets 3.6 Millions Dollars From Swiss


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - The International Center for Insect Physiology and Ecology (ICIPE) in Nairobi received a grant of 200 million kenya shillings (about 3.6 million U.S. dollars) Wednesday from the Swiss government.

The funds, released through the Swiss Agency for Development Cooperation, are to be used in research. They will cover the period 1996 to 1999 and follows a similar grant of 144 million shillings (2.62 million dollars at today's rate) in 1995.

Wednesday's agreement was signed by the Swiss ambassador to Kenya, Peter- Hans Erisman and the center's director-general, Hans Herren.

"One of the most significant recent breakthroughs at ICIPE is the uncovering of the chemical basis of locust communication and behavior," Herren said.

This discovery, he added, will pave way for the environmental sound control of the insect.

The center depends on grants. For the 1994 fiscal year, it received 9 million dollars from 23 donors.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


146 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 9, 1996


Science and Health;
Zimbabwe AIDS Prevention Campaigns


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - It is estimated that one in every 10 people in Zimbabwe is infected with the AIDS-causing virus, HIV.

Yet, in 1995, for example, more than 42 million condoms were distributed for a population of 11 million people.

Zimbabwe also has more than 52 support groups of people with AIDS, more than 60 NGOs dealing with the pandemic, and at least 100 companies which have HIV/AIDS prevention programmes within their work places for their employees. 

"What is still lacking is the clear and significant evidence of behavior change to impact on the spread of HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases, " said Dr Everisto Marowa, head of the National AIDS Coordination Programme, Tuesday at a conference on AIDS.

While in the past few months 300 people were dying from AIDS every week, Marowa said, now the deaths were between 300 and 500.

Although over 42 million condoms were distributed in 1995, there is no guarantee that they were all used. Peer educators present at the conference said users were often skeptical because of numerous untrue rumours about the latex device.

The educators said there was need to work hard to dispel rumours that the condoms were laced the HIV virus.

Marowa said it was estimated that by the end of 1996, more than 200,000 people would have developed full-blown AIDS.

He applauded the growing number of support groups constituted by people with AIDS, saying they were a positive trend through which infected people could help one another.

But he said he was concerned at the continued absence of a national HIV/AIDS prevention and control body in Zimbabwe, especially now when infection is rapid and weekly deaths have almost doubled.

Another impediment in the fight against AIDS, he pointed out, was the absence of a working national multi-sectoral committee.

"We are concerned that in 1996 we do not have an AIDS body to provide advocacy and direction in prevention and control and we also do not have a national multi-sectoral committee to motivate and mobilize the different sectors," said Marowa.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


147 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 9, 1996


Science and Health;
South African Population Drop Likely Because Of AIDS


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa's projected population over the next 15 years is expected to show a substantial drop as a direct result of AIDS-related deaths.

The University of South Africa's Bureau Research revealed in Pretoria this week that AIDS could cause the country's projected population for the year 2011 to be 750,000 below the expected figure. 

In a report entitled "Global Population Growth and Structural Changes in the RSA Population 1951 - 2011", the Bureau said: "The South Africa population is expected to grow at a rate of 1.7 percent per annum from 42.1 million in 1996 to 54.1 million in the year 2011".

"But," the report added, "if AIDS deaths continue at the current rate, the population may be three-quarters-of-a-million less than the projected 54.1 million".

It said AIDS deaths were expected to increase by almost 23 percent in the next 14 years.

The bureau also revealed that South Africa's so-called brain-drain was less dramatic than many people assumed. In the five years up to May, 1996, almost 4,000 more immigrants entered the country than the number of emigrants who left.

"The effect of legal migration figures on population figures for South Africa is minimal," according to the report, which also estimated that the country's population should eventually stagnate at around 103 million.

The report warned that rapid population growth in developing countries hampered economic growth, led to the degradation of natural resources and promoted poverty and income inequality.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

October 9, 1996


Zambia;
Striking Nurses Defy Ultimatum To Resume Work


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Some 800 Zambian striking nurses defied an ultimatum to resume work Wednesday or be fired.

The nurses, working at the University Teaching Hospital (UTH) in Lusaka, who went on strike in September for almost a week, resumed their strike Monday, saying they would only return to work until their demands for 100 percent salary increment and improved conditions of service were met. 

UTH assistant public relations officer, Pauline Mbangweta, confirmed to PANA in Lusaka that the nurses had defied the management orders and did not turn up for work Wednesday.

"The reports we have received so far indicate that one or two nurses reported for work, but the majority have decided to stay away," said Mbangweta.

The hospital had mobilized military medical personnel and other volunteers to keep operations running. The latest strike has been joined by nurses in government-run clinics in the city's townships.

Africa News


October 9, 1996


Senegal;
Senegal Renames Airport After Senghor


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegal has renamed its Dakar-Yoff international airport after its first president, Leopold Sedar Senghor, who is celebrating his 90th birthday on Wednesday.

President Abdou Diouf presided over events commemoratiNG Senghor's birthday, which also included the renaming of an avenue and a stadium in the capital in his name. 

He quit office on Dec. 31 1980 and handed power to Diouf, then prime minister and constitutional heir. He ruled Senegal from independence in 1960.

The other national symbols renamed after him are the Roume avenue, which leads to the state house and the Stade Amitie (Friendship Stadium) built by China for the Africa Cup of Nations finals, which Senegal Hosted in 1992.

Events marking Senghor's anniversary also took place simultaneously in Verson, his wife's hometown in the north-Western French region of Normandy, where he currently lives.

The Paris-based United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) is also honoring him in a series of Ceremonies in the French Capital.

October 9, 1996


Uganda;
Mandela Receives Uganda's Top Medal


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda - South African President Nelson Mandela received Wednesday Uganda's highest and prestigious medal, the Order of the Pearl of Africa Class One, in Kampala during celebrations to mark the country's 34th independence anniversary. 

Mandela received the medal from his host, President Yoweri Museveni, in recognition for his dedication to the struggle for freedom in South Africa and to the whole humanity.

He becomes the third head of state to receive the highest medal. President Museveni and the prime minister of Ethiopia, Meles Zenawi, received the medals during the 1995 independence anniversary celebrations.

The Order of the Pearl of Africa Class One is only bestowed upon heads of state.

151 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 9, 1996


Business;
Zambia's Geography Behind High Prices


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia'a geographical location and pattern of trade makes her exports expensive resulting in uncompetitive pricing of her goods, deputy commerce, trade and industry minister Alfred Lienda told Parliament yesterday.

Lienda, responding to a question by ruling MMD's Kafue member of parliament Yusuf Badat who wanted to know what trade barriers the country's businessmen were facing when exporting their products to European markets, COMESA states, North African states and the Middle East, said Zambia's geographical location is making exporters incur high freight costs.

Lienda told Parliament that Zambia enjoys preferential access to the European markets for most of its primary products under the Generalised Systems of Preferences Schemes within the context of the Lome Convention. 

"For manufactured items, such as sugar, access to European market is through quotas," Lienda said, adding that Zambia has recently been admitted to the European Sugar Protocol with a zero quota allocation.

"This implies that Zambia can only export to the European market if other countries allocated quotas fail to meet their commitment," Lienda explained.

He also disclosed that stringent application of regulations and standards in respect of manufactured and processed goods militate strongly against Zambia's exports into the European market.

"Zambia is not in a position to fully comply with ISO 9000 standards that are applicable in the European markets and are very high," the deputy minister said.

As for the COMESA states, Lienda said the trade barriers faced by Zambian exporters relate to tariff levels and existenc of import licences and foreign exchange regulations in some member countries.

"Some member countries have not complied with the agreed time table for reduction of tariffs. This has created tariff distortions in COMESA, consequently posing trade barriers to Zambia which has fully liberalised its economy," he said.

He also told the House that the only countries that Zambia trades with in North Africa are Egypt and Algeria - under trade agreements.

He further said although the middle east is the country's source of crude oil, it has not been Zambia's trading partner and there are no identifiable barriers.

In conclusion, Lienda said "there are no trade barriers to exporters wanting to export to Zambia" but that agricultural products require " phytosanitary certificates and animal products require veterinary certificates."


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


152 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 9, 1996


Business;
World Bank To Create Fund For Zambian Banks


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - A long term fund facility to help banks in Zambia invest in all sectors of the economy is being created by the World Bank.

The facility, which is intended to improve the lending capacity of commercial banks, will divert World Bank's funding from certain institutions, such as the Development Bank of Zambia, to commercial banks. 

Sources at the World Bank office in Washington explained that commercial banks were seen to be more responsible in terms of management as they would ensure that the funds were recovered to the fullest possible capacity.

But the on-going World Bank projects at DBZ, such as the Coffee II project, would be let to run the projected course.

And Bankers Association Chairman, Bill Irwin, disclosed in a statement to The Post last week that the proposal for the World Bank's new funding facility was discussed with his association some months back.

"The new financial institution will be an apex organisation only responsible for the treasury function of disbursing drawings to individual banks and receiving repayments from them," Irwin said in a statement on October 3. "At present it is envisaged that the credit risk would rest with participating commercial banks."

Irwin revealed that the World Bank initiative will also "include a matching grant scheme to assist with capacity building". He said it was unlikely that arrangements would be finalised before the end of the first quarter of 1997.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


153 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 9, 1996


Zambia;
Opposition Party Loses Voters' Roll Appeal


BYLINE: Mukalya Nampito, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Lusaka - An appeal by opposition UNIP and the Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) to have the contract between the government and Nikuv Computers (Israel) Limited for the updating of the voters' roll declared null and void was yesterday dismissed by the Supreme Court.

The full sitting of the Supreme Court, comprising Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube, deputy Chief Justice Bornaventure Bweupe, Justices Matthew Chaila, Dennis Chirwa and David Lewanika , however, upheld a decision of the High Court to remove the veil of secrecy on the Nikuv contract saying the government erred in marking a public issue "Top Secret".

The Supreme Court threw out all the nine grounds of appeal raised by the two opposition parties. 

"In ground one, counsel (for UNIP and LPF) argued that the learned trial commissioner misdirected himself by finding that the evidence of Rabson Mwansa satisfactorily responded to the applicant's apprehension that many eligible voters may be disenfranchised...," Justice Lewanika read out the judgement.

The court found that the apprehension by the applicants was without foundation.

"Our understanding of his (counsel) apprehension is that the contract should not have had a cut off of 4 million voters cards as he thought that the number expected to register would have exceeded...," justice Lewanika said and explained that Mwansa had said only 2.5 million had so far registered and that the apprehension was over optimistic.

The second ground of appeal was that the commissioner was wrong at law not to find a connection between the electoral officers who were responsible for electoral malpractices and the MMD party when the electoral officer in each district is a town clerk or a district secretary.

The Supreme Court disagreed with this appeal saying even in the Second Republic, town clerks and district secretaries were appointed as electoral or registration officers.

"Note that section 15 of the Electoral Act as read with Regulation 5 of the Electoral Regulations 1973 do not prohibit the appointment of a town clerk or district secretary as registration officers," the judgement read in part.

On the third ground, the commissioner's finding that Isaac Zimba's evidence appeared fabricated, was upheld and the fourth ground on the possibility of a conspiracy to rig elections was also thrown out.

UNIP secretary general, Sebastian Zulu's evidence that Nikuv was an intelligence organisation was dismissed for lack of proof.

The Supreme Court was also satisfied that the Electoral Commission did not abdicate its role to Nikuv Computers and that there was no grounds upon which commissioner Mutale could have nullified the contract.

The two parties were appealing against a decision by High Court commissioner Bornaventure Mutale not to quash the Nikuv contract although he admitted to a lot of irregularities in the awarding of the contract.

But argument in a cross-appeal by State Advocate, Abdul-Aziz Kinariwala that the contract was right to be marked "Secret" was also thrown out.

The court agreed with the commissioner that the contract was wrongly classified as "Secret" and he was right to set aside that classification because an election is public issue and should be as open and transparent as possible.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 9, 1996


Zambia;
Presidential Qualifications Sealed


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - Parliament yesterday sealed the presidential candidates' qualifications in support of the 1996 amended Constitution by passing the Electoral (Amendment) Bill 1996 through committee stage.

And a deputy minister confessed in Parliament yesterday that one non governmental organisation has 'misinformed' the people about the Land Act so much that traditional chiefs have now become hostile to the government.

Opposition UNIP Petauke member of parliament, Lavu Mulimba, protested during debate on the Electoral Bill that the government has failed to clarify the clause that allows presidential candidates to declare their nationality on the strength of the word from their chief or clergy. 

"Is this the proof that we were promised would be elaborated upon? To rely on a candidate to provide his own proof where not even his uncle, father, grandparents or any other relative can testify remains unsatisfactory," said Mulimba.

In answer to Mulimba's observation, Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda said if there was any dispute it was to be determined by a full bench of the Supreme Court under Article 41.

Such an appeal could, however, only be made 14 days after the date of elections.

Miyanda dismissed Mulimba's calls that the returning officer be given the powers to reconsider a rejected candidate saying petitions presented after nominations would unnecessarily delay the elections.

The Bill was passed with Mulimba emerging as the only dissenter in the committee stage.

Earlier in the day lands minister Peter Machungwa, presenting a ministerial statement on the 1995 Land Act, said out of the seven provinces where officers from his ministry have held seminars on the Land Act, chiefs from one province which he, however, did not name expressed hostility.

"This NGO is only referring to Section 3 (1) which talks about vesting land in the hands of the President without explaining anything else," Machungwa said. He did not name the NGO.

Machungwa's response, however, drew a question from MMD's Bweengwa member of parliament, Edgar Keembe, who wanted to know whether government would deal with erring NGO.

"That is not my area. But the Honourable Home Affairs minister, Chitalu 'Stalin' Sampa, may wish to deal with this particular individual," Machungwa replied.

Africa News


October 10, 1996


Liberia;
Distribution of Food In Western Liberia Halted


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The World Food Programme has stopped distributing dry food rations in parts of strife-torn Liberia because of fear of attack by faction fighters in the civilian population, leaving tens of thousands of hungry people without food.

In a news release Thursday, the organization said the fighters were harassing the civilians, stealing food and any other commodities they have. 

"We are worried about the security of our beneficiaries" said Arnt Breivik, WFP'S country director in Liberia.

Last month, WFP and its partners distributed two-week rations to almost 40, 000 hungry people in Tubmanburg and Cape Mount county. However, recipients became targets of foreign fighters.

As a result, WFP is now only engaged in limited targeted wet-feeding programs -- where the food is cooked and then given to people on the spot -- in Tubmanburg and Cape Mount county. WFP food is now only reaching about 2, 500 people in these areas.

"Although we are very concerned about the malnutrition levels in these parts of Liberia, we cannot put these people at risk", Breivik said.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

156 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 10, 1996


Liberia;
Liberian Leader Wants More Support For Her Country


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

NEW YORK - The chairman of Liberia's Council of State, Ruth Perry, has described the support of the international community for the country's peace process as slow and inadequate, and appealed for more assistance.

Addressing the United Nations General Assembly in New York Thursday, Perry particularly criticized the lack of a strong support for the Nigeria-led sub- regional peacekeeping force, ECOMOG.

She said since the initiative to deploy ECOMOG in Liberia in 1990 it had been hoped that the mission would receive the full support of the U.N.

"Unfortunately, the assistance of the international community has been both slow and inadequate, thereby imposing severe pressure on the scarce resources of the member states of ECOWAS," added Perry, Africa's first woman head of state. 

She said the efforts of ECOWAS (the Economic Community of West African States) must be complemented by the international community through the provision of substantial material and financial support.

"It is therefore my appeal that the U.N. assumes its share of the burden of peace-keeping in Liberia," she said, noting that "the sub-region is facing extreme economic hardships due to external factors beyond its control."

She told the assembly that the last ECOWAS summit in Abuja had given renewed hope for peace in Liberia, in spite of the set-back caused by the fighting which broke out in April.

Perry thanked Nigeria, to whom she said Liberians owed "a debt of gratitude, " and other members of ECOWAS for their sacrifices for the quest for peace in Liberia, and the U.S., the Netherlands and Germany for their assistance to ECOMOG.

Meanwhile, Perry warned that Liberian women will take over the country's leadership if the faction leaders fail to work toward the achievement of peace in the country.

"If they (the faction leaders, who are all men) do not want to cooperate with us..., I will ask the women to please come on board and lead the country, " she told a news conference in New York, after the speech.

She noted, however, that her male counterparts on the six-member council had been cooperating with her since she assumed office in September.

"I will be a stabilizer among the male counterparts," she said, adding " we've been working together. We've been cooperating."

She said her selection to lead Liberia at a critical stage in the country's search for peace reflected the recognition of the active involvement of Liberian women in the peace process.

"The resolution of the Liberian conflict is therefore not only a challenge to me but to all Liberian women, yea, women in Africa and the world," Perry said.

Liberia supports the decisions emanating from conferences on the advancement of women, particularly the Beijing conference held last year, she said.

The 57-year-old Liberian leader, who was a senator in the 1980s, was selected to replace the former chairman of the council, Wilton Sankawulo, at a summit of ECOWAS leaders in Abuja in August.

The summit also approved a revised time table for the implementation of the Abuja accord, the latest in a string of peace agreements aimed ending the Liberian civil war, which has claimed more than 150,000 lives since it started in 1989.

Under the revised timetable, elections are scheduled for May 30.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 10, 1996


Sports - General;
Nigerian Athletes Receive Cash Rewards


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Nigerian government has redeemed its financial pledge to members of the country's contingent to the last Olympic Games in Atlanta, United States.

Sports Minister Jim Nwobodo distributed the cheques to the victorious athletes and officials at a ceremony in Lagos Wednesday.

The newly elected chairman of the Nigerian Football Association, retired Col. Mumini Aminu received the cheque on behalf of the players. 

Each of the under-23 soccer gold-winning squad but one player got one million naira, about 12,500 U.S. dollars).

However, Jonathan Akpoborie, who plays for Hansa Rostock soccer club of Germany was excluded from the reward because he left mid-way during the Olympic soccer gold campaign to attend to club assignment.

Athletes who benefitted from the windfall included police woman long jumper, Chioma Ajunwa.

Silver-medalists including sprinter Falilat Ogunkoya, received 750,000 naira (about 9,375 U.S. dollars) each, while bronze winners such as African track queen Mary Onyali-Omagbemi got 500,000 naira (about 6,250 U.S. dollars) each.

Athletes who won no medals got 100,000 naira (about 1,250 U.S. dollars) each.

The under-23 soccer team's coach, Willy Bazuaye received one million naira, while all other registered team officials got 500,000 naira.

On the whole, some 38.4 million naira (4,800,000 U.S. dollars) were disbursed to the Nigerian Olympic contingent.

The sum of 43 million naira was realized from individual and corporate donations to the team.

Nwobodo said members of the Nigerian contingent to the paralympic games, which took place after those of the able bodied, are also to receive similar cash rewards from government.

Conspicuously missing from Wednesday's ceremony, although his cheque of 1.5 million naira is being kept for him, was Nigeria's national team Dutch coach, Johannes Bonfrere, who is at the center of a controversy for taking up temporary job with the Gulf state of Qatar.

Bonfrere, who is half way in a two-year contract with Nigeria, has been accused by Nigerian soccer officials of insincerity by taking up the two- month job in Qatar, during his vacation.

The officials argue that the Dutchman has some explanation to make if he resumes work in Nigeria at the end of this month.

Africa News


October 10, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
FAO Report Warns Of Dwindling Food Supplies In Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - The United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) , has warned that despite an improved food supply in sub-Sahara Africa, 13 of these nations are suffering from food shortages and emergencies.

Unless exceptional food assistance is allocated to these countries, the agency said in a report, the countries will face increased hardships.

The report, by the agency's Global Information and Early Warning System's chief, Abdul Rashid, urged large-scale national and international interventions to bring about a rapid improvement in the region's food security situation. 

The report, carried in a quarterly special issue on the food supply situation and crop prospects in sub-Saharan Africa, comes ahead of the World Food Summit scheduled for Nov. 1 to 17 at agency's Rome headquarters.

The hardest hit countries are Burundi, Liberia and Somalia. Other countries facing serious food emergencies include Angola, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Tanzania and Zaire.

The agency cites civil strife, displacement of hordes of rural population and economic sanctions as main hindrances to food supplies in such countries as Burundi.

It calls on the international community to focus on adequate relief assistance in Liberia, the affected populations in Somalia and Sudan as well as other parts of Southern and Eastern Africa as areas requiring assistance.

Others include refugees and internally displaced persons and vulnerable groups in the Great Lakes region.

"Despite the continuing problem areas, there are marked improvement in Southern Africa in terms of food supply," the agency says.

It estimates the sub-region's 1995/96 grain crop harvested earlier in 1996 at 19.8 tons, some 89 percent above the 1985 drought affected level.

The agency notes that the level of cereal imports required in sub-Saharan Africa is expected to decline in 1996/97, reflecting improved harvests in Southern Africa and elsewhere in West Africa.

It says about 40 percent of the total population in sub-Saharan Africa is chronically undernourished. The number could rise from the current 215 million people to 265 million in the year 2010, unless an action is taken to stem the trend.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 10, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Has Over 2,000 United Nations Peacekeepers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - Africa has 2,910 soldiers serving among the 25,488 U.N. peacekeepers worldwide, according to the latest figures released Wednesday by the U.N. Information Service in Accra.

The statistics, which cover up to Sept. 30, show that 19 African countries have soldiers serving with the U.N.

Zimbabwe, with 894 troops, tops African countries contribution to U.N. peacekeepers, followed by Ghana which has 765 blue helmets. Other African countries include Zambia, Namibia, Kenya, Egypt, Nigeria, Senegal, Mali, Tunisia and Algeria.

Pakistan tops the list of blue helmets with 1,713 soldiers followed by India, 1,200, and Bangladesh,1,182.

Five other countries which have more 1,000 soldiers are Jordan 1,126, Brazil 1,115, the Russian Federation 1,112 Poland 1,045 and Canada 1,034.

Down the ladder, El Salvador has two soldiers, while Albania and Trinidad and Tobago have one each.
