Africa News


October 10, 1996


United States and Africa;
Christopher Explains African Crises Response Force


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - United States secretary of state, Warren Christopher, said Thursday his government has resolved to work closely with the Organization of African Unity (OAU) in promoting peace and strengthening its conflict management mechanism in the continent.

"I am an admirer of the OAU, particularly of its activities in recent years in promoting peace and its efforts at conflict resolution," he told diplomats at the OAU headquarters in an address on "the OAU and peace in Africa."

He emphasized that the proposed All-Africa Crises Response Force which Washington DC is helping to build was is not a standing force but a humanitarian one to protect lives with the full backing of the U.N. and the OAU. 

Christopher reminded the diplomats the U.S. government had worked closely in the past with OAU in such conflict situations as Somalia, Angola, Mozambique, Liberia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone and Burundi.

The latest proposal by President Bill clinton for establishing the African force is a logical next step of strengthening this working relations for a viable peace in the region, he said.

Christopher said the U.S. interest in peace in Africa is also aimed at strengthening its economic links, "beneficial two-way trade links rather than aid."

For this to be possible, he pointed out, peace must prevail in the continent, countries must initiate economic reforms, build democracy, promote development through popular participation and stamp out corruption. "These cannot be attained with the endless drain of lives and resources in conflict situations."

Welcoming Christopher, the OAU Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, said he considers U.S. support to the organization's efforts for peace and conflict management as a great encouragement.

"The OAU is determined," he said," to work assiduously towards ensuring that an atmosphere of peace, security and stability prevail in the continent so that the energies of the African people would be focused on what constitutes the most challenging task before our people, the task of improving the living conditions of our people..."

He also called for greater understanding of the U.S. government of the critical issues undermining Africa's development efforts, namely the debt burden, transfer of resources and technology to African countries and the promotion of foreign investment.

Earlier, Christopher and Salim held talks lasting over two hours on a wide- range of issues. Christopher also toured the facilities of the OAU conflict management center and its early warning system, which was built and equipped with American financial support.

Ghana;
Ashanti Gold Company Pulls Down Shares Prices


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Accra, Ghana - Shares on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) Wednesday finished a drab session lower in thin trading, weighted down mainly by Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC), which was subdued by declining gold price on the world market.

For the third straight sessions, the GSE All-Share Index dropped, ending Wednesday's trading at 376.04 points, down 2.44 points from Monday's 378.48 points.

In the broader market, two equities gained and two declined on a volume of 15,520 shares, dropping from previous session's 26,730 shares. 

Market total shares offered continued to stay ahead of shares demand at 1. 27 million to 177,190 shares.

AGC lost 1,000 cedis to close at 27,000 cedis but the Company has successfully concluded a merger deal with Australian mining firm, Golden Shamrock.

The merger will certainly enlarge and strengthen AGC's portfolio of world class gold properties in Africa and its market value.

The other equity decliner was Mobil Oil Ghana Limited (MOGL) which lost 100 cedis to close at 6,400 cedis.

But Pioneer Tobacco Company (PTC) and Ghana Commercial Bank (GCB) continue to consolidate their market gains with two cedis and one cedi respectively at 128 and 762 cedis.

The market capitalization, however, dropped to 3,015.34 billion cedis from 3,110.73 billion cedis.

The last prices of the listed equities were as follows at the close of trading on Wednesday: ABL, 530 cedis; AGC, 27,000 cedis; CFAO, 18 cedis; EIC, 430 cedis; FML, 401 cedis; GCB, 762 cedis; GGL, 242 cedis; HFC, 130 cedis; KBL, 650 cedis; MGL, 130 cedis; MLC, 50 cedis; MOGL, 6,400 cedis; PAF, 156 cedis; PTC, 128 cedis; PZ, 370 cedis; SCB, 5,300 cedis; SPPC, 111 cedis; SSB, 1,035 cedis; and UTC-E, 44 cedis.

Meanwhile, the following were the average inter-bank exchange rates for Wednesday, as issued by the Ghana Association of Bankers: (ST) Cedi Equivalent Country Currency Buying Selling France French Franc 329.75 334.80 Switzerland Swiss Franc 1,359.06 1,379.85 U.K. Pound Sterling 2,660.63 2,704. 10 United States U.S. Dollar 1,703.45 1,730.18 Germany Deutsche Mark 1,113.84 1,131.57 Belgium Belgian Franc 54.09 54.92 Canada Canadian Dollar 1,258.57 1, 277.81 Japan Japanese Yen 15.29 15.53 Holland Dutch Guilder 992.84 1,008.17 South Africa Rand 375.62 381.10 Nigeria Naira 21.01 21.34 (ET)

Africa News


October 10, 1996


Zambia;
Striking Nurses Sacked


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - More than three hundred striking nurses were by yesterday said to have been dismissed by the University Teaching hospital (UTH).

And labour minister Newstead Zimba said on ZNBC Tell The Nation radio programme yesterday that the strike by most of the essential workers in the country was distabilising operations in the nation.

UTH public relations manager, Don Mwape, said the nurses had defied a management ultimatum to call off their action and resume work by 14:00 hours yesterday. 

"We have noted with concern that you have taken part in an unconstitutional action contrary to UTH Disciplinary code 4.6 (a). You are therefore, requested to report to your supervisors at ward or departmental level by 14: 00 hours on Wednesday 9th October, 1996, failure to which you consider yourself to having terminated your services with the board," read the letter signed by acting human resources manager, Evaristo Kasompe and dated October 8.

Mwape told The Post in an interview yesterday that the UTH action will however, only affect those nurses directly employed or contracted by the hospital board.

"The decision will only affect those nurses directly or indirectly employed by UTH. Those from the clinic centres though on strike, do not fall under us," Mwape explained.

He said only about one hundred and eighty-seven nurses had complied with the ultimatum and resumed work by yesterday morning.

Health minister Katele Kalumba asked the nurses to return to work on moral grounds because their strike would result in a number of lives being lost.

But most nurses insisted their conditions of service, mainly their salaries, should be reviewed before they called off their strike.

And primary school teachers in Kitwe have refused to return to work after failing to reach an agreemnt with the government over their salaries.

The strike also spread to Mpika, Nakonde, and Mbala districts of the nothern province.

Africa News


October 10, 1996


Sports - General;
Track & Field: Two Runners To Represent Zambia


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Amateur Athletics Association (ZAAA) executive committee last Sunday endorsed the selection of veteran Francis Mukuka and Noah Chilongoshi to represent the country at next week's international meet in China.

The selection of the duo, comes in the wake of differences within the ZAAA top leadership over alleged irregularities in team selections. 

Differences raged after word went round that bare-foot, Fackson Nkandu and Sam Mwape who were both believed to be unsuitable for the China meet were ZAAA's choice. The two run between 5,000 and 10,000 metres while the China meet will focus on marathon races which are a speciality of Francis Mukuka and his colleague.

The differences culminated in the resignation of secretary general , Phili Kubombela.

"It was decided to pick Francis Mukuka and Noah Chilongoshi because we thought there was no reason to divide ourselves over a simple selection," said an official who attended the meeting.

But an effort to get an official position from Kubombela, who bounced back as general secretary last Sunday, flopped as he was said to be on his way from Kitwe to Lusaka.

But sources further disclosed that apart from the two that will leave for China before Wednesday next week, eight other runners will be picked after two weeks to represent Zambia at the Uganda international meet.

"The other eight will be picked at a tournament to be held at Nkana Stadium in two weeks time, but these two will start off for China before Wednesday next week," said sources.

Sports - General;
Auto Racing: Motor Sport Cheating Worries Promoter


BYLINE: Staff Reporters, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - A leading Zambia Motor sport promoter has expressed concern that continued high levels of breaking motoring rules could doom the future of Zambian motor rally.

Jaine Von Kalckstain, who heads the JUA KALI Motorsport promotions, wondered in a letter to The Post yesterday that it has taken just too long for authorities to act on rule-breakers. 

"Well, well, well, I can hardly believe that a Clerk of the course of a Zambian rally has finally had the courage to disqualify Mr and Mrs Satwant Singh for breaking the rules," reads part of the letter she wrote yesterday following the disqualification of four-time Africa Motor rally champion, Satwant Singh.

Jaine, who warned that the clerk of the Siavonga Fun rally where Satwant was disqualified after he used a short cut, Fleming Mumba that he may pay for his courageous stance since Satwant's wife, Lee Anne happens to be the president of the Zambia Motor Sports Association,(ZMSA). She further claimed that Satwant did not win the 1996 Zambia International Rally held earlier this year.

"The real winners of the 1996 Zambia International Rally were Jamie Whyte and Phil Archenoul of Zimbabwe, and the leader on points for the African Rally Championship at that stage was Azar Anwar of Kenya. It's too much to hope that the ZMSA will make an effort to correct this situation at this stage, but Zambia would have gained greater credibility in international motor sport circles had justice been done in July this year at Control 29," says Jaine in her letter.

But when efforts to talk to Satwant family were made, Satwant was said to be out of the country.

Issue Date: September 25, 1996


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 10, 1996


Zambia;
Opposition Warns It's October 31 Or Else


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Lusaka - The MMD government will be illegitimate after October 31 and the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) has announced that it will not recognise it after that period.

But chief government spokesman Amusaa Mwanamwambwa described the ZDC position as "immature."

In a press conference address which highlighted about eight major disagreements with the MMD government and stipulated the way forward, ZDC says there is no negotiation to the fact that the MMD mandate expires this month-end. 

"As ZDC, we shall have no recognition of his (President Chiluba) government after 31 st October and therefore reserve the right to take whatever steps necessary to ensure that Mr. Chiluba does not extend his stay in office beyond 31st October, 1996,"said ZDC president Dean Mung'omba.

But Mung'omba did not indicate what practical measures his party will take to express its non-recognition of the Chiluba administration after October.

He outlined ZDC's opposition to the recently passed Electoral Bill which gives President Chiluba regulatory powers; the lack of government commitment to ensure counting of votes took place at polling stations and the lack of equitable access to public media.

Other areas of disagreement were the Public Order Act, the Nikuv voters cards which ZDC wants substituted with National Registration Cards, the continued detention of UNIP leaders and the government adoption of 1996 constitution.

But Mung'omba anchored his party's message on a summary that ZDC shall consider the MMD government illegitimate after October 31 and will refuse to recognise it unless it called elections by that time.

"Without Mr. Chiluba going through an election and without him obtaining the essential mandate through consensus, it will be impossible for Mr. Chiluba to extend his stay in office without contravening the constitution and unilaterally abrogating the contract he went into with the Zambian people in 1991," Mung'omba said.

He concluded on a four point demand that "genuine legitimate free and fair elections" be held before 31st October, 1996. ZDC will boycott elections if they will not be pre-viewed as free and fair.

The other demand is that "a national indaba of all political stake holders be convened to resolve" the issues it raised.

ZDC also wants modalities of a transition government to be agreed upon ahead of time by all political stakeholders; "in the event that Mr. Chiluba's term expires without holding elections.

The fourth demand was that Chiluba takes steps to preserve national security during the period.

ZDC's stance has been supported by a newly-formed non-governmental organisation , Pan-African Peace Foundation of Zambia (PAPF) which also called for dialogue among political parties to iron out the current political differences.

"Issues relating to the constitutional impasse and the controversial Nikuv voters' register are all very sensitive and could lead to violence in the country. The MMD must discard its intolerance and political immaturity and ensure that these conflicts are resolved before it is too late, " PAPF president, Clive Kunda said in an interview in Lusaka yesterday.

But chief government spokesman Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, said he was surprised that ZDC were giving deadlines because the government had already made its position clear over the issue of the term of office. He called on all political parties to operate within the law in preparation for the elections.

"We are calling on everybody to work within the law particularly the Constitution. Any sign of operating outside or without the law does not show maturity," Mwanamwambwa said.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 10, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: Chilumba Hits Top Form!


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - Versatile, brilliant attacking midfielder. This is how South Africa's Spur Amazulu coach, Mike Makaab, described former international, Tenant Chilumba, in a telephone interview from Durban yesterday, wondering: " Why is such a player not featured for the Zambian national team?" 

Formerly of Power Dynamos, Chilumba is now playing for the top South African premier division side.

"He is not the same player you knew, he has improved a lot and I really can not understand why he cannot be called to play for Zambia, he is a very good attacking midfielder," disclosed Makaab, adding: "He does not fear defenders and faces them, he is a world class player."

Makaab wondered why Roald Poulsen is not calling Chilumba to beef up his team in the World and Africa cup run ups.

The trainer, who further disclosed that Chilumba has been instrumental in getting Amazulu vital goals, said he is now working on the player's defence tactics.

"He is a very perfect attacker and all we are doing now is simply working on his defensive tactics, once he masters playing as both an attacking and defending midfielder, he will be very hot," enthused the coach.

But national team coach, Roald Poulsen, whose side clearly lacked a play- maker last Sunday, was said to be out for a holiday in Livingstone.

Chilumba was dropped from the national team last year when Zambia played Gabon at the Independence Stadium.

He has had professional spells in Saudi Arabia and Morocco and was a silver- medalist with the Zambian team that finished second to Nigeria at the 1994 Africa Cup of Nations in Tunisia.

Africa News


October 10, 1996


United States and Africa;
Africare To Celebrate 25th Anniversary


BYLINE: Africare (Washington D.C.)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Washington D.C. - Africare will salute former President Jimmy Carter for his lifetime of humanitarian achievement -- promoting peace and human rights, enabling self-help development initiatives -- at the 1996 Africare Bishop John T. Walker Memorial Dinner on Thursday evening, October 17, at the Sheraton Washington Hotel in Washington, D.C. That same event will feature a celebration of Africare's 25th anniversary.

"For Africa and for Africare, this will be a momentous occasion," says Africare President C. Payne Lucas. "Jimmy Carter has contributed so much to Africa. He's helping about a dozen nations on the road to food self- sufficiency. He's addressing Guinea worm disease, river blindness and other causes of ill health. He's easing tensions among nations and between cultural groups. 

"And," Lucas continues, "Mr Carter's contributions reach far beyond Africa alone. Through his Atlanta-based Carter Center, he has reached people in 65 countries worldwide, including our own. His programs have been outstanding. Even more remarkable has been Jimmy Carter the person -- for just as he has promoted human dignity, he deeply and genuinely exemplifies that principle. Jimmy Carter relates to all people, all races, all classes, all nationalities. We are, therefore, extremely proud to have this opportunity to mount a major tribute to a truly great human being."

The annual Dinner is now the largest benefit in the United States for Africa, with proceeds supporting Africare. The event attracts about 2,500 people and raises about $1 million.

Gen. Colin L. Powell, USA (Ret.) and Alma Powell are the 1996 Dinner's National Honorary Patrons. As National Chair this year, Africare is privileged to have Jan Leschly, Chief Executive of SmithKline Beecham. Carter Administration veterans Jody Powell and Valerie Pinson are serving as the event's General Chairs. Sam Donaldson will emcee. Andrew Young will make the award presentation to Mr. Carter.

The event attracts notables in the U.S. government and in international and corporate circles, from heads of state to leaders of the Fortunate 500 and almost the entire African diplomatic corps in Washington. Past speakers have included President Bill Clinton, Vice President Al Gore, President Nelson Mandela, then-President Nicephore Soglo of Benin, the late Commerce Secretary Ron Brown, Sen. Nancy Landon Kassebaum and South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu.

Founded in 1971, Africare is the oldest and largest African-American organization specializing in aid to Africa. Africare has carried out several thousand programs, reaching millions of people, in 35 nations Africa-wide over the past quarter-century. Today, Africare has about 150 programs in 28 nations, from Egypt to South Africa. Africare's work is in food, water, the environment, health and emergency humanitarian aid as well as enterprise development and governance.

For more information contact Africare at (202) 462-3614

October 11, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1787 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - ESDL Chairman Dr. Abdul Mejid Hussien says the Somali Democratic League has a reason for wishing to merge with the Ethiopian Peoples' Revolutionary Democratic Front, EPRDF. Basically, he said, merger with EPRDF is the interest of Ethiopians somalis.

Dr. Abdul Mejid who is also Minister of Transport and Communications was quoted by Abiotawi Democracy, Organ of the EPRDF as saying the stage of development the country is at calls the consolidation of peoples' unity targeted at creating a new, democratic Ethiopia. The Somali nationality whose right to administer itself has been ensured by the Federal Constitution desires to work in cooperation and close relation with other democratic forces in the country, he added.

The chairman said the Somali Regional State which covers 1(3 rd of the total area of the country with an estimated population of 5-6 million should live in conformity and cooperation with the rest of the democratic forces in order to benefit from the fruits of the democratic changes taking place in the country. 

This, he said, is a guarantee for the peace and development of Ethiopia and the Horn of Africa.

The merger with EPRDF, according to Minister Abdul Mejid is a pillar for the new Ethiopia and a guarantor for the peace of both the country and the Somali Regional State.

The paper wrote quoting Dr. Abdul Mejid that the Somali people have been working in close cooperation with members of the Defence Force to resist the possible threats from neighbouring Somalia, a country with out a recognised government.

Witnesses testify to torture, killings

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Witnesses of the Special Prosecutor yesterday testified that they had seen the arms of two youths chopped off during investigation. They also said they had buried the body of the late General Teferi Banti.

One of the eight witnesses, a retired teacher, said he saw two youths who returned home form Europe and were put in custody for a allegedly being members of the Ethiopian People Revolutionary Party, EPRP, bathed in their blood after their arms had been cut off.

The witness said he had been thrown to jail five times in the years between 1977 and 1991.

He said he sustained permanent injury to his reproductive organ under incessant torture and was forced to name Fissha Desta in desperation as the man who conscripted him into the Tigray People Liberation Front.

"A doctor named Fekade who used to examine me and my friends severed genitials was unable to bare watching our ministries and committed suicide by throwing himself from a building," the witness said.

The second witness the Special Prosecutor said he, along with the other inmates at the Central Prison had been forced to dig pit near the prison administration.

"Seven human bodies unloaded from a care were buried in that very same pit in the evening of January 1977. I was horrified to see the body of General Teferi Banti among them," the witness said.

The witness said he also saw the bodies of Captain Alemayehu Haile and Major Haile-Sellasie thrown into the same pit that very night.

A Mercedes car that used to take away the inmates from their prison cells usually came back with blood stains and the prisoners never returned, he said.

Another witness, 86, said his elder brother was killed with the 60 officials of the late Emperor Haile-Sellasie. He said he also lost two sons, a daughter and a nephew.

Defence lawyers and the defendants who dismissed their lawyers were asked to cross-examine yesterday's witness, but did not. The court would resume hearing on Oct. 15.

EC vows to assist road construction projects here

Addis Ababa (ENA) - EC representative said here yesterday that the European Community would assist the road construction projects under way in Ethiopia.

A spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs informed the Ethiopian News Agency yesterday that the representative, Mr. Karl Harbo said after presenting his credence to President Negasso Gidada that the community would continue assisting Ethiopia's road construction projects that have a significant role to play in facilitating economic development in the country.

The community, he said, is desirous of strengthening cooperation with Ethiopia in the coming five years, the spokesman added.

Meantime, the Thai ambassador whose residence is in Nairobi, Kenya, said his country wishes to further cooperate with Ethiopia and this desire, he added, could best be expressed by importing some Ethiopian minerals into Thailand.

The ambassador who took leave of president Negasso upon completion of his tour of duty said Thailand has a very scarce mineral resource and its cooperation with Ethiopia should put emphasis on the importation of Ethiopian minerals into that country, according to the spokesman.

Mr. Mansoor Abdul Galil Abdul Rab, Yemeni Ambassador to Ethiopia who also took leave of the Ethiopian head of state on completion of his diplomatic mission here said his country is very much interested in furthering relations with Ethiopia and lauded the tangible good results this country has registered in its economic development endeavour.

President Negasso said on the occasion that it is in Ethiopia's best interest to forge and consolidate relations with all on the basis of the principle of promoting mutual benefits.

The president briefed the representative and the departing ambassadors on the efforts made to ensure peace and stability across the nation and the achievements gained so far in this respect.

The president on the occasion appreciated the government of Yemen for accepting Ethiopia's peace effort in its territorial dispute with Eritrea and said Ethiopia is always ready to help bring about a negotiated peace in the area.

Ethiopia to export tea to world market: Paper

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Ethiopia regional home for mankind and coffee, is to supply the international market with tea products beginning this year, a state newspaper reported yesterday.

Addis Zemen, the Amharic Daily, said the pilot programme of exporting tea to Far East, Canada, U.S. and Djibouti has bore fruit.

The paper said quoting Ato Deresse Kassa, general manager of the Tea and Marketing Enterprise as saying the country has earned 6.3 million birr in hard currency.

It said the enterprise has just satisfied the country's demand for tea and saved foreign currency spent on importing tea.

The paper said the individual daily consumption of tea in the country is 75 grams on the average.

Efforts in curbing traditional practices

Assossa (ENA) - The Benishangul Gumuz regional women affairs bureau says encouraging achievements have been made in curbing some of the traditional practices affecting women.

A considerable number of women have lost their lives or sustained serious injuries as a result of traditional, practices, the bureau head, Woizero Tenaye Hika said.

The head said the various women's affairs offices in the region, in close cooperation with administrative bodies have made significant contributions towards alleviating the problems.

Staining hair with red mud, going to a nearby forest for delivery, being naked above the waist and avoiding diet are some of the practices women in the region exercise.

Fuel supply improved in two southern towns

Negele (ENA) - Filling stations in Negele and Kibre Mengist towns said the supply of fuel and other petroleum product has been improving since the adjustment of fuel price in the country.

Owner of the Ajip filling stations in both towns, Ato Getachew Demissie said taking full advantage of the new price adjustment tank trucks have begun freighting day and night to reach that towns.

He, however, said there was a serious shortage of kerosine, mainly used by the residents for cooking purposes.

Residents of the Kibre Mengist town approached by ENA said " We support the adjustment of fuel price," but voiced dissatisfaction with the shortage of Kerosene in filling stations.

Mauritania;
Parliamentary Elections Begin In Mauritania


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania - Mauritanians started voting Friday to choose 79 parliamentarians out of the 200 candidates contesting for the National Assembly.

A total of 1.03 million voters have registered in the country's 53 constituencies. 

Inter-city traffic has been banned until 1900 gmt as a measure against double voting.

Electoral observers from the Organization of African Unity, France, Germany, Spain, the United States and human rights bodies are monitoring the polls.

The two weeks of campaigning which ended Wednesday allowed the candidates to present their political programmes.

The opposition campaigns focused on the need for a more representative parliament and for transparency in government business.

The ruling party campaigned on the progress it has made in instilling democracy, building social infrastructure and improving the economy.

Africa News


October 11, 1996


West Africa;
U.N. Mission On Bakassi Presents Report


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

NEW YORK - The United Nations goodwill mission on the Bakassi Peninsula, in dispute between Nigeria and Cameroon, has submitted its report to the U.N. Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

U.N. Spokeswoman Sylvana Foa quoted the Secretary-General as saying, after receiving the report Thursday, that his first impression was that the mission was "very, very positive." 

However, Foa did not give details of the report, saying she was yet to get a copy of it.

The four-member mission returned to New York on Sept. 29, after visiting Nigeria and Cameroon, which have since 1994 been involved in a dispute over ownership of the oil-rich peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea.

The U.N. team, headed by Omar Halim of Indonesia, also visited the peninsula and Togo, whose leader, resident Gnassingbe Eyadema, is mediating the conflict.

Its mandate included gathering information and formulating suggestions which might help the parties to adopt confidence-building measures.

The matter is also before the Organization of African Unity, the U.N. Security Council and the International Court of Justice at the Hague, at the instance of Cameroon.

The two neighbors have repeatedly clashed since 1994 in the disputed territory, with their troops stationed on either side of the peninsula.

Africa News


October 11, 1996


Angola;
Nigeria Urges Savimbi To Hasten Angolan Peace Plan


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations - Nigeria has urged Jonas Savimbi, president of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA), to take urgent steps to update UNITA's implementation of key issues in the Angolan peace process.

Speaking in New York Thursday, during a Security Council debate on the Angolan peace process, Nigeria's ambassador to the U.N., Ibrahim Gambari, said that UNITA's wavering commitment to the peace process was of "serious concern" to Nigeria.

He said the peace process was being implemented in "fits and starts" largely due to the intransigence of UNITA. 

"The latest report of the secretary-general on the situation in Angola... contains a catalogue of broken promises, half-hearted implementations and non- compliance, mostly if not entirely by UNITA, with the obligations it has assumed under the peace accords," Gambari added.

The Nigerian envoy listed UNITA's failure to hand over its heavy weapons to the U.N. mission, procrastination over the incorporation of UNITA troops into Angola's unified armed forces and the restriction of the activities of the U. N. forces as part of the obligations which it (UNITA) had failed to fulfil.

He therefore appealed to UNITA to respond positively to all the appeals that had been made by African and world leaders, and called on those with leverage on the parties to help bring about a speedy implementation of the peace process.

Gambari said that while Nigeria supported the exertion of further pressure on UNITA, the organization's leadership should be given more time to "restore our faith in their expressed desire for peace."

Earlier, Stan Mudenge, the minister of foreign affairs of Zimbabwe -- representing the five countries mandated by the Southern African Development Community (SADC) to attend the debate -- urged the council to act to stop UNITA's intransigence.

"The time has come to say enough is enough," Mudenge told the council. " Recalcitrance and obstinacy should not be tolerated, or worse still, rewarded, " he added.

The Zimbabwean foreign minister called for the freezing of UNITA's bank accounts and closing of its offices unless it was willing to honor its commitments under the Lusaka protocol, signed in the Zambian capital in 1994.

Zimbabwe, acting on behalf of SADC, had on Monday requested an urgent meeting of the council to consider the "critical situation" in Angola, where several peace agreements had failed to end two decades of internecine civil war.

In his latest report to the council on Angola, the U.N. secretary-general also expressed "serious concern" about the delay in the peace process and recommended only a two-month extension of the mandate of the U.N. mission in the country.

LANGUAGE: English

172 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 11, 1996


Business;
Zimbabwe Not Keen On WTO Agreement


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe is not keen on a Multilateral Investment Agreement (MIA) within the context of the World Trade Organization (WTO) because it might be forced to abandon schemes started to economically empower the majority blacks, a deputy minister has said.

Speaking in parliament, deputy minister of industry and commerce, Obert Mpofu, said the creation of the WTO had resulted in calls for multilateral negotiations on investments in WTO member countries.

The idea was to establish an agreement on investment within the framework of the rights and obligations of the WTO agreement, signed in the Moroccan resort town of Marrakesh in 1994. 

For Zimbabwe to accede to MIA would among other things entail abolition of the affirmative action and indigenization programmes, said Mpofu.

Government has adopted the indigenization programme to facilitate the entry of blacks in the mainstream economy currently dominated by whites, who constitute less than one percent of the country's population of over 10.5 million people.

Mpofu said it would also mean abolishing reserved sectors for local investors, opening the floodgates for foreign investors to make inroads in selected sectors which government wanted reserved for locals.

If government was to abolish the reserved sector list, it would then be forced to amend the Zimbabwe Investment Center Act.

Mpofu said acceding to the MIA would also mean amendments to some clauses and provision of national development plans and changes to parts of the constitution.

"We believe that each government should have freedom to choose its own particular policy mix combining liberalization with regulation, which can then be fine-tuned or altered according to the country's economic condition and development needs," he said.

He suggested that developing countries unhappy about the proposed MIA could use the forthcoming G-15 summit of heads of state and government, scheduled to be held in Harare next month "to promote dialogue on this issue".


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


173 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 11, 1996


Nigeria;
Dejected Politicians Throw In The Towel


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nine prominent Nigerian politicians, belonging to the so- called 'old brigade', have announced their withdrawal from active politics after their political association was denied registration.

The nine who formed the Social Progressive Party (SPP), made their position known in a statement issued Thursday.

They included six former state governors and two ex-ministers. 

"Since we remain peaceful patriots, we have resolved to withdraw from politics during the current transition programme," the nine said in the statement citing what they called "unjust, unfair and highly provocative verdict of NECON (the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria)," on the recent political party registration.

Fifteen associations applied for registration, but only five met NECON's requirements.

The nine dissolved SPP chieftains, included Solomon Lar, former civilian governor of the middle belt state of Plateau, Lateef Jakande, who was governor of Lagos State and Abubakar Rimi, of Kano. The trio also served as ministers in the government of Gen. Sani Abacha, who has promised to return power to elected politicians in 1996.

The others are Sam Mbakwe, former governor of the eastern state of Imo, former information minister Jerry Gana, former education minister and senate president Iyorchia Ayu, and Sule Amido, national secretary of the defunct Social Democratic party of the botched third republic.

The other two are Abdu Dawakin-Tofa, former governor of Kano State in the north as well as ex-governor Wilberforce Jatu of the old northern state of Gongola.

They said in their statement that "this principled withdrawal by the leadership is to ensure the survival and protection of progressive ideals."

"We have firmly resolved to stand for and promote the ideals of human rights, human dignity, human security, social justice, democratic government, the rule of law ...and the restoration of a free and democratic society."

In legalizing the five political parties on Oct. 1, for the transition programme expected to end in oct. 1998, the electoral commission said politicians whose associations were not registered were free to individually join the five registered parties.

The commission warned that the unregistered associations remain dissolved and could not join any of the political parties as a group. This is to forestall "hijacking" of the legal parties by outsiders.

Reacting to a newspaper advertisement issued Thursday by one of the unregistered associations, special duties minister Laz Unaogu, warned that " government would not allow anybody or group to make a mockery of the political process."

"This is not the time for mergers anymore," the minister said in a statement, adding: "sufficient time was given for mergers but some of the associations refused to make use of it. Anything done in that regard now is illegal and subversive of the political process."

Political analysts said from the pattern of registration, associations tilted towards the so-called 'old brigade' politicians, partly blamed for Nigeria's political problem, would appear to have been rejected in favor of the so-called "new breed."


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 11, 1996


Mozambique;
Mozambique Commemorates Death Of Machel In Plane Crash


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique - Mozambique is making preparations for the 10th anniversary commemorations of the death of Samora Machel, the country's first president, in a plane crash.

The Mozambican minister of culture, youth and sports, Mateus Katupha, Friday visited M'buzini, in South Africa, as head of a government delegation making the final arrangements for the visit of Machel's successor, President Joaquim Chissano, to the crash site next week. 

The presidential plane, Soviet-made Tupolev, crashed on Oct. 19, 1986, killing 34 other Mozambican officials who were returning from a summit in Zambia.

It was lured off course, apparently by a pirate navigational radio beacon, using the same frequency as the Maputo airport beacon, and crashed at M'buzini, close to the point where the borders of Mozambique, South Africa and Swaziland all meet.

Chissano has urged Mozambicans to get involved in the commemorations and has appealed to them to raise funds to build a monument to be erected at the spot where Machel lost his life.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Science;
Outer Space Comes To Town


BYLINE: Lesley Cowling, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 93 words


 

Johannesburg - The United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs will hold a regional conference in South Africa next month. The conference, called "The role of space technology in addressing local needs", will be hosted by the Department of Trade and Industry in Pretoria from November 4. It will look at how space technology can be used for development by African countries. More information at: http://www3.un.or.at/OOSA/Kiosk/sched/sacall.html


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


176 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 11, 1996


Science;
Candy At The End Of The Universe


BYLINE: Lesley Cowlings, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Johannesburg - Tony Fairall greets questions on his subject with a wry smile and the deceptive simplicity of a Zen master. When your daily work combines the task of mapping the unimaginable - our universe - and a job as director of Cape Town's planetarium, where you need to teach children and other neophytes about the cosmos, you have to have a special touch.

Exposure to the realities of the universe can crack the ordinary notions of our world and make it all seem a little beside the point.

Try this for a Zen concept: Fairall, associate professor at the University of Cape Town (UCT), was part of a team of astronomers who recently located a rich cluster of galaxies in a region of the universe dubbed "the Great Attractor". Our galaxy and our neighbouring galaxies are all streaming towards it at the speed of 600km/ second, but with no danger of collision - it is moving away from us at the even faster rate of 5 000km/second. 

Where is it going? Why are we chasing it? And why so fast?

Fairall smiles gently. "Actually, by cosmological standards, 600 kilometres a second is quite sedate."

Our galaxy is moving towards the attractor because of gravity - such a large clump of cosmic matter exerts a pull on its neighbours, drawing galaxies after it as it moves through space.

Fairall compares the movements of the universe to a currant cake baking in an oven. As the cake gets bigger, the currants move away from each other.

The baking cake phenomenon is a result of how the universe began. Fairall says that, scientifically, the accepted way as to how the universe began is the "Big Bang" theory.

"In the beginning, everything was very dense - and all that we know of in the universe was confined into a very small volume," he says. "The volume grew explosively larger - much like a bomb going off."

It is still doing that today, though more slowly. Some of the material in the volume - originally very hot gas - cooled into galaxies, while the space between the galaxies is still expanding.

Over and above this cosmological expansion, astronomers have long been aware of the streaming of galaxies towards a particular region, but until earlier this year there had always been a blank spot on the map that the " Great Attractor" now occupies.

This was partly because the region is somewhat obscured by the Milky Way. Galaxies, Fairall explains, are like towns or villages - a vast number of suns and their satellites bunched together and surrounded by dark matter. They are separated from each other by empty space.

The shape of a galaxy is usually disc-like - a spiral or coil of material - and our galaxy is typical in this respect. Our solar system is not at the centre of the galaxy, but off to one side, and the Milky Way, seen only from the Southern Sky, is the bulk of our galaxy.

Trying to look beyond and through it is like trying to see through the high- rises and suburban ridges of a city to the area beyond. Fairall and UCT student Patrick Woudt worked with four international astronomers to map what was behind the Milky Way, using a whole-sky photographic survey.

The photographs were magnified 50 times and then carefully scrutinised to separate the stars of the Milky Way from what lay further out in space. This is a painstaking process.

As Fairall points out, the photographs are two-dimensional and don't have depth, so they show galaxies next to each that might be quite far apart. To find out how far from us each galaxy or star was, Fairall and Woudt used the telescope at the South African observatory at Sutherland. He would look at each galaxy, and from the spread of colours it produced work out the distance of the galaxy from us.

This process was also used by Fairall's colleagues at European observatories based in South America, and it unearthed more than 10 000 previously obscured galaxies. The observations enabled the astronomers to calculate the size and mass of the "Great Attractor".

The leader of the research is Dr Ren_e Kraan-Korteweg, of the observatory of Paris- Meudon, who began collaborating with Fairall in 1991. He has visited the Sutherland observatory several times.

The "Great Attractor" is 300-million light years away. This makes the discovery historic in another sense - not only a modern event, but a phenomenon of the past. Light takes time to travel across distance. This time is negligible when the light is coming to us from the moon, but as the distance increases, time becomes history.

What Fairall and his team have mapped and seen is 300-million years old. The "Great Attractor" may look somewhat different from what the telescopes have made visible to us, but we will only know what those differences are 300- million years from now.

This makes mapping the universe increasingly a process of mapping the past as astronomers reach further and further out into the universe.

The technology of the Hubble telescope has made the furthest areas of the universe visually accessible and, in covering this immense distance, has crossed the divide of history to show the origins of the universe.

The lifetime of the universe is around 15- billion years, so when astronomers start to look at a distance of 15-billion light years away - whatever direction they point the telescope - they no longer see stars and galaxies, but clouds of opaque gases. Those are the materials from which a universe grows, and what astronomers are seeing is the beginning of its life.

"It's as if we are an egg, surrounded by shell," says Fairall. The map of the universe, seen from above in a God's eye- view, is therefore a circle, with our galaxy right at its centre.

"Beyond this line are licorice allsorts," Fairall quips, pointing to the circular boundary. "And no one can prove any different."

Astronomy sites: http://da.saao.ac.za

http://fits.cv.nrao.edu/www/astronomy.html


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 11, 1996


Angola;
Pressure Mounts For Angolan Peace


BYLINE: Joshua Amupadhi, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Johannesburg - While the UN reconsiders its mission in Angola, the SADC is rethinking its own obligations there.

The United Nations Security Council will decide this week whether to extend its costly operation to maintain Angola's fragile peace.

Meanwhile, fears that the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Organ on Politics, Defence and Security set up to promote peace in the region is not achieving results in Angola, have led to calls for South African President Nelson Mandela and Mozambican President Joachim Chissano to take the lead in pushing for peace in that country.

The calls, made privately to the Mail & Guardian by Western diplomats, followed the first SADC peace summit on Angola held last week in Luanda. The summit was attended by several Southern African presidents and was intended to bring together President Jos_ Eduardo dos Santos and Uniaco Nacional para a Independencia Total de Angola (Unita) opposition leader Jonas Savimbi. However, Savimbi failed to attend, claiming he had not been given enough notice. 

The summit went ahead, however, and focused on what initiatives regional leaders should take in achieving peace in Angola.

Foreign diplomats in South Africa this week expressed confidence that Chissano has had the appropriate experience of bringing peace to Mozambique after a long civil war and because Mozambique, like Angola, was colonised by the Portugese, has empathy with the Angolan culture. They also described Mandela as having the presence and conciliatory skills to bring Savimbi and Dos Santos together.

Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Aziz Pahad said this week that now that South Africa was the head of the SADC Mandela will play a more "reinforced" role in Angola. However he added Mandela's input would be made through the SADC Organ on Politics, Defence and Security.

An official in the Department of Foreign Affairs said South Africa will " play a more active role" but did not want to be seen to supplant regional efforts. He said: "Mugabe was the chair of the Frontline States for a long time and was chosen to head the SADC organ. So Mandela is very sensitive and careful not to be seen to be steamrolling the process."

The SADC summit last week chose three presidents - Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe, Chissano and Zambia's Frederick Chiluba - to increase pressure on the ruling party, the Movimento Popular de Libertacao de Angola (MPLA) and Unita, to overcome the final hurdles to peace.

But both Unita and the MPLA have privately let it be known progress would be swifter if Mandela and Chissano rather than Mugabe were at the helm of the regional effort to halt the growing anarchy in Angola.

Southern African countries fear the United Nations' Angola Verification Mission (Unavem) mandate may not be extended if the peace process is seen to be leading nowhere, and have sent five foreign ministers to New York this week to lobby for an extension to Unavem. It is costing the the UN R4,5- million a day for the upkeep of its forces in Angola.

An Angolan embassy representative in Pretoria, Jorge Morais, said he would be happy with Mandela and Chissano taking the lead in calling for the MPLA and Unita to sort out their differences.

'We welcome that iniative," Morais said. "In our region we identify Mr Mandela as a respectable man who is in a good position to address the problems of Angola.We believe that Mr Mandela and Mr Chissano have the experience."

An adviser to Savimbi in South Africa, who asked not to be named, said: " Savimbi is very keen on having Presidents Mandela and Chissano take the lead. They made miracles happen in their respective countries ... If Mandela and Chissano fail, then we are doomed."

The Angolans have implemented most points of the Lusaka Protocol, a peace agreement signed by the MPLA and Unita in 1994, which specified among other things that both parties participate in a government of national unity and reconciliation, and that they demobilise their troops and create a unified army.

According to the Lusaka Protocol, Unita would fill four Cabinet posts, and Savimbi would become vice-president to Dos Santos.

Savimbi later reversed his decision and went back on the agreement to become vice-president.

But now Savimbi is reportedly reconsidering accepting the position of vice- president as pressure mounts from the UN, which has threatened sanctions against either or both of the Angolan parties if they impede the progress of the protocol.

Lack of trust between the two parties remains the major obstacle to peace. Although Unita has said it has demobilised its 62 000 forces in quartering areas monitored by the UN, a Unita insider said this week that about 10 000 of Unita's top soldiers are elsewhere in Angola, on alert in case the peace flounders. Unita has also accused MPLA forces of moving into positions vacated by its forces instead of going into military barracks.

Unita has, however, recently sent some of its generals to Luanda to be integrated into the Forcas Armadas Angolanas, the unified Angolan army.

Savimbi remains in his headquarters at Bailundo and his advisers say lack of trust is still the central and most deep-seated problem affecting progress towards multi- party government in Angola.

But there are growing fears in the region that progress is so slow, and the peace so shallow, that war could once again break out.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 11, 1996


Kenya;
Kenyan Commission Has A Devil Of A Time


BYLINE: Chris McGreal, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Nairobi - Paul Muite has been accused of a few things in his time. There was the conspiracy to recolonise Kenya and the plot to overthrow the government. But the opposition leader and other members of Kenya's elite are braced for a new charge: consorting with the devil. And the government has an official commission to prove it. 

Kenya is falling apart. Crime and corruption are booming. Most Kenyans see little hope for the future and blame the government. Yet President Daniel arap Moi would have Kenyans believe the real threats are imaginary guerrilla groups, manipulated tribal violence and devil worshippers.

Two years ago, amid a flourish of press reports of children kidnapped for ritual sacrifice, Arap Moi appointed Kenya's archbishop to head an official commission into devil worship. The report was completed last month. Arap Moi has refused to release it, but the government has issued a warning that Lucifer's followers abound.

The commission says devil worshippers have brought a plague of human sacrifice, cannibalism, "incantations in unintelligible language" and rape of children - and gives hints on how to spot Lucifer's agents at work. Citizens should look out for the "magic horns of witchcraft", the numbers 666, images of witches on broomsticks, nudity and snakes. Other giveaways are an " obsession with sex, especially lesbianism or homosexuality".

Bonifes Adoyo, a member of the commission and senior pastor of the Nairobi Pentecostal Church, says it found devil worship at every level of society but mostly among the elite.

'The elites entice people into it with money," Adoyo said. "Materialism and affluence do not answer spiritual longings ... they want mystical powers to control people." He said those who have "joined the bandwagon of economic and political freedoms" played into the hands of devil worshippers.

Muite thinks he knows exactly who the commission is talking about - Arap Moi's political opponents. "Moi won't release the report, but it won't be long before he says it names his enemies as devil worshippers. I know from statements of those around the president that I am one of the people he would like to use the report to destroy," Muite said.

The president has often resorted to scaremongering to distract from the shortcomings of his rule. Before the 1992 presidential elections, the first free vote in decades, the government whipped up ethnic killings, which it blamed on the coming of democracy.

In a new campaign before next year's elections, the government has accused neighbouring Uganda of training a rebel army for invasion. Last month Arap Moi produced three alleged rebels he said were part of a plot to kill him. The three were promised a pardon if they confessed. Two did so, though the family of one said he had been bought off. A third agreed to confess but changed his mind; soon after, he was killed in a police car when it was rammed by a goods train; he was the only fatality.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 11, 1996


Business;
New Twist In South African Satellite Link-Up


BYLINE: Mungo Soggot, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Johannesburg - The puzzle surrounding possible South African involvment in a United States satellite phone system took another twist this week when it emerged the system might not be geared to work above South Africa.

A report compiled by the University of Colorado indicates the Ellipso satellite phone system will not function south of 20 degrees. And, according to an Internet document compiled by the Bradley Department of Electrical Engineering at the Virginia Polytechnic and State University, Ellipsat CEO David Castiel has said: "Frankly, my business plan can do without the people on Easter Island. The university says the system is designed to cover 'more populated areas'."

It was reported at the weekend that a group of South African companies - including Vula Communications, in which Sanco Investments Holdings has a 40% stake and various unions - had pledged R1,6-billion towards the Ellipso satellite phone system. Papers before the Federal Commuications Commission presented the consortium as being backed by the African National Congress and trade unions.

Vula Commuications head Mark Headbush told the Mail & Guardian this week that as far as he understood, the system will work in this country. Suggestions to the contrary were probably the result of "propoganda" directed against Ellipso because it was "driven by blacks". He suggested the M&G contact Ellipsat in the US, which could not be reached for comment at the time of going to press.

According to Virginia Polytechnic, Ellipsat is up against the Iridium system developed by Motorola, which will be able to cover the globe by cross- linking its satellites.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 11, 1996


South Africa;
Civic Group Swaps Stones For Shares


BYLINE: Mungo Soggot, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1534 words


 

Johannesburg - The South African National Civics Organisation (Sanco) has stopped throwing stones and is going into business.

The radical anti-apartheid civic organisation is poised to move into the heart of capitalism when it branches out into direct insurance, marketing and advertising in the next two months.

This shift into the business world comes a year after Sanco, which spearheaded opposition to apartheid's "puppet" local governments in townships, set up its own independent investment company, Sanco Investments Holdings, which operates from offices in Sandton.

Sanco's move into insurance and marketing is aimed at building up a solid membership which will give the investment company the "people's company" status it needs.

The men behind the transition - former Sanco president Moses Mayekiso and businessman Michael Levinsohn - have been plotting the quiet revolution since 1993, when it became apparent Sanco's role would have to change with the arrival of a democratic government. 

The political changeover deprived the organisation of its foreign funding and left it isolated - a marginalisation Levinsohn and Mayekiso intend to eradicate as they launch an ambitious scheme to rebuild Sanco membership and capitalise on foreign and local companies' appetite for politically correct " empowerment" partners.

The plan is that profits from Sanco's business operations and from the investment company will ultimately flow back into development projects and black empowerment schemes.

"We had to turn Sanco into a product, an empowerment organ," says Mayekiso, who is also a former head of the National Union of Metalworkers and a member of the African National Congress's national executive committee.

By the end of the year, Sanco intends to issue membership cards -credit cards with magnetic stripes - to its existing members in exchange for a R30 annual membership fee. Mayekiso estimates the existing membership base is about 1,2-million. Members will also receive a book of coupons offering them discounts for goods from about eight companies, including Tiger Oats and Ster Kinekor.

"We have been offering them a new marketing opportunity. We will be harnessing the buying power of the existing Sanco membership base." In return, the companies pay for printing the coupons.

Despite the Mayekiso and Levinsohn mantra that Sanco and Sanco Investment Holdings have a separate, if symbiotic relationship, they talk about both in the same business tongue. "When we talk to a business like Tiger Oats, we represent two things. We are a mass-based black empowerment company. We genuinely represent people. But we can also participate in the financial arena as contractual partners. We bring something else to the table that nobody else can claim: we are a people's company."

The most daring part of the scheme is that they plan to use the barcoded coupons to build up a market-research data base which they will sell. "It will be a highly accurate market-research tool."

Apart from the boon of the various discounts, members will get life insurance (R1 000 for funeral expenses and R1 500 a year for up to three children for three years). For an extra R10 a month additional insurance will be available from electronic "speedpoints" at Sanco offices around the country.

Next month Mayekiso and Levisohn will fly to New York to give a presentation to United States insurance group AIG - which is also backing the life-assurance scheme - in a bid to bring "direct insurance" to Sanco members. If they succeed, Sanco members will be the first South Africans with access to direct insurance, which cuts out the middle man by allowing customers to phone through their insurance requirements.

Mayekiso insists he has not abandoned his socialist roots: "I am more a socialist than ever. The only shift is that we now have to look for a new way of effecting empowerment. Before we just had to throw stones ... We are now facing the reality that we cannot depend on rhetoric any more. We have to shift from throwing stones to using stones to build foundations for the future."

In 1989 Mayekiso was tried for treason for his work with the Alexandra Action Committee. Perhaps the only amusing aspect of his trial was that the authorities allowed him to build up a substantial library of Marxist literature in his prison cell at Diepkloof, south of Johannesburg.

Mayekiso says the shift into business was vital. "We have to resort to these empowerment projects in order that Sanco can have a role and survive. Sanco has to survive as it is a crucial structure if we are to democratise our society."

Levinsohn's main job has been to get the investment company on the road. He arranged R1,5-million in start-up capital from insurance giant Liberty Life. A further R2-million came from Dato Samsudings's Malaysian holding company SMG.

Mayekiso says Sanco Investments Holdings concentrates on investments which will promote black empowerment. Its portfolio includes a 26% stake in Vula Communications Group, which could become a key investor in a US satellite phone company; 20% in Powerlib, a "shell" company talking to Sasol and Engen about a possible black empowerment fuel operation; 20% of Solid Gold Commercial Radio, which is applying for a broadcast licence; and 51% in Price Tag Wholesalers, a door-to-door sales company started by Sanco. Levinsohn does not like to talk figures, beyond saying these investments should start yielding returns in three years.

It was Vula Communications's possible involvement in the satellite deal which recently put Sanco's business affairs in the spotlight. Since the Sunday Times broke the story, it has emerged that the satellite system is not geared to function above South Africa - a fact which does not bother Levisohn. He shrugs it off:"The reality of technology today is that technoogy is universally applicable."

The link between Sanco and the investment company is the Sanco Development Trust, on whose board sits Mayekiso, Levinsohn and other Sanco executives. Levinsohn says the trust's share of profits from the company will be distributed to regional Sanco offices.

The company's link with development is the Ilima Community Development Company, which has won a R1-million tender from the Reconstruction and Development Programme office in the Eastern Cape. Levinsohn says the company also plans to make money by offering, for a fee, expertise on local communities to companies keen to invest in rural areas. "We will be an integral part of the communication channel between communities and business".

In particular, it is targeting government projects like the Maputo Development Corridor. It will charge small fees to communities which use the facilities it develops.

Mayekiso has already lined up Swedish phone company Ericsson as a 6,6% shareholder in Ilima, and is looking for other multinational companies to take shares. "Ericsson has identified Ilima as a means of making true empowerment on the ground a reality."

Mayekiso concedes that Sanco Investments Holdings depends on a substantial, established Sanco membership if it is to present itself as an authentic mass- based company. Apart from an initial 1,2-million from Sanco's existing base, he hopes to attract about a million new members a year.

If the pilot project in the Eastern Cape is anything to go by, he might be on to a winner - 800 of the 2 000 residents of the village of Xalanga have signed up to the new Sanco and paid their R30 joining fee.


LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
