Africa News


October 14, 1996


Burundi;
UN Humanitarian Situation Report - Burundi


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Bujumbura - (The following Press Release has been received from the Office of the Regional Chairman of the Sanctions Coordinating Committee in Nairobi.)

PRESS RELEASE

In response to the Arusha III Summit meeting concern over the fate of internally displaced persons under the care of UN Agencies and Non- Governmental Organisations in Burundi, the regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee during its extraordinary meeting in Arusha on 21 October, 1966, allowed the importation of the following items to cater for the 250,000 displaced persons in Burundi:-

i. Food

ii. Bean Seeds

iii. Water purification agents

iv. Blankets v. Plastic sheeting

vi. Jerry cans and buckets

vii. Cooking materials (pots and utensils)

viii. Sanitary facilities

ix. Mats.

Quantities and details of the above will have to be defined by the respective UN systems and NGOs and be submitted to the Office of the Regional Chairman of Sanctions Coordinating Committee before importation. The decision has been taken by the Committee on humanitarian grounds.

(For additional information/clarification please contact the Office of the UN Resident Coordinator, UNDP, Nairobi telephone 228776.)

Africa News


October 14, 1996


United States and Africa;
Warren Christopher In Luanda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 808 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - United States Secretary of State Warren

Christopher arrived in Luanda, the Angolan capital, Monday on the last stage of his five-nation African trip.

He is expected to hold talks with President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos and take part in a special meeting of Angola's Joint Committee, the body charged with implementing the country's peace accord between the government and former rebels. 

The agreement between Luanda and former anti-government rebels, UNITA, was signed Nov. 20, 1994 in the Zambian capital, Lusaka. It sets out measures to end the two decades of civil war and integrate part of UNITA's army, for instance, into the national army.

Implementation of the deal should feature in Christopher's talks with the Angolan authorities. He is also to table before them the U.S. proposal for an African crises response force.

The proposal is for the force to be manned by Africans and funded by the United States and some European countries.

The idea has received a mixed reaction from the countries visited by Christopher: Mali, Ethiopia, Tanzania and South Africa.

Mali and Ethiopia have supported the idea, but South Africa has expressed reservations, although it says the idea is good in principle.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

232 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


United States and Africa;
E.U. Supports South African Stand on African Peace Force


BYLINE: Lionel Williams , PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The European Union (E.U), will follow the stand taken by President Nelson Mandela of South Africa regarding the American proposal for the formation of an African crises intervention force.

This was confirmed Sunday by E.U. Trade Commissioner Joao de Deus Pinheiro in the Namibian capital of Windhoek where he arrived for the Southern African Development Community-European Union ministerial conference. 

He said the E.U. would support a United Nations, Organisation of African Unity or regional initiative for conflict resolution in Africa but not the proposed American initiative.

The U.S. proposal is for a force of between 5,000 and 10,000 manned by Africans and funded by the United States and its Western allies.

Conflict resolution is on the agenda of the SADC-EU conference, and Pinheiro said he would propose that this issue be tackled immediately to prevent any further eruption of violence in Africa.

"But the major players must be the Africans themselves, with the E.U. providing technical and financial support," he said.

Against this background, the U.S. proposal seems unlikely to succeed and SADC members are expected to express their further concerns at the Windhoek conference Monday and Tuesday.

SADC Executive-Secretary Kaire Mbuende says the community is concerned about the increasing militarization of peace processes. Members fear that peacekeeping could become a new forum for militarization and arms buildup.

Mbuende added that SADC countries had, through the decolonization process, developed skills for dealing with ethnic conflict and would now like a greater role in African conflict resolution.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


233 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


Science & Health;
Africa Loses Over 1 Million Hectares Of Forest A Year


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Africa loses some 1.3 million hectares of forest annually, a Nigerian environmentalist, Luka Achi, has said.

"Everyday, about 6,500 hectares of African savanna are being cleared," said Achi, general manager of Environmental Protection Authority in Nigeria's northern state of Kaduna. 

"Annual rituals of bush-burning during the dry season is taking its toll on the forest reserves," he said.

His comments were made Monday at the opening of a three-day sub-Saharan Africa forum for environmental journalists.

Journalists from Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Nigeria and Zambia are attending the forum.

Achi said the over-exploitation of African forests had resulted in droughts, land degradation and "concomitant spread of arid and desert lands."

In Kaduna state (northern Nigeria) alone, he said, "no fewer than 10 lorry loads of firewood" were carried to other states everyday.

Achi pointed out that another dangerous trend in industrial pollution was the dumping of toxic wastes in some African countries.

He warned that the trend pointed to "a deepening environmental crisis", especially for developing countries. All hands must be on deck to develop and implement policies to stem the crisis.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


234 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


Sudan;
Former Prime Minister Criticizes Sudan's Education Policies


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Former Sudanese prime minister, Sadeq al

Mahdi, has strongly criticized a higher education policy adopted by the government of Gen. Omar Bashir, saying it would lead to the destruction of higher education in the country.

Mahdi, whose government was toppled by Bashir in a bloodless coup d'etat in June 1989, was quoted Monday by the daily Al Rai Alaam as saying the new educational policies has "led to a catastrophe." 

When Bashir seized power, there were only three universities in the Sudan, in addition to the Khartoum-based Cairo University. The annual intake was about 3,500 students.

Two years after coming to power, Bashir increased the number of universities to 20, with an annual intake of over 33,000 students. But this has been at the expense of what some higher education experts called "quality" .

The new policy has also scrapped a system of free accommodation and feeding offered to students. Instead, most students are now obliged to pay high entry fees.

"Students are now facing the severest educational and living conditions ever," asserted the former premier, the only senior politician from the dissolved political parties to have stayed in the Sudan.

Mahdi, head of the outlawed Umma political party, said the new policy has made many a university lecturer leave the country. An average university professor salary, minus allowances, is currently put at about 40,000 Sudanese pounds a month (about 28.50 U.S. dollars).

He complained that lack of proper labs, libraries and housing has "made all live in a state of loss and calamity" at the Sudanese universities, the daily quoted him as saying.

Scores of PhD holders, teaching assistants, and lecturers are now quitting the country each week, mainly to go to Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


Cote d'Ivoire;
Emergency Plan for Abidjan


BYLINE: Kabie Boni, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire (PANA) - An emergency plan worked out by the Ivorian government allows Abidjan to recover its former cleanliness within six months.

Some 658 million cfa francs (500 cfa = 1 USD) has been released for the creation of a motorized health brigade, cleaning of gutters and equipping the town with public dust bins, latrines and rest rooms. 

From now on, Abidjan's big markets will be closed two days a week from 2.30 pm (14.30 GMT), to allow their cleaning up and maintenance.

Abidjan mayor, Ernest N'Koumbo Mobio, has also proposed the removal of street vendors.

A first operation, to remove the vendors, has already been carried out and a second one will be launched later this month. The two operations requires not less than 572 million cfa francs.

The fight against weeds growing in lagoon waters is also targeted. The floating vegetation is in fact a source of organic pollution and unbearable smells, particularly towards the lagoon bay where state house and the residences of several dignitaries are located.

To solve the problem of the weeds, two boats equipped with mechanical scythes which will be used, operated by the firm, Ash International.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


236 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


Science and Health;
Congolese Experts Adopt A New Forest Code


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Experts from the Congolese ministry of water

and forests and forest managers agreed Sunday in Brazzaville on the reform of the forest policy in Congo, by adopting a new forest code defining this policy.

The code, replacing the one adopted in January 1974, includes five types of contracts -- development contracts, development-improvement contracts, conversion-improvement contracts, industrial conversion contracts, and special permits.

According to the new policy, forest lease lasts a maximum 20 years, indefinitely renewable. However, development titles will be only given to persons of good morals, according to Congolese law, or persons of Congolese citizenship. 

Any contract holder is now compelled to earmark the number of trees to develop.

"This provision is very important in order to put an end to the forest managers' anarchy, who did not hesitate to cut trees beyond the limits of their properties", said water and forest department director, Rogobert Ebondzo.

The new forest code also establisheS a forest fund, financed by the sale of forest products, taxes and grants.

The fund will finance forestry and reforestation activities and the implementation of a forest development plan. The code also provides for a fine of 20.000 cfa (40 U.S. dollars) to 10 million cfa (20,000 dollars), for the anarchic destruction of forests.

The code recommends the conversion of forest products in the country.

"The benefit of the measure is that now exports will concern only finished or semi-finished goods and no longer raw materials.

"We therefore benefit from the increase in value contrary to the former 1974 code recommending a 50 percent conversion, which were not applied by forest managers", added Ebondzo.

The new forest code will be revised by the government before being submitted to the parliament for possible adoption.

Congo, which has about 20 million hectares of forest, exports annually 600, 000 cubic meters of rough timber and 400,000 cubic meters of eucalyptus logs.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


237 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


Mozambique;
Vehicle Of Murdered Anthropologist Recovered


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican police have recovered the

vehicle belonging to murdered Swiss anthropologist, Nicole Besenczon, according to a report on Radio Mozambique on Monday.

Besenczon was killed by car thieves on Sept. 30, in an attack mounted in broad daylight at Tsalala, about 15 kilometers (9.3 miles) from central Maputo.

Armenio Panguene, head of the information and planning department of the Maputo Provincial Police Command, told the radio that the vehicle, a four- wheel drive Toyota, was recovered last week in Matola, the industrial town that adjoins Maputo. 

Panguene said before recovering the vehicle, the police intercepted a group of suspected thieves who opened fire on the police unit. One of the gunmen was killed in the shootout while his companions escaped. He said the group may be connected with the death of the Swiss which is being investigated.

The police also claim to have captured three people who took part in the murder of the well-known Mozambican artist, Eugenio de Lemos, in March, 1995.

Lemos' body was discovered on a patch of wasteland near the Costa Do Sol beach. The motive for his murder, as in the case of Besenczon, was car theft.

Two of the suspects have been in detention for several months, but a police source said Monday the third, a man named as Carlitos Armacao, was arrested on Saturday night in the Maputo suburb of Jardim.

Armacao has confessed to the crime and told the police that shortly after the murder he went to South Africa, where he remained until a few weeks ago.

Meanwhile, on Monday morning armed robbers attacked a vehicle belonging to a soft drinks and confectionery company, Loumar, stealing some 55 million meticais (about 4,900 U.S. dollars), witnesses said.

They added that the attack took place just 100 meters (109 yards) from the factory gates, as the vehicle was heading to the bank to deposit the money.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
O.A.U. Cool On U.S. Idea Of An African Force


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) says it needs to consult widely with member states and the United Nations on the modalities and sustenance of a proposed All-African Crises Response Force before any commitments can be made.

While Western countries, including United States, France and Britain, had offered to finance the establishment of African conflict prevention force, many questions still remained unanswered, O.A.U. Assistant Secretary-General Ahmed Haggag said Monday

"There is need for more information and wide-ranging consultations on what Africa has to do, the modalities and deployment of such a force and immediate payments for the deployments," said Haggag, adding that peace-keeping operations were very costly.

He was addressing some 40 senior military officers from Southern Africa who are attending a two-week regional peace-keeping course at Zimbabwe's army headquarters. 

The O.A.U., which has played major roles in settlements of conflicts in Africa, says there are several constraints to its initiatives. These include prohibitive costs of deploying troops and their upkeep.

The United Nations, for example, spent 1.5 billion U.S. dollars on the Rwanda peace-keeping mission which, Haggag said, African states could not mobilize given a similar conflict.

There were also the legal limitation that arose from the membership of O.A. U. states in the United Nations, forcing them to adhere to the rule that international peace and security was the responsibility of the U.N. alone.

"We will need to coordinate all the proposals that have been made by the Western countries and then consult with member states while the U.N. has to answer all underlying questions," said Haggag.

However, he said the O.A.U. had in the past experienced a number of difficulties in mobilisation, logistics and funding of peace-keeping missions.

In view of the current limitations, the O.A.U. was concentrating on conflict prevention which, Haggag said, started with preventive diplomacy.

He said a database was being prepared on each of the 53 member countries featuring profiles of personalities who could serve as representatives of the O.A.U. secretary-general and provide information on elections monitoring, effects of conflict situation and initiatives on conflict resolutions.

Africa's conflicts have created the highest number of political refugees and displaced persons in the world, standing at seven million, which is 45 percent of the world refugee population.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


Zaire;
UN Human Rights Rapporteur Visiting Zaire


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Geneva - Roberto Garreton, the Commission on Human Rights' Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights in Zaire, began today a new visit to the country. Over the course of the two-week mission he will meet with several officials of the Zairean Government and query them on human- matters and on the ethnic conflict in the region of Kivu.

He also will meet with humanitarian organizations, human-rights groups, and various representatives of civil society. In addition, he will travel to the interior of the country, notably to Lubumbashi, Goma, and Bukavu. 

The latest report of Mr. Garreton, officially released this week, focuses on the situation in the northern Kivu region (E/CN.4/1997/6/Add.1). In this study, which followed a mission he carried out in July 1996 and included a trip to bordering Rwanda, he outlines the aggravation of ethnic conflicts in Kivu, in particular in the area of Masisi and Rutshuru. The Special Rapporteur reviews in the document the state of ethnic tension between Tutsis and Hutus installed in Zairean refugee camps which resulted in numerous cases of violence, pillaging, and the setting of fires in which the armed security forces of Zaire had participated.

Deploring the violence which had led to a great number of victims, injuries, breaches of security and damage to property, to violations of other rights, and to population displacements, and for which he cites as partly responsible the Zairean State, the Zairean political class, certain ethnic leaders, certain human-rights organizations, and the international community, the Special Rapporteur exhorts the State and the people of Zaire to show tolerance for Rwandan ethnic groups seeking sanctuary in Zaire, to find an adequate solution to the problem of nationality, and asks the international community not to ignore a situation which could worsen into an tragedy with results as grave as those encountered in Rwanda and Burundi.

The Special Rapporteur adds that he is concerned by a deterioration of ethnic relations in the south of Kivu and warns of a worsening of the human- rights situation in the east of Zaire. He further recommends that the Commission on Human Rights consider holding a special session to find solutions to ethnic tensions prevailing in the Great Lakes region of Africa.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

240 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


East Africa;
Weekly Roundup of Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2494 words


 

Nairobi - This is number 30 (7-13 October 1996) in a series of weekly reports from IRIN on general developments in the Great Lakes region. Sources for the information below include UN agencies, NGOs, other international organisations and media reports. IRIN issues these reports for the benefit of the humanitarian community, but accepts no responsibility as to the accuracy of the original sources.

Weekly Roundup of Main Events in the Great Lakes region

* Some 19,000 refugees fled from a camp near Uvira, eastern Zaire on Sunday following an attack on the camp by armed men, described by local media as " Zairean Tutsis". The gunmen are reported to have killed four refugees and injured nine others in Runingo camp. The refugees have mostly fled into two neighbouring refugee camps. As of late Sunday, there were no reports of movement into Rwanda. 

Since early September, the area around Uvira has been wracked by violent clashes between the Zairean army, local tribes and the Banyamulenge (ethnic Tutsis). The UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights in Zaire, Roberto Garreton, warned on Friday that violence would continue to escalate "if the international community failed to intervene to end government-sponsored massacres". Calling for a military observer force to be dispatched to the region, Garreton said that if the political situation in Zaire explodes, its consequences will be far greater even than the crises in Rwanda and Burundi.

The Rapporteur was sharply critical of Zaire which he said "has been directly involved in and has incited people to commit such violations and has not made sufficient effort either to prevent or restrain them". On Thursday, the UN Secretary-General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali called on Zairean authorities and the Banyamulenge to restore calm.

Zairean troops and local residents are said to have mounted "witch hunts" for the Banyamulenge in Uvira and Bukavu after the deputy Governor of South Kivu announced on 8 October that the estimated 300,000 Banyamulenge had one week to leave or be hunted down as rebels. Earlier in the week Zairean soldiers went on a looting spree in Uvira town.

The Zairean government has declared a state of war in South Kivu and has accused the Banyamulenge of attempting to destabilise Zaire, of raising an army and of attempting to secede from Zaire. The Zairean government also alleges that Rwanda and Burundi are supporting the Banyamulenge. Both countries have denied their involvement. About a dozen aid workers left Uvira on Sunday for a rest in Nairobi - the third such group to leave in less than a week.

Rwanda's President, Pasteur Bizimungu, says that Rwanda will allow Banyamulenge women and children into the country but will block the arrival of Banyamulenge men. "Zaire needs to accept that the Banyamulenge are also Zaireans", he said.

The situation in North Kivu, meanwhile, was reported to be calm over the weekend after last week's fighting. About 10,000 local people were internally displaced as result of attacks by the Bangilima on Bambu village and surrounding settlements. The displaced, mainly ethnic Hutus, took shelter in Rutshuru.

* US Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, told a news conference in Tanzania that it was safe for Hutu refugees to return to Rwanda and that their camps in Zaire and Tanzania should be closed. In a written statement issued after the news conference, Christopher said that the refugees should be enouraged to return home voluntarily. "We believe it is time to close the camps closest to the Rwandan border that pose the greatest security threat", he said. Zaire welcomed the call for the closure of the camps and said it was now up to international agencies to help avert forced repatriation.

* Regional leaders decided at the weekend to maintain sanctions against Burundi and gave its opposing factions one month to open talks or face further penalties. The Regional Summit, held in Arusha on Saturday, brought together the Presidents of Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, Tanzania and Zambia, the prime ministers of Ethiopia and Zaire and the Secretary-General of the Organisation of African Unity. Also present in Arusha were the former Tanzanian president, Julius Nyerere and observers from the US government, the European Union, the UN and South Africa.

The regional leaders rejected a US suggestion to ease sanctions, but agreed to send a team to Burundi to assess Buyoya's commitment to returning democratic order and holding peace talks. The team is due to arrive in Bujumbura on Tuesday. In its final communique, the leaders warned of " appropriate measures" against any group or faction that refused to participate in talks or placed obstacles in the way of the process. Buyoya and the leader of Burundi's National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), Leonard Nyangoma, have both written to Nyerere saying that they are ready to enter into open negotiations. However, the leader of Burundi's main Tutsi-dominated party, UPRONA, said on Sunday that the party was opposed to holding talks with Hutu rebels.

Since the beginning of sanctions on 31 July, Buyoya has met two of the three demands made by regional leaders - the reopening of parliament and the unbanning of political parties. The military regime is reported to have reacted angrily to the continuation of sanctions and has accused African leaders of "undermining peace and having a secret agenda". Buyoya was not invited to the Summit, but had appealed for an easing or lifting of sanctions. The embargo makes some exemptions for the delivery of humanitarian aid, including seeds and fertiliser, but blocks all imports and exports as well as commercial flights. No changes were announced to the sanctions during the week.

* The Burundi Army has accused rebels of killing about 40 villagers in the southwestern province of Bururi on Friday. The attack, described as one of the worst since the 25 July coup d'etat, is said to have taken place at Burambi, some 50 kilometres south of Bujumbura. The Army says that most of the victims were women, children and old people. Tens of thousands of local peple are reported to be displaced as a result of fighting in Bururi, and in the northern province of Kayanza.

* The OAU said on Thursday that it broadly welcomed the US proposal to create an inter-African Crisis Response Force. US Secretary of State, Warren Christopher presented the plan to OAU Ambassadors in Addis Ababa. The plan calls for a 10,000 strong inter-African force which would set up safe havens for civilians during conflicts on the continent. The OAU has asked for clarification on who would command the new force and has expressed concern about the issue of substainable (financial) support for it.

According to US sources, a number of African nations, including Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania and Mali, have accepted the principle of supplying troops, while the US, Belgium, Britain, Canada, and Ireland have promised financial or training support. Prior to the 25 July coup, Kenya had distanced herself from a proposal calling for a regional military peace-keeping force to intervene in Burundi.

* Rwanda's former Minister of Interior, Seth Sendashonga, denounced the " exportation of state terrorism" after two prominent Rwandans - a former Rwandan colonel and a businessman - were assassinated in Kenya. Colonel Theoneste Lizinde, who had defected from the RPF last December, and Augustin Bugilimfura, the owner of a print shop in Kigali, went missing in Nairobi on Sunday evening. Their bodies were found on Tuesday about 20 kilometres north of Nairobi. Both victims were shot in the mouth. Sendashonga, who was himself shot and wounded in Nairobi in February, said that the murders "exposed the bloodstained RPF regime".

* The United States announced on Friday a grant of US$ 650,000 for the UN International Tribunal to assist the Tribunal prosecute those accused of mass rape and other sexual crimes during the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. The Tribunal, based in Arusha, Tanzania has indicted so far 21 people accused on charges related to the genocide. The US Government has already contributed US$ 5 million to the Tribunal's costs.

* Blood donations in Kenya have fallen by 50% in 13 years and available stocks represent only a third of the national requirement. Statistics from the Blood Donor Centre indicate that the present national stock is 75,000 half litre units. The country's demand is estimated at 240,000 units, mainly for surgery, including for victims of road accidents and treatment of certain diseases. Some patients, mostly children, are reported to have died from lack of blood transfusions. The blood donor slump is attributed to fears by potential donors that they will be diagnosed HIV positive.

* Rebels of the West Nile Bank Front operating in Uganda attacked a missionary hospital and two High Schools at the weekend, looting equipment and damaging the properties. The Ugandan Army is reported to have killed some 25 rebels near the Zairean border after repulsing the attackers. Some 200 rebels are said to have been involved. Eye-witnesses said that more than 300 villagers fled the area during the attack. The raids come within the same week as the Lord's Resistence Army (LRA) rebels abducted 150 high school girls from Aboke in the northern region of the country. About 60 of the hostages escaped when the rebels came under attack from government forces. Sixty more were released on Friday. Uganda has accused Sudan of arming the rebels and Zaire of allowing them to operate from its territory.

* South African President Nelson Mandela was awarded Uganda's highest honour, the Pearl of Africa Order First Class when he visited Kampala for Wednesday's Independance celebrations.

* Uganda's Finance Minister has agreed that there were flaws in the implementation of Value Added Tax (VAT). A tax board to mediate between Uganda's Revenue Authority and taxpayers has been established following a week long strike by traders who demanded that the VAT (at 17%) introduced in July be reduced or scrapped.

* The Ugandan Cabinet approved a bill for a massive nationwide election of over 300,000 members of district and local councils. The council poll, which involves the filling of nine posts in each of the country's 29,000 villages, 4,251 parishes, 850 subcounties and municipalities, 169 counties and 39 districts, completes a process which started with presidential elections under a new constitution on 9 May.

* Low morale amongst Uganda's farmers has contributed to a country-wide shortage of staple crops and has sent prices soaring. In Kampala, beans are reported to have risen from US$0.3 per kilogram to US$0.7. A kilogram of maize has doubled from US$ 2 to US$ 4. Prices of both commodities are reported to be higher outside Kampala. The national secretary of the Uganda Commercial Farmers Association says that some farmers, demoralised by the impending sale of their properties, opted last season not to produce the country's two staples. The sale of the farms is part of a bid by the Government to recover government loans.

* Tanzania is to receive a soft loan next year of US$ 100 million in balance of payment support from the World Bank. The decision, announced in Dar-es-Salaam last week, was taken at a Washington meeting which expressed satisfaction with Tanzania's economic reforms.

* The UN's Consolidated Fund Raising Document for the Great Lakes has helped secure 60.9% of the funds required for 1996, according to data received from DHA's Financial Tracking System. A shortfall of $227 is still outstanding.

* Despite a generally improved crop and food supply situation in much of sub-Saharan Africa, thirteen African countries are suffering from continued food shortages and emergencies. A special report released by the UN's Food and Agricultural Organisation (FAO) on 10 October says that Burundi, Liberia and Somalia have been hardest hit. Despite a good overall cereal harvest, large numbers of people in Tanzania are reported to be in need of food aid following localised crop failures. The FAO report, which cites civil strife, displacement of rural population and economic sanctions as the main causes threatening food supplies in Burundi, says the situation in Burundi is likely to deteriorate further in coming months. The report comes just weeks in advance of the World Food Summit to be held at FAO headquarters in Rome from 13 to 17 November 1996.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

241 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 14, 1996


East Africa;
Arusha Summit Reaffirms Burundi Stance


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Nairobi - Following is the Joint Communique of The Third Arusha Regional Summit on Burundi, as transcribed by the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network.

1. At the invitation of President Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania, Presidents Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda, Prime Ministers Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia and Kengo wa Dondo of Zaire met on 12th October, 1996 in Arusha, Tanzania to review the situation in Burundi after the imposition of economic sanctions.

2. Also participating in the Regional Summit were the Minister of External Relations of Cameroon, Hon. Ferdinand Leopold Oyono, representing the current Chairman of the OAU, the Secretary General of the OAU, Dr. Salim Ahmed Salim and the Facilitator of the Burundi Peace Talks, Mwalimu Julius Nyerere. 

3. The Regional Summit received and took note of the report of the Ministerial Technical Committee on the implementation and co-ordination of the economic sanctions imposed on 31st July, 1996 in the effort to obtain a peaceful settlement of the Burundi crisis.

4. The Summit reaffirmed the commitment and solidarity of the countries of the region in their ongoing efforts to achieve lasting peace and stability in Burundi through a negotiated settlement.

5. The Regional Summit expressed its satisfaction with the implementation of the sanctions and commended the countries of the region and other implementing countries for the cooperation and cohesion shown in applying the sanctions to ensure the attainment of the intended objective. It also commended the support extended to the countries of the region by the international community and in particular the UN through its Resolution 1072 (1996) and the OAU.

6. The Summit reiterated that the objective of the sanctions is to serve as an effective means of securing a negotiated settlement between all the parties to the conflict in Burundi in an effort to avert a human disaster in the country. This should also remain a common objective of the international community as a whole and deserves its continued support.

7. The Regional Summit also took note of the exemptions already granted in respect of fertilisers and vegetable seeds in recognition of the steps taken by the Buyoya regime towards meeting the conditions set by the Arusha II Summit. It also undertook to further respond positively should the regime enter into negotiations with all parties to the conflict in the context of the Arusha II Summit. It commended the work of the Regional Sanctions Co- ordinating Committee and directed the latter to ensure the speedy implementation of decisions already taken or to be taken with respect to exemptions on humanitarian grounds.

8. The Summit emphasized that the central requirement of the Arusha II Summit was unconditional negotiations of all parties to the conflict and armed factions inside and outside the country. The Summit decided that these negotiations in the context of the Mwanza Peace Process should start within a period of one month from the date of this communique. The preparatory phase of these negotiations should commence immediately. The Summit further expressed its readiness to take appropriate measures against any group or faction that refuses to participate in the negotiations or places obstacles in the way of the peace process.

9. The Summit reiterated that sanctions were not imposed for the benefit of, or to the detriment of any group or faction. The imposition of sanctions was intended, inter-alia, to exert the necessary pressure in order to achieve the political objective of a negotiated and peaceful solution to the conflict.

10. The Summit was briefed by the Facilitator on the contacts and efforts he has made towards promoting negotiations since Arusha II Summit. In this connection, the Summit was informed by the Facilitator that he has now received a written communication from Major Buyoya confirming the latter's commitment to enter into negotiations with CNDD and all other armed factions which are ready to negotiate. In view of this development, the Summit decided to send a Ministerial delegation to Bujumbura to follow up on this development, so as to enable the countries of the region to evaluate the situation and take appropriate action.

11. The Regional Summit expressed its appreciation to President Mkapa, his Government and the people of Tanzania for hosting the Summit and extending the usual hospitality to the Heads and delegation.

Done at Arusha, Tanzania, on 12th October 1996.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 441125 Fax: +254 2 448816 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

Africa News


October 15, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Gold Production Falls Slightly


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Gold production in Zimbabwe fell slightly in September compared with the same period in 1995, but total output in the first nine months of the year showed a slight increase of over 2 percent.

An official at the Chamber of Mines of Zimbabwe told said on Tuesday production in September reached 1,925.25 kg (4,245 pounds) worth 35.1 million U.S. dollars, compared with 2,161 kg (4,765 pounds) mined the same month in 1995, then worth 23.1 million dollars.

But in the first nine months of 1996, 18.43 tons of gold worth 227 million dollars were produced, whereas in the corresponding period in 1995, 18.031 tons, then worth 188 million dollars were mined. 

Output up to the end of August totalled 16.504 tons valued at 201 million dollars, which was up from the 15.87 tons mined in the same period in 1995, then valued at 160 million dollars.

The official said production could have been affected by the "fairly static" gold price, which had not moved much in both United States and Zimbabwe dollar terms.

In 1995, gold, the country's second largest foreign currency earner after tobacco, brought 260 million dollars from exports, while output exceeded 24 tons for the first time in five decades.

The country's leading gold producers are Falcon Gold, Rio Tinto, Lonrho Zimbabwe, Anglo American Corporation and Ashanti Goldfields.

Zimbabwe is Africa's third largest gold producer after South Africa and Ghana, and is ranked number 17 in the world.

The official also said it was too early to assess the success of a recent scheme introduced by the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe to pay large gold producers in foreign currency.

Meanwhile, the official said production of other minerals in the first seven months of 1996 showed a slight increase, particularly nickel, copper, asbestos and ferro-chrome.

"These all seem to be doing reasonably well, like nickel considering that it had some price problems," he said.

He also said the mining industry, which in 1995 produced minerals worth over 500 million dollars, was trying to absorb recent increases in input costs.

Major input items which went up in the last two months included wages and salaries, electricity and fuel.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


243 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 15, 1996


Business and Finance;
Rice Business Falls In Benin As Nigeria Resumes Imports


BYLINE: Celestine Okonkwo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

COTONOU, Benin (PANA) - Businessmen in Benin Republic are currently counting their losses over Nigeria's decision to lift the ban on the importation of rice, according to an investigation by the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN).

The situation is such that 'La Nation', a daily newspaper in Benin, wrote in its current edition that importers in the country had a "stock" of over 35, 000 tons of unsold parboiled rice in their various warehouses.

Another 20,000 tons of the favorite Nigerian staple have also been cleared from the ships that brought the commodity into Benin. 

According to the paper, "if nothing is done to cushion the effects of the action taken by the Nigerian government, it will not only slow down imports to the country, but will equally cause the country to lose about 10 billion f cfa," (about 20 million U.S. dollars).

The report noted that the assertion that "when the Nigerian economy is afflicted with catarrh, Republic of Benin will sneeze" was correct.

"It is clear that the loss of about 5.4 billion f cfa earnings currently being realized by Beninese importers of the commodity, will not only bring about a loss to the country's shipping agents and the customs, but it will also affect the Republic of Togo," La Nation said.

The paper said that because of the strategic position of Benin Republic, it had been realizing enormous profits from the re-exportation of rice to Nigeria.

According to official figures, Benin has been importing over 200,000 tons of rice every year, 85 percent of which go to Nigeria, the remaining 15 percent represent the white rice consumed locally and exported to neighboring Niger and Burkina Faso.

The Benin customs realizes about 9 billion f cfa, while its ports authority gets about 547 million f cfa and the transit company, (Sobema) realizes 768 million f cfa from the transactions every year (500 f cfa = 1 USD).

The agents as well as transit organizations from the country smile to the banks with as much as 300 million and 390 million f cfa respectively per annum from the rice business with Nigeria, according to the statistics.

La Nation said that businessmen in Benin, who have been affected by the slur in the rice business, had urged their government to take some measures to save the business in the country.

The businessmen are asking the government to reduce customs tariff from the present 21.18 percent to 9.08 percent, which will still leave the country with earning of about 5 billion f cfa yearly.

Informed sources said that the businessmen, who had already completed their customs formality forms, were urging the government to refund the Valued Added Tax they paid for the goods or convert it to duty for future imports.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


244 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 15, 1996


Ghana;
Ghana To Spend 240 Million Dollars On Ports Rehabilitation


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

TEMA, Ghana (PANA) - The Ghana Ports and Harbors Authority, (GPHA), will

soon embark on a 240-million-dollar rehabilitation project to improve services at the Tema and Takoradi ports.

Speaking to journalists on an industrial tour of Tema, Nestor Galley, acting director of Ports, said the rehabilitation will include the dredging of the Tema Port from the present depth of 9 meters to about 15 meters (10 to 16 yards). 

The rehabilitation is to enable bigger vessels to berth at the port in line with the government's GATEWAY policy which is to make the country the main entry into the West African market by foreign investors.

A free port and an export processing zone have been created in Tema to promote the GATEWAY programme.

Galley said a container terminal will be developed in Tema.

In Takoradi, two specialized dry bulk berths will be built to support the expected increase in the export of manganese and bauxite.

Galley said GPHA also plans to develop 500 meters (547 yards) quay with three new berths for handling container and mixed cargoes for both exports and imports.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 15, 1996


Mozambique;
Chissano Discusses Crime With Diplomats


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican president Joaquim Chissano

has met with diplomats to discuss the alarming rise in violent crime, particularly in Maputo, the capital.

The president's press attache, Antonio Matonse, told Tuesday the state news agency, AIM, that Chissano had met Monday the visiting deputy general director of the Swiss Cooperation Office, Rudolf Dannecker, and diplomats from Switzerland, the United States, Holland, South Africa and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). 

The diplomatic community in Maputo was particularly outraged by the brutal murder 30 Sept. of Swiss anthropologist, Nicole Besenczon, killed by a gang of car thieves who made off with her Toyota four-wheel drive vehicle. The car was recovered by the police last week in the town of Matola, but the murderers have not yet been arrested.

Matonse said Chissano and the diplomats met for more than two hours, and that the meeting was characterized by "frankness, a frontal approach, and a desire to go forward in partnership to find solutions to the crime wave."

The meeting, he added, "made an exhaustive analysis of the crime situation, of the state of the Mozambican police, and of the support the international community can provide to train the police and enhance its skills."

The diplomats "were encouraged by the measures that the Mozambican government is taking to improve the public security situation," said Matonse. "They reaffirmed their support for the implementation of the government's plan in this area."

He said that the donor countries had stated their willingness to support a programme of police training through the UNDP.

Africa News


October 15, 1996


Arts;
African American Author Blasts Racist Writers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Racist writers are largely responsible for

portraying Africa negatively, an African American writer charged Tuesday.

In an interview, at a workshop in Harare for Zimbabwean and American writers, publishers and booksellers, Ishmael Reed said many western novelists still painted Africa as a jungle and dark continent. 

Reed said Africans were not winning international awards on their writings like the Nobel Prize for literature because of racists who blocked such moves, adding that he would make a personal effort to introduce work by African writers to the American readership. The United States Information Service cultural affairs officer, Paul Patin, conceded Americans were ignorant about real contemporary African literature.

Patin said it was hard to get literature by African writers in the United States.

He said the American publishers and writers attending the workshop had resolved to help their Zimbabwean counterparts penetrate the American market.

"Zimbabweans still have a lot to learn about how to adequately market themselves in the states and I am happy the Americans have agreed to do that," he said.

However, he urged Zimbabweans to expose themselves to African American literature to learn more about problems faced by blacks in America.

The three-day workshop, dubbed Corridors of Culture - From the Muse to the Market Place, was organized by the U.S. information service. It aims to find ways of making the writing and publishing industry in Zimbabwe more viable.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 15, 1996


Uganda;
Rebels Kill Army Captain, Burn UN Vehicles


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) have killed four people, including a Ugandan army captain, and burnt 14 vehicles used by the United Nations and Lutheran World Federation in an attack Monday in north-western Uganda.

State-owned daily, The New Vision, reported Tuesday that the wives of two soldiers were killed in the attack at Pakele in Adjumani sub-district.

"They temporarily overran our detachment in the dawn attack. This morning we sent reinforcement of gun ships which sent them in disarray," confirmed Maj. Gen. Salim Saleh, commander of the Uganda Peoples' Defence Forces (UPDF) operations in northern Uganda. 

A spokesperson of the U.N. High Commissioner for refugees in Kampala also confirmed Tuesday the attack on the U.N. compound in Pakele.

"Yes, the place was attacked at around 5.45 a.m. (2.45 GMT), but no U.N. staff was killed or injured. But a lot of property was destroyed and looted. Most of the vehicles destroyed were hired by the U.N.," said the spokesman. The rebels also grabbed the radios from the vehicles which they later set ablaze.

UNHCR in Adjumani caters for an estimated 100,000 refugees from Sudan. President Yoweri Museveni is expected to visit northern Uganda Tuesday, his second visit this month.

Salim said the rebels crossed from neighboring Gulu district, the heart of the insurgency for the last 10 years.

He said the army has since occupied the area and are pursuing the rebels. " They are desperately looking for a new base because the army is taking control of Acholi".

Acholi is comprised of Gulu and Kitgum districts. For years, the rebels of Joseph Kony's LRA have operated in the two districts.

Last week, the rebels attacked St. Mary's College Aboke, in the neighboring district of Apac, and abducted about 150 girls. About 20 of the girls still remain in rebel captivity.

Africa News


October 15, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Policy On Landmines Contradicts Christopher's Remarks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - United States Secretary of State Warren Christopher said Monday he was "deeply shocked" by the number of Angolans maimed by anti- personnel mines.

"It is urgent to get rid of all anti-personnel landmines in Angola," he said. 

His comments were made at the destruction of 54 tonnes of mines at the Angolan National Police Academy in Luanda.

Christopher, who arrived in the country Monday, was told that between 150 and 200 Angolans died each week from landmine blasts.

The United States government, under President Bill Clinton, ironically opposed a recent international draft convention proposal to completely ban the production of landmines.

Christopher, however, said that the United States would continue to help Angola in clearing these mines and advocated for the end of their production worldwide.

During the cold war between East and West, and which pitted the administration in Luanda against pro-West anti-government forces; the United States backed Unita while the Soviet Union, Cuba and many African states backed the Luanda government of President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos.

During the two decades of civil war and the war of independence against Portugal, hundreds of thousands of mines were laid across Angola.

Following the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, the United States eventually established diplomatic relations with its erswhile enemy.

"Without doubt, the Angolan tragedy has helped the world understand the dangers anti-personnel landmines hold for the world," he said.

United States and Africa;
Christopher Describes Addis Talks


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa - United States Secretary of State Mr. Warren Christopher made an official visits here recently as part of his five-nation tour to help continue Africa's progress towards democracy and economic development.

In a press conference he gave to local and international newsmen, at the Addis Ababa Hilton, US Secretary of State Warren Christopher said he was impressed by the openness with which prime Minister Meles was engaged in their "extensive discussion". The Secretary of State also expressed his appreciation to the Ethiopian people, who he said were showing great courage in their efforts to reconstruct the country, to achieve peace and democracy.

The secretary of State called on all active political parties and the free press to actively participate in the democratization process assuring that the United States will continue to provide its support to the democratization process the country is embarking upon.

During his meeting with Prime Minister Meles, the Secretary of State said he stressed the importance of respecting human rights and the need for a strong support for the free press.

Ethiopia;
Ethiopian News Roundup


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

SEBETA - Opening a twenty day workshop organized to train coordinators of some 124 community skill training centres (CSTCs) in Oromia Regional State Ato Mulugeta Amena, head of the Oromia Bureau of Education noted yesterday that the new education and training policy underlies the importance of adult education in order to attain the overall objective of the education system.

According to Ato Mulugeta, in order to achieve these objectives, the Education Bureau of Ormoia drawn up "different strategies of which expanding CSTCs in rural areas, conducting trainings in acquiring various skills and training of trainers are the major ones.

With the aim "to strengthen and expand adult education in the region", the bureau was last year engaged in the tasks of preparing over 230,000 copies of eight types of adult education materials which were dispatched to 720 centres, the bureau head noted.

Speaking on the importance of functional literacy to adult trainees which are due to be enrolled in the training centres as of this year Ato Mulugeta said that equipping them merely with basic reading and writing skills was not the interest of the bureau. According to him what counted more was training them in other basic skills in order to help them "improve their life-style and thereby contribute their part to their 

 

Ministry organizes workshop for construction executives

DEBREZEIT (ENA) - A workshop on the implementation of construction projects aimed at helping curb problems encountered and devise a better mechanism for successful construction undertakings in regions got under way yesterday at the Debre Zeit Management Institute.

The workshop at which construction executives of all regions are participating has the objective of introducing to regions a uniform working system capable of implementing the huge capital allocated for the sector.

According to Ato Birhanu Tamirat, Vice-Minister of public Works and Urban Development, the workshop will discuss such topics as plan designing, construction, administration of contracts, price analysis, bids, permissions and document preparations.

Ato Girma Abebe, contract administration, control and registration department head said on the occasion problems in the construction sector would involve the owner, the advisor and the contractor, adding the solution is always in these three working together.

The workshop was organized by the Ministry of Works and Urban Development.

State media urged to avoid dependency on subsidy

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - State-owned mass media should avoid dependence on subsidy and work on competitive basis, general manager of the recently established Journalists Training Centre said.

Opening a workshop yesterday, Ato Tsehaye Debalkew said the government media should be able to raise their own means of subsistence with a view to freeing themselves from dependence on government subsidy.

The information the mass media disseminate to the society should touch upon the problems the society faces and contribute to the economic growth of the country, he said.

"Government media should not wait advertisements to come to their office, but must go out and solicit as to augment their income," he said.

The workshop being held at the training centre would discuss mainly on the nature and meaning of the market economy system.

Journalists and marketing experts drawn from the Ethiopian Radio, Television, Press Agency, Ethiopian News Agency and the private media are in attendance.

Joint meeting

Opening the joint meeting of House of Peoples" Representatives and the House of the Federation, President Negasso Gidada of the FDRE urged members of both houses to discharge their legislative role with due quality and caution. President Negasso said it is expected of both houses to timely issue vital proclamations and work with vigour to discharge responsibilities in facilitating the economic programme of the country.

The president assured members of both houses that regional governments, the Federal Government as well as the general public are on their side in implementing proclamations to be issued this year.

Meanwhile, opening the 3rd ordinary session of the House of Federation, speaker of the House, Woizero Almaz Meko, said that the House is expected to discharge its onerous constitutional duties responsibly and with sense of mutual trust. Woizero Almaz noted that the role of the House should not be limited to helping solve problems after they transpire but also in forestalling them by devising prevention measures in anticipation.

In another development, Members of the Houses of Peoples' Representatives and the Federation said that the workshops they had attended were meant to introduce them to democratic working procedures which has helped them learn means and ways of discharging their public responsibilities.

Speaker of the House, Ato Dawit Yohannes said policy makers and legislators, should exert greater efforts to broaden out their understanding on legislative processes.

Woizero Almaz Meko, speaker of the House of the Federation, in her part said earlier opening the workshop that the principal objective of the workshop was to acquaint parliamentarians with democratic practices and to widen their awarenesses.

Decline in food production

The discrepancy between demographic growth and agricultural production in the past 20 years in Africa has resulted in the decline of per capita food production, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said in a statement it issued in connection with the World Food Day to be observed tomorrow.

The manager said a bid document has been sold to contractors to select one from among many who can undertake the construction of a steam-engined turbine believed to increase the present electric power by 60 mega watt.

Efforts are being made to facilitate the reconstruction of the Tis(Smoke) Abay and the Koka hydro electric power stations as well as the Alto Langano Electric Power Station and to finalize the study of the Tis Abay second station to alleviate the problem of electric power supply, he added.

Acting manager Yousuf told the Ethiopian News Agency the problem of occasional power interruption in Addis and other towns caused by falling old pylons and electric cables can be solved very soon by importing transformers with money obtained from the governments of Netherlands and Japan in loan.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


251 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 15, 1996


United States and Africa;
Christopher: Comply with Angolan Accord


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Luanda - Remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher at a demining site on October 14.

Nearly two years ago, after decades of war and the loss of half a million lives, Angolans decided that enough was enough. The signing of the Lusaka Protocol in November, 1994, gave the people of Angola their best chance for peace in a generation. 

Today, the largest current U.N. peacekeeping mission is deployed here in Angola. Under the leadership of Special Representative Beye, UNAVEM III has been a success.

Much has been accomplished. But with UNAVEM leaving in a matter of months, it is imperative that both sides move rapidly to meet their obligations.

UNITA must fulfill its pledge to send its remaining Generals to Luanda, to provide 26,000 volunteers for the combined armed forces, and to assure the free movement of goods and peoples throughout the country. The government must recover weapons from civilians and ensure that the UNITA soldiers it integrates have real jobs, security, and respect.

Political integration is also essential. I welcome the proposals UNITA has recently put forward on the government of national unity. I urge the government to ensure that UNITA has the resources and freedom it needs to make the transition from an armed movement to a political party. And I call on President Dos Santos and Dr. Savimbi to fulfill their commitment to meet in Luanda as soon as possible.

Above all let me stress, as the Security Council made clear last Friday, that the international community expects full compliance with the peace accord. It will not tolerate any resumption of conflict. The United States is committed to a long-term partnership with Angola and we will pursue that partnership with all those who maintain their commitment to peace.

In the past year, the United States has provided $100 million for programs to reform Angola's economy, to demobilize soldiers, to build democratic institutions, and to help the innocent victims of the war.

An unprecedented effort is also under way to clear Angola of landmines. Today, there are more landmines in Angola than people. Between 150 and 200 Angolans are killed every week; millions more walk this country's roads and farm its lands in fear. With support from USAID, American organizations like the Vietnam Veterans of America, Save the Children, and CARE are helping Angolans rid themselves of this scourge. President Clinton is also committed to a global ban on anti-personnel mines. Angola's tragedy has helped awaken the world to the urgency of this goal.

Angola's future can be bright. It has immense natural and human resources. Angola should join the rest of southern Africa in moving toward democracy, peace, and prosperity. Angola's friends will stay engaged to help make that happen so long as Angola's leaders take the tough but necessary steps they have pledged to take.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


252 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 15, 1996


Sudan;
Beneficiaries Ignored: The OLS Review Report


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

London - The long awaited report of the United Nations Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) review team was finally published last month. Any of our readers who may have already read the report could be forgiven for feeling that it is not worth the cost of undertaking the review.

Seasoned observers who have come to know the machinations of such international operations will not be surprised by the report and will have expected little better. Such reviews usually vindicate the organisation concerned and provide mitigation for each of its shortcomings or failures. This report of the OLS review team has proved to be little different. 

The conclusion of the report is that, on balance, OLS has done a good job and should continue doing much the same thing. A short paragraph of page 263 states that:

"Some fundamental criticisms of OLS have been made in the review. It should be stated at the outset, however, that the review team believes that the OLS should continue."

Whilst the entire review is punctuated with criticisms of the operation, these criticisms are also always justified by some mitigating evidence. An example of this is one page 220, where OLS and the UN are excused the responsibility for failing to protect the displaced people of Southern Sudan who live in subhuman conditions in Northern Sudan:

"The analysis of OLS Northern Sector suggests that a major failure of international and UN policy has occurred, particularly with regard to the crisis of internal displacement. The fundamental issue of protection for the large, internally-displaced population within Sudan has remained unaddressed. The origins of this failure are linked to a number of factors, including the lack of clarity with regard to the mandates of different UN agencies in applying the existing international instruments for the protection of war- displaced populations globally, and the poorly-developed contractual framework which guides UN operations in the Northern Sector. In effect, the UN is constrained by the sovereignty of the Government of Sudan from confronting disaster-producing policies which create vulnerability among those displaced by the war.

"While in part reflecting managerial and organisational problems, the UN policy failure in the Northern Sector represents a more fundamental flaw in the conceptualisation of chronic political emergencies, and especially the contradiction of demanding that the UN ensure the neutrality of its operations in a context where a sovereign government is also a party to the conflict. In this regard, the policy failure on the Northern Sector does not just lie with the UN, but with the international community in general.

Sovereignty is one of the areas in which the review fails to impress. Members of the review team included people who know Sudan well enough to appreciate that Sudanese sovereignty is at best questionable and it was the contesting of this sovereignty in the South which led to OLS being created in the first place. Some members of the review team have risked their lives in Sudan in the recent past to deliver relief assistance to Southern Sudan in spite of Khartoum's claim to sovereignty over the region. To suggest that the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime be permitted to use sovereignty as a way f flouting agreement over relief assistance in the South, or amongst the displaced Southern Sudanese communities in Northern Sudan, would be to sentence the entire population to the whims of a regime whose policies towards the people are genocidal, to say the least.

Sovereignty has not prevented the UN from operating in other parts of the world independently of the the government when a government has deliberately targeted a community for genocide or ethnic cleansing. Such communities have been afforded international protection from their own governments. Recent examples include Rwanda, Burundi, and Bosnia. If the the NIF regime is allowed to use the sovereignty card in Southern Sudan, it will make the work of the OLS that much more meaningless. Instead of recommending its continuation, the review team should have recommended that the OLS close down and give the regime in Khartoum its sovereign reign over the people.

In many respects the review is too voluminous, giving too much information and detail which is not entirely relevant to the central issues which need addressing. Evidence has been presented in an unstructured and incoherent way, so that it is difficult to follow related items and subject matter. The net result of this layout is that the reader finds it more difficult to discern whether or not a comment is meant as a criticism of OLS.

Over the years the Gazette has been quite critical of the OLS over the way it has allowed the NIF regime to manipulate the original OLS mandate and turn it against the principles and the objectives for which it was established. In the belief that a comprehensive review might recognize this and work to return OLS to its original mandates, the Gazette welcomed the establishment of the review team. The terms of reference of the review team raised these issues:

"To analyze the OLS mandate, its appropriateness in creating maximum access to populations in need and ensuring respect for fundamental humanitarian principles.

"To assess the effectiveness of OLS' coordination structures, in particular the relationship between the UN, donors, NGO and Sudanese Counterparts.

"To assess the efficiency of OLS' modus operandi, identifying constraints and achievements of OLS' various activities in:

* the provision of appropriate, timely and cost-effective relief assistance to populations in need;

* the provision of programmmes contributing to the promotion of self- sufficiency and food security;

* the efficiency of OLS operational support to programme delivery."

The review report ignores these main objectives for setting up the OLS review! Not a single voice of those who are affected by the war and whom the OLS is supposed to serve is heard in this report. In stead of providing a voice for the affected population, the review team legitimizes the patronizing attitude of relief agencies that think that once a person is hungry, he no longer knows what he wants, has no voice and should be fed what others decide they should be given.

Who, for instance, are the "counterparts" mentioned in the terms of reference for the review team? Are they the government in Khartoum and the SPLA? Was it too difficult for the review team to speak to some of the communities who had been served by the OLS over the years and to include a small passage in the words of these people themselves?

The review team has not really faced up to the criticisms of OLS made by the Gazette and others over the years. The answers provided are substantial and leave a lot to be desired. Then, again, the review was not intended to placate this publication but was designed to ensure the continued support for the OLS from the international donor community.

Issue cover date: October 1996.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
