270 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 17, 1996


Arts and Culture;
French-language Novel Wins 1996 Noma Award


BYLINE: The Noma Award for Publishing in Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Oxford,England - Kitia Toure's novel "Destins Paralleles", published in 1995 by Nouvelles Editions Ivoiriennes, Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, has been named as the winner of the 1996 Noma Award for Publishing in Africa.

This is the second time in the Award's sixteen-year history that the winning book has been published in Cote d'Ivoire, and the third time that a novel in the French language has won. The book was cited by the jury as "a remarkable subtle and sophisticated novel, extremely original both in concept and construction.

The vigor of the writing and use of language is executed with tremendous confidence. It is a book about Africa in a very profound sense: traditional values and approaches to the resolving of problems are explored; and the impact of the West is portrayed with more discernment than is usual." 

The novel constructs the narrative development around three characters with the same name and identical life backgrounds, but with divergent fortunes (the "parallel destinies" of the title). The three namesakes, Ki-Ca, are a ten-year-old poor orphan, an ambitious student, and an ambitious, unscrupulous politician. The web of interactions between them is brought into a single poignant focus at the end of the novel. The author portrays a cross- section of Ivorian society, focusing on the contrast between the dire conditions of the urban poor eking out an existence in the shanty towns, set against the blatant corruption and decadence of the ruling elite. the sharp socio-political satire is illuminated with subtle irony, and the sustained use of the monologue form enables the author to confront his social theme from a new, multiple perspective. It is an intellectual novel, but firmly based in reality; a political novel at the level at which society is at the heart of politics; and is sustained by an imaginative verve and inventiveness.

The award will be presented by H.E. The President of Ghana, on Saturday 9 November 1996, during the 1st. Ghana International Book Fair, in Accra. In 1996 the value of the award has doubled to US$10,000.

"Women & Geometry in Southern Africa. Some Suggestions for Further Research" by Paulus Gerdes, published in 1995 by the Universidade Pedagogica in Mozambique, was awarded "Special Commendation". The book was praised by the jury as "combining in an ingenious way the study of geometry with that of the visual arts, presenting an important challenge and stimulant to the future of mathematics and education in Africa. It demystifies ethnomatics in relation to gender and race, and erases the borders between mathematics and popular culture as experienced in the work and crafts of women in southern Africa. the book's importance lies in its prospective impact on the education of African women in mathematics".

A record number of 176 titles, from 72 African publishers, in 19 countries, were submitted for the 1996 competition.

The Noma Award jury is chaired by Walter Bgoya from Tanzania, one of Africa's most distinguished and respected publishers, with wide knowledge of both African and international publishing. The other members of the jury are Adewale Maja-Pearce, Nigerian writer and critic; and two new jury members in 1996 - Kay Raseroka, University Librarian of the University of Botswana, a children's book expert, and head of the African section of the International Federation of Librarian Associations (IFLA); and Dr. Thandike Mkandawire, a noted social scientist and until recently head of the Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) in Senegal. The fifth member of the jury is Mary Jay, who succeeded Hans Zell in 1996 as Secretary of the Managing Committee (the jury).

In considering the record number of entries in 1996, the jury considered various issues about future directions of the award. To encourage publishers to be responsibly selective in submitting titles, they decided that, as from 1997, publishers would be limited to three entries each year. The maximum of three entries can be made at the publisher's choice between the three eligible categories: scholarly and academic, literature (including works of criticism), and children's books.

The jury also noted with concern the continuing deterioration in production standards of many entries. Whilst they are conscious of the difficult manufacturing conditions prevailing in many parts of Africa, they nonetheless considered that standards in many cases were unacceptably low and not accounted for by lack of facilities. Whilst the jury has always paid regard to standards of production, this aspect will in future receive more critical attention.

The jury also single out four further books for "Honourable Mention". They are (in alphabetical order by author):

"The Law of Interpretation in Ghana" (exposition & critique), by S.Y. Bimpong-Buta (Accra: Advanced Legal Publication, 1995)

"Rope of Sand. The Rise and Fall of the Zulu Kingdom in the Nineteenth Century," by John Laband (Jeppestown, South Africa: Jonathan Ball Publishers, 1995).

"Ways of Dying" (novel) by Zakes Mda (Cape Town: Oxford University Press, Southern Africa, 1995).

"Presence of the Earth" (new poems) by Stephen Watson (Cape Town: David Philip publishers, 1995).


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 17, 1996


Sudan;
War and Politics: Regime Feeling Pressure All Round


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

London - Whilst the battlefields of the South have been quiet over the past month, the streets of Khartoum have witnessed almost continual demonstrations against the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime. The regime's security forces have become so alarmed at the scale of the demonstrations that they have started to disperse them by using live ammunition.

For three days in early September demonstrators protested against the policies of the regime. Six demonstrators were killed by live ammunition fired into the crowd from point blank range and scores were wounded. However, two of the regime's security agents were identified in the crowd by the protesters and they were hacked to death by the angry mob. Only heavy rains which resulted in widespread flooding across Khartoum brought an end to the demonstrations. Four of the six dead were named as: Karar Ali Mohamed, an eighteen year old bakery worker; Afaf Mohamed Adam, a female student at East Nile University; Huda Abdalla, a female student at the University of Technology; and Osman Mohamed Hussein, a student at Khartoum University. 

The Police Factor - To avoid the blame for the eight deaths being attributed to its own security forces, the NIF regime attempted to place the blame on the police force. This angered the police authorities so much that they carried out swift investigation which revealed that all the ammunition issued to its officers on the days in question had been accounted for and not one shot had been fired by a police officer. Eighty police officers refused to be made into the regime's scapegoats and stayed at home, declining to go back to duty. A regime spokesperson backtracked on the original statement, saying that there had been a misunderstanding over the role of the police.

The Port Sudan Factor - It seems that the regime prevented a coup d'etat from taking place in Port Sudan in late August or early September and blamed the opposition National Democratic Alliance (NDA) for fomenting the trouble. Rumours that eleven officers had been executed in the aftermath of the coup swept the country in early September and were given credence by the fact that Major Ibrahim Shams El Din had been dispatched to Port Sudan to sort things out for the regime.

Major Ibrahim Shams El Din is the regime's trouble shooter and has been responsible for some of its worst atrocities. He was responsible for the execution of twenty-eight army officers in 1990 after another alleged coup attempt. The twenty-eight were arrested, tried, found guilty and executed all in the space of two hours and were then buried in a mass grave. It is now believed that the story of the trial was a cover up, in order to give the incident a veneer of legitimacy. Apparently Lieutenant General Omer Hassan El Beshir, the regime's figurehead leader who signed the execution warrant, has told his close friends that by the time he signed the death warrants the officers had already been executed and he was merely ensuring that the regime's actions would later be seen as being legitimate.

Known Murderer - Major Ibrahim Shams El Din, along with Major General Faith Erwa, the regime's current ambassador to the United Nations, were responsible for a mass of extra-judicial killings in Juba in 1992. The Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) was very close to capturing the Southern capital and the two men were sent there to ensure that this did not happen. They terrorised the local population by randomly executing anybody they considered to be a potential supporter of the SPLA. Two Southerners employed by the United States Agency for International Development (USIAD) were executed in this manner. The errant major only left the South after he had a close encounter with the SPLA on the road to Torit. His helicopter was attacked and destroyed on the ground at Liria between Juba and Torit, and he was forced to flee back to Juba on foot. He has never returned to the South since. This time, Major Ibrahim Shams El Din was sent to Port Sudan to clear up the coup d'etat in his usual brutal fashion.

Military Action in the East - Elsewhere in the Eastern Sudan, the NIF regime has admitted that the forces of the Beja Congress and the Sudan Alliance Forces (SAF) of the NDA had clashed with its own troops near the border with Eritrea. The NIF regime insists that the Eritrean government is sending its own regular forces into Eastern Sudan in the guise of these rebel groups.

A military spokesperson in Khartoum announced last month that their forces had engaged NDA forces near the borders in September, but did not give any specific dates. The spokesperson said that the rebels had been forced back across the border into Eritrea and the situation had retirned to normal.

In reality both Beja and the SAF forces have continued to operate inside Eastern Sudan throughout September, disrupting supplies from Port Sudan along the road and rail routes. Large numbers of troops have been seen on the road between Khartoum and Port Sudan, although none of them have arrived at the Port city. This suggests that they have been moved to other parts of Eastern Sudan as reinforcements against the activities of the anti-NIF regime groups.

Troubles in Machar's Camp - To add to the regime's headaches with rebel groups, one of its friendly militias is experiencing a crisis of leadership. The regime has feted Riek Machar since the 10 April Charter was signed but has also been impatient for his forces to begin operations against the SPLA in Southern Sudan.

By mid-September, Riek Macher's autority over his Southern Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM) forces was being brought into question. Mr Machar ordered Gabriel Tang, one of his junior commanders, to move his forces from Zaraf Island at Pangak to join up with the forces of Timothy Taban Nyuon, another of his junior commanders, to attack SPLA positions at Kongor and Bor. Mr Tang refused to obey these orders, insisting that he had reached local agreements with SPLA commanders in the area not to attack each others' forces.

Mr Tang was then ordered to attack the SPLA forces of Commander George Athor at nearby Atar, which would have given the SSIM complete control of central Upper Nile. Mr Tang refused to carry out this order as well. Riek Machar them travelled to Pangak to try and personally persuade Gabriel Tang to carry out the orders. When this direct approach failed, he ordered Mr Tang to be disarmed and detained. Fighting broke out between the supporters of the two men, and Mr Machar is believed to be still trapped at Pangak in the centre of the conflict.

Meanwhile, self-styled Major General Paulino Matip of the Anya Nya Two militia, who is also in alliance with the NIF regime, has returned to Bentiu after a period of treatment and convalescence at the military hospital in Omdurman. He is reported to be unhappy with recent developments. Firstly, he is unhappy with Riek Machar and Kerubino Kuanyin Bol for going ahead with the 10 April Charter without consulting him. Secondly, he is concerned about Arakis International extracting the oil from the Bentiu fields. General Matip was told to move his militia forces away from Bentiu and onto Leer to join in an attack on the SPLA at Bor but he has refused to follow these orders.

Issue cover date: October 1996.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


272 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 17, 1996


Sudan;
Sudair 150: How Iraqi Hijackers Came to be in Sudan


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

London - The hijacking of Sudan Airways flight number SUD 150 on 27 August ended on the morning of 29 August at London's Stansted airport when all the passengers and crew were released unharmed.

The flight had set off from Khartoum to Amman in Jordan when it was hijacked by seen Iraqi nationals wielding fake guns and explosives. The hijackers demanded to fly to London, refusing to land at any Arab or Moslem airport. They only agreed to land at Larnaca in Cyprus because the pilot had convinced them that the plane did not have enough fuel to make the journey to London. Captain Abdel Hamid Hidirbi was to emerge as the hero of the piece for his calm handling of the situation and ensuring the safety of all his crew and passengers. 

The Sketchy Facts

Full details of the hijacking and the hijackers have not been made public. Only the investigating authorities in Britain have a complete picture of the events. The facts which have emerged into the international media are sketchy.

The seven Iraqi nationals were accompanied on the flight by their wives and children. There were approximately 200 other passengers on the flight, including a small boy with a brain tumour who was travelling to Jordan for an operation. He stayed behind in Britain and was operated on in Cambridge at the expense of the British taxpayer.

All of the hijackers have been held in detention in Britain and charged. Members of their families were questioned by police but later released. They have since requested political asylum in Britain. It is unlikely that these requests will be dealt with until the criminal charges connected to the hijacking have been settled in court.

It is unlikely that the hijackers will be extradited to either Iraq or Sudan, and it is more that certain that they will be tried in a British court. In fact, neither country has made any request for the extradition of the seven men. The National Islamic Front (NIF) regime has expressed its satisfaction with the British authorities' handling of the affair and indicated that it may well send officials to London to participate in the ongoing investigation. Khartoum's responsible behaviour probably owes more to its international isolation than to anything else.

Good Relations

The British media has taken the view that the seven Iraqis are opponents of Saddam Hussein who fear for their lives if they return to Iraq. Speculation included a view that they were part of the Shiite minority in Southern Iraq who were persecuted by Saddam Husssein in the aftermath of the Gulf War in 1991, and that they have been fugitives from the Iraqi regime ever since. Such speculation, however, does not really fit in with the facts as known.

The NIF regime has had good relations with Baghdad since it took Saddam Hussein's side in the Gulf War of 1991. Iraqi advisors on military matters and chemical weapons production have worked in Sudan for the past five years. Iraqi air force pilots have flown sorties over Southern Sudan and have been involved in the bombing of civilian targets there. Any Iraqi in Sudan today is likely to be an Iraqi government official of some kind or a member of the Iraqi armed forces. It would be very unlikely for an Iraqi Shiite rebel to choose Sudan as a safe haven from Saddam Hussein.

Iraqi Activities in Sudan

Iraq is currently converting the old and disused ammunition factory at Shajara, outside Khartoum, into a chemical weapons production factory. At least one of the seven hijackers is believed to have been a technician working on this project. Four of the hijackers are believed to have been Iraqi government employees seconded to duties in Sudan.

It appears likely that the Iraqis were officials who were being recalled to Iraq some time ahead of their scheduled departure dates. This signalled that something was amiss and the seven men feared that they would be arrested upon their return to Iraq.

Khartoum's Role

Some observers have speculated that the NIF regime stage-managed the hijacking in order to obtain some positive press coverage in the international media. Whilst this may sound unlikely, it is not beyond the warped mentality of the rogue regime of Khartoum.

Sudan Airways has suffered a spate of hijackings on its domestic flights recently. The only tow successful ones have been carried out by security officials of the regime, who have had little problem in taking weapons aboard undetected. A hijacking carried out by a newly wed and his bride was quickly foiled because he was not a security official. The authorities were certain that a weapon could not possibly have been smuggled on board and so the captains was ordered to return to the airport and the hijacker was overpowered and arrested. It is unlikely, then, that security would have been so lax at Khartoum airport as to allow seven Iraqis to take weapons on board an international flight. There is no way the Sudanese security authorities would have allowed seven dissident Iraqis to take weapons aboard a regular passenger flight. There is, therefore, more than meets the eye in the story of the hijack of flight SUD 150 as so far told.

Contradictory Stories

Khartoum has given out contradictory stories as to what the Iraqis were doing in Sudan in the first place. Initially, the Sudanese minister of state for foreign affairs, Mustapha Osman, announced that the Iraqis had been deported from Sudan. No further details were given. Not even the reason whey they were being deported or to where.

Since then the regime has not issued any denials that the Iraqis were government officials working on projects in Sudan. The regime has not said when they entered Sudan, from which country they came nor on what passports.

It was reported at first that the seven were unknown to the Sudanese authorities and this was later changed to say that they were ordinary Iraqi citizens who has spent some time living in Sudan. it is to be expected that British authorities have uncovered more of the truth and this will be eventually made public. For the time being, events surrounding Flight SUD 150 are not all that they might seem.

Issue cover date: October 1996.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


273 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 17, 1996


Business;
Arakis To Hire Mercenaries to Protect Sudan Oil Fields


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

London - The Canadian oil company, Arakis International, which is under contract with the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime to extract the crude oil from the Southern Sudanese oil fields at Bentiu, is planning to employ white mercenaries from South Africa as a security force to protect the oil wells, The mercenaries are being recruited through an agency known as Executive Outcomes. The mercenaries will be employed directly by Arakis and will operate independently from the Sudanese authorities in the area.

It seems that the Canadian oil company was not satisfied by the provision of 10,000 Iranian revolutionary guards and the NIF regime's own Popular Defense Forces (PDF) as a security force for the oil fields. The idea is to surround the area of the oil fields, making it impossible for the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) to infiltrate and sabotage the operation. Arakis International is attempting to copy the Sierra Leone example, where South African mercenaries have been used to protect the diamond mining operations in the midst of the civil war in that country. However, there is a major difference in Sierra Leone where the mercenaries have been directly employed by the government rather than by a private company such as Arakis. 

Complicated Dealings

The Arakis connection with the NIF regime is A complicated one. The original deal brokered between the two involved financing from Arabian Gulf countries and when this deal collapsed it cost the chief executive of the oil company his job. The present connection has a strong Islamic Fundamentalist bent to it. the new chief executive officer at Arakis is a naturalised Canadian citizen of Pakistani Moslem descent, Mr. Lutfur Rahman Khan. He appears to have been given a free hand by the president of Arakis International to spend whatever is necessary to make the operation in Southern Sudan a success. Whilst the financial profitability is far from assured, Mr. Khan has been guaranteed generous funding from the Iranian government. This is why the oil company is so ready to risk the lives of foreign employees in Southern Sudan.

Canadian government officials have said that they are unaware of Arakis International's involvement in the oil fields of Southern Sudan. The Canadian government has not been consulted over the matter. As a private business transaction this is not at all unusual. However, the Canadian government will take an interest is the lives of Canadian citizens are put at risk because of the operation. The United States of America's state department has also expressed its concern about foreign employees of Arakis risking their lives in a war zone. It will be remembered that the American Chevron Oil Company first opened the wells at Bentiu and then had to close down the operation when several of its employees were killed in 1984, one year after the present civil war broke out.

Oil Already Being Extracted

Even before the various security forces have arrived in Bentiu, Arakis International has begun to extract oil and transport it to El Obeid in Northern Sudan. It is said that between 10,000 and 15,000 barrels a day are being produced and trucked to El Obeid, the capital of Kordofan province. The crude is being refined locally and/or used to generate electricity supplies.

The profitability of such a small scale operation is debatable. Unfortunately, it is the political factor rather than the economic factor which is justifying the operation at present. The simple fact that oil is being extracted from the Bentiu fields in Southern Sudan is a considerable propaganda coup for the NIF regime.

Wider Coalition

In addition to the Iranian revolutionary guards and the South African mercenaries, the NIF regime has instructed the two renegade commanders, Riek Machar an Kerubino Kuanyin Bol, to send forces to help protect the oil fields. The two renegade commanders have been instructed to set up a buffer zone between any SPLA forces and the forces directly protecting the oil fields.

Kerubino Kuanyin was instructed to move a force into the Twic Dinka country of Northern Gogrial in Bahr El Ghazal and to control the area from the north of the River Lol to Abyei and then to link up with Riek Machar's forces. The combined forces would be expected to confront any SPLA force moving towards Bentiu.

Commander Kuanyin took his orders seriously and moved his forces out of Gogrial town and headed for Twic country in late August. His forces were ambushed by the SPLA at Panliet en route to the River Lol and fighting there was continuing at the time of going to press with this edition.

It is difficult to understand how Southern Sudanese leaders could become involved in the exploitation of the South's oil reserves for the benefit of the NIF regime. It only goes to show how far Commanders Kuanyin and Machar have become the willing tools of the NIF regime. Whilst one can accept that Commanders Machar and Kuanyin have become so corrupted with lust for power that they are willing do anything for their own individual glory, it is not so easy to accept why their troops are willing to keep obeying their orders.

SPLA Dilemma

Trying to prevent the NIF regime from exploiting the oil resources has presented the SPLA with quite a dilemma. The South regards the SPLA as its national army and so is looking towards it to protect the South's natural resources. There was satisfaction across the South when the SPLA forced Chevron to close down its operations in 1984. However, the situation today is not as straightforward as it was then. Back in 1984 the SPLA was a united organisation. The Arab militias went to protect the Bentiu oil fields were no match for it. Today, the SPLA has suffered schisms and a splintering of forces. It no longer has large numbers of forces in the Nuer territory of the Bentiu area. The only SPLA forces within the vicinity of the oil fields are in the Nuba Mountains to the North and they are fully engaged in a struggle against the regime's war of genocide against the Nuba people and so cannot be diverted to the oil fields.

Another factor which could prevent the SPLA from creating a large force to attack the oil fields is the perceived crisis between the Nuer and Dinka people. Whilst the SPLA still has a large number of Nuer commanders and troops, there is the misperception that the SPLA is a Dinka organisation and the Riek Machar's renegade Southern Sudan Independence Army (SSIA) is a Nuer militia. Such is the state of Southern politics today that an SPLA attack on the Bentiu oil fields could well be misconstrued as a Dinka invasion of the Nuer tribal territory. The NIF regime would then be able to sit back and watch the spectacle of Southerner killing Southerner and the oil issue would cease to be the important factor. The outside world would quickly forget the Riek Machar's militia is merely another NIF unit arrayed against the South.

Whilst the SPLA works its way around this dilemma, however, the South still expects it to disrupt the oil production. After all, what will the war of liberation have been for if the NIF regime can exploit the South's oil resources at its own convenience? It could be that Arakis International is waiting for an excuse to pull out of its contract with the regime. It is time the SPLA acted to give it that excuse to leave, just as the Chevron Oil Company did in 1984.

Issue cover date: October 1996.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


274 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 18, 1996


Business and Finance;
Tunis chosen as IBM's North Africa Headquarters


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Tunis - IBM, the giant U.S. computer manufacturer, has chosen Tunis as the headquarters of its North African activities. IBM North Africa general manager Christian Poujardieu announced at a press conference, October 17, that Tunisia's" political stability, economic development and strategic location", as well as its advanced communications infrastructure and well- trained engineers were the reasons for the choice. He added that the North African region has a great potential as an emerging computer market.

IBM North Africa will provide support services and advice in marketing and technical matters to its representatives in the various countries in the region. In addition to Tunisia, IBM North Africa encompasses Algeria, Egypt, Malta, Morocco, and Mauritania. IBM is represented in Tunisia by Tunisian Business Machines (TBM).


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

275 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 18, 1996


Business and Finance;
South African Labour's 'New Kids On The Block'


BYLINE: Jacquie Golding-Duffy and Anthony Kunda, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1880 words


 

Johannesburg - The exodus in 1994 of many experienced unionists into the government and business dealt the labour movement a massive blow.

When the likes of Jay Naidoo, Alec Erwin and Cyril Ramaphosa left, murmurings about a drain of talent rippled across the industry. The whispers were laden with concern levelled by unions and management alike that the movement would falter.

This has not happened, and the Mail & Guardian spoke to four union leaders who have been credited by their peers with "strengthening" the movement following post- election losses.

They are National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) general secretary Kgalema Motlanthe; National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa (Numsa) general secretary Enoch Godongwana; Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) assistant general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi; and South African Clothing and Textiles Workers Union (Sactwu) general secretary Jabu Ncgobo. 

One industry source says many of those who left the unions to take up government posts were recently returned exiles who had although contributed little to the movement.

"It is sad sometimes when people purport to know what is happening within labour," he said. "Some of the people who hold high profile positions now really did not do any of the slog work that was required to build up a worker base.

"In some instances, they took the credit and did nothing. There were often people whom they left behind as shop stewards that deserved to be more than just that. Sometimes those union information officers or stewards were in actual fact general secretary material."

Labour analyst Gavin Brown says a "serious crisis of leadership" still exists in unions. It is not just a question of "filling the gaps", he says, but "nurturing and developing" leadership skills.

Brown says it is also difficult for the movement to compete with the better prospects and pay offered in government and the private sector.

The players:

ZWELINZIMA VAVI, assistant general secretary of Cosatu, was apparently born in 1962, or so he says. He has no exact birth date as he came from an " unfortunate family who lived on a farm and was uneducated".

Vavi's involvement in the trade union movement began at a young age, when he was still a student in the Congress of South African Students (Cosas).

He says there was an important slogan used at Cosas which prompted him into valuing the "skill of organising people".

The slogan used was: "It is the duty of Cosas cadres to build organisations ... When you are with women, organise them, when you are with the youth, organise them and when you are with the workers, organise them.''

Vavi says he started organising public service workers back home in an Eastern Cape rural town and developed a strong passion for organised labour. He then moved from the South African Allied Workers' Union to work at a Vaal Reef mine in 1984 before being dismissed with thousands of workers during the National Union of Mineworkers' 21-day strike.

Involved in civic, youth and unions simultaneously, Vavi became regional secretary of Cosatu's Western Transvaal region and was "quite dynamic", says one colleague.

The union, says Vavi, keeps the government in check and Cosatu, with its 19 affiliates and 1,8-million members, has proven that it is a force to be reckoned with.

However, he says it is extremely difficult to adjust to a different tack of consultation. Dealing with the government often means "thinking on your feet during negotiations and not leaving much time for consulting with member unions.

"It is difficult but necessary to make on the spot decisions in the interest of workers while bearing in mind that you have to find ways of making sure you include your members in your decision," he says.

"My personal view is that within the pressure, you always find ways to bring your members on board."

Vavi is facing elections next year during the federation's national congress.

JABU NGCOBO (46), general secretary of Sactwu - the third largest union in the country - formed an interest in labour in the early Sixties. This was when his father was sacked after 15 years of service. Ngcobo junior started work earning R5,95 a week.

Within two years of starting work in Durban, Ngcobo was involved in a strike over bonuses. Frame Textiles, the factory where he worked, had no union, leaving 20 000 workers at the mercy of management.

In 1973, Ngcobo led another strike, part of an action in which 100 000 textile workers downed tools for better conditions and a living wage.

Ngcobo is passionate about his work, reputedly organising and recruiting more than 40 000 workers singlehandedly.

A founding member of the Federation of South African Trade Unions, Ngcobo became regional treasurer of the federation in 1979. Within Sactwu he was a shop steward and national organiser before becoming general secretary.

Ngcobo believes that no one "should be held prisoner to the union" and that unions should not rely on individuals.

But the unions are facing strain. It is not only the top layer of officials moving into other sectors, but also the second and third layers such as regional chairs and treasurers who are going into local government.

"I am saddened when the cream is skimmed from the unions. But we must realise that the strength lies in the union. It is the only place where black people have learnt to organise."

ENOCH GODONGWANA, Numsa general secretary, believes the only thing that has changed for a unionist since the 1994 election is the need to become more militant. A democratic government doesn't mean workers' conditions are any better, and complacency abounds.

"The same injustices persist. The relationships between labour and management still reflect the pre-1994 situation," he says.

"If apartheid was the only problem, then there is no role for trade unions now. But that's not true. In fact, there is need for more militant trade unionism." Strangely, he insists he is not a militant.

Born in the Eastern Cape in 1957, Godongwana joined Numsa in 1979, a year after he started work for Barlows in Alberton. He was immediately elected shop steward.

Moses Mayekiso's move into politics in 1994 opened the door to the general secretary's office; Godongwana was overwhelmingly re-elected at the union's annual congress in September.

South African Democratic Teachers Union (Sadtu) president Willy Madisha, who knows Godongwana from their days together in the South African Communist Party, says: "He is a hardworking man, who has got where he is through nothing but determination and hard work." Godongwana has also been recommended for various government and private sector positions, Madisha says.

Godongwana is ambivalent about the union movement losing good people. "If somebody thinks they can contribute more effectively in nation-building in other sectors, that's all right," he says.

But the 1994 exodus came "at a time when we were facing new challenges and difficulties, when we needed experienced, seasoned and mature leadership".

The union movement has now developed a leadership system at all levels so that "as soon as there is a gap, we have other people."

If he is considering offers, Godongwana says he has no plans to move yet. He adds, however, that he also won't be a permanent fixture at Numsa. "When you stay too long you become a hindrance to progress. You become suspicious of new ideas."

KGALEMA MOTLANTHE (47) is not a miner and never was. This didn't stop him rising through the ranks of the NUM to replace Cyril Ramaphosa as general secretary of the union - the largest in the country.

Ironically, Motlanthe is critical of unionists in such a position. "It is unusual for me to hold the position I hold as I am not a mineworker. But this is changing within the union itself, and so it should. I am now the only one who serves on the national executive that has not worked in a mine."

Motlanthe is respected by his colleagues for his dedication and commitment. A tough but diplomatic negotiator, Motlanthe has proved the union can survive by drawing leadership from within its own ranks.

"Nature never allows a vacuum, even when the most important leaders leave," he says. He adds he is by no means the best man for the job, citing several people who are capable and adequately equipped to be general secretary.

Motlanthe joined the union as an education officer in June 1987, after spending 10 years on Robben Island as a political prisoner.

He was acting general secretary for two years after Ramaphosa left the NUM and was only officially made general secretary at the NUM's national congress in 1994.

"My own view is that the labour movement is relatively young," he says. " The NUM is only 14 years old but the movement is nurturing potential leaders, almost aware that people move on.

"We must realise that salaries are better in the private sector and we will only be able to keep our own within the union if we improve wages."


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
