October 21, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa Supports Middle East Peace Process


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa has given its official backing to the current peace process in the Middle East.

After a meeting in Cape Town Sunday with former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Perez, South African President Nelson Mandela pledged his support for the peace negotiations. 

Mandela said he would soon be visiting the Middle East "as a peace messenger," but said he would not interfere in the internal affairs of the countries of the region.

However, he said he would share the South African experience with them. He said that the Middle East would have to work out solutions to its problems for itself.

"Outsiders can only play a role to strengthen the peace process," He said.

Initiation of the Middle East peace process, he said, had brought a powerful message of hope. But like all peace-loving people throughout the world, he added, "we are extremely concerned by the apparent impasse" regarding the implementation of the accord.

"Our own humble experience has taught us that such accords are delicate matters," he said, "and integrity in their implementation, and mutual consent where a review of their content may seem necessary, are as important as the substance of the agreements."

Accepting a peace award at an International Leadership Reunion dinner Sunday, Mandela said that if South Africa had become a symbol of the peace process, it was due to the people of the country themselves.

"It is they who are honored by the award which you have bestowed upon me," he said.

"On their behalf," he said, "I humbly accept it in the fervent hope that what we have achieved as a nation will in some small way serve as a powerful force of example to our continent, and further afield."


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


317 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Ghana;
Sanitation Project To Cost 90 Million Dollars


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

KUMASI, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana's World Bank-sponsored Urban Environmental Sanitation Project (Urban Four), to cover five major towns, is estimated to cost 89.3 million U.S. dollars.

Major components of the project -- to cover the cities of Accra, Kumasi, Sekondi-Takoradi, Tema and Tamale -- are storm drainage, sanitation, solid waste, upgrading of low-income urban areas and capacity building to promote productivity and raise living standards.

It is especially designed for lower-income people by improving drainage, sanitation and solid waste services, while it helps to build up the capacity of the metropolitan and municipal assemblies to manage environmental sanitation services. 

The project will help establish better institutional and financing mechanisms and more effective policy frameworks so that improvements are sustained.

A report on the project, to be implemented over a six-year period from September 1996 to the year 2002, says it is being funded with International Development Association (IDA) credit of 71 million dollars, payable in 40 years with a 10-year grace period.

The government of Ghana will contribute 8.9 million dollars towards the project, while the metropolitan and municipal assemblies, which are the beneficiaries, would contribute about 5.3 million dollars, representing their shares of community upgrading works, sanitation facilities and solid waste collection.

Co-financing of about 3.4 million dollars has been secured from the Nordic Development Fund, while the Netherlands Government would contribute about 600, 000 dollars towards a training programme.

The report says the focus of the storm drainage component is to alleviate flooding in built-up urban areas and the highest priority interventions have been selected in Accra, Kumasi and Sekondi-Takoradi.

In Accra, approximately seven kilometers (4.3 miles) of the city's primary drainage channel, the Odaw, from the Abossey Okai road to the Motorway extension would be dredged and reconstructed as a trapezoidal channel.

This would significantly alleviate flooding in major industrial, commercial and residential areas in and around the city. At the same time, about 20 kilometers (12.5 miles) of secondary drains serving 13 neighborhoods will be reconstructed to alleviate flooding affecting about 20,000 people.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

318 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Ghana;
Ghana's Interior Minister Resigns


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana's Interior minister, Col. E.M. Osei-Owusu has resigned, an official statement said Sunday in Accra.

President Jerry Rawlings has accepted Osei-Owusu's resignation.

His resignation, effective from Nov. 1, follows the publication of an interim report by the Commission on Human Rights and Administrative Justice of investigations into alleged illegal acquisition of assets by some public officers. 

The commission, last week, made adverse findings against Osei-Owusu; the minister of trade and industry, Ibrahim Adam, and Isaac Adjei-Maafo, a member on the presidential staff. But it exonerated P.V. Obeng, the presidential adviser on governmental Affairs.

The statement quoted Osei-Owusu as saying in letter of resignation that he intended to contest the adverse findings made against him by the commission. He described the commission's conclusions as grossly unfair and highly disputable in the face of available evidence.

He said he had no alternative than to resign so he could seek justice.

So, he said he would challenge the commission's findings "in the appropriate quarters" so save his family, friends and colleagues embarrassment and to clear his name, as well as protect his honor and hard- won reputation.

He expressed hope that the attorney-general's office would grant him the opportunity to study and comment on the report before a White Paper on the final report is issued.

In its findings, the commission said that the allegation or suspicion that the minister's house was worth 600 million cedis (351,943.31 U.S. dollars) could not be substantiated having regard to the evidence on record.

However, the report says the Commission made "an adverse finding" against Osei-Owusu in that he was "unable to account" for 33 million cedis in excess income from April 1993 to June 1995, a period during which the house was constructed.

"We are not in a position to determine how his extra income was acquired," the report says. "Neither has the minister offered any satisfactory explanation or any explanation at all."

So, the reports says: "We recommend that the minister should be made to refund to the state, the excess income of 33,023,182.48 cedis."

Osei-Owusu joined military government of the Provisional National Defence Council as the Ashanti regional minister. He was later promoted a cabinet minister and continued as minister of interior when Rawlings won democratic elections in 1992.

319 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


United States and Africa;
Nigerian Media Chief Berates U.S. Ambassador


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Managing Director of the influential and authoritative Daily Times of Nigeria newspaper, Peter Enahoro, has accused the U.S. Ambassador to Nigeria, Walter Carrington, of being responsible for the deterioration of relations between Washington and Abuja.

According to him, "Ambassador Carrington has had his own way with his careless utterances in this country for too long. He is blamed by knowledgeable observers for personally carrying a torch for confrontation", Enahoro, who assumed office recently, said in a critical opinion piece, published by the paper this week.

Informed observers believe that he was expressing official reaction to the embarrassing treatment of the Nigerian foreign minister, Tom Ikimi, at the New York JFK International Airport, and the recent five-nation tour by the Secretary of State, Warren Christopher that sidelined Nigeria. 

The highly respected Nigerian journalist alleged that each time there was an apparent thaw in relations between the two countries, the ambassador and his cronies at the State Department would work out another strategy to heighten the tension.

The article, published on Oct. 15, fell short of calling Ambassador Carrington a loverboy.

Enahoro attuned that shortly on arrival in Nigeria, the ambassador got himself hooked to a Nigerian belle, whom he later married.

Ambassador Carrington is now being accused of abusing the specific privilege he bestowed on himself by virtue of his marrying a Nigerian. " Perhaps the ambassador feels he had earned the right to interfere rudely in our affairs because he has availed himself of a wife from among us," the writer says.

Enahoro quipped: "Ambassador Carrington's amazing lassitude with freely given remarks about the current political affairs of Nigeria has frequently been as unbecoming in its indignity as it had breached diplomatic politesse.

Peter Enahoro (alias Peter Pan), returned from more than 20 years in self exile in England, following Nigeria's first 1966 military coup, assumed office as chief of the DAily Times of Nigeria Plc, (the largest media empire in the country in which the government has controlling shares) last month. He is the brother of one of Nigeria's frontline politicians and former information minister under the Gowon military administration that ruled Nigeria for eight years, Anthony Enahoro, now a leading prodemocracy activist in exile in North America. The Daily Times boss accused ambassador Carrington of also abusing his position as an African American, throwing all diplomatic niceties to the wind in his efforts to fan the embers of hate in Nigeria-U.S. relations.

Enahoro stated that "...he should also be reminded that there is a thing called sovereignty and that Nigeria places a higher value on protecting her status as an independent nation, than putting out the welcome mat for a foreign envoy's anxiety to be seen to have gone native."

The article also suggested that Ambassador Carrington does not wield any clout in Washington. Enahoro said, "his allies may be at the State Department and among a declining scattering of influences in the house of representatives, but they are scarcely plentiful at the White House."

He further stated that "Each time they sense a thaw on the horizon, they promptly move the goal posts. Thus when Nigeria strengthened its laws against drug trafficking, Washington said they were not good enough. When Nigeria was commended by no less a body than the United Nations drug control programme for its anti-drug trafficking strictures, Washington buffed that the measures were not being applied anyway."

Enahoro said that "all fair-minded persons must surely now begin to wonder what really are the reasons the administration of President Bill Clinton does not wish to restore the traditional good relations between the United States and Nigeria." He cited the recent tour of some African countries by Secretary of State Warren Christopher who spoke about imposing more sanctions on Nigeria before putting forward his country's proposal to fund an African army that excludes Nigeria, as a case in point.

He recollected that "South Africa told him to take his case to the U.N. Ethiopia said the idea was best handled at the level of the OAU, where of course Nigeria has considerable clout. No wonder Christopher took a swipe at Nigeria."

He noted that the trouble with the Clinton African doctrine was that "it equates the voguish pro-democracy campaign with a crude Americanization of the universe. Any country, any administration that resists this misinterpretation becomes a target of calumny and bullying rhetoric.

Enahoro recalled that for the past three years, Nigeria had not received a cent from international financial institutions because of Washington's blocking tactics.

"The longer Nigeria survives the blockade, the more vexed Clinton's washington that this country is setting a bad example for other third world countries to stand up to U.S. excesses," he said.

"Happily there is little the U.S. administration can do to try to undermine the increasing consolidation of Nigeria's regional and continental power. It was balmy in the first place to imagine that you could speak of a continental African army that excludes Nigeria," Enahoro concluded.

October 21, 1996


Zaire;
Huge Refugee Flow Reported By Churches


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Geneva - Text of an October 20 ALERT on Zaire from "Action by Churches Together (ACT)," a worldwide network of churches and their related agencies.

While awaiting last details and revision of appeals (in the magnitude of 1. 3 million US dollars) from partners in Great Lakes Region some news relating to unrest and serious displacement in South Kivu, Eastern Zaire.

According to news agencies up to 250.000 refugees have fled 12 camps near Uvira in South Kivu. The refugees are originally Hutus from Rwanda and Burundi and they are now said to be heading north on the road toward Bukavu. The situation in Bukavu itself has been tense over several weeks with increasing Za?rian military presence and road blocks in the streets. A large scale influx of refugees to the Bukavu area is likely to increase tension and will put heavy strain on all available resources there. 

The flight of refugees from Uvira started yesterday (Sunday) and has been on the increase today. It follows recent fights between Za?rian army units and local Tutsi groups, Banyamulenge, including attacks at refugee camps and a hospital in the Uvira area.

Fighting around Goma (further north) on Saturday only increased tension and may be a warning of further unrest and displacement. Should more fights break out in larger parts of Eastern Zaire (involving forces across the border to Rwanda) the amount of displaced refugees could double or triple on a short notice. This situation has led ACT related partners in the region to start working on contingency plans in case of a worsening situation.

* The ACT network is organizationally based in the Lutheran World Federation (LWF) and the World Council of Churches (WCC) and is a co- ordinating rather than an operational office. Contact information:

For more information: Phone: ++41-22-791.60.33. Fax: ++41-22-791.65.06. E- Mail: act@wcc-coe.org.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

Africa News


October 21, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Kenya Replaces Botswana on UN Council


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

United Nations - The General Assembly this morning elected Costa Rica, Japan, Kenya, Portugal and Sweden to two-year terms on the Security Council, filling non- permanent seats to be vacated on 31 December by Botswana, Germany, Honduras, Indonesia and Italy.

Those elections were determined during two rounds of balloting, with Japan, Kenya and Sweden obtaining the required two-thirds majority during the first round. The elections of Costa Rica and Portugal were determined during the second round of voting, which followed Bolivia's withdrawal of its candidature.

The newly elected non-permanent members will assume their Council seats on 1 January 1997. The five non-permanent Security Council members which will serve for another year, until 31 December 1997, are Chile, Egypt, Guinea- Bissau, Poland and the Republic of Korea.

Africa News


October 21, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
JOURNALISTS DISCUSS MEDIA ROLE IN CONFLICT RESOLUTION


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) OCTOBER 14 - A journalism programme here recently organized a workshop to discuss the role of media in conflict prevention and resolution.

The eighth in a series, the seminar which was facilitated by the United States International University - African (USIU-A) ran from September 25 to 27.

The programme which began on February 1995 has trained more than 200 practitioners in various fields of specialization including the coverage of elections, feature writing, gender issues, interpretative reporting and investigative journalism. 

At the latest seminar, participants observed that conflicts worldwide, in Africa or Kenya, will always be a source of news and good copy for journalists everywhere, but whenever journalists write about conflicts they probably make situations worse than they already are.

Wars, bloodshed and death are the very substance which dominate front pages and news bulletins in both print and electronic media the world over, the meeting noted.

Conflicts make an important part of human interest stories, they will continue to dominate both space and time in all the news media, participants agreed.

In a stimulated contribution Mr. Joe Kadhi, former managing editor of Kenya's leading mass circulation daily, the Daily Nation, who is currently the journalism programme coordinator at the USIU-A, challenged journalists to become more involved in efforts to ensure that Kenya will never degenerate into a state of bloody civil war similar to what has been experienced elsewhere in Africa.

Referring to bloodshed during the 1991-93 political/ethnic land clashes in parts of the country, Mr Kadhi underscored the need for journalists to be exposed to professional ethics of covering conflicts and peace efforts.

The role played by media in stirring up ill feelings among people can clearly be seen in Rwanda, where radio effectively built up hatred among nationals of the same country, although from different ethnic back


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


323 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Sierra Leone;
NEW FIGHTING THREATENS CEASEFIRE IN SIERRA LEONE


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

FREETOWN (APS) OCTOBER 14 - At least 17 people were killed in one week in attacks in Sierra Leone by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels, heightening fears that an official ceasefire which has been observed since March this year could be crumbling.

On October 4, the RUF rebels killed at least 12 people in attacks on villages in the eastern Kenema district and seriously wounded about 20 others, including six children aged between 10 and 12 years, reports reaching the Sierra Leonean capital said on October 5.

A week earlier, four civilian mechanics and a soldier died in an ambush by the RUF rebels on the Makeni-Kono highway in the north of the country, military officials in Makeni said on September 27.

The officials said the ambush was commanded by a woman who used a bayonet to stab the victims before pouring petrol on their corpses to burn them. 

The driver of the vehicle escaped into the bush with a gunshot wound, and a military search party later found him and took him to the Makeni government hospital.

A military checkpoint about a mile from the ambush also came under heavy rebel fire which sent the soldiers dashing into the forest, local reporters said.

The new flare-up in fighting came amid other unconfirmed reports that a military helicopter was hit by sporadic gunfire by rebels at the strategic Mile-91 location, seriously damaging it, although it did not crash. Two soldiers were reportedly killed in the attack.

Defence sources said government troops later destroyed a rebel base on the outskirts of Mile-91, killing an unspecified number of rebels and capturing a large quantity of arms and ammunition, assorted food items and a stock of rice which was later burnt by the troops.

And on October 7, troops were forced to evacuate about 180 patients suffering from leprosy, polio or tuberculosis from a hospital at Massanga in the north of the country for fear of another rebel attack, officials said.

The local military commander, Melvin Keita, said that the evacuation was aimed at protecting the hospital from possible looting, while the army wanted to stop rebels setting the town of Massanga ablaze.

The hospital, run by an American mission, is fitted with surgical and laboratory equipment.

"We are taking no chances and we are mounting an armed dragnet around the area. We shall do everything to protect the area as it is a tactical zone bordering a river (the Pampana) which can be used by the rebels to invade other villages," Keita said on telephone from the town.

The Argentine specialist surgeon at the hospital, Reuben Rostan, was quoted by a local correspondent as saying: "I realise the security issue, but I cannot keep patients here under such heavy military presence."

Massanga has become a ghost town deserted by most of its 6,000 inhabitants who have sought refuge in the bush so as to avoid being caught in cross-fire should the rebels attack.

About 30 patients signed discharge sheets from the hospital, with those suffering from leprosy being transferred to the Magburaka hospital, while some 70 others with polio or tuberculosis were transported to Makeni, not far from Massanga.

On September 4, RUF rebels were blamed for an attack in which three civilians and a soldier died in the town of Mile Five, about 15 kilometres from Massanga.

Massanga is about 12 kilometres from Bumbuna, where an Italian company is currently building a hydro-electric dam.

This diamond-rich former tourist paradise has been ravaged by civil war between the rebel Revolutionary United Front and successive governments since 1991.

Around 10,000 people have been killed and more than half the population of 4.5 million have fled.

Clashes have continued despite declarations in favour of peace by both sides.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


324 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Ghana;
GHANA'S PRESBYTERIAN SYNOD CAUTIONS JUDICIARY


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

GHANA (APS) OCTOBER 14 - The 67th synod of the Presbyterian Church of Ghana (PCG) has cautioned the judiciary in this West African country to resist any temptation that might come their way and stand for truth and justice.

In a 17-point communique read by the moderator of the synod of the PCG,Rt. Rev. Antony Antwi Beeko at the Church of the Resurrection, Accra Central on September 4, the synod reminded the judiciary of the noble role they are expected to play under the Fourth Republican Constitution and urged them not to deviate from it.

The synod described the judiciary as an institution that is essential for maintenance of democratic gains in the country and prayed that these should not be eroded. 

On the media, the PCG Synod asked the practitioners to be mindful of the great responsibilities in the free practice of their profession and strive to be objective, fair and decent.

The meeting also expressed concern about the increased poverty and suffering of the majority of Ghanaians and the looming spectre of a sense of hopelessness and helplessness that threaten many families.

The synod appealed to the government to give poverty alleviation measures priority to enable the nation to deal more realistically and effectively with the debilitating poverty which "is obvious in the streets of our towns and villages."

It also noted with concern the increasing crime wave and violence in the society and emphasised that the containment these vices is an essential element in national development.

The PCG appealed to the government "to provide the law enforcement agencies with up to date equipment to enable them deal effectively with this situation which is gradually threatening the quality of life of the people."

On the Economic Recovery Programme (ERP), the PCG synod noted that the social fallout of the ERP which had resulted in the creation of PAMSCAD - aimed at mitigating the social costs of adjustment, persisted both in scope and intensity.

The meeting observed that the health and education sectors are seriously affected by the economic measures and urged the government to take a critical look at the present "Cash and Carry" health system and the experiments in education.

The synod nevertheless commended the Ministry of Health and the Ghana Medical Association for the measures they had taken to discipline doctors who charge patients extra fees.

The meeting expressed great concern that by the end of 1995, Ghana with a population of 18 million people, had 400,000 cases of HIV/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) carriers. Early this year, the Ministry of Health had recorded 18,054 cases countrywide.

Describing these statistics as alarming, the PCG synod appealed to parents and guardians to educate their children and wards to avoid pre-marital sex which is gradually becoming a regular part of youth culture.

It further urged churches and all other religious bodies to use their pulpits and other educational facilities available to them to wage a relentless war on the spread of AIDS.

The theme of the 67th synod which was held at Kyebi in the Akyum Abuakwa presbytery from August 24 to 25, 1995 was Our Lord Our God, Hope for the nation.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


325 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Sudan;
ELUSIVE EDUCATION FOR SUDANESE TEEN GIRL REFUGEES


BYLINE: Santino Makur Kot, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Nairobi - The definition of education as a basic universal right does not carry much weight when placed against cultural practices affecting the girl- child particularly in Africa. For the Sudanese refugee girl, tradition refers to her early teens as the "maturity" and thus marriageable age, a factor that impacts greatly on the future of this refugee girl/woman.

Among the Nuer and Dinka, mainly inhabitants of southern Sudan, girls are still considered a source of wealth as they bring in dowry upon marriage. This means education for a girl may be overtaken by other cultural priorities, in turn denying her any chance of ever becoming literate. 

As civil war rages in the vast semi-arid expanse of the southern Sudanese territory, the Sudanese girl is exposed to varying changes and greater risks in her new status as a refugee seeking shelter in other countries. But not so for her culture -- it remains as dominant as ever.

Of the nearly 50,000 refugees at the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) camp in the north-western Kenya border town of Kakuma, Turkana district, the overwhelming majority (28,000) are Sudanese. Other nationalities include Zaireans, Somali, Rwandese, Burundians and Angolans.

However, out of 17,700 pupils attending primary school at the camp, only about 2,000 are girls. Due to the disruptions caused by war, many of the girls are in the 14 to 16 years age-group which is traditionally considered the "maturity stage" at which a girl in the village should already be married.

Much as the Dinka and Nuer girls are poorly represented in primary schools at the camp, they are not spared the impact of culture even in a foreign land. "They become irritable and anxious for marriage. It may be their parents who give them away," says Mr. Shadrack Chol a former teacher at Kakuma.

Mr. Chol laments that there are many cases where the girl's parents have hope in their daughter's education, and thus insist against all odds that she continue with schooling. Unfortunately, cases of girls eloping with their suitors are common. The girl may not necessarily have to leave the camp, she could get married right within the same camp.

Elopement is common in Kakuma, despite the fact that it is treated as a taboo among the Dinka and Nuer who believe that a marriage should never occur between a boy and a girl unless the proper rituals have been conducted.

Sources at the camp told APS that at times, such is the anger of the girl's parents that it has led to physical confrontation with the offending boy to assuage their honour.

Traditionally in the village setting in Sudan, parents of the girl may exact stiff penalties on the family of the young man in the form of cattle -- not less than 100 cows.

Like Mr. Chol, Mrs. Ding Majak, a middle-aged refugee woman in Kakuma believes the problem of elopement in the camp finds root in the perception of "maturity" by the girl.

"Girls become pregnant and sexual pressures lead to vulnerability, now a determining factor in low enrolment and poor retention of females in schools in Kakuma," says Mrs. Majak. She notes that "by the age of 16, Dinka and Nuer girls are already restive. They begin to get anxious that if they wait longer, nobody will want to marry them thereafter."

But ayoung educated Sudanese woman says girls mainly elope because they are staying with relatives and guardians, persons who are not their real parents. As such, girls lack genuine parental guidance.

A Sudanese teacher who requested anonymity told APS that some girls have been raped at the camp. Girls are regularly sexually harassed which is not surprising given that most of the young men were child soldiers fighting in the civil war, and they retain their violent temperament in the refugee camps, the source explained.

However, Mr. Maker Thiong, director of education at the UNHCR refugee camp told APS education services for refugee children have expanded rapidly since 1992 when the current camp was set up.

There are over 20 primary schools run by about 350 teachers drawn from different nationalities in the camp. The schools follow the Kenyan curriculum. Foreign teachers are regularly oriented to the system through courses at Kakuma and at Lodwar Teachers' Training Institute (LTTI).

"Those courses are conducted because most of the Sudanese teachers followed the Arabic system at home before coming as refugees to Kakuma. Apart from preparing them for the Kenyan education system, the training courses help the beneficiaries encourage the use of the English language," Thiong told APS.

Non-formal education is offered at the Don-Bosco vocational training centre operated by the Holy Cross Catholic church and sponsored by the Lutheran World Federation (LWF). Annually, it recruits students aged 18 and above among the refugees for courses in masonry, building, carpentry, and tailoring for young women and girls.

The International Rescue Committee (IRC) offers skills to the disabled through reading and writing as well as sewing and sign language for the deaf and braille for the blind.

Adult education for women and those deprived by war has already taken off. Radda Barnen, the Swedish Save the Children Fund, supplies text books and other stationery towards education at the camp. The organization is also involved in the rehabilitation of child soldiers whose traumatic experiences as a result of the conflicts back home make it difficult for them to settle down to a normal life.

Radda Barnen's "psycho-social programme" involves giving extensive counselling to children, many of whom have been separated from their parents for a long time or have been orphaned. These are in two categories -- the unaccompanied minors who are catered for separately and are encouraged to cook and care for themselves as one way of rediscovering their self worth; and the community based minors who live with guardians in the camp.

In all, the Radda Barnen programme assistant for services at Radda Barnen in Nairobi told APS: "We are happy that traumatization among the children has been reduced. Some children have been re-united with their parents. The main purpose of the psycho-social programme is to enhance the psycho-social circumstances of affected children."

According to Mr. Ocholla, Radda Barnen which focusses on the needs of refugee children that go beyond food and shelter, is also influencing other non-governmental organizations working in southern Sudan to initiate psycho- social and educational programmes to rehabilitate children affected by the traumatic disasters inflicted by wars.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


326 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Rwanda and Burundi;
RWANDA, BURUNDI DESPERATE FOR A DROP OF HUMANITY


BYLINE: Florence Bamanyaki, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Nairobi - Psychologically, the countries of Rwanda and Burundi in Central Africa are full of walking wounded people, traumatised survivors and numerous orphans - it is from this base that these states have to be re-started.

Of late, there has been a vigorous debate about the unfortunate position of women in conflict situations. Many times, the argument is based on the impact of conflict on women's lives as individuals and as key bearers of family responsibilities.

Little attention has been paid to the role of women in sustaining conflicts and their capacity to inflict cruelty, not as organised fighters, but as ordinary people shrouded by the notion that they are the 'fairer' sex.

The intricacies of the theories concerning the origins of the races at war in Rwanda and Burundi are often hard to fathom but the fact is, the seemingly irreconcilable differences between the ethnic Hutu and Tutsi remain the stumbling block to ending hostility in the Central African states. 

Both at national and international levels, women and girls have been described as the principal victims of the genocide in Rwanda, thus obscuring the role of women as aggressors. Another factor which has highlighted women's suffering in the genocide is the extent to which Tutsi women and girls were raped and abducted.

Yet another argument to minimise women's responsibilities for their actions is to claim that women killed because they were obliged by their husbands and men-folk.

In September, the Medical Assistance Programme (MAP) International, an organization that concerns itself with conflict resolution and prevention of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) organised a four-day conference in Nairobi, Kenya for traumatised Rwandese and Burundian women with the aim of building hope and stamina in them, following their tragic experiences during genocide in their respective countries.

Among other activities at the conference, women testified about their experiences and how they have been dealing with the trauma. Most of them confessed that it is their Christian faith that has kept them going.

One Rwandese Hutu woman told of how her three children were killed with machetes right in her face because they were Tutsi. She was married to a Tutsi man, who too, was murdered.

Another Tutsi Rwandese, Liberata, told of how her ten-hour-old infant boy was cut into pieces by a neighbour old woman on her way to fetch water. Liberata said the old woman feigned sympathy and asked to see the new-born and suddenly, the woman stabbed the baby, claiming that the boy child would be just another Tutsi "inyezi" (cockroach).

Most of the participants at the conference said they had no relatives because they had been killed as they tried to seek refuge.

Rwanda and its "twin" Burundi have been described by scholars as a " climatic and ecological island." Agriculture has always been prosperous. One unique aspect is that the two countries are culturally and linguistically similar. Both have a similar ethnic mix of about 85 per cent Hutu, 14 per cent Tutsi while the remaining one per cent comprises the Twa ethnic group.

Rwanda was plunged into a frenzy of violence and bloodshed on April 6, 1994, the day its president and that of Burundi, Juvenile Habyarimana and Cyprien Ntaryamira respectively, were killed in a suspicious plane crash. Within days, hundreds of thousands of men, women and children had been brutally and systematically murdered.

Those who survived the initial massacres and the escalating civil war fled in panic, desperately seeking some sort of safety in neighbouring countries of Zaire, Tanzania, Uganda and Burundi. Rwanda, one of the most densely populated countries in Africa has been virtually emptied of its people.

Burundi has been in turmoil since 1993, following a failed coup attempt that resulted in the death of the country's first Hutu president, Melchior Ndadaye.

Today, Burundi suffers economic sanctions imposed by neighbouring African states in an effort to reverse the July military coup that ousted Hutu president, Sylvestre Ntibatunganya and replaced him with former military ruler, Pierre Buyoya, amid continuing massacres and increasing refugees in the Central African region.

The hundred days genocide in Rwanda and the escalating civil strife in Burundi is no spontaneous outburst. According to French historian, Gerard Prunier, in his recent book, History of a genocide, the genocide is a result of indoctrination in the "democratic majority" and the "demonisation" of the " feudalists." The vast majority of victims were the Tutsis. All of them were slated to die, be it women, old people, children or even babies.

Anyhow, the main agents of the genocide were the ordinary peasants themselves. Evidence of this lies in the majority of the survivors' stories.

According to Rwanda: Not so innocent, a report published in August 1995 by African Rights, the widespread participation of women in the genocide is a fact that cannot be denied or explained away.

The publication says the responsibility lies not only with the chief male architects of the genocide whose strategy was to include as much of the population as possible, but also with many of Rwanda's educated women.

African Rights is dedicated to working on issues of grave human rights abuses, conflict, famine and civil reconstruction in Africa. The organization does its work by trying to give a voice to Africans concerned with these pressing issues and to urge for more accountability from the international community.

Research findings of African Rights carried out last year, indicate that the extent to which women actively participated in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda is unprecedented anywhere in the world.

The report revealed that a huge number of educated Hutu women used their education, experience and standing in the community to urge less fortunate women to commit genocide. Some women killed with their own hands, according to the survivors' testimonies published in the report.

One wonders, what happened to the compassion, institution and motherly instinct women are said to be blessed with? It was even more horrifying to learn from the African Rights publication that even some nuns were involved in precipitating the killing of Tutsis by denying them refuge in their monasteries.

Probably, millions would never have died in Rwanda if they had not been betrayed by their neighbours, many of them, people they had considered friends and with whom they were linked in a variety of ways. Many of the survivors can give the names of the people who killed their loved ones and friends, and who tried to murder them, precisely because these killers were men and women who lived in their neighbourhood.

When all is said and done, trauma or no trauma, there is an immense need for labour in Rwanda, with almost 40 per cent of its population of about 7 million people dead or in exile. Burundi, with some 6 million people faces the danger of a Rwanda-style genocide if immediate steps towards a constitutional rule are not taken.

Rwanda and Burundi are two countries in Africa where the people can justifiably claim to be of the same origin because the degree of similarity in their ethnic groups is remarkable.

Theoretically therefore, one might imagine that it should be reasonably simple to devise workable solutions that could cater for the aspirations of the Hutus and the Tutsis.

A democratic political system that could ensure equal participation of all groupings would be a step in the right direction. However, finding that system proves to be a major and almost impossible challenge facing the two Central African states.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


327 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Science and Health;
A MOTHER'S WOES WITH "BLACK MAN'S" HEREDITARY DISEASE


BYLINE: Joseph K'Amolo, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1987 words


 

NAIROBI - Call it tragedy, fate or misfortune, but the ordeal of losing nearly all one's children to a debilitating hereditary disease that society hardly understands is a painful experience, at best narrated by one such mother.

Mary Nyambok, (not her real name) 38, from western Kenya is a sickle cell carrier. Her situation has changed what was once a splendid marriage.

She has had six live births since her marriage in 1979 to Wycliff Osore (also not his real name), a clinical officer. However, only one child is still alive today. All the others died in their infancy, but not as one would assume from malaria which is endemic in the area. 

Osore told APS, pressure from his relatives to divorce Nyambok for another wife mounted. To them, she had become the scorn of the village, the carrier of a bad omen from her ancestral home.

Gradually, he too started despising and mistreating her, something he now blames on ignorance. But his attitude began to change after visiting a private clinic where a doctor diagnosed both of them as sickle cell carriers. Their children, they realised had died of sickle cell anaemia, a genetical abnormality more prevalent in their home area than elsewhere in this East African country.

But the Osores are not unique. Today in Kenya much like elsewhere in Africa, there are many people who are not aware of sickle cell anaemia. Yet it is an ailment that is particularly prevalent in dark skinned people especially blacks. Hence the name "black man's disease." It is a disease that strains family resources as testified by Lucy Ogot in Nairobi, a mother of girl twins, one of whom is a sickler.

And just what is sickle cell anaemia? Prof. Joseph Aluoch, a Kenyan haematologist doctor explains: "The disease is a result of a molecular abnormality in the blood which turns some red cells into the shape of a crescent (quarter moon) or sickle. It is a hereditary abnormality which affects both sexes and cannot be contracted through infection or any other contact," he adds.

The term sickle cell disease, however, describes a group of inherited disorders of the haemoglobin. Haemoglobin is a substance (protein) in the red blood cells which picks oxygen from the air in the lungs and carries it to other parts of the body where it is needed.

Characterised by sickling, the disorders, are as such, a result of an inherited disorder of the haemoglobin structure. Of the disorders, sickle cell anaemia is the most aggressive, devastating and therefore, feared condition. Although it can be managed up to the early 20s, a patient may die from any of its various complications.

"The physical pain the patient goes through and the psychological suffering the minder of such a patient experiences, let alone the constant medical bills are beyond description," says Lucy Ogot.

A typical characteristic of a red blood cell with sickle cell anaemia is that it has a short life span of only 90 days. The normal blood cell, red or white, has a life span of 120 days.

"This means that such a sickle cell breaks-off quickly in the body to release components that should otherwise be dealt with in the general body metabolism and then broken-down into materials (unwanted waste) that are got rid of by the kidney and liver," explains Dr. Aluoch.

But because these components are released very rapidly, some of them get into the blood circulation and into the tissues before they have been treated under general metabolism. When untreated components get into the blood circulation system, a manifestation of jaundice develops, normally seen in the yellowness of the white of the eye, in skin and the urine.

Sometimes, the victim experiences pain in the arms, legs, back and stomach when the sickle shaped blood cell gets in the small vessels and obstructs normal blood flow. The obstruction leads to other body tissues being deprived of oxygen.

People with such conditions are chronically fatigued because they do not have enough oxygen to burn energy. Other symptoms may include distress, stroke and in children, bed-wetting. For children below two years, because their bones have not fully formed, the swelling diffuses through the rest of the tissues causing the hands and feet to swell.

Detecting sickle cell in an infant below six months is difficult. At this age, the baby still has pedohaemoglobin, the haemoglobin with which it was born. The baby haemoglobin prevents sickling from taking place but this is short lived as it is replaced with adult haemoglobin six months after birth. It is usually at this age that the adult haemoglobin, if it is an abnormal sickle cell gene, superimposes on the baby haemoglobin and the symptoms start to manifest.

But thanks to modern science, a pre-natal test can detect whether the unborn baby is either sickle cell positive or has a sickle cell trait. Modern medicine can also determine a child's blood gene composition. This is because as an hereditary abnormality, it shows immediately after conception.

A child will be a sickle cell carrier or have a sickle cell trait if it has inherited an abnormal haemoglobin gene from one of the parents, be a sickler or have sickle cell anaemia if it inherited two abnormal genes, one from each parent. Off-springs whose parents are both sicklers will definitely be sicklers themselves.

Experts advise, therefore, to test for blood gene composition before marriage to ensure that not both of the intending couple are either carriers or indeed have sickle cell anaemia.

Marriage where one of the spouses is only a carrier, may but will not necessarily, bring off-springs who are carriers but not sicklers. On the other hand, children of a sickler parent married to a normal person will always be carriers, but stand a high risk of being sicklers if the other parent is a carrier.

Carriers, that is people who only have the trait, do not suffer from any symptoms of sickle cell anaemia. This is because sickle cell trait is not an illness and, therefore, they are perfectly healthy. When such two people marry, however, they will bear children who are either carriers (have sickle cell trait) or who are sicklers (have sickle cell anaemia.)

Sickle cell dates back to 1910 when Dr. Herrick discovered its symptoms in an African-American patient in North America. In 1949, a bio-chemist, Leonard Pauline made a molecular description of it.

The ailment has for a long time been regarded as a disease of the black man. But it has also been found in India, Pakistan, the Middle East and in the Mediterranean region among white people. It is particularly prevalent in malaria endemic zones.

Not surprisingly, Dr. Ian Franklin, a consultant haematologist says in his book, Sickle Cell Disease: A Guide for Patients, Care and Health Workers, that the disease developed as "a by-product of human defence mechanism against malaria."

Some experts, among them Dr. Aluoch, dispute the link between sickle cell gene and malaria. Dr. Aluoch admits, however, "it has been established that those children with sickle cell trait are able to survive malaria attacks better than those with normal haemoglobin."

The highest incidence of sickle cell disorders in the world is said to be among the Bakonjo people of the Ruwenzori Mountains in Western Uganda's border areas with Zaire. Here, because of communication problems in the mountain forest, inter-marriage is common among close families, hence the rampant incidence of sickle cell anaemia due to the high carrier rate.

Presently, the only available treatment for sicklers which is close to a cure is the bone marrow transplant. This procedure is done in some specialised centres in Italy, United States of America, England, Israel, South Africa, Iran and others.

The bone marrow transplant is meant to change the sickle cell anaemia patient into a carrier or sickle cell negative, depending on the status of the donor. It is an expensive and tricky undertaking, with some bodies rejecting foreign marrow weeks after the operation.

The transplant is best in children between two and ten years when chances of rejection are lower. Chances of rejection are also lower when the donor has a compatible marrow as the patient.

Lucy's daughter, Adongo Ambala, 8, underwent transplant in Italy in April this year, thanks to donations from friends, relatives and especially the " invaluable help" of Rev. Fr. Renato Sesana Kizito, an Italian missionary priest of the Comboni Missionaries, and David and Sarah, an Italian couple.

Chances of Adongo's body rejecting the foreign marrow donated by her twin sister, Apiyo who is only a carrier, are now slim and their mother is very hopeful that the transplant will in due course successfully change Adongo's status from a sickler to a carrier.

While the mean age one can live with the disease in Kenya today is 20 years, only a very small number of sicklers survive up to adulthood and even have children. Prof. Aluoch says he has himself looked after a 66 year-old woman with sickle cell anaemia, who is also a mother of four healthy children.

He recommends extra care for sicklers and especially prompt response to crises. This includes taking their prescribed drugs and any other medication such as blood transfusions without fail.

He also advises that in the case of children, they should be kept warm and dry, especially in cold or wet weather. They also require lots of fluids to avoid dehydration. They should also be exempted from strenuous activities.

Prof. Aluoch advises that when one is diagnosed as a sickler, the patient should be attended to by the same doctor or medical institution, simply due to the fact that both become familiar with that particular condition.

Other experts recommend the formation of national sickle cell associations similar to "heart foundations" or "cancer groupings" in regions where the hereditary ailment is endemic.

October 21, 1996


Nigeria;
RIOTS ROCK NIGERIA AS SHIITE GROUP'S COMPLEX DEMOLISHED


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

LAGOS (APS) OCTOBER 7 - Nigerian security forces demolished on September 29 an educational and religious complex being built by the fundamentalist Shiite Muslims in the northern town of Zaria, Shiite sources said on September 30.

The complex comprising a school and a prayer room, was under construction in the Padamar Bono district of Zaria - a stronghold of the fundamentalists, who are still angry about the arrest on September 15 of their leader Sheikh Ibrahim Ahmed Zak-Zaki.

The latter was detained after bloody clashes between Christians and Muslims which left two dead and 15 injured at the beginning of September in the mainly Muslim Kaduna state.

Since then at least 17 people have been killed in clashes between the fundamentalists and police during demonstrations organised to demand Zak- Zaki's release. 

More than 70 supporters of Zak-Zaki have been arrested and around 60 have been charged with offences which carry the death penalty.

No charges have been brought so far against Zak-Zaki who, according to relatives and press reports, has been moved to Port-Harcourt in the extreme south of Nigeria to lessen the risk of his supporters making attempts to free him.

The troubles by the fundamentalists also spilled over to neighbouring Niger, where security forces were forced to move in and arrest 17 of the Islamic extremists that claim support for Zak-Zaki who is well-known for making inflammatory statements that have often triggered bitter fighting between Christians and Muslims, Niger's local radio reported on September 18.

Citing local authorities, the radio further said that Niger Muslim fundamentalists were arrested on September 13 in Maradi, in eastern Niger, near the border with Nigeria.

Northern Nigeria is populated mainly by Muslims, who form about 45 per cent of the country's total population of more than 100 million people.

Meanwhile, furious crowds set fire to a church connected with a series of gruesome ritual murders and burned down a score of other buildings in a town in south-eastern Nigeria before police and troops restored order on September 26.

Residents of Owerri, contacted on telephone said the security forces appeared to have stopped the rioting, which began on September 24 after police handed the body of a murdered, headless child to his parents and uncovered a trail of bloody killings.

More human remains, including two heads and two tongues, were found in the church on September 25, before angry residents of Owerri burnt it down, torched other buildings and wrecked dozens of cars in spite of measures by the authorities to quell the rioting, according to press reports.

The government-owned daily Times said that no fewer than 20 human skulls had been found in different parts of Owerri and local people linked the ritual murders with notorious alleged swindlers in the town and burnt down their homes during the rampage.

The military administrator of Imo state, Colonel Tanko Zabairu, imposed an overnight curfew on Owerri late on September 25 and pledged in a radio broadcast to shed light on the string of killings there.

One of the first targets of the mobs on September 24 was a hotel where police discovered the body of the 11-year-old child, peanut seller Ikechukwu Antony Okonkwo, after finding his head in the boot (truck) of a car during a routine check.

Police arrested the car's driver, an unidentified man of 32 who worked at the hotel, who later died in mysterious circumstances on September 22.

Before crowds set fire to the hotel on September 24, police unearthed 17 other headless bodies there, according to the daily Times, while the independent Champion said human remains had been found in nine graves dug on the premises.

Some 15 more buildings were burnt down on October 1 and soldiers were despatched to Owerri to help restore calm.

Africa News


October 21, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
AFRICAN CHURCHES CHALLENGED TO INCLUDE WOMEN, YOUTH


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

HARARE (APS) OCTOBER 7 - Churches in Africa have been challenged to incorporate women and youth in church programmes.

About 80 women and youth delegates, attending a pan-African consultation here from September 30 to October 4 on the subject; Celebrating in Hope; Restoring Just Relationships emphasized the fact that although women and youth comprise the majority of followers in any given Christian community, their presence is not matched with the kind of responsibility they are accorded in the church arena.

"In some instances, they (youth) have been regarded as radicals when they have raised their concerns on certain issues concerning their role in the church. The phenomenon has reduced some of them to mere church goers rather than participants in the vineyard," Rev. MacDonald Sylvester Sembereka, one of the regional co-ordinators for the Association of Christian Lay Centres in Africa (ACLCA), which had organised the consultation, complained. 

In her presentation focussing on the marginalisation of women and youth, Cameroonian social worker Mrs. Grace Eneme, said women's demand for equal participation with men in the vineyard has been viewed as "simple noise from women wanting to be equal with men."

She cited the issue of women's ordination into priesthood as a case at hand. Despite the fact that women have raised the concern for some time now, women's ordination continues to divide rather than unite the church, Eneme lamented.

The delegates, who represented member lay centres of ACLCA were drawn from Kenya, Zimbabwe, Uganda, Tanzania, South Africa, Lesotho, Cameroon, Sierra Leone, Benin, Malawi, Zambia, Egypt, Uganda, and Ghana. There was also an invited fraternal delegate from the Netherlands.

The consultation deliberated on various issues including drug abuse and trafficking, human rights, democracy and civil society; liberalization of economies and their effects; marginalisation of women and youth and caring partnership with the environment.

"The issues were designed to match with the ACLCA silver jubilee celebrations, under the challenging theme; Celebrating in Hope; Restoring Just Relationships, and we hope they will not only have impact on the celebrations, to be marked from October 6 to 13, but also in the years to come," said Rev. Johan Katoneene, the association's Executive Secretary in an interview with APS here.

In her paper on drugs abuse and trafficking, Zimbabwean health educator Mrs. Ginah Madlela told delegates that the trends in the frequency of drug abuse reveal a general increase in the problem.

"Although many of the so-called hard drugs which are freely available in many countries throughout the world are severely restricted or prohibited in Zimbabwe, nevertheless such common drugs as alcohol and tobacco also have far reaching health and social consequences," she stressed.

Although drugs in medicine are prescribed following clinical diagnosis with the intention to cure disease, with others going to induce comfort and relieve pain, the Zimbabwean health educator cautioned that "drugs need wise use as their misuse is dangerous, producing effects of dependence, overdose and even death."

At the end of the consultation, delegates made various recommendations. These included an appeal on churches in Africa to change their current structures, to accommodate the equal participation of women, youth and men in church development.

"As of now, some of the church structures make it impossible for women and young people to participate fully in the pastoral programmes. Their rights are either blocked or completely not free. We definitely need to change some of the church structures to accommodate this," noted Rev. Lawford Imunde, one of the resource persons at the consultation.

The delegates also called for a change of attitude and mentality among the men, who happen to dominate church leadership.

"Some of them will have to change; lest the change changes them. Some of their mentality and attitudes towards both women and youth participation in the church are detrimental to the church institution, more so today and should be done away with," remarked a youth delegate from Tanzania.

Churches and church organizations like the ACLCA were called upon to develop diversified programmes which would contribute effectively towards combating issues of human rights and drug abuse/trafficking, which the meeting described as a threat to the health of both the nation and the church.

In a goodwill message to the consultation, the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) Youth Executive Secretary, Mr. Khepi Shole lamented that the consultation is being held at a time when the youth of Africa have little to celebrate about.

"You also meet at a time when we are all witnessing disintegration of social fabrics, breaking of families and relationships, the AACC message further stressed.

But the message also called upon the youth not to despair, saying in celebration there is thanksgiving, unity in relationships and a mission in hope.

Another goodwill message sent from the AACC Women's Desk, assured the meeting and the church in Africa that the women's department was willing to cooperate and work together for a just and better church and Christian communities in Africa.

The message, was delivered on behalf of the AACC by Suzane Mutale of the Women's Desk of the Zambian Christian Council.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


330 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
SCHOLAR STRESSES ROLE OF CHURCH AS AFRICA'S HOPE


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) OCTOBER 7 - The church in Africa should work harder for the survival of the continent, taking into account that she is among the social institutions with facilities and resources for leadership development.

Delivering a public lecture at the University of Nairobi here on September 26, Kenyan theologian Prof. Jesse Mugambi, said.."at a time when state apparatus in many African countries seem desolate, the churches and other religious agencies can and should provide a stabilizing and catapulting influence, on the African societies.

"Philosophy can and should help churches and other religious agencies to become more self-critical in this endeavour of norm- setting," said the theology scholar, who is also a consultant with the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC). 

Cautioning that a society which is religiously divided cannot achieve national unity, Prof. Mugambi quoting the Bible said "...it was for this reason that Constantine summoned and presided over the council of Nicea in the fourth century."

Citing Kenya as an example, Prof. Mugambi said; "In Kenya today, the concern for mutual respect, mutual appreciation and reciprocation will go a long way towards enhancing national cohesion and social harmony. Social reconstruction in this direction, he stressed, can be achieved through the principle of co-existence on the basis of concerns."

He noted that much as common-sense demands that we accept our different individualities, we should at the same time acknowledge that we have many things in common, he emphasised.

Observing that religion can facilitate this perspective, Prof. Mugambi also regretted that "religion has often been used to highlight differences, while it should have been used to promote reconciliation.

Religious people of all religions ought to be peacemakers and agents of reconciliation, Prof. Mugambi pointed out. In all culture, he added, the people are searching for lighthouses in the troubled ocean of life.

But if a religion fails to provide guidance, its followers become very frustrated and end up experimenting with other new cults in their search for help, Prof. Mugambi explained.

The Kenyan scholar singled out South Africa as one country where the church has not only been an important agent of change, but a stabilizing and harmonising factor.

He however, also lamented that in most African countries, the role of religion has sometimes been ambiguous if not confused. He attributed this lack of a clear purpose to failure to know when one should advocate for change and when one should press for conservatism.

Prof. Mugambi challenged the leaders to take up their responsibility seriously arguing that the majority of their followers often depend on that guidance be it headed by conservatives, reformers, iconoclasts or prophets.

That "people live in tension between the past and the future," might sound a commonplace statement said the Kenyan scholar. But he noted that it has very serious implications, given that "whether we shall starve as a nation in the next decade will depend on how we perceive ourselves today."

-0
