Ghana and Liberia;
GHANAIAN BECOMES SALVATION ARMY TERRITORIAL HEAD


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

GHANA (APS) OCTOBER 7 - Colonel John Edward Amoah has been appointed Territory Commander of the Salvation Army in charge of Ghana and Liberia.

Col. Amoah 57, becomes the first Ghanaian Commander since the advent of the Salvation Army in Ghana in 1922. He is currently the chairman of the Christian Council of Ghana.

The new Salvation Army Territorial Commander succeeds Col. William P. Norris who completed his four-year term of office last April and has since left for the United States of America.

Col. Amoah and his wife, Hannah were commissioned as Salvation Army officers in 1960 after two-and- half years' training at the Army's officers training college in Lagos, Nigeria.

While a major, Amoah and his wife served at the Army's International Headquarters in London where he was then the first African under- secretary for the Salvation Army for Africa.

The couple returned to Ghana in July 1993. Col. Amoah's wife, then a lieutenant had served in various capacities at the personnel department of the Salvation Army headquarters.

Meanwhile, the Very Rev. Justice Ofei Akrofi was on September 8 consecrated the eighth bishop of the Anglican Diocese of Accra.

He succeeds Rt. Rev. Bishop F.W.B. Thompson who retired last December after seven years in office.

Bishop Akrofi 54, was educated at St. Peter's Anglican Church School and Ghana Secondary School at Koforidua. He pursued his BSc (Education) and M.Ed in guidance and counselling at Central Connecticut State College in 1969.

He earned his Masters degree in Divinity from Yale University Divinity School.

Bishop Akrofi was ordained priest and deacon in 1976.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


332 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
AFRICA'S COMMUNITY MEDIA WORKERS MEET IN MALAWI


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

MANGOCHI, CENTRAL MALAWI (APS) OCTOBER 7 - More than 130 media workers drawn from all over Africa and beyond arrive in Malawi at the weekend for the start of a week-long conference which will thrash out ways in which community and independent broadcasters, film-makers and publishers can work together more effectively.

According to the Windhoek-based Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), which is organising the conference, the 'Community Voices' meeting will address issues of sustanability of independent media, net-working between media organizations and the reform of broadcasting legislation in Southern and Eastern Africa.

MISA - a non-governmental organization promoting media freedom and diversity - will also hold its annual general meeting during the 'Community Voices' conference. 

Delegates include independent film and video makers, community broadcasters, journalists from both the print and electronic media, representatives of some of the region's public broadcasters as well as members of South Africa's Independent Broadcasting Authority.

"It is heartening to see the Southern African public sector broadcasting Authority taking a keen interest in community and grassroots initiatives like this one," says MISA Director Methaetsile Leepile.

"The conference should come out with strategies for co-ordinating the efforts of the various players in community broadcasting in eastern and southern Africa." The 'Community Voices' conference comes in the wake of MISA's commitment to represent all forms of independent media.

Topics for discussion during the five-day 'Community Voices' conference include, community media funding; the role of community media in promoting democracy and development; capacity building, training needs; and strategies for promoting the reform of broadcast legislation.

The conference will close with the presentation of MISA's annual media freedom award, which goes to an organization or individual in recognition of their contribution towards promoting media freedom in the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region.

Keynote speaker at the award ceremony, to be staged during a gala dinner on October 11, will be Dr. Brazao Mazula, Vice-Chancellor of the University of Mozambique. The Times of Swaziland newspaper, the Zimbabwean feature film 'Flame', and veteran South African journalist, Allister Sparks, have been nominated for this year's MISA award.

During the same ceremony, another award - presented for the first time by Southern Africa Communication for Development (SACOD) an umbrella body of independent film and video-makers - will go to the producers of a video or film which has contributed towards the promotion of democracy and development in the SADC region.

Chairperson of MISA's Chapter in Malawi, Bentry Mndhluli, says Malawi is privileged to host the largest MISA conference yet to be held. "It will be a great opportunity for Malawian journalists to learn from their colleagues elsewhere in the continent. It will also be a chance for us to show them why Malawi is known as the Warm Heart of Africa."

Mundhluli further urges Malawian media workers to take a keen interest in the conference with a view to seeing how they too can work towards promoting media freedom and plurality in all sectors of the media.

Delegates to the MISA 'Community Voices' conference, which is being sponsored by IBIS, the Open Society Institute, the Swedish International Development Aid (SIDA), and Communication Association Foundation, will be drawn from all SADC countries, as well as from Ethiopia, Uganda, Sudan, Kenya, Ghana, Senegal, Europe and North America.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


333 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Liberia;
SCORES KILLED IN NEW FACTIONAL FIGHTING IN WESTERN LIBERIA


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

MONROVIA (APS) OCTOBER 7 - More than 40 people have been killed in fighting between rival groups of the United Liberation Movement (ULIMO), one of Liberia's warring factions, United Nations sources said on October 1.

The fighting in the western Bomi and Grand Cape Mount counties, in which scores of people have been wounded, has threatened the fragile peace process, once again dashing the hopes of war-weary Liberians.

The clashes intensified on September 29 in Sinje, 75 kilometres northwest of here, and came after a latest pact signed in August to end Liberia's civil war, which began in December 1989.

An official of the UN department of humanitarian affairs in Liberia, Kent Page, said aid workers had counted 15 bodies of women and children who were either shot or hacked to death by fighters on the Grand Cape Mount highway on September 30. 

He said relief workers on September 30 brought to Monrovia four wounded people, including an eight-year-old girl with her right foot chopped off, for medical treatment.

Aid staff also saw civilians fleeing down the road on foot with their belongings, while others fled in the forest for safety, Page said.

Humanitarian agencies last week resumed operations in Bomi and Grand Cape Mount counties, which had been cut off for nearly seven months due to clashes between rival ULIMO factions.

But fresh clashes are currently taking place in towns and villages on the Grand Cape Mount highway, with one witness, who arrived in Monrovia late September 30 from Sinje, telling reporters that the town, which has borne the brunt of the renewed fighting, was attacked by members of the ethnic Mandingo faction known as ULIMO-K, the militia loyal to council of state member Alhaji Kromah.

Aid worker Morris Dolley said the fighters arrived in Sinje at dawn on September 29 and began shooting indiscriminately.

"Everyone ran into the bushes, leaving behind our food ration provided by aid agencies. We knew they were ULIMO-K fighters because they were not the ones we were with," Dolley said.

Aid agencies distributed 21 tonnes of relief food, medicines ad other assorted goods on September 27 to some 5,000 residents in Sinje and four other towns along the highway.

A spokesman for ULIMO-K, Alieu Jabateh, denied the accusation his faction was involved in any clashes, saying, "The fighting is between two groups of the Krahn ULIMO wing."

The combat has forced local and international relief agencies temporarily to suspend their operations in the two counties in western Liberia.

Liberia's head of state, Ruth Perry, in a strongly worded statement, on October 1 condemned the new hostilities in Bomi and Grand Cape Mount counties and called on "factions involved in the skirmishes to cease hostilities or be held responsible for endangering the Liberian peace process."

Perry, a member of the council of state which includes rival faction chiefs, said: "I find it difficult to believe that factional leaders would meet at conferences, sign agreements, and embrace one another only to return home and allow the suffering of the Liberian people to continue."

Perry, who was expected to attend the current UN General Assembly meetings in New York, said that while attending a session she would give "a full account of developments in the peace process."

The UN special representative to Liberia, Anthony Nyakyi, said in a statement he was in "shock and anguish" about reports of "a cold- blooded massacre of civilians which took place in Sinje, and promised to make urgent arrangements" to probe the incident.

"The callousness of the attack is demonstrated by the savage hacking of the leg of an eight-month-old girl who was evacuated by relief workers to Monrovia with other wounded victims," Nyakyi said, terming it as "a most serious violation of human rights and the rights of children.

It is also a violation of the ceasefire which cannot go unpunished," he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


334 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Gambia;
GAMBIAN STRONGMAN LEGALIZES HIS RULE CONSTITUTIONALLY


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

BANJUL (APS) OCTOBER 7 - Gambia's military strongman Yahya Jammeh, in power since a bloodless military coup two years ago, clinched victory in presidential polls, finally legalizing his rule constitutionally, official results issued on September 27 confirmed.

But as the results were being announced, his main rival Ousainu Darbo was said to be holed up in the Senegalese ambassador's residence in the Gambian capital, but has since left the embassy and congratulated Jammeh for his victory.

Jammeh, 31, won 55.76 per cent of the vote, electoral commission chairman Gabriel Roberts said on national television, compared with 35.34 per cent for his key rival Darbo.

Some 88.35 per cent of the 446,541 registered voters cast ballots in the September 26 election in this small west African country of 1.03 million people. 

Several thousand supporters of the president went onto the streets of Banjul at nightfall to celebrate his victory, to the sound of drums and music.

Reliable sources said Darbo, a 48-year-old lawyer, had sought refuge in the ambassador's home with his family and three other leaders of his United Democratic Party (UDP) late on September 26 "for security reasons."

At the end of the election campaign pitting Darbo and two other candidates against the 31-year-old colonel, the UDP candidate claimed that there was a plot to assassinate him.

Late on September 27, Jammeh went on television to urge Gambians to forget their political differences and unite to build a better future, saying he was "very surprised" at reports that Darbo had taken refuge at the Senegalese ambassador's residence.

"The election has been peaceful and free and as far as we are concerned, I have nothing against anybody. I have no scores to settle with him," Jammeh said.

Asked if he was disappointed at failing to obtain the 99 per cent of votes he had hoped for, Jammeh said "God decided otherwise."

Jammeh criticised the organization of the elections saying many voters could not find their names on the electoral rolls, notably those who could not read.

On September 22, Darbo's supporters had been accused of attacking Jammeh's motorcade. The opposition leader said three people were killed and 36 wounded in clashes and accused "agents provocateurs" in Jammeh's Alliance for Patriotic Reorientation and Construction (APRC) of organizing the disturbances.

Darbo said Jammeh, who was promoted from lieutenant to colonel before he quit the army to contest the elections, could then declare a state of emergency and cancel the vote.

The election represented the second stage in restoring democratic rule, after a referendum in August in which a large majority of citizens backed a new constitution.

The staged return to democracy is also aimed at winning vital Western development funds, and turnout was high, with some 90 per cent of electors voting in the capital Banjul.

Jammeh, who overthrew Gambia's long-serving president Sir Dawda Jawara in a coup in July 1994, is backed by the army, traditional chiefs who asked him to stand and many young people, following the lowering of the voting age to 18. He has won a certain standing after leading a two-year battle against corruption and unemployment.

During the campaign he traded his normal military uniform for stunning traditional dress, and held top-level discussions with the country's mainly Muslim religious leaders.

Darbo, the deputy head of the Banjul bar association, who leads the new United Democratic Party (UDP), is supported by followers of three banned political parties from the Jawara era.

His rivals claim that he wants to return to the style of the Jawara regime, which the army accused of corruption. He asserts that sources close to State House, the president's residence, told him of an assassination plot.

The two other candidates were far behind the front-runners, the early electoral commission figures showed.

Hamat Bah, 37, a hotel owner and leader of the National Reconciliation Party, took 5.52 per cent of the votes while radical socialist Sidia Jatta, 50, leader of the People's Democratic Organization for Independence and Socialism, took 2.87 per cent. Parliamentary elections are due to take place before the end of the year.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


335 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 21, 1996


Uganda;
UGANDAN BUSINESSMEN PARALYSE ACTIVITY COUNTRYWIDE


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

KAMPALA (APS) OCTOBER 7 - One legislator, a journalist and two unidentified people were arested on October 3, in a crackdown on a four-day contrywide strike by traders protesting the introduction of a new levy - the Value Added Tax (VAT) in Uganda.

Police spokesman Eric Naigambi confirmed that MP John Ken Lukyamuzi was arrested from his home near Kampala but gave no further details.

Journalist Mulindwa Mulwonge working for the Baganda monarchy Central Broadcasting Service (CBS) radio was arrested from his work station a few hours after the nabbing of the Member of Parliament. 

The CBS, owned by Uganda's influential monarchy has been broadcasting interviews given by people commenting on the strike which began on September 30.

The strike action paralysed business throughout the country with streets and shopping centres entirely abandoned. The traders say they will not re- open their business unless Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni tells them when the new 17 per cent VAT will be abolished or reduced.

They say VAT at 17 per cent is forcing them out of business as customers cannot afford to pay the escalated prices on most commodities due to the tax.

The strike action was initiated by the Uganda Import and Export Traders Association (UGIETA) whose members distributed anti-VAT leaflets from door to door in the last week of September after the traders' body issued an ultimatum to the government that it withdraw the controversial tax that was introduced during the budget last July. The leaflets read: "Traders please heed this call. We are suspending operations countrywide starting September."

Former chairman of UGIETA Captain Mike Mukula said the strike action was the outcry of traders who had been subjected to immense harassment by the Uganda Revenue Authority. He conceded that many traders did not get tax clearances because they had failed to keep proper records.

As traders demanded direct talks with President Museveni, they complained bitterly that the Ministry of Finance had not taken heed of their grievances.

Meanwhile, the government has said it will review the matter in two weeks after consultation with the Cabinet. But the Minister in charge of Internal Security Major Tom Butime said the government will also give protection to any traders who wish to open their shops.

This follows reports that many traders were coerced to join the strike against their will. An Indian trader in Iganga, a town in eastern Uganda, escaped mob action after he attempted to open his shop.

However, in Entebbe where the main airport is situated, traders unanimously refused to join in the strike saying it "constitutes a revolt against a popularly elected government."

Observers say the traders' strike will have far reaching repercussions on President Museveni's modernization campaign as it is likely to curtail the flow of funds to the exchequer. According to the budget estimates, Uganda Revenue Authorities collect approximately US$700 million from taxes each year.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


336 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Sudan;
Khartoum Passes Draconian Law on Public Decency


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) -- Authorities in Khartoum, capital of the Sudan, Tuesday, adopted a law that seeks to separate men and women in public places and public gatherings and introduce strict "decency" rules.

The public order, that touches on everything from drinking to dressing, regulates public conduct along the tenets of the Islamic sharia'a law.

The law, passed by the Khartoum state council, says men and women attending public parties such as wedding parties and galas, should be separated by a barrier and they should not sit facing each other.

Women using public transport will not be allowed to sit on the seat near to the driver and the verse from the Koran asking the believers not to look at the opposite sex should be written clearly on the bus wall. 

Owners of cars used for public transport should not write any expression or word that offends the public taste inside the carriage, the law further says.

The law bans the use of tape recordings of "obscene" songs in public transport, public and private places.

Smoking is prohibited in public transport or closed public places, the law stipulates.

In case of demonstrations and popular processions men and women should march in separate columns. Women should be separated from men in public meetings and political gatherings as well .

Men and women, the law further demands, should sit separately in places of recreation.

Women are not allowed to "move about in marketplaces at night unless with a close male relative."

No sports should be performed with short or tight fitting clothes that may reveal the structure of the human body.

Women sports should be performed in private places and away from places frequented by men, the law adds.

Called the Provisional Decree for Public Order of the State of Khartoum for 1996, the law bans the allocation of dark areas in public places where individuals and groups can sit.

Members of folklore troupes are obliged to put on dresses that cover the body when performing their shows, the law says.

No person, male or female, should go out of his house without wearing clothes that well cover the body.

The taking of or trafficking of alcohol and narcotics is prohibited in public and in private places.

The law bans the taking, developing, trafficking and displaying of pictures that contain scenes of naked bodies.

Individuals and groups taking part in picnics, of all sorts, should observe this law.

Males are obliged not to wait near girl schools or the roads leading to these schools without justification.

Public places that render services near girls schools should not use dark glass windows or curtains at the entrances and such places should be well lit.

The law also demands that private schools should separate male students from females.

Pupils are not allowed to move about outside the school fence during the school day without obtaining permission from the school.

Urinating and defecating is prohibited on roadways.

Cards and the like should not be played in front of houses or on public roads.

The Khartoum council has suggested a comprehensive media campaign to explain the law to the public.

Sudan adopted the Islamic sharia'a law in 1983. In 1991 the government of General Omar el Bashir issued an amended version of that law.

In 1992 the government adopted federal rule to run the culturally and ethnically diverse country of 26 million.

Now it remains to be seen whether other states with Muslim majorities would issue laws similar to the Khartoum law.

Already courts in northern Sudan apply the Islamic penal code that prescribes certain punishments for thefts, liquor drinking and adultery according to the teachings of the Koran or the tradition of Prophet Mohammed.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


337 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Business and Finance;
International Coffee Brokers End Tour of Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - An American coffee specialty group concluded a five-day working visit to Ethiopia Tuesday, after a "coffee safari" that also took the group to Kenya.

The tour, organized under the auspices of the California-based Coffee Specialty Association of America, consisted of producers, importers, roasters and retailers representing 15 U.S. firms, as well as Latin American, European and Australian operators. 

The group of 27 delegates, of whom 20 were Americans, visited the country as guest of the Ethiopian Coffee Exporters Association, a private sector brokers group, the Ethiopian Coffee Export Enterprise and the Guna Trading Company.

Apart from briefings by the state-run Ethiopian Coffee and Tea Development Authority, the visitors undertook a two-day field trip to southern Ethiopia. They toured coffee plantations and coffee washing stations at Yirgachefe and Yirgalem, two major coffee-producing areas, respectively 450 and 10 km south of Addis Ababa, the capital.

The United States is Ethiopia's fourth largest coffee importer, accounting for about 40 million dollars of some 280 million dollars the country earned from the crop in the 1995-96 fiscal year ended in June. Total exports of green beans reached 102,000 tons during the period.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


338 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Liberia;
Boutros-Ghali On Strength Of UN Mission In Libera


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

NEW YORK, (PANA) - The United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) will require less than its authorized total strength of 160 military personnel in carrying out its mandate in the West African country, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has said.

In a report Monday to the Security Council, he said that while the final composition of UNOMIL's military component would depend on the deployment of the West African Peace Monitoring Force, or ECOMOG, the U.N. would not field more than 92 military observers.

He said in accordance with UNOMIL's mandate, which includes investigating cease-fire violations and monitoring demobilization and disarmament, the mission would require 1 disarmament team of 6 military observers at each of about five disarmament and demobilization centers. 

UNOMIL will also require 2 mobile teams of 6 observers to monitor the implementation of cease-fire, the disengagement of forces and the collection of weapons at areas other than disarmament and demobilization sites.

The council had requested Boutros-Ghali to submit to it proposals for the assistance to be contributed by UNOMIL in support of the Liberian peace process, particularly in the area of disarmament and demobilization.

To assess the U.N.'s contributions in these areas, Boutros-Ghali sent a technical team to Liberia from Sept. 26 to Oct. 3.

UNOMIL has 10 military observers in Liberia. An additional 24 of these observers are expected to be deployed later in October.

Meanwhile, Boutros-Ghali is yet to comply with another request by the council on the contributions which the international community could make toward the holding of elections in Liberia.

"ECOWAS and the (Liberian) Council of State are continuing consultations on the nature of the role that the international community should be asked to play in the electoral process," he said in explaining the delay in making the recommendations.

He said that with little time left before the elections, scheduled for May 1997, the Economic Community of West African States, which sent ECOMOG to Liberian in 1990, should encourage the Council of State to make an early decision on the issue.

ECOMOG, which still has about 8,500 troops in Liberia, and UNOMIL are monitoring the implementation of the revised Abuja Peace Accord, signed to end just over six years of war in Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


339 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Telecom PTC, Siemens Sign Cellphone Contract


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe Posts and Telecommunications Corporation (PTC) and Siemens Telecommunications of South Africa on Tuesday signed a 240- -million-zimdollar (24 million USD) contract to introduce a mobile telephone service, a first for Zimbabwe.

Postmaster-General Raymond Mutambirwa, who described the development as historic, said negotiations between the two parties had yielded a final contract sum of 24,204,928 U.S. dollars. 

"This day marks a momentous occasion in the history of telecommunications in Zimbabwe-the signing of the long awaited mobile telephone services contract," Mutambirwa said.

The tender was awarded to Siemens Telecommunications (PTY) Ltd of South Africa on Sept. 2, following approval by the government tender board.

"The tender had called for a commissioning period of five months after the effective date of contract for Harare and Bulawayo areas. The other major cities and resort areas shall be commissioned four months later.

"We are confident that the giant Siemens company shall be able to pool all its resources and complete the project earlier than the tender projected time, " he said.

The network will have an initial capacity of 20,000 lines, expandable to 70, 000 with an initial coverage of the major cities, tourist centers and the Harare-Bulawayo highway.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


340 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Kenya Elected To UN Security Council Seat


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

NEW YORK, (PANA) - The United Nations General Assembly has elected Kenya, Costa Rica, Japan, Portugal and Sweden, for two-year terms on the Security Council, starting Jan. 1, 1997.

Kenya, endorsed by the African group at the U.N. for the African seat to be vacated by Botswana at the end of the year, got 172 votes to win in the first round of balloting Monday. 

With 180 member-nations voting, Kenya needed 120 votes to secure its seat under the two-thirds majority rule.

The East African country, which served on the council in the 1970s, will join the Egypt and Guinea-Bissau, which are in the first of their two years as non-permanent members on the 15-member body.

Japan and Sweden also won in the first round. Japan polled 142 votes to beat India (40). Sweden got 153 votes to beat Portugal (112) and Australia (91), thereby clinching one of the two seats reserved for Western European and other states.

In the election for the South and Central America, and Caribbean seat, no winner emerged in the first round, where Costa Rica scored 105, Bolivia 73, and Colombia as well as Dominican Republic got one each.

In the second round of balloting, Portugal outpolled Australia 124 to 57 to win the other seat for Western European and other states. Bolivia withdrew to increase Costa Rica's chances of winning, with 167 votes.

The newly-elected members will join Chile, Egypt, Guinea-Bissau, Poland and the Republic of Korea (South Korea) -- as the 10 non-permanent members.

China, France, the Russian Federation, the United Kingdom and the United States are the five permanent members on the council, the powerful organ responsible for maintenance of international peace and security.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


341 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Zambia;
Commission Sets Zambia's Elections Nomination Dates


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's newly appointed independent electoral commission has set Oct. 25 and 28 as nominations dates, respectively, for presidential and parliamentary candidates intending to contest the general elections in November.

The dates were announced Monday in the capital, Lusaka, by Deputy Director of Elections Joel Sikazwe. The dates, which seem to have caught some opposition parties unawares, were unveiled hours after President Frederick Chiluba swore-in the five-man Electoral Commission, charged with conducting the November polls. 

Presidential candidates will lodge their nomination papers with Chief Justice Mathew Ngulube on Friday. He is, by law, the returning officer for the presidential poll.

Parliamentary aspirants vying for the 150 elective seats will hand in their papers to district executive secretaries in various parts of the country.

Candidates for the presidency will need to satisfy the chief justice that their bid is supported by 200 registered voters who are holders of green national registration cards to confirm their Zambian citizenship. The candidates are also required to pay a 200-U.S. dollar non-refundable election fee.

Those vying for parliament need to produce nine registered voters in their constituencies and pay a 20-dollar election fee.

New constitutional amendments to the citizenship qualification for the presidency require only Zambians with both parents born in Zambia.

This effectively bars the country's first post-independence president, Kenneth Kaunda, who had Malawian parents. He had ruled Zambia from 1964 to 1991.

The new constitution, which is being challenged by Kaunda, also bars citizens who have held the office of president for at least two previous terms.

Kaunda's insistence that he will contest the elections has raised, further, the political tension in the southern African country. He refused Sunday to be photographed together with Chiluba, to signify the leaders' commitment to peaceful elections.

Kaunda charged that there were still serious political and constitutional matters that needed to be ironed out between the government and opposition groups.

The "peace photo" was proposed by church leaders at a national thanksgiving ceremony to mark the country's 32nd independence anniversary Oct. 24 and to pray for peace during elections.

The country's third largest opposition, the Zambia Democratic Congress wrote to the Electoral Commission on Monday to arrange a meeting of political stakeholders in the elections "to level the political playing field."

Highly placed opposition circles among the country's major parties, including Kaunda's United National Independence Party, have spoken out in favor of boycotting the elections in protest against the constitution and the disputed voters register prepared by Nikuv, a private Israeli firm.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


342 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Zaire;
UN Agency To Try Evacuating Stranded Personnel


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - A United Nations agency, the World Food Programme, said Tuesday it would try later in the day to evacuate scores of U.N. personnel and those of non-governmental organizations stranded in eastern Zaire because of fighting between government troops and ethnic Tutsi.

In a statement from its Rome headquarters to PANA in Dakar, it said that the measure followed a last minute decision by Zaire to allow a chartered aircraft to fly into the strife-torn Uvira, in eastern Zaire. 

The number of U.N. and other aid workers stranded there is estimated at between 44 and 54, including two World Food Programme officials.

Aid workers are fleeing the fighting between Zairean troops and ethnic Tutsi, originally from Rwanda but who have been living in Zaire for several generations.

An American-built Hercules transport plane chartered by the U.N. agency has twice tried to fly into Uvira. It was denied permission to land, each time, by the Zaireans.

Authorities "insisted that the plane first stop at Bukavu," the agency said.

The agency said there were reports that refugees were abandoning their camps and that an exodus of at least 200,000 people had begun.

"However, other estimates indicate there may be less than 100,000 refugees fleeing the fighting," it said.

The agency, the largest international food aid donor, has been providing emergency food rations to some 225,000 refugees in the Uvira refugee camps.

It fed at least 50 million people in 1995, including half of the world's refugees and internally displaced people.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


343 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Science and Health;
Experts Meet On Epidemics Control


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso (PANA) - About 100 experts from 10 African countries are meeting in Ouagadougou to work out a strategy for epidemics control in the sub-region.

The meeting, which began Monday, is also aimed at "putting an end to the inadequacies still characterizing our capacity to control epidemics", said Bara Kamfitiye, representative of World Health Organization regional director for Africa. 

For three days, the experts will work out a policy including actions to be taken for epidemiological control and cases management. Their suggestions will also include the launching of immunization campaigns, social mobilization, and epidemics control systems.

The meeting comes ahead of the ministers of health conference to be held Oct. 25 in the Burkinabe capital, to discuss the spread of meningitis, cholera and measles epidemics which have claimed several lives in the sub- region in 1996.

About 150,000 meningitis cases, including 16,000 deaths, and 50,000 cholera cases (4,000 deaths), were recorded in 1996, according to WHO statistics.

"The figures are appalling and unacceptable", Kamfitiye said, adding that, " we have to take coherent and concerted actions."

"Technologies are available, human and financial resources can be found. We have to change our ways of working and direct our actions and resources to get appreciable results," he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


344 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Sudan;
Khartoum Passes Draconian Law on Public Decency

Africa News


October 22, 1996


Business and Finance;
International Coffee Brokers End Tour of Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - An American coffee specialty group concluded a five-day working visit to Ethiopia Tuesday, after a "coffee safari" that also took the group to Kenya.

The tour, organized under the auspices of the California-based Coffee Specialty Association of America, consisted of producers, importers, roasters and retailers representing 15 U.S. firms, as well as Latin American, European and Australian operators.

Africa News


October 22, 1996


Liberia;
Boutros-Ghali On Strength Of UN Mission In Libera


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

NEW YORK, (PANA) - The United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) will require less than its authorized total strength of 160 military personnel in carrying out its mandate in the West African country, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has said.

In a report Monday to the Security Council, he said that while the final composition of UNOMIL's military component would depend on the deployment of the West African Peace Monitoring Force, or ECOMOG, the U.N. would not field more than 92 military observers.

UNOMIL will also require 2 mobile teams of 6 observers to monitor the implementation of cease-fire, the disengagement of forces and the collection of weapons at areas other than disarmament and demobilization sites.

The council had requested Boutros-Ghali to submit to it proposals for the assistance to be contributed by UNOMIL in support of the Liberian peace process, particularly in the area of disarmament and demobilization.

UNOMIL has 10 military observers in Liberia. An additional 24 of these observers are expected to be deployed later in October.

Meanwhile, Boutros-Ghali is yet to comply with another request by the council on the contributions which the international community could make toward the holding of elections in Liberia.

"ECOWAS and the (Liberian) Council of State are continuing consultations on the nature of the role that the international community should be asked to play in the electoral process," he said in explaining the delay in making the recommendations.

He said that with little time left before the elections, scheduled for May 1997, the Economic Community of West African States, which sent ECOMOG to Liberian in 1990, should encourage the Council of State to make an early decision on the issue.

ECOMOG, which still has about 8,500 troops in Liberia, and UNOMIL are monitoring the implementation of the revised Abuja Peace Accord, signed to end just over six years of war in Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

347 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Telecom PTC, Siemens Sign Cellphone Contract


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe Posts and Telecommunications Corporation (PTC) and Siemens Telecommunications of South Africa on Tuesday signed a 240- -million-zimdollar (24 million USD) contract to introduce a mobile telephone service, a first for Zimbabwe.

Postmaster-General Raymond Mutambirwa, who described the development as historic, said negotiations between the two parties had yielded a final contract sum of 24,204,928 U.S. dollars. 

"This day marks a momentous occasion in the history of telecommunications in Zimbabwe-the signing of the long awaited mobile telephone services contract," Mutambirwa said.

The tender was awarded to Siemens Telecommunications (PTY) Ltd of South Africa on Sept. 2, following approval by the government tender board.

"The tender had called for a commissioning period of five months after the effective date of contract for Harare and Bulawayo areas. The other major cities and resort areas shall be commissioned four months later.

"We are confident that the giant Siemens company shall be able to pool all its resources and complete the project earlier than the tender projected time, " he said.

The network will have an initial capacity of 20,000 lines, expandable to 70, 000 with an initial coverage of the major cities, tourist centers and the Harare-Bulawayo highway.
