LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


348 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Kenya Elected To UN Security Council Seat


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

NEW YORK, (PANA) - The United Nations General Assembly has elected Kenya, Costa Rica, Japan, Portugal and Sweden, for two-year terms on the Security Council, starting Jan. 1, 1997.

Kenya, endorsed by the African group at the U.N. for the African seat to be vacated by Botswana at the end of the year, got 172 votes to win in the first round of balloting Monday. 

With 180 member-nations voting, Kenya needed 120 votes to secure its seat under the two-thirds majority rule.

The East African country, which served on the council in the 1970s, will join the Egypt and Guinea-Bissau, which are in the first of their two years as non-permanent members on the 15-member body.

Japan and Sweden also won in the first round. Japan polled 142 votes to beat India (40). Sweden got 153 votes to beat Portugal (112) and Australia (91), thereby clinching one of the two seats reserved for Western European and other states.

In the election for the South and Central America, and Caribbean seat, no winner emerged in the first round, where Costa Rica scored 105, Bolivia 73, and Colombia as well as Dominican Republic got one each.

In the second round of balloting, Portugal outpolled Australia 124 to 57 to win the other seat for Western European and other states. Bolivia withdrew to increase Costa Rica's chances of winning, with 167 votes.

The newly-elected members will join Chile, Egypt, Guinea-Bissau, Poland and the Republic of Korea (South Korea) -- as the 10 non-permanent members.

China, France, the Russian Federation, the United Kingdom and the United States are the five permanent members on the council, the powerful organ responsible for maintenance of international peace and security.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


349 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Zambia;
Commission Sets Zambia's Elections Nomination Dates


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's newly appointed independent electoral commission has set Oct. 25 and 28 as nominations dates, respectively, for presidential and parliamentary candidates intending to contest the general elections in November.

The dates were announced Monday in the capital, Lusaka, by Deputy Director of Elections Joel Sikazwe. The dates, which seem to have caught some opposition parties unawares, were unveiled hours after President Frederick Chiluba swore-in the five-man Electoral Commission, charged with conducting the November polls. 

Presidential candidates will lodge their nomination papers with Chief Justice Mathew Ngulube on Friday. He is, by law, the returning officer for the presidential poll.

Parliamentary aspirants vying for the 150 elective seats will hand in their papers to district executive secretaries in various parts of the country.

Candidates for the presidency will need to satisfy the chief justice that their bid is supported by 200 registered voters who are holders of green national registration cards to confirm their Zambian citizenship. The candidates are also required to pay a 200-U.S. dollar non-refundable election fee.

Those vying for parliament need to produce nine registered voters in their constituencies and pay a 20-dollar election fee.

New constitutional amendments to the citizenship qualification for the presidency require only Zambians with both parents born in Zambia.

This effectively bars the country's first post-independence president, Kenneth Kaunda, who had Malawian parents. He had ruled Zambia from 1964 to 1991.

The new constitution, which is being challenged by Kaunda, also bars citizens who have held the office of president for at least two previous terms.

Kaunda's insistence that he will contest the elections has raised, further, the political tension in the southern African country. He refused Sunday to be photographed together with Chiluba, to signify the leaders' commitment to peaceful elections.

Kaunda charged that there were still serious political and constitutional matters that needed to be ironed out between the government and opposition groups.

The "peace photo" was proposed by church leaders at a national thanksgiving ceremony to mark the country's 32nd independence anniversary Oct. 24 and to pray for peace during elections.

The country's third largest opposition, the Zambia Democratic Congress wrote to the Electoral Commission on Monday to arrange a meeting of political stakeholders in the elections "to level the political playing field."

Highly placed opposition circles among the country's major parties, including Kaunda's United National Independence Party, have spoken out in favor of boycotting the elections in protest against the constitution and the disputed voters register prepared by Nikuv, a private Israeli firm.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


350 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Zaire;
UN Agency To Try Evacuating Stranded Personnel


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - A United Nations agency, the World Food Programme, said Tuesday it would try later in the day to evacuate scores of U.N. personnel and those of non-governmental organizations stranded in eastern Zaire because of fighting between government troops and ethnic Tutsi.

In a statement from its Rome headquarters to PANA in Dakar, it said that the measure followed a last minute decision by Zaire to allow a chartered aircraft to fly into the strife-torn Uvira, in eastern Zaire. 

The number of U.N. and other aid workers stranded there is estimated at between 44 and 54, including two World Food Programme officials.

Aid workers are fleeing the fighting between Zairean troops and ethnic Tutsi, originally from Rwanda but who have been living in Zaire for several generations.

An American-built Hercules transport plane chartered by the U.N. agency has twice tried to fly into Uvira. It was denied permission to land, each time, by the Zaireans.

Authorities "insisted that the plane first stop at Bukavu," the agency said.

The agency said there were reports that refugees were abandoning their camps and that an exodus of at least 200,000 people had begun.

"However, other estimates indicate there may be less than 100,000 refugees fleeing the fighting," it said.

The agency, the largest international food aid donor, has been providing emergency food rations to some 225,000 refugees in the Uvira refugee camps.

It fed at least 50 million people in 1995, including half of the world's refugees and internally displaced people.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


351 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Science and Health;
Experts Meet On Epidemics Control


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso (PANA) - About 100 experts from 10 African countries are meeting in Ouagadougou to work out a strategy for epidemics control in the sub-region.

The meeting, which began Monday, is also aimed at "putting an end to the inadequacies still characterizing our capacity to control epidemics", said Bara Kamfitiye, representative of World Health Organization regional director for Africa. 

For three days, the experts will work out a policy including actions to be taken for epidemiological control and cases management. Their suggestions will also include the launching of immunization campaigns, social mobilization, and epidemics control systems.

The meeting comes ahead of the ministers of health conference to be held Oct. 25 in the Burkinabe capital, to discuss the spread of meningitis, cholera and measles epidemics which have claimed several lives in the sub- region in 1996.

About 150,000 meningitis cases, including 16,000 deaths, and 50,000 cholera cases (4,000 deaths), were recorded in 1996, according to WHO statistics.

"The figures are appalling and unacceptable", Kamfitiye said, adding that, " we have to take coherent and concerted actions."

"Technologies are available, human and financial resources can be found. We have to change our ways of working and direct our actions and resources to get appreciable results," he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


352 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


East Africa;
Weekly Roundup of Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2214 words


 

Nairobi - This is number 31 (14 - 21 October 1996) in a series of weekly reports from IRIN on general developments in the Great Lakes region. Sources for the information below include UN agencies, NGOs, other international organisations and media reports. IRIN issues these reports for the benefit of the humanitarian community, but accepts no responsibility as to the accuracy of the original sources.

Given the events in Eastern Zaire over the last few days, this Weekly Round Up includes events up to and including Monday 21 October.

# Thousands of Hutu refugees are reported as arriving near Bukavu town after having fled refugee camps in the Uvira area on Monday. Yesterday (Monday 21 October), UNHCR declared that the 12 camps, home to 220,000 refugees, two thirds of whom are Burundian, had been deserted and that refugees were heading into neighbouring hills or north towards Bukavu town. Their flight was prompted by fighting between armed groups, including the Zairean Army and Banyamulenge militia, which flared up on Friday and lasted through the weekend, claiming at least 78 lives. The fighting was reported to be particularly intense in the area around the Kiliba airstrip, 20 kms north of Uvira town. (WFP evacuated 48 humanitarian workers from Uvira on Tuesday 22 October 1996.) 

The current crisis is the most serious to have affected Eastern Zaire since refugees began to flee Burundi following the killing of President Ndadaye in October 1993. The fighting which compelled the refugees to leave is a clear sign of the escalation of the conflict, which has been sparked off by claims to Zairean nationality by people of Rwandan descent who migrated into the region over several centuries. The recent upsurge in hostilities follows the 8 October statement by the deputy governor of South Kivu, Lwasi Ngabo Lwabanji, in which he said that the Banyamulenge had one week to leave Uvira for neighbouring countries. The statement prompted Zaire's Prime Minister, Kengo wa Dondo, to suspend the deputy governor for overstepping his authority.

Zaire and Rwanda continue to trade accusations of responsibility for the crisis, with Kengo wa Dondo claiming on Wednesday that the Rwandese Patriotic Army had supplied the Banyamulenge with heavy weapons. The Rwandese Government, for its part, has denied Zaire's allegations and accused the Zairean authorities of instigating the conflict. Meanwhile, responsibility for the attack on Runingo refugee camp during the weekend of 12 and 13 October, which resulted in four deaths and 6 injuries, continues to be unclear, with Banyamulenge spokesmen alleging that the Zairean Army carried it out and the Zairean authorities blaming the Banyamulenge.

The escalating insecurity in the Uvira area has been matched by a growing number of incidents near Goma town in North Kivu. On 21 October there were reports of an attack on the ZCSC contingent base at Katale camp and on villages in the area, while an attack near Kibumba camp on a bus carrying a local football team was reported to have resulted in several deaths. On 6 October a rocket against a bus near Kibumba camp left 7 local people dead and 6 injured. Responsibility for these attacks remains unclear.

The escalating insecurity in the Kivu Provinces prompted expressions of concern from aid agencies and diplomats working on the region. On Thursday the EU's Special Envoy for the Great Lakes, Aldo Ajello, said that the EU was extremely concerned about the tension between Rwanda and Zaire and warned the Zairean Government not to confuse the "limited problem of possible infiltration by young armed Banyamulenge with the much larger problem of the legal status of the Banyamulenge who have long lived, sometimes for several generations, on the plateaux of the Uvira region." He said any such confusion would "spark off a campaign of ethnic hatred". On Friday the ICRC called for restraint by the parties to the conflict and urged them to respect the laws of war and ensure the safety of the staff of humanitarian organizations.

Meanwhile, two senior UN officials are on mission in the region. Ibrahima Fall, the UN Secretary General's Special Envoy to Zaire, is undertaking discussions with the Zairean authorities to quash repeated allegations that the UNHCR has assisted Banyamulenge to infiltrate from Rwanda. These had previously been retracted by the Zairean Government but had later been repeated by General Eluki, Zairean Armed Forces Chief of Staff. The Secretary- General on 14 October dismissed the repeated allegations as "baseless and outdated". Roberto Garreton, the UN Special Rapporteur on human rights in Zaire is also on a two week mission to the region, which began on 14 October.

# Burundi's leader Pierre Buyoya said again at the weekend that the new regime will not be forced into peace talks with rebels while regional economic sanctions on Burundi remain in place. Buyoya told a visiting delegation of foreign ministers that he was committed to eventual negotiations, but would not hold talks "while there was a noose around his neck". The sanctions were imposed by regional leaders shortly after July's military coup in an effort to force Buyoya to unban political parties, restore the constitution and meet rebel groups for peace talks. Buyoya has, to some extent, met two of the three conditions.

Friday's visit by the Ministers followed the 14 October Arusha III Summit where it was agreed that sanctions would continue but that a review would be carried out in Burundi by foreign ministers. The ministers postponed the visit from Wednesday after Buyoya announced that it would not begin talks with rebels until the blockade was lifted. At the Summit, Burundi was given a month's deadline for the start of unconditional all-party negotiations. The next meeting of the sanctions monitoring committee is due to be held in Lusaka on 7 November and there are strong indications that another regional Summit may be held shortly afterwards, perhaps on the 12th. The National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), meanwhile, has stated that it is ready to enter into talks but has urged an extension of the sanctions to cover supplies of arms and ammunition.

Earlier last week, the Prime Minister of Burundi called the sanctions " illegal, unjust and biased" and said that it had already cost Burundi a loss of income of more than US$ 162 million. Food prices in Bujumbura are reported to have stabilised and a steady supply of black market fuel has helped to bring down the cost of petrol and diesel. Burundi's main brewery which suspended distribution last month after two of its staff were killed in ambushes on beer trucks may have to stop operations altogether because of shortages of fuel and spare parts. The brewery is one of the main sources of government revenue.

# The World Health Organisation (WHO) is sending 50,000 doses of vaccine to Burundi in a bid to halt the spread of meningitis which has claimed almost 40 lives. As of 17 October, 131 cases had been registered. Medical supplies were amongst the first items to be exempted from sanctions and over 100,000 doses of vaccine have already been delivered. Doctors say that an early response by the health ministry has averted a crisis on a much larger scale.

# The European Union's special envoy to the Great Lakes region, Aldo Ajello said on Thursday that he hoped for positive results over the repatriation of Rwandan refugees in Zaire. Mr. Ajello said that a plan had been drawn up by UNHCR but that this could be carried out only with the cooperation of the international community, the concerned nations and "above all, cooperation from the nations concerned themselves". Zaire's Prime Minister, Kengo wa Dondo said on Wednesday that Zaire will systematically close the camps before elections scheduled for next year.

# Rwanda has appointed a new Minister of Justice, Faustin Nteziryayo, a university professor and former consultant to the International Monetary Fund. He replaces Marthe Mukamurenzi who resigned last month after being accused of bad management. The appointment coincides with the start of an information campaign on the new legislation designed to facilitate the trial of those accused of genocide. The law was adopted by parliament in August. Over 81,000 people are currently in Rwanda's prisons and places of detention, mostly on charges relating to the 1994 genocide.

# Israel and Rwanda have joined forces to build a memorial in Rwanda for the victims of the 1994 genocide. Following a five day visit to Israel, Rwanda's Vice-President and Minister of Defence Paul Kagame said that he had reached an agreement with Jerusalem's Yad Vashem Memorial to build a similar memorial in Rwanda. Kagame told Radio Rwanda: "We have to perpetuate the memory of the 1994 massacres, reform our judicial system so that criminals will be judged and educate our people to build a united nation". Israeli groups specializing in dealing with genocide have offered assistance to Rwanda and discussions have taken place about Israeli technical aid in training and irrigation, as well as fertilisers and pesticides. Rwanda broke diplomatic ties with Israel in 1976 but restored them after the 1994 genocide.

# Some 84 UN and NGO staff were pulled out of Pakele, northern Uganda after the UNHCR/Lutheran World Federation offices were attacked and ransacked. The armed gang burned vehicles and communications equipment and is reported to have also attacked military installations in the area. The UNHCR office supports about half of the 229,000 Sudanese refugees in northern Uganda.

Over the last few weeks, the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) has been accused of kidnapping 300 Ugandans from villages in northern Uganda and taking them to their training camps in Sudan. On Monday, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni launched a new attack on the Sudan government whom Uganda accuses of supporting two rebel movements, including the LRA, in an effort to destabilise Uganda. Sudan has denied the charges and accuses Uganda of supporting the southern Sudanese rebel groups. The two countries broke off diplomatic relations in April 1995, but signed a normalization accord in September during talks brokered by Iran. Since the peace talks began, there has ironically been a marked escalation in rebel activities in northern Uganda. Museveni's recent comment that he had "no faith in the current negotiations" have cast doubts on the talks.

# Tanzania hopes to reach agreement shortly with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank on the release of funds frozen in 1994. Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa, who met with IMF and World Bank officials in Washington last week, said that the IMF and World Bank were "satisfied" with Tanzania's reform programme. He said both agencies had agreed to resume talks for a three-year Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (US$ 200 million) and Structural Adjustment Credit (US$ 100 million) for 1996/97 and 1998/99 to help rehabilitate the country's economy. Mkapa said that agreement with the IMF and World Bank would lead to the release of aid withheld by other donors amounting to US$ 1.2 billion as well as open the door for negotiations on debt relief. Tanzania's external debt stands at US$ 7.8 billion and its servicing consumes 32.5% of the government's income.

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


353 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Women's Bank Convenes in Nairobi


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

New York - Following is a statement from Women's World Banking on its global meeting next month in Nairobi.

Economic growth through private sector development is working, and the poor are making it happen. Thousands of small-scale businesses and low income entrepreneurs are bringing new dynamism to the economies of many countries around the world, thanks to a handful of innovative financial institutions that provide small loans, savings facilities and business development services to poor microenterpreneurs. The work of these microfinance providers is fast being recognised as one of the most promising efforts to alleviate poverty. 

Women's World Banking (WWB), a leading microfinance organization and the only global microfinance network that focuses exclusively on women, will be holding its biannual global meeting in Nairobi, Kenya from November 4 to 8, 1996. The theme of the meeting will be on developing strategies for expanding WWB's reach and impact globally. The meeting will be attended leaders of WWB's 47 affiliates, as well as the WWB Board. In addition, representatives from other leading microfinance organizations have been invited to share their experiences on building financial services for the poor, especially in the African context.

Nancy Barry, President of Women's World Banking, believes that the global meeting is taking place at a critical time. She says, "if we hope to reduce the gap between the 500 million microentrepreneurs who require financial services and the 10 million who currently receive such services, it is essential to develop strategies for reaching more of the poor in sustainable ways."

Barry believes that the poor are potential economic producers, not permanent consumers of international aid, and that the major impediment to economic development is that low income people lack access to finance, information and markets.

Through its network of affiliates WWB provides loans, savings programs, technical assistance, business development services, and other financial services to thousands of low income women around the world who are not served by formal banks. The affiliates vary in the size of their assets, number of clients, sources of funding, services provided, and age. They all, however share the same mission: improving the lives of poor women by creating economic opportunity.

WWB has shown that increases assets for women lead to important social investments in the family. This means better health and nutrition, education and housing.

In many parts of the world the vast majority of economic activity takes place in small-scale, low-technology enterprises operating outside the formal economy. In Western Africa, for example, it is estimated that this informal sector accounts for a third to a half of GDP, and half to three-quarters of employment. These enterprises are entrepreneurial and market-driven, many are operated by women, and almost all rely on personal sources of credit.

For more information about the WWB Global Meeting please contact Nicola Cunningham Armacost in New York City at 1-212-768-8513, and after November 1 in Nairobi c/o Wairimu Kanja at 569410.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


354 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 22, 1996


Zaire;
Churches Tell of Huge Refugee Flow


BYLINE: Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Washington DC - Text of an ALERT from Action by Churches Together (ACT), a worldwide network of churches and related agencies.

Uvira refugees approaching Bukavu at a rate of 700 per hour Geneva, 22. October, 96: Aid workers at a field hospital in Nyangezi, Eastern Zaire, report that approximately 700 refugees per hour are passing their hospital. The refugees are mainly Hutus originally from Burundi and Rwanda and they are heading north, fleeing fighting around their previous camps in Uvira, Zaire. The field hospital at Nyangezi is operated by ACT (Action by churches together), Norwegian Church Aid and local agency CEPZa/CELPa.Despite a very difficult security and supply situation in the area the hospital staff is trying to provide basic medical assistance to the refugees. 

Nyangezi hospital is just 22 kilometers south of the town Bukavu where the majority of the refugees seem headed for. Only 1.500 - 2.000 refugees out of potentially 250.000 refugees from Uvira have so far reached Bukavu. ACT staff present in Bukavu express great concern for the supply situation in the area. Bukavu is practically cut off from overland routes and only holds food and medicine for a few days. Based on what is available preparations are being made by ACT, UNHCR and other NGOs to cover basic needs of the refugees as they reach Bukavu.

The fighting at Uvira is between Zairian forces and a local Tutsi militia mainly composed of Banyamulenge. This group has been residing in Eastern Zaire long before the influx of Hutu refugees from Rwanda started in 1994. The earliest records of Banyamulenge in Zaire dates several centuries back, but recently their relations to the Za?rian Army and the Hutu refugees in the area have developed into armed confrontations and attacks on civilians on both sides of the conflicts. Sunday and Monday the fighting intensified apparently sending the Za?rian Army forces on the retreat and prompting up to 250.000 Hutu refugees to flee ahead of the attacking Banyamulenge militia. Because of insecurity on the road linking Uvira and Bukavu very little is known about the situation of these refugees. The Banyamulenge militia now seems to be only 50 kilometer south of Bukavu, a major center for humanitarian aid operations in the area. If the armed conflict should spread further into the Bukavu area the humanitarian consequences and related needs are frightening.

Further north in Eastern Zaire armed conflict and detoriating security situation has been reported over the last days with a focus on fighting in the border region between Zaire, Uganda and Rwanda cutting off the main supply road for humanitarian assistance to the camps near Goma. ACT staff present in the area reports Goma town quiet but roads impassable because of landmines. There have been recent attacks at villages and camps at Kibumba and Katale. Food distributions have been suspended for so far two days. All in all the situation in Eastern Zaire gives reason for great concern. ACT and its partners and in Bukavu (Norwgian Church Aid and CEPZa/CELPa) are working toward meeting immediate medical needs while planning further emergency measures. In Goma (ACT/Lutheran World Federation) is monitoring the situation closely in cooperation with UNHCR. These agencies along with other ACT partners in the region (Rwanda, Burundi and Tanzania) are currently drawing up contingency plans for a number of crisis scenarios in the region.

The ACT Co-ordination Office in Geneva will be putting out one or more appeals on the Greater Lakes Region shortly. For further information, please contact the ACT Communications Officer, Mr Nils Carstensen (Direct phone +41 22 791 6039).


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


355 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
African Countries Slide In FIFA Rankings


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Zambia is the only African country that maintained its top slot in the latest ranking of soccer nations released by the world's football governing body, FIFA.

The southern African country was unchanged on the 16th position with 53.57 points, followed by South Africa, which slipped from the 17th to the 19th position with 52.95 points in the rankings released Wednesday from FIFA headquarters Zurich. 

Ghana, with 51.44 points, fell to the 23rd from the 19th position. Zimbabwe moved up the FIFA ladder, from the 67th to 58th position with 37.66 points.

Despite winning the centennial Olympic soccer gold, Nigeria was down to the 63rd position from the 51st, with 36.19 points.

Nigeria's under-23 squad beat all comers to clinch the gold, but Fifa says it does not rank countries based on results of age-group tournaments.

The next African country on the latest FIFA ranking is Kenya, 102nd, up from the 105th with 24.07 points.

World soccer giants, Brazil, Germany and France retained their 1-2-3 slots with 68.38, 64.79 and 61.93 points, respectively.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Sudan;
Floods Kill More Than 100 People In Southern Sudan


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Floods and torrential rains have killed 102 persons and rendered 8,000 homeless in southern Sudan, a government official said Wednesday. 

The number of those killed, since the beginning of the rainy season, is now 123 persons, with scores of thousands rendered homeless.

State minister of the federal government, John Dor Majok, said a committee he heads for the provision of food and assistance to the victims will send a delegation to southern Sudan next week to assess the damage.

"We will conduct an overall survey and send emergency relief assistance to the victims," he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


357 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Bonfrere Resigns from Nigerian Post After Double Deals


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Dutch soccer coach Johannes Bonfrere confirmed Wednesday he was resigning his job with Nigeria after almost two months' double deal even as the country's football association denied knowledge of the breakup.

"I sent my resignation letter in August to the Nigerian Football Association secretary and the chairman, and to Fifa (the world's soccer governing body)," Bonfrere said in a radio interview from Doha, capital of the Gulf state of Qatar.

Reacting to the interview, the spokesman of the Nigerian Football Association, Austin Mgbolu, said as far as he was concerned, "Bonfrere has not ended his two-year contract with Nigeria." 

The Dutchman, who took Nigeria's under-23 team to win the 1996 Olympic soccer gold, has been embroiled in controversy after he failed to return from Atlanta with the victorious squad, claiming alleged shoddy treatment from some officials of the Nigerian Football Association.

Bonfrere, who has a two-year contract with Nigeria which ends in 1997, had ended his initial protest and flown to the country in August to receive the 1. 5 million naira (about 9,000 U.S. dollars) cash prize promised him by the Nigerian government for the Olympic success.

In apparent response to Bonfrere's complaint, the military government effected changes in the composition of Football Association, although independent soccer buffs in Nigeria had always warned that the Dutchman could have a hidden agenda.

This followed the discovery that, under the guise of being on vacation, Bonfrere left Nigeria in August to take up a clandestine two-month contract with the Qatari national team.

In effect, the Dutch coach had enjoyed the best of two worlds, at the expense of Nigeria, according to his resignation "on the air" Wednesday.

Bonfrere declined to give the reason for quitting the Nigerian job. He simply said "Nigerians know why I am leaving."

Legal experts say it is illegal for a coach to handle two national teams preparing for the same Fifa competition.

Soccer analysts say Nigeria may require the services of Fifa to bring the Dutchman to book.

Bonfrere's compatriot and former boss, Clemens Westerhof, left Nigeria in a similar fashion after leading the country to its first world cup outing in USA'94.

The only difference was that Westerhof, who is now jobless after a dismal stint in South Africa, announced his own resignation from his home in The Netherlands at end of his annual contract.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


358 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


South Africa;
Crime Cuts Down Tourism In South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's tourism industry, which surged to new record levels in 1995, is declining in 1996 as a direct result of violent crime in the country's major cities.

Latest figures released by the Central Statistical Service show that potential foreign visitors, fearful of South Africa's notorious crime rate, have begun to avoid the country in favor of alternative holiday destinations. 

It says that hotel bed nights sold to foreign tourists in August dropped below 183,000, a decrease of more than 6 percent in comparison with the same month in 1995.

The most severe effect was felt in Johannesburg, regarded as one of the world's crime capitals, where its share of the national market plummeted to little over half of the level held a year ago, from 20 to only 11 percent.

The top destination in South Africa remains Cape Town and the surrounding wine regions, with a share of more than 26 percent of bed-nights sold throughout the country.

Following South Africa's first democratic elections in April 1994, the country's tourist industry blossomed, and in 1995 tourist arrivals rocketed by more than 50 percent to over 1.1 million.

It was hoped that the boom would continue in 1996, but growing fears over South Africa's mounting crime rate have in fact reversed the trend.

Official police statistics show that the country is one of the world's most crime-ridden societies. A total of just under 2 million serious crimes were reported in the country in 1995, including about 37,000 rapes, 19,000 murders and 67,000 armed robberies. Only half of these crimes have been solved.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


359 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Zimbabwe;
'Death Camp' Sect Refuses Scientific Medication


BYLINE: Elliot Mahende ANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Tendai Murape, 15, lies groaning on an old canvass mat on the dusty floor of a thatched wooden-pole hut.

With his gaunt frame almost limp, he is helped to sit and stare at his visitors.

Tendai can hardly speak or eat because of a severe infection of the throat and chest.

He mumbles a "thank you" for the soft drinks that his visitors have brought him. 

His groans have become part of the sounds of this newly-built bush camp on the western slope of Ziruware hill at Madzima village in Musana communal lands, 70 kilometers (44 miles) north of the capital, Harare, in Zimbabwe's Mashonaland central province. Outside, Dorcas, not her real name, a mental patient, sings praises to "Saint Noah", leader of the Johane Marange apostolic faith sect otherwise known as Noah Momberume. It is based in Eastern Manicaland province.

Dorcas dances, oblivious of the October mid-day heat, the chains and leg irons tying her to a tree and the cries of her sick baby whom she is loath to suckle for now.

In another hut a woman is in labor, while about 10 meters (11 yards) away another patient, Tendai's sister, dozes off under a tree, one of the few moments she can escape the pain that came with complications after she gave birth.

She too is having problems breast-feeding her newly-born baby.

These are the remaining patients of Chitsidzo, as the camp is called by the local members of the purist sect notorious for its total rejection of any form of scientific medication.

Two others, James Murape and his son, Ishmael, died last week while two weeks earlier. On Sept. 26, the camp lost another patient, Annah Murape, again from the same family.

So devastating have been these deaths that some people now call Chitsidzo the "death camp".

But the disaster in the Murape family has not shaken the faith or the bareheaded and single-minded resolve of the elders of the church.

They insist the remaining patients will stay at the camp and will not receive any conventional medication except prayers and water.

Even the thought itself of taking these patients to a hospital or any such institution for treatment is considered a sin.

"The mortuaries are full of dead bodies. There is nothing there that would persuade me to go to hospital. Death is everywhere. We have lost people here just as people have died in hospitals," said Simon Nzou, an elder (or Rabahuma) of the local church.

Nzou's words echo those of other sect members spread across Zimbabwe and in neighbouring countries while the deaths in the Murape family are consistent with the tragedies that have hit sect members across the country because of their rejection of modern medicine.

The Mashonaland Central provincial governor, Border Gezi, recently warned sect members in his province that they risked being arrested if they prevented medical authorities from immunizing their children against child killer diseases.

This followed the deaths of about 10 children of sect members from measles in the northern Muzarabani district.

However, the "apostles" of Madzima village simply hid their children in the mountains, according to the locals, and a few of them were immunized during the recent campaign.

A measles outbreak in Gutu district of Masvingo province two weeks ago claimed the lives of six children believed to have been members of the sect, whose parents also resisted government efforts to have them immunized against child killer diseases.

In another incident, Daniel Mashanda of Uzumba-Maramba-Pfungwe district in Mashonaland East lost his four children to measles in 1995 after refusing to have them treated because of his faith in the sect's teachings.

He later died recently from untreated burns after he refused hospital treatment.

Tendai is trapped in the camp and only survives on the hope that the misfortune that struck his family will not return to him.

The remaining members of his family say he has to stay at the camp. They cannot afford to be heard or even be seen as entertaining the thought of taking Tendai to hospital. Doing so would be an affront to the dignity of their dead father and they might be shunned by other sect members.

"That decision can only be made by you men," says Tendai's mother defensively when it is suggested to her that Tendai should be taken to hospital.

His elder brother, William, says hospital will not be necessary because Tendai will definitely heal.

A healer specializing in "throat-cleansing" was expected to return this week to cleanse Tendai's throat wounds using salt and vinegar and his bare hands.

Forget about anaesthesia, anti-biotics or sterilization of the "surgical instruments".

Last week's "throat cleansing" was not successful because Tendai says the wounds did not heal, swallowing solid food is still painful and only milk and mineral drinks will do for now.

If the faith healers fails to treat him, as has already happened with three members of his family, Tendai might be staring into a long dark future, unless the authorities rescue him.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


360 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Business;
Nigeria Plans Divestment In Vital Petroleum Sector


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian government is giving serious consideration to selling its 57 percent equities in the petroleum sector to private investors, Finance Minister Anthony Ani has said.

Speaking Tuesday in Lagos, at a workshop on "promoting foreign direct investment in Nigeria", he said the move would aim at maximizing the opportunities in the oil sector, which accounts for at least 80 percent of the country's total foreign exchange earnings.

The government, he said, was also willing to grant licenses to competent private investors for the establishment of export-oriented refineries in the country. 

"Government has opened up the gas sector to foreign investment and is willing to consider appropriate tailor-made incentives for private projects in the sector," he said.

Industry officials have said that the American company, Exxon and the French concern, Total, could emerge as major beneficiaries of the divestment plan for five years from 1997. Divestment could affect six oil prospecting joint ventures.

The investment is worth at least 20 billion U.S. dollars.

The six joint venture partners -- Shell, Mobil, Chevron, Agip, Elf and Texaco -- may not have been officially notified of the planned divestment, industry officials said. But the partners could be preparing to use the opportunity in strengthening their shareholding, one official added.

The joint partners held majority interests before the Nigerian government acquisitions from 1971 to 1979 that reversed the order.

Besides the blue chips, indigenous entrepreneurs may be offered fiscal incentives to ease their bids for parts of the equity interest.

At stake is the government's holding on 12 billion barrels of crude oil, or 60 percent of Nigeria's proven oil reserve estimated at 20 billion barrels.

As one of the investment incentives, Ani said that government intended to privatize the country's four refineries after an evaluation of the current value of each of them.

He also said there had been heavy investment in the generation of vital information on solid minerals like coal, gypsum, barytes, kaolin and talc.

There was room, he added, for foreign investors to invest in coal production in the country on their own account or in joint venture projects.

In the unfolding foreign investment drive, private investors are also to enjoy the liberty to use the abundant gas in the country to provide additional energy which could be sold to the National Electric Power Authority or export to other African countries.

Government, the minister said, had also opened up the telecommunication sector to private investment.

He said that Nigeria had decided to privatize a number of state-owned enterprises in order to free the resources tied up in them for other projects. But the measure, he said, would not throw people out of work.

"Clearly there shall be no job-losses arising from the restructuring of enterprises necessitated by privatization," he said.

Instead privatization would open the nation's economy for the needed foreign investment, he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


361 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Zambia;
Main Opposition UNIP To Boycott General Elections


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP), headed by former President Kenneth Kaunda, has decided to boycott the Nov. 18 presidential and general elections in protest against the country's new constitution which bars citizens of migrant parents from contesting the presidency.

The boycott was announced by Kaunda during an emotional press conference in Lusaka, at which he also appealed to other democratic forces within the country to snub what he called President Frederick Chiluba's "sham elections."

Kaunda broke into tears as he berated the Zambian leadership for playing pranks at a time when their countrymen were suffering all sorts of humiliation from poverty and social decay. 

"The UNIP central committee after a thorough examination of the state of the nation and events leading up to the presidential and parliamentary elections set for Nov. 18, has decided that UNIP will not participate in the elections under the current conditions," said Kaunda.

"We the men and women in UNIP, our supporters, sympathizers and all Zambians who appreciate the value of free, fair and legitimate elections are determined to keep the peace as we fight for our rights and rights of fellow Zambians against the evil perpetrated by the MMD through its manipulation of the constitution and the electoral process."

Kaunda said that the decision had been taken in pursuit of the party's cherished ideals of love, truth, honesty, social justice and fair play and intended to establish genuine democracy and good governance in peace, honor and integrity.

It is generally accepted, he said, that free and fair elections is the only way of forming government that would have the confidence of the people, but pointed out that the current electoral process fell short of this requirement.

"From the very beginning there has been no consensus whatsoever among the stake-holders on the process and conduct of the 1996 elections. The entire process has been characterized by irregularities that has led to suspicion and lack of public confidence," alleged Kaunda, who had Malawian parents.

He accused Nikuv, the private Israeli firm, contracted to register voters of mismanaging the entire registration exercise. Only 2.296 million voters were registered out of an estimated 4.6 million eligible voters.

Referring to the new constitution amendments, Kaunda said that it was "a product of extreme bad faith."

"We do not accept that any political party has any rights to impose the constitution on the people of Zambia without their direct consent," said Kaunda, who charged that President Frederick Chiluba and his party wanted to " hold onto power at all costs" to plunder public resources.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


362 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
African Countries Slide In FIFA Rankings


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Zambia is the only African country that maintained its top slot in the latest ranking of soccer nations released by the world's football governing body, FIFA.

The southern African country was unchanged on the 16th position with 53.57 points, followed by South Africa, which slipped from the 17th to the 19th position with 52.95 points in the rankings released Wednesday from FIFA headquarters Zurich. 

Ghana, with 51.44 points, fell to the 23rd from the 19th position. Zimbabwe moved up the FIFA ladder, from the 67th to 58th position with 37.66 points.

Despite winning the centennial Olympic soccer gold, Nigeria was down to the 63rd position from the 51st, with 36.19 points.

Nigeria's under-23 squad beat all comers to clinch the gold, but Fifa says it does not rank countries based on results of age-group tournaments.

The next African country on the latest FIFA ranking is Kenya, 102nd, up from the 105th with 24.07 points.

World soccer giants, Brazil, Germany and France retained their 1-2-3 slots with 68.38, 64.79 and 61.93 points, respectively.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


363 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Sudan;
Floods Kill More Than 100 People In Southern Sudan


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Floods and torrential rains have killed 102 persons and rendered 8,000 homeless in southern Sudan, a government official said Wednesday. 

The number of those killed, since the beginning of the rainy season, is now 123 persons, with scores of thousands rendered homeless.

State minister of the federal government, John Dor Majok, said a committee he heads for the provision of food and assistance to the victims will send a delegation to southern Sudan next week to assess the damage.

"We will conduct an overall survey and send emergency relief assistance to the victims," he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


364 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Bonfrere Resigns from Nigerian Post After Double Deals


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Dutch soccer coach Johannes Bonfrere confirmed Wednesday he was resigning his job with Nigeria after almost two months' double deal even as the country's football association denied knowledge of the breakup.

"I sent my resignation letter in August to the Nigerian Football Association secretary and the chairman, and to Fifa (the world's soccer governing body)," Bonfrere said in a radio interview from Doha, capital of the Gulf state of Qatar.

Reacting to the interview, the spokesman of the Nigerian Football Association, Austin Mgbolu, said as far as he was concerned, "Bonfrere has not ended his two-year contract with Nigeria." 

The Dutchman, who took Nigeria's under-23 team to win the 1996 Olympic soccer gold, has been embroiled in controversy after he failed to return from Atlanta with the victorious squad, claiming alleged shoddy treatment from some officials of the Nigerian Football Association.

Bonfrere, who has a two-year contract with Nigeria which ends in 1997, had ended his initial protest and flown to the country in August to receive the 1. 5 million naira (about 9,000 U.S. dollars) cash prize promised him by the Nigerian government for the Olympic success.

In apparent response to Bonfrere's complaint, the military government effected changes in the composition of Football Association, although independent soccer buffs in Nigeria had always warned that the Dutchman could have a hidden agenda.

This followed the discovery that, under the guise of being on vacation, Bonfrere left Nigeria in August to take up a clandestine two-month contract with the Qatari national team.

In effect, the Dutch coach had enjoyed the best of two worlds, at the expense of Nigeria, according to his resignation "on the air" Wednesday.

Bonfrere declined to give the reason for quitting the Nigerian job. He simply said "Nigerians know why I am leaving."

Legal experts say it is illegal for a coach to handle two national teams preparing for the same Fifa competition.

Soccer analysts say Nigeria may require the services of Fifa to bring the Dutchman to book.

Bonfrere's compatriot and former boss, Clemens Westerhof, left Nigeria in a similar fashion after leading the country to its first world cup outing in USA'94.

The only difference was that Westerhof, who is now jobless after a dismal stint in South Africa, announced his own resignation from his home in The Netherlands at end of his annual contract.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


365 of 541 DOCUMENTS

October 23, 1996

October 23, 1996


Business;
Nigeria Plans Divestment In Vital Petroleum Sector


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words

Africa News


October 23, 1996


Zambia;
Main Opposition UNIP To Boycott General Elections


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words

"We the men and women in UNIP, our supporters, sympathizers and all Zambians who appreciate the value of free, fair and legitimate elections are determined to keep the peace as we fight for our rights and rights of fellow Zambians against the evil perpetrated by the MMD through its manipulation of the constitution and the electoral process."

LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


369 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Business and Finance;
Sweden On Zambian Economy


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Swedish ambassador to Zambia Anders Johnson has said that the decline in economic of Zambia has severely affected the provision of health services.

Mr. Johnson said constant and persistent budgetary allocations for health care were essential if improved health services, productivity and development was to be realised.

Mr. Johnson was speaking today in Lusaka when he officially opened a discusion aimed at revealing Zambia health sector expenditure draft report. 

The 1995 health expenditure draft report estimated that the nation was spending about K177 billion for health services under the 1995 prices, and was being financed by government, donors, ZCCM, households and missions.

According to the report, the government was only spending about 38 per cent of this total amount.

The report further found that over the past two decades, real government spending on health has been terribly squeezed and noted that the reduced funding has also affected other sectors that are funded by government.

The report, which currently under reveal, however, observed that the ministry of health has increased financial allocations for district health centres from 40 to almost 50 per cent during the last three years, but has reduced the uth and other central hospitals allocation from 32 to 23 per cent.

Mr. Johnson noted that difficulties in the provision of health services in Zambia had been hampered by the fact that the economic reform efforts had not yet generated the neccessary growth result a situation which had adversely affected government budget and sustainability of health services.

To alleviate some rigidities in the provision of health services, the ambassador said, there was need for efficiency utilisation of the available resources and need to source for new financing.

And speaking at the same occasion, head of economics department at the University of Zambia (UNZA) Christopher Mupimpila said that sustainable development in a country could only be realised if there was corresponding developments in economic, social and ecological areas.

Dr. Mupimpila said said economic development without corresponding social development and ecological conservation could not be sustainable.

He said provision of social services like health and education was imperative if sustainable development was to be achieved.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


370 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Zaire;
UN Refugee Head Warns of Situation in Zaire


BYLINE: UN High Commission for Refugees


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Geneva - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on Tuesday expressed deep concern over the plight of Burundi and Rwandan refugees forced to flee their camps in eastern Zaire in the face of intensified ethnic fighting.

"I am deeply worried by the widening scale of violence in eastern Zaire in recent weeks that has once again sent tens of thousands of refugees -- women, children, sick and elderly -- fleeing for their lives," High Commissioner Sadako Ogata said in a statement. "Unless all parties to this conflict step back, we are, I am afraid, heading toward a humanitarian catastrophe." 

Ogata also expressed concern for the safety of humanitarian staff who have been unable to carry out their work because of the fighting between Zairian troops and the Banyamulenge, people of Rwandan origin. As of Tuesday morning, more than 50 international staff members of UNHCR, other U.N. agencies and non-governmental organizations were trapped in UNHCR's office in Uvira. Over the last 24 hours, the staff reported they could hear sound of gunfire outside.

"After all our efforts the past few years to provide help and some sense of stability in the Uvira camps in almost impossible conditions, we are once again facing an emergency operation. The refugees and humanitarian workers are at the mercy of a very unstable and dangerous security situation, and it is impossible at this time to predict the outcome. I thus appeal to all sides to halt the violence immediately and avoid another humanitarian disaster in a region that has already suffered enough."

Zairian military authorities report that all 12 camps in the Uvira region have been abandoned because of the fighting. The 220,000 refugees from the camps -- 143,000 Burundi and 75,000 Rwandan -- are reported to be either hiding in the surrounding hills or are heading toward Bukavu, about 75 kms north of Uvira. UNHCR field officers have also observed hundreds of local Zaireans moving towards Uvira town, fleeing the conflict.

Some 3,000 refugees have arrived in the Nyengezi-Mulwa camp in the Bukavu region and scores are in Bukavu town itself. UNHCR is preparing existing camps in Bukavu to receive refugee arrivals from Uvira.

UNHCR field officers expect the Burundi refugees will remain in the Uvira region. Rwandan refugees wishing to return to Rwanda will be assisted.

In the Goma region on Sunday, there were military reports of fighting in the vicinity of three camps, leaving one officer dead and another soldier wounded. Reports on the ground indicate that fighting was continuing on Tuesday in at least one area north of Goma.

Zaire hosts 1 million of the 1.6 million Rwandan refugees. The rest are in Tanzania.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


371 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 23, 1996


Zaire;
World Food Program Appeals for Eastern Zaire


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Rome - The World Food Programme today warned that intensified armed fighting and the worsening security situation in eastern Zaire has led to a cut-off in humanitarian supplies which could result in a major hunger crisis affecting over one million Rwandan and Burundian refugees. "Unless supply lines to the refugee camps are opened immediately, the humanitarian consequences in coming weeks could be devastating," said Trevor Rowe, WFP chief spokesman.

"Our window of opportunity is quickly diminishing as events spiral out of control," Rowe added. "We appeal to the international community to exert maximum pressure to ensure the free movement of humanitarian relief." 

WFP has the capability to deliver food stocks from neighboring Uganda and Tanzania for the refugees in eastern Zaire for the next two months. However, delivering the food to the camps has become virtually impossible because of worsening security conditions.

"Until we can move the food into eastern Zaire, we face a situation that is daily growing more tense and more desperate," Rowe said. "The situation is made more difficult by the fact that thousands of refugees are now on the move and we are unable to reach them."

Since the weekend 75 WFP trucks with more than 2,200 metric tons of food destined for Goma and Bukavu have been halted at the Zaire/Uganda border for security reasons by Zairian authorities.

In Bukavu, WFP already distributed food supplies to the refugees which will last until the end of the month. The Programme now has only enough additional food stocks to feed the 300,000 refugees for an extra week.

In Goma, WFP has 7,200 tonnes of food in stock. However, while these supplies are enough to feed 727,000 people for three weeks, delivery has been blocked by continued fighting in the north where an estimated 500,000 refugees are camped. Zairian authorities have not allowed relief personnel to enter the area where food warehouses are located. To the west of Goma, where there are some 22O,000 refugees, there are no food stocks.

In order to prevent a major crisis in Goma, WFP intends to cut rations in half in order to extend supplies by an additional week. Nonetheless, with the current influx of refugees the amounts of supplies available will be reduced.

The main route for delivering food to Goma and Bukavu is from Kampala, Uganda. Food for Bukavu had also been arriving via the now strife-torn Uvira region.

In Uvira, where up to 250,000 refugees had been living in camps but where most are reported to be on the move, there are no significant food supplies. Fighting at Uvira between Zairian forces and the Banyamulenge militia has forced a suspension of relief operations. International aid workers from the town were evacuated on a WFP-chartered aircraft on Tuesday.

WFP is monitoring the situation closely in cooperation with other aid agencies. The Programme is drawing up contingency plans for a number of crisis scenarios in the region.

The World Food Programme is the largest international food agency. Last year it fed more than 50 million people, including half of the world's refugees and internally displaced people.

For more information please contact: Trevor Rowe WFP/Rome Chief Spokesman Tel:(396)-5228-2602 679-6565 (home). Francis Mwanza WFP/Rome Information Officer Tel: (396)-5228-2623 5191569. Brenda Barton WFP/Nairobi Tel:254-2- 622794 732-392 (home).

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

372 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Countries Get 16 Million Dollars From BADEA


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa, or BADEA, has approved some 16.5 million U.S. dollars for development and technical help to five African countries.

Some 15.5 million dollars of the money is for development projects and close to one million dollars is grant for technical assistance, the bank said Wednesday in a statement from Khartoum. 

With the new commitment, BADEA's cumulative financial assistance to Africa amount to some 1.8 billion dollars.

The bank approved the assistance during a three-day meeting of its board of directors held Oct. 16 in Amman, Jordan.

Senegal will get 6.7 million dollars for land reclamation and Seychelles 5. 85 million dollars for the rehabilitation of an airport. Namibia is to get three million dollars for road rehabilitation.

Grants for technical help are for Gabon. These will provide services of an expert in agro-economics and for feasibility studies in Guinea, Equatorial Guinea and Namibia.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Nigeria;
University Teachers Suspend Seven-Month Strike


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian university teachers say they will resume classes Monday, ending a seven-month strike called by their union to press for adequate funding of universities and better pay for lecturers.

Announcing the suspension Wednesday, the leader of the proscribed Academic Staff Union of Universities (ASUU), Assisi Asobie, said "the goals of the struggle of the academics and the objectives of the strike will still be pursued through all appropriate and legitimate means."

He described the strike, which began April 9, as the "second phase of the struggle to save Nigerian universities," warning that "true normalcy" would only return to the campuses if the problems identified by the banned union were addressed by government. 

Nigerian university education has been in turmoil since the strike, with the majority of teachers refusing to return to work even under government threats of mass sacking, ejection from official quarters and freezing of their pay.

A number of lecturers fled abroad for better jobs while hundreds of others announced their resignation.

Military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, acknowledged the education problem in his Oct. 1 speech to mark Nigeria's 36th anniversary of independence.

Consequently, he announced that a national panel of professionals and well- meaning Nigerians would be set up to address the crisis.

A cross-section of Nigerians, especially women organizations, appealed for a quick resolution of the problem, before it jeopardized the future of millions of young people.

But Asobie accused government of showing "unwillingness to resolve the industrial dispute through collective bargaining, and ignoring calls by the public ..., even while acknowledging the validity of ASUU's fundamental issues."

He said the teachers met Monday and resolved to shelve the strike " believing that the struggle for the Nigerian universities is a continuous one, part of an unfolding historical process for Nigeria's development."

Critics consider as unsatisfactory the situation of Nigerian universities and the service conditions of its teachers in the oil-rich nation.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


374 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Urges Zambians to Consolidate Democracy


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - President Frederick Chiluba called on Zambians Thursday to strive to build on the country's new democratic culture by tolerating opposing views.

"We should build a strong culture, so strong that divergent opinion will not lead to conflict or conflagration," he said in a speech to mark Zambia's independence from Britain in 1964. "Democracy must be seen as the art of balancing competing interests best resolved by the ballot," Chiluba told guests at his official residence, that included visiting Zairean singer, Tshala Muana.

Chiluba's remarks were generally seen as a direct rebuke of his main political rival, former President Kenneth Kaunda, whose United National Independence Party (UNIP), pulled out of the Nov. 18 parliamentary and presidential elections on Wednesday.

Kaunda, who ruled Zambia from 1964 until 1991, announced that his party would boycott the elections in protest of the new constitution that bars Zambian citizens with migrant parents from contesting the presidency. He had Malawian parents.

Chiluba, however, charged Kaunda of hypocrisy and "immorality" because of denying a section of Zambian voters the opportunity to democratically participate in the elections.

"It is hypocritical and totally immoral for an individual who has not registered as a voter to contrive to deny registered voters their right to vote by invoking individual grievances," said the president.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigerians Unhappy With Bonfrere's Resignation


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerians have reacted with indignation to the sudden resignation of their country's soccer coach, Dutchman Johannes Bonfrere, describing it as a national embarrassment.

"Bonfrere ought to have been fired long ago for taking Nigeria for a ride," sports analyst Lance Aribike said Thursday.

His view is echoed by other soccer fans, who say Nigeria should ignore the Dutchman and concentrate on preparations for international engagements in preparation for World Cup '98 in France.

Soccer buff and image maker of the Central Bank of Nigeria, Tony Ede, said Nigeria should not lose any sleep on Bonfrere's "abscondment." 

He said the country should not let the controversy over the issue impair its preparation for France '98.

Angus Okoli, veteran journalist and former general manager of Nigeria's mass circulation Daily Times newspaper, agrees, saying the Nigerian Football Association (NFA) should not act "as if Bonfrere's departure" meant the end of football in the country.

"Let us forget Bonfrere now because in the first place, we would have been campaigning for a World Cup slot even without him," Okoli added.

He recalled the case of Bonfrere's predecessor, Clemens Westerhof, who left Nigeria in 1994 and is currently jobless after a dismal stint in South Africa.

Okoli and Aribike believe that any coach worth his name will excel in Nigeria where soccer talents abound.

"We have star professional players in abundance with the result that a good coach will even have a problem of choice," Aribike added.

Bonfrere landed the Nigerian job --a two-year contract in 1995 -- after his former boss and compatriot, Westerhof, left Nigeria unceremoniously at the end of the 1994 World Cup tournament in the United States.

Bonfrere soon ran into trouble with the Nigeria Football Association, then headed by Emeka Omerua, which accused him of misappropriation of funds involving 10,000 and 25,000 U.S. dollars he was given on separate occasions to prepare the national team for international engagements.

The Dutchman denied the allegation.

However, after leading Nigeria's Under-23 squad to win the gold at the centennial Olympic games in Atlanta early this year, Bonfrere failed to return with the team to Nigeria.

He went straight home claiming he received shoddy treatment from some NFA officials.

But some Nigerian sports officials insisted the Dutchman had invented the allegation to cover-up the alleged financial impropriety against him.

Bonfrere finally flew into Nigeria in September to receive a national honor --Member of the Order of the Niger (MON) -- and 1.5 million naira (some 9,000 U.S. dollars) as reward from the government for the Olympic success.

He was decorated personally by military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha in a widely publicized ceremony.

The same Bonfrere announced Wednesday that his resignation from the Nigerian job took effect from August.

In its reaction, the NFA has said as far as it was concerned, the Dutchman is still its staff.

"We have not received any letter of resignation from Bonfrere," the FA said in a statement, adding that the Dutch coach was granted a two-month vacation, which expires at the end of October.

It had been revealed that since September, Bonfrere has been handling the national team of the Gulf state of Qatar on another contract worth some 25, 000 U.S. dollars a month, contrary to the rules of the world's soccer governing body, FIFA.

Observers suspect that Bonfrere, who is on a monthly pay of 7,500 u.s. dollars in Nigeria might have been lured by the bigger pay package to the Gulf state.

An official said the NFA is expected to take the case to FIFA if Bonfrere fails to return at the end of October.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


376 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Defence Minister Fired


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopia's deputy prime minister and minister of defence, Tamirat Layne, has been relieved of his post as of Wednesday, state-run radio announced Thursday.

The broadcast said he was relieved of his post after the central committee of the Amhara National Democratic Movement (ANDM), stripped him of his post as secretary of the movement during an emergency meeting on Tuesday, for " acting contrary to the principles for which the ANDM had stood during the last 16 years." 

The broadcast gave no further details.

ANDM is among the four ethnic-based parties that form the coalition of the ruling Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF). The others are the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF), the Oromo People's Democratic Organization and the South Ethiopia Peoples Alliance.

The EPRDF acted swiftly on the decision of the ANDM and accordingly removed Layne.

The Federal Parliament on its part voted Tafara Walwa, president of the Addis Ababa metropolitan administration to replace Layne. ANDM had played a key role in the armed struggle, spearheaded by the TPLF, to oust the former military dictator, Mengistu Haile Mariam, in May 1991, after ruling Ethiopia for 17 years.

As secretary of the ANDM, Layne served as Ethiopia's prime minister during the transitional period.

With a new federal constitution and the country's first multi-party elections in 1995, he joined the cabinet formed in August the same year under Executive Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, holding the key portfolio of deputy prime minister and minister of defence until the announcement of his removal from office Thursday.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Africa-at-Large;

BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words

Grants for technical help are for Gabon. These will provide services of an expert in agro-economics and for feasibility studies in Guinea, Equatorial Guinea and Namibia.

Africa News

Nigeria;

Ethiopia;
Ethiopian Defence Minister Fired


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopia's deputy prime minister and minister of defence, Tamirat Layne, has been relieved of his post as of Wednesday, state-run radio announced Thursday.
