LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


382 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia Celebrates National Day


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba this morning led diplomats accredited to Zambia to the 32nd commemoration of Zambia's national day - independence day - with the laying of wreaths at the Freedom statue in Lusaka.

The ceremony was attended by defence chiefs, ministers and government officials.

Speaking at the ceremony, First Brigade of the Zambia Army chaplain, Major James Phiri said freedom was a duty and responsibility with a claim of justice to the demands of rightful law, governance and guidance of legitimate authority.

Later President Chiluba said that he will not allow the subversion of democracy by individualswhose political agenda is at variance with the wishes of many Zambians. 

The President said elections and the ballot, form the basis of any democracy and therefore no single person should be allowed to defranchise citizens.

"The vote is the one vital and cardinal attribute that differentiates a democracy from a dictatorship, I will defend the right to vote, even if the vote is against my party,' Mr Chiluba said.

He was speaking at State House during independence day celebrations attended by government leaders, diplomats, party cadres and some members of the opposition.

Yesterday UNIP president, Kenneth Kaunda, said that his party was boycotting the forthcoming elections and that he would go flat out to discourage voters in the country to take part in the electoral process.

But President Chiluba described the move as hypocritical and totally immoral for an indivindual who has not even registered as a voter to deny registerd voters their right to vote by invoking individual grievances.

He said responsible leaders should build a society and promote a climate that encourages people to exercise their rights as citizens.

"It is neither responsible nor patriotic to rob registered voters of their vote," he said.

Mr Chiluba said however, that he is aware that the reforms that MMD embarked upon have exacted a toll on the people but that the pain endured should not undermine national stability.

He said every Zambian must assume a personal responsibility to safeguard the country from destructive force saying exmple abound in Africa where selfish political interests have plunged countries into violence and bloodshed.

In Kabwe, Mayor James Chansa, has condemned the recent riots that rocked the town after President Chiluba announced that ougoing central member of parliament, Mr Paul Tembo will recontest the seat.

Speaking at a brief flag hosting ceremony to mark this year's independence day celebrations held at the civic centre early this morning, Mr Chansa said the hooliganism exhibited by some MMD candidates last week was not only embarassing but uncalled for.

He urged MMD supporters in the area to refrain from acts of violence that would disrupt the peace the nation was enjoying, saying last Saturday's incident should not happen again.

"It is unwarranted in a peaceful town like Kabwe, we should remain as peacefula s ever," Mr Chansa said.

Mr Chansa who is Highridge MMD ward councillor also appealed to residents to jealously guard Zambia's hard won independence.

In Solwezi,it was disclosed that fifteen chiefs out of thirty-one in North- Western province have benefitted from the direct funding from President Chiluba for the rehabilitation of palaces.

Provincial permanent secretary, Jairus Kasono said in Solwezi today when he officiated at the celebrations to mark the 32nd anniversary of independence that President Chiluba had so far released a total of K20 million for improving the standards of chiefs palaces.

In Lusaka Zambia Democratic Congress leader, Dean Mung'omba paid tribute to the people of Zambia for maintaining peace since the country attained its independence in 1964.

He was speaking when he addressed a press briefing at his office on the occasion of Zambia's 32nd independence anniversary.

Mr Mung'omba also appealed to all political players to ensure that peace is maintained as the country moves towards the first elections since advent of multi-party democracy.

"I appeal to all political players especially Dr. Kenneth Kaunda who is the most experienced politician to maintain peace for the benefit of the people of Zambia, " he said.

Mr Mung'omba further appealed to the new independent electoral commission to ensure that all registered voters in the country are given a chance to vote.

In Ndola as the date for the presidential and parliamentary elections draws nearer, Mayor Fidelis Kangwa appealed to residents in the town who registered as voters to collect their cards in readiness for the polls.

Mr Kangwa who was speaking at Musa Kasonka stadium during celebrations to mark the 32nd independence anniversary said those who have collected their voters'cards should check for their names on the final roll.

Mr Kangwa said this year's anniversary was special in that it came at a time when parliament has been dissolved and all Zambians who are eligible voters prepare to go to the polls.

"As we celebrate today we should refelct on where we have come from and where we are now," he added.

He observed that experience the Zambians have gone through has enabled them to be in command of their destiny especially given the enabling environment that exists now.

In Livingstone, residents last night celerbated the 32nd independence anniversary with nostalgia when they recalled the old good days when the event was commemorated with enough to eat and fill up stomachs.

In his message southern province permanent secretary Sylvester Mpishi said his office sat to refelct on what used to happen and decided to give a small cocktail to meet as a family to celebrate the happy occasion though with less to eat.

"This year we sat to find how we keep some of our friends happy on this great birth day. we settled to give you a small cocktail, small though but will keep out memories fresh," Mr Mpishi told his audience at the New Fairmount Hotel, the residents later moved to Civic Centre where the Zambian flag was raised at exactly midnight to mark the 32nd birth of the nation.

In Kafue, a civic leader has called on all Zambians in the country to bury their political differences as Zambia commemorates 32 years of independence.

Officiating at independence day celerbations at Khosa stadium in Kafue today, Kafue district council chairman Mr Emmerson Shakombo said Zambians should celebrate their independence as members of one family.

Mr Shakombo told his audience who include Kafue MMD district chairman Dr Goodson Sansakuwa that Zambia would only develop in an environment of peace and tranquility.

In Mufulira thousands of residents converged at Shinde stadium to take part in celebrations marking the country's 32nd independence anniversary.

Town Mayor Levies Bwacha took the salute during a courful march past led by members of the defence forces, combined cadets and school children.

The popular 'Sappers Band' was at hand to provide music and entertaining dances to the crowd. Various other entertaining groups from the churches and school were also present.

The afternoon has been reserved for sports activities that will include a karate competition between ZCCM and Mufulira Municipal council workers, a tug- of-war between the MMD and opposition party members plus netball and football by various school teams.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 24, 1996


Zambia;
Shun Sham Polls ... Appeals Boycotting Opposition


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - UNIP, Zambia's leading opposition party, has decided not to participate in the next month's presidential and general elections "under the current conditions" and appealed to all its "supporters and all peace loving Zambians not to cast their votes in this sham elections".

UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda told a press conference at Lusaka's Pamodzi Hotel yesterday that after a thorough examination of the events leading up to the elections UNIP has decided not to participate.

"The United National Independence Party (UNIP) Central Committee, after a thorough examination of the state of our nation and the events leading up to the presidential and parliamentary elections set for November 18, 1996 has decided that UNIP will not participate in the elections under the current conditions," president Kaunda told a press conference which was attended by most diplomats based in Zambia. 

But ruling MMD national chairman, Sikota Wina, assured that UNIP's boycott " will not affect the timetable for the elections".

Wina, without analysing the similarities and differences of the circumstances, said this was not the first time in Africa the opposition was boycotting elections and urged Zambians to turn up in numbers to cast their votes.

Kaunda declared that he would with immediate effect mount a massive campaign to urge Zambians not to cast their votes to legitimatise the government of President Chiluba.

"All of us will be on tour to tell the people about their plight. UNIP candidates will be in all provinces campaigning that their will be no voting," Kaunda said. " Then this government will fall in the next 3-6 months, that is if there will be elections at all."

But ZDC president Dean Mung'omba, at a separate meeting in Lusaka yesterday, said president Kaunda had made a wrong decision to boycott the elections.

Mung'omba claimed that ZDC had carried out consultations with the people of Zambia who urged them

not to boycott the elections.

"Boycotting elections is not the best solution. We consulted with SADC member countries and the international community and other partners who said the best was to meet Chiluba is at the polls," Mung'omba said.

He added that UNIP should have consulted other opposition parties before deciding to go it alone to boycott the elections.

"Therefore there won't be boycotting," Mung'omba said. " I find it very difficult to take any other decision."

Zambia Civic Education Association (ZCEA) chairperson, Lucy Sichone, said her organisation supported the decision by UNIP on "principle".

Sichone warned that her association will physically disrupt the elections if the government attempted to go ahead under the current conditions.

"No election will take place on the basis of the Nikuv registers," Sichone said in an interview last night. "We want the entire thing to be declared null and void. No Zambians should legitimise the whole process going to the polls."

The Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) described the decision by UNIP as a blow to the democratic process in the country.

ZIMT board secretary, Gershom Musonda, noted that what happened was a " clear manifestation of the frustration UNIP has gone through at the hands of the MMD".

"UNIP was the strongest opponent to MMD. In the absence of UNIP we are now ready to enter into a dictatorship," Musonda warned


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

October 24, 1996


Zambia;
Mugabe Launches Fresh Attacks On Whites


BYLINE: Michael Hartnack, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - A fresh threat from Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe to frustrate the attachment of assets of politically influential debtors is causing concern among the country's financial institutions.

This was carried in Monday's Business Day newspaper of South Africa. 

Speaking at the burial of Simon Muzazenhamo, who died of a heart attack before creditors could foreclose, President Mugabe made a fresh attack on the country's 70,000 whites and alleged they were responsible for the inhuman policies of banks.

"Why should we even keep such people in our institutions at all?" he said.

"They were oppressors yesterday, they are still oppressors today of the liberated people. Where is our freedom if institutions meant to assist our people are destroying them?"

He singled out prominent banker Brian Bostock, agri-business manager for the state controlled Zimbabwe Banking Corporation. Mugabe alleged Bostock had been implicated in irregularities at Zimbank and had victimised blacks from " a sense of grudge".

Zimbank general manager, Sigaboliso Biya, has not commented on Mugabe's attack on Bostock and the policies of the bank, in which the parastatal reserve bank has a controlling interest.

Africa News


October 24, 1996


Zambia;
Privatisation Of Hospitals Worry Experts


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Medical specialists have advised government to ensure that great care is taken when privatising Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines health utilities as they contributed a great deal to the country's health sector.

According to a draft on the study of Health Sector Expenditure Review prepared jointly by the Swedish Institute for Health Economics, the University of Zambia (UNZA) department of economics and the Ministry of Health advised the government to exercise caution when privatising ZCCM's health utilities so that they are taken over in the most cost effective way by the buyers, by other companies and other private sources.

"ZCCM is in the pipeline of being privatised. At present, they account for 12 per cent of the total financing of the health sector, which is a substantial part. As they account for such a large part of health financing in Zambia great care must be taken when privatising the company," the draft report further read. 

According to the financial contribution rating contained in the report, government accounts for 38 per cent of the health sector financing, followed by the donors' 36 per cent while ZCCM is third at 12 per cent.

The remaining section is financed by the households (through chemists) accounting for 10 per cent, followed by other companies at two per cent and lastly at one per cent for missions and non-governmental organisations.

The government funding for the health sector, despite having risen in monetary terms by 14 per cent this year, recorded a decrease in real terms.

"The US$20 per capita was spent on health during 1995, out of which approximately US$7.3 came from the government,has however dropped to US$18 this year due to depreciation of the kwacha," the report further read.

And speaking in an interview at the presentation of a draft at the Swedish Embassy yesterday, Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines group medical services manager, Garvin Silomba, admitted that there was uncertainty over what will happen to the mines health institutions when the mining conglomerate is privatised.

"Its difficult to state whether the investors will want to run the hospitals and health facilities or they may only want to deal with the mines," Silomba said in an interview.

The study also showed that a large proportion amounting to over 62 per cent of private spending is spent drugs which accounts for six per cent of health care spending.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


386 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Consider NGOs As Partners, African Governments Urged


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Le-Reduit, Mauritius - African governments have been urged to consider Non Governmental Organisations (NGOs) as partners in development and not competitors.

African Centre for Democracy and Human Rights executive director, Zoe Tembo, told Mauritian President Cassam Uteem that NGOs played a very significant role in the development of any nation. 

Tembo, a Zambian heading the Gambian-based Pan African institution, said when her group paid a courtesy call on President Uteem at State House yesterday that her organisation was working towards bridging the gap between governments and NGOs on the continent.

"What the organisation is doing is to ensure that the government and NGO officials are trained so that both realise that they have a role to play in the affairs of their countries and that they are fighting for the same cause," she said.

Tembo noted that governments tended to be suspicious of NGOs and regard them as trouble makers because of the foreign funding that most of them get.

Tembo said more seminars were needed to educate both sides to minimise unnecessary suspicions and fears.

Tembo, who is attending the 20th Ordinary Session of the African Commission on Human and Peoples Rights, however, observed that NGOs also tended to view themselves as institutions that were fighting governments.

President Uteem told the delegation that his government appreciated the role of the NGOs and that they would continue to encourage them in their tasks and urged them to pressurise the government and suggest the best course to take on issues relating to human rights in Africa.

Recently the Zambian government threatened to ban some NGOs while Vice- President Godfrey Miyanda told Parliament that his government would start regulating the activities of some of the organisations.

He accused them of not following their constitutions and disrupting some government programmes.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 24, 1996


Zambia;
Catholic Bishops Call For Dialogue


BYLINE: Mukalya Nampito, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's Catholic bishops yesterday, in a pastoral letter, said constructive dialogue on issues like the Constitution, the Electoral Act and voters registration should be encouraged.

The bishops also urged political parties to keep their campaigns pertinent to issues that are important to the people. 

In an elections pastoral letter released yesterday, the bishops said important issues such as service to the poor, social welfare, agricultural policy or economic recovery should be addressed and issues which may be insulting to their opponents and not promote peaceful elections be avoided.

"All parties should have equal access to the publicly owned media which has the duty of reporting political campaigns fairly and accurately," the letter reads in part.

In their letter, the bishops called upon the government and the ruling party to realise that they have a serious responsibility to ensure that the concerns of all key players are adequately addressed.

The bishops also advised the opposition parties to be open and constructive in participating in the electoral process.

"The people of Zambia are urged to be intelligent and responsible voters, informing themselves of the manifestos of the various political parties," the letter reads.

The bishops have said the qualities needed by candidates seeking political office are professional competence, courage to speak out the truth, concern for social justice and desire to work for the common good instead of self- enrichment.

They have also expressed the need to have transparency in the organisation of the elections.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 24, 1996


Cameroon;
President Biya Meets Boutros-Ghali at UN


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

United Nations - The following was issued today by the Spokeswoman for Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali:

On 23 October, the Secretary-General met with President Paul Biya of Cameroon in the latter's capacity as current Chairman of the Organization of African Unity.

Among other issues, they discussed the current tension in eastern Zaire between the Banyamulenge and Zairian forces. Noting with grave concern that the tension was further damaging relations among neighbouring countries and had therefore a very negative impact on the stability of the whole region, they both called upon all the parties involved and the regional leaders to take all the necessary measures in order to bring an end to the violence.

The encouraged the authorities of the region to resume the dialogue and to strive for a lasting and peaceful solution in order to ensure the stability of that area of strategic importance for the African continent as a whole.

President Biya and the Secretary-General declared their readiness to assist all the parties concerned in achieving peace and security, including the convening of a conference for peace, security and development in the Great Lakes region of Africa.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 24, 1996


United States and Africa;
U.S. Calls for End to Zaire Clashes


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Washington DC - Text of statement by Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns deploring the recent fighting in Eastern Zaire.

The United States deplores the recent fighting in Eastern Zaire. Such actions only tend to inflame the already-tense situation in the Great Lakes region of Africa. We call upon all parties to cease the violence and defuse the situation.

We also call upon Rwanda and Zaire to build upon their recent cooperation, which has been evidenced by high-level Zairian visits to Kigali, meetings among Zairian and Rwandan local officials, joint participation in the Carter Center summit process, and partnership in the Arusha series of meetings regarding Burundi.

We are working with UNHCR and the governments of Zaire and Rwanda towards the voluntary repatriation of all the Rwanda refugees. We welcome the Rwandan government's statement urging all refugees to return home.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


390 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
OAU Head Reiterates Support for Boutros-Ghali


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

United Nations - President Paul Biya of Cameroon told the General Assembly this afternoon that, as current Chairman of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), he had been instructed by it to undertake the necessary contacts to ensure a second term for Africa at the head of the United Nations, with Boutros Boutros-Ghali as the OAU candidate.

In his address to the Assembly, President Biya also said that the regional mechanism for the settlement of disputes established by OAU members in 1993 had become the paramount mechanism of preventive diplomacy in the region. However, in order to flourish, regional initiatives must receive adequate material and technical support. He stressed that for Africa, peace was an absolute requirement, so that all of the continent's resources could be committed to development. 

President Biya said the members of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) had met in July and confirmed their support for the re-election of Secretary- General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. The President said that he had been instructed by the OAU to undertake the necessary contacts to ensure a second term for Africa at the head of the United Nations, with Boutros Boutros-Ghali as the OAU candidate.

Continuing, the President said the regional mechanism for the settlement of disputes established by OAU members in 1993 had become the paramount mechanism of preventive diplomacy in the region. However, in order to flourish, regional initiatives must receive adequate material and technical support. In Africa, conflicts within and between States continued. In Angola, peace must be reinforced. Hopes for the return to normalcy in Burundi called for dialogue between all parties and a return to constitutional order. In Rwanda, he welcomed the trial of those suspected of genocide by the International Tribunal for Rwanda, meeting in Arusha, United Republic of Tanzania. The border dispute between Cameroon and Nigeria also continued. His Government had brought the matter before the OAU, the Security Council and the International Court of Justice, in hope of finding a peaceful settlement. The international community must continue to support the peace-keeping efforts of the Economic Community of West African States' Monitoring Observer Group (ECOMOG).

For Africa, peace was an absolute requirement, he said. Peace was necessary so that all of Africa's resources could be committed to development. Africa needed peace to promote democracy, economic development and to build the rule of law. The democratic process must be supported and protected against sectarianism, violence and extremism. Without peace, without development there could be no democracy. Africa was indeed the least developed continent and the most affected by economic crisis. Africa, vulnerable to economic changes, was enduring a widespread tendency towards disinvestment. To ensure stability, increased support from the international community was vital. Programmes, particularly under the encouragement of the United Nations, had been undertaken in support of Africa. Significant resources must be mobilized by the international community to ensure that the programmes were successful.

He called for the revitalization of the United Nations. Equitable geographic representation on the Security Council must be achieved, as must a strengthening of the role of the General Assembly in maintaining international peace, security and cooperation, he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


391 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 24, 1996


Zaire;
Update on South Kivu


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3147 words


 

Nairobi - The information in this report is current as of early this morning (26 October 1996). An evacuation of international aid staff from Bukavu is likely today. The situation is very fluid, and events may overtake this report over the next hours.

1. THE WIDENING CONFLICT

1.1 The conflict in South Kivu is reaching a peak as the provincial capital, Bukavu, is squeezed by military advances from the south and land routes for aid and trade are blocked. An attack on Bukavu is regarded by the Zairean Camp Security Contingent as within the capacity of the Banyamulenge-dominated forces at any time. 

1.2 Despite urgings (and even appeals for contributions for the war effort) from the Zairean Prime Minister and President, it appears clear that the FAZ are losing territory and retreating, sometimes even before engaging the rebels. Zairean forces have been pushed back beyond Nyangezi, less than 30 kms south of Bukavu, where some 10 Zairean Camp Security Contingent soldiers were captured mid-week. The Banyamulenge-dominated forces opposing them now control most of the area between Uvira and Buakvu, including Kamanyola and part, if not all of the border with Rwanda. Zairean forces occupying Uvira have apparently been defeated by the rebels during Friday night and Saturday morning after shelling was reported on the night of the 24th October and in the morning of the 25th. BBC carried an interview with a spokesman for the " Alliance of Forces for Democracy and Liberation of Congo-Zaire", who claimed to be in Uvira, having won the town with a force of 400 fighters.

1.3 The FAZ have mounted roadblocks in Bukavu city for checking identification papers and the number of car-jackings by Zairean soldiers is high - 10-15 UN and NGO vehicles were seized on Tuesday alone. While the Governor declared himself "serene" earlier in the week, the FAZ have reportedly set up defensive positions around the city. A 8pm to 6am curfew was enforced on Wednesday.

1.4 While the Banyamulenge forces control most of the Rusizi plain and probably parts of the Haut Plateaux in the west, some observers expressed surprise that they had climbed the escarpment road and taken highland areas around Nyangezi on Wednesday.

1.5 The ultimate objective of the Banyamulenge-dominated forces is unclear, as the conflict obstensibly began as an exercise in self-defence. The possibility of some kind of "master-plan" linking attacks in North Kivu and the South Kivu conflict is hard to discount entirely.

1.6 Zairean state radio announced that military aircraft are to be deployed in the South Kivu conflict. Further ammunition was supplied to the FAZ during the week. Accusations and denials continue to fly between Kinshasa and Kigali as to the alleged involvement of Rwandan Patriotic Army forces in the fighting. Zaire has also protested to the UN Security Council. There remains no conclusive evidence of RPA involvement nor of Burundian forces taking part. Other allegations include reports of anti-Zairean forces using Burundian and Rwandan territory in the campaign.

1.7 Prompt diplomatic initiatives by the EU, UN and OAU have yet to bear fruit but talks hosted by Belgium have started in an attempt to broker a meeting between Zairean Prime Minster Kengo wa Dondo and either Rwandan Prime Minister Pierre Celestin Rwigema or Vice President and Minister of Defence, Paul Kagame. The US, France and EU Special Envoy have lent weight to Belgian efforts. The UN Secretary-General and the Chairman of the OAU, have lent their support to the idea of a regional Conference for Peace, Security and Development in the Great Lakes Region. UN Special Envoy, Ibrahima Fall, is reported to have made progress in persuading Uganda and Rwanda of the usefulness of the Conference. The UN Secretary-General has further proposed a mediator to negotiate a ceasefire. Zairean President Mobutu is reported to remain in very poor health in Switzerland, adding to the general uncertainty.

1.8 Opposition groups from Rwanda (the RDR) and Burundi (CNDD) have weighed in with statements alleging an over-arching plan for a "Tutsiland" beyond the borders of Rwanda and Burundi. Muller Ruhimbika, exiled Banyamulenge leader of the newly-named Democratic Alliance for the People, said that Shaba and Kasai-based Zairean opposition groups now support the Tutsi rebels. This raises the possibility of an even broader conflict within Zaire. Also the Banyamulenge were ready for talks, he said in a BBC interview on Thursday. On Friday, he upped the stakes by saying to "We are not fighting for the Kivu region, but for the whole of Zaire ... Mobutu must go."

1.9 The widening conflict in North Kivu includes border areas between Uganda and Zaire. Uganda's Major-General Salim Saleh, Special Presidential Advisor on Military and Political Affairs in the North has asked parliament to allow government Ugandan People's Defence Forces to pursue and assault bases of Ugandan rebels in Zaire and Sudan.

2. HUMANITARIAN IMPACT

2.1 As the crisis broke, all 220,000 refugees grouped in the Uvira camps were reported to all have fled. Now, however, it appears that some camps remian more or less intact and the refugees are still in residence. Those that were abandoned have since reportedly been burnt. As far as anyone can tell, four or five camps to the north of Uvira are the ones which have been abandoned. Figures being used by the humanitarian community in Bukavu indicate that there are up to 80,000 mainly Rwandan refugees from the Uvira camps on the move. But some refugees from the Uvira camps have reportedly fled westwards - and some may have returned to Burundi. Since the deterioration in security and the evacuation of relief workers, as many as 140,000 refugees may remain around Uvira and are unlikely to receive any supplies in the near future.

2.2 The second group of affected people are the refugees of the southern Bukavu camps, in particular the two at Nyangezi. A total of 37,000 refugees from those two camps left beginning Tuesday 22 October. In addition, it appears that Nyantende camp may also be abandoned (approximately 9,000 more " displaced refugees" may have moved out).

2.3 The third group of affected people are local Zairean populations displaced by the fighting. In the whole of South Kivu, a current "guesstimate" of the numbers suggests 15,000 displaced in Fizi Zone, south of Uvira, 30, 000 between Uvira and Bukavu and 10,000 in the environs of Bukavu. Some urban Zaireans in Uvira and Bukavu are also leaving town to seek sanctuary in the countryside. These figures are little better than guesses, and needs among this group are likely to be talken care of by relatives. However, the strain of accomodating displaced family members will, in the medium term, begin to take a toll on local services in health and other sectors.

The hospital in Bukavu is full, with wounded soldiers still armed, causing disruption.

3. BREAKDOWN OF POPULATION IN NEED

3.1 Table of current population estimates

Displaced refugees (frm Uvira): 80,000

Displaced refugees (from Bukavu): 46,000

Remaining refugees (at Bukavu): 264,000

Remaining refugees (at Uvira): 140,000

Total: 530,000

3.2 Additional non-food needs are likely for Zairean displaced in the mid- term.

3.3 Up to 16,000 of the estimated displaced refugees from both areas listed above have re-appeared at other Bukavu camps.

3.4 These figures shoiuld of course be treated wiuth caution, as they are " best available" estimates.

4. HUMANITARIAN RESPONSE

4.1 The activities of humanitarian agencies are severly restricted by looting of vehicles in the town, the possibility of ambushes outside and the threat of a rebel assault on the town. WFP had a warehouse looted on Wednesday and a staff member assaulted on Thursday. It is questionable whether the current level of insecurity can be tolerated by the majority of aid agencies, and a planned pull-out is being reviewed constantly. Within these limitations, aid agencies are trying to assist the displaced refugees on arrival at the Bukavu camps, continue services to established refugees and give some support to local structures.

4.2 The displaced refugees are beginning to arrive in westerly Bukavu camps, giuded by Zairean soldiers along the route. This group are - in general - prevented from entering Bukavu by Zairean security forces. As many of the Bukavu camps are effectively "full" (no unused or suitable land is adjacent), UNHCR is encouraging those who wish to stay, to move to emptier camps, and Chimanga in particular.

4.3 Chimanga, managed by CARE, is the most westerly of the Bukavu camps, and had a population of about 18,000 before the crisis broke. So far, about 2, 000 displaced refugees have arrived there. Larger numbers of refugees (7,000- 14,000) have arrived at camps along the route, but protest at having to move further. They are building shelters on the edges of the current camps, and are accepted by the other refugees. Aid agencies are planning to porvide water and high-protein biscuits along the road if security permits.

4.4 The UNHCR, however, has urged the Rwandan refugees to seriously consider retunrning home in a message from Ms Ogata braodcast to the region on 25 October.

5. HUMANITARIAN IMPLICATIONS

5.1 The current land routes to Bukavu seem likely to be closed or unreliable for the near future. If the roads to Uganda, north of Goma become safer, Bukavu could then be supplied by barge from Goma. The road between the two provincial capitals is unsuitable for any truck carrying more than 10 metric tonnes, and even then it is a rough road.

5.2 The southern route through Uvira (itself supplied either by barge from Kigoma, Tanzania, or in the past, overland through Burundi) seems likely to be closed for some time unless there is a resolution to the fighting one way or the other. There are alternative land routes - through Rwanda, but since April 1995, the Rwandan Government has blocked the transit of refugee relief supplies through its territory. On its past record, it would be surprising if Rwanda were to relent now.

5.3 Monthly food requirements for the 310,000 refugees of the Bukavu caseload plus the additional displaced refugees from Uvira could be over 6, 000 metric tonnes per month. The World Food Programme intends to operate an airlift from Uganda to Bukavu, using a C-130 transport aircraft. The first flight of food was planned for Saturday, carrying nutritional biscuits or CSB. However, the supply of the current caseload in South Kivu with a general raytion would be prohibitively expensive. An attempt to supply even a half ration by air could cost well over $100,000 oer day. A single C-130 flight from Entebbe to Bukavu costs between $12,000 to $15,000.

5.4 Other relief items may be deliverable by barge from stock in Goma, but in general, further supplies will have to come by air. However, Bukavu airport is a 40-minute drive north of the town and so is vulnerable to being cut off too.

5.5 The delivery of food and other relief items to Bukavu is only one part of the story. If Bukavu remains cut off, the effects of a de facto blockade will begin to show in fuel shortages, inflation and perhaps additional population displacement and looting. Diesel is already in very short supply.

5.6 The contortions required to "classify" the affected populations in South Kivu are one aspect of the humanitarian system's sometimes overlapping mandates: refugees, internally displaced persons (IDPs) and recipients of " development aid".

5.7 The UNHCR message urges Rwandan refugees to make a virtue of a necessity, and go home where their security and dignity are assured by the Rwandan government and attested to by the international community. While reassuring them that the choice is theirs, in a "terrible" situation, UNHCR urges them to ignore "malicious rumours" when deciding where to go. If the rebels control the southern land border between Rwanda and Zaire, however, there may not presently be a safe corridor for refugees willing to return.

6. CONCLUSIONS

6.1 Reliable information on the number and location of the displaced and refugees of all groups is very scarce. Also, details of the progress of the fighting is almost non-existent. The few foreign journalists in Bukavu are constantly harrassed and asked for bribes. A foreign correspondent (with a valid visa) leaving Bukavu on Friday had to pay a total of $500 in bribes at seven checkpoints along the airport road and at the airport itself. Another journalist, fully accredited with Kinshasa was locked up overnight earlier in the week.

6.2 The size, composition and location of rebel forces is also hard to confirm. Even displaced refugees interviewed at Nyamirangwe could not report actually seeing rebel troops. Several camp populations made decisions to move on hearing shooting or after the Zairean troops pulled out. They do not seem to have fled in panic in disarray, but rather with trepidation, planning and forethought.

6.3 While the situation for the displaced refugees appears precarious, the needs of the remaining Uvira caseload (mainly Burundian Hutus) may in fact be greater and more urgent, given their location near the centre of the conflict, and the complete absence of international aid or monitoring.

6.4 Insecurity may increase in Bukavu, either from a direct attack, or a breakdown in discipline by already jumpy Zairean troops, and trigger an evacuation of aid workers. Already, armed soldiers are paid by agencies when moving around the city, but car-jackings continue. Soldiers are sometimes reported to want the cars to move themselves and their families out of the area.

6.5 Humanitarian agencies should continue to seek access to populations in need, and insist on their impartiality, and state their intentions and modus operandi clearly and publicly. However, given the experience of aid agencies in Uvira, it may be impossible in the short term to deliver even basic life- saving services in South Kivu. The principle of maintaining a joint approach to evacuation and/or suspension of activites among the UN agencies and partners seems well-established. External assessment missions (a two-man French team arrived Friday from Paris) will no doubt proliferate.

6.6 Options open to humanitarian agencies are extremely limited. The current crisis is a "litmus test" of the willingness of Rwandan refugees to return home. The humanitarian community may wish to consider ways to guarantee safe corridors for the refugees to reach Rwanda. For the displaced refugees in South Kivu, there is no easy route to the Rwandan border.

6.7 The real crisis is not about refugees - they, in the widening conflict, are both a symptom and a cause of the problems of the Great Lakes. The status of the Banyamulenge has been an issue for at least 200 years, but the arrival of Burundian and Rwandan refugees over the last three years - caused by internal conflicts - has brought the Banyamulenge's predicament to a climax, and potentially drawn others into the conflict.

6.8 Eastern Zaire - lush, fertile and well-watered, is now the theatre of many unresolved regional political problems. The widening conflict, unless cooled by talks, external military intervention or ceasefire has the potential to generate a new spiral of crises, putting more and more civilian populations at risk, and at worst, breaking into full-scale war.

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

392 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


South Africa;
Mandela Says He Will Not Resign


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - President Nelson Mandela has denied newspaper reports that he is to resign as South Africa's Head of State over party and government differences on economic policy.

Presidential Spokesman Parks Mankahlana said Thursday that Mandela had not threatened to quit if his party, the African National Congress, failed to support his government's macro- economic plan. 

Mankahlana said Mandela would not resign as either the party spot or as President of South Africa, thereby risk driving the nation toward instability.

He said Mandela would push through, the government's controversial economic policy. Although details were still open for discussion, Mankahlana said, the principles of the strategy were not negotiable.

"It is not in the president's nature to deal with matters of national concern in a way that prioritises his personal feelings," Mankahlana added. " We find it strange that there will still be people who, when they come across a rumor of this kind, will not sit back and question whether this is the kind of judgment that would be compatible with President Mandela."

He said that Mandela's recent announcement that he would not be available for re-election in 1997 as A.N.C. president was proof that his main concern was to conduct matters of state in a way which would ensure national stability.

That announcement -- made earlier in the year -- was not, Mankahlana said, related to the refusal by certain A.N.C. party members to the government's macro-economic policy.

A new A.N.C. president will be elected at the 1997 annual congress.

However, Mandela will remain President of South African until the 1999 general elections but will not be available for a second term of this office.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


393 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Ouagadougou To Host Global Coalition For Africa Forum


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina (PANA) - Six African heads of states are expected to attend from Wednesday the 5th forum of the Global Coalition for Africa (GCA), in Ouagadougou, organizers said in the Burkinabe capital.

The presidents of Benin, Botswana, Mali, Senegal and Uganda will join their Burkinabe counterpart for the two-day forum to be preceded from Oct. 26 to 29 by a meeting of 60 NGOs working in the area of development, human rights organizations, trade unions, as well as representatives of the World Bank and IMF. 

The forum will discuss Africa's reaction to the structural adjustment programme and the political transition process.

It will identify the obstacles to economic growth and discuss the creation of bodies necessary for democratic transition, as well as the role of institutions such as the army and civil society.

About 150 participants from Africa, America and Europe will attend the forum.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


Nigeria;
Over 100 Heads of State Expected For Azikiwe's Burial


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian government has announced the programme for the burial of the country's first president, Nnamdi Azikiwe, who died May 11 at the age of 91.

More than 100 heads of state and government are among dignitaries expected to attend Nnamdi Azikiwe's funeral in Nigeria's famous eastern market city of Onitsha, his ancestral home. 

The secretary of the government of Enugu state, one of the present-day nine eastern states, of the former eastern region of Nigeria, where Zik was its premier, Onyeama Ocheoha, told journalists Friday, that the funeral rites would begin Nov. 14 with the arrival of Zik's remains at the Enugu international airport.

A church service will take place at the Nnamdi Azikiwe stadium, Enugu, the same day.

The body will then lie in state at the Onuiyi Haven, in the university town, Nsukka, where the late nationalist, politician, orator, author and journalist spent the greater part of his retirement age.

The University of Nigeria, Nsukka, founded by Azikiwe, who was also called " the Great Zik of Africa", will host a colloquium in his honor.

His remains will later be buried Nov. 16, his 92nd birthday, at his Onira residence in Onitsha.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


395 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


Burundi;
Ninety Days After Buyoya's Putsch


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - The 90 days Maj. Pierre Buyoya has spent as Burundian head of state have been marked by daily violence against a background of severe economic sanctions imposed by neighbouring countries to force the military regime to "restore constitutional legality".

Over 162 million U.S. dollars have been lost in the economic sector, according to figures from the country's prime minister, and at least 10,000 civilians have been killed since the July 25 coup, according to various sources, including Amnesty International.

The short tenure of office of Burundi's new strongman has also been marked by political deadlock, despite concrete measures aimed at improving the local socio-political climate and the lifting of the sanctions. 

Buyoya agreed to the international community's request to restore political parties and the national assembly on Sept. 13, while maintaining the suspension of the constitution which provides that in case of a vacancy at the presidency, the national assembly speaker should be in charge.

A decree establishing the three-year transition was also signed by Buyoya in early September, which meant there is no question of going back to the old constitution and no handing over power to the majority party, the Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU).

This explains the reluctance of FRODEBU and the international community to endorse Buyoya's action. FRODEBU is thus refusing to sit in parliament in the absence of the constitution.

The embargo has been maintained by the regional states. But the prime minister announced the refusal by the government to negotiate with the armed opposition prior to the lifting of the embargo.

This toughening of Burundi's position led the neighbouring countries to send their foreign ministers to Bujumbura on Oct. 18.

A government statement then "commended the contact" and expressed the hope that "the unjust and illegal sanctions" would be lifted swiftly.

Burundi will closely follow developments in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, where a new summit is to be held Nov. 12 by heads of states who imposed the sanctions on Burundi.

However, new developments in the sub-region, including the war between the Banyamurenge (Zairean Tutsi of Rwandan origin) and the Zairean army in eastern Zaire, may further complicate the situation.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


396 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


Uganda;
Some 30 University Students Arrested In Kampala


BYLINE: Moses Draku, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Some 30 students from Kampala's Makerere University were arrested Thursday and 35 others dismissed following a battle with police over the closure of a hall of residence.

The skirmishes flared after police fired tear gas to disperse students who had converged at the campus' Freedom Square to demonstrate.

A cloud of tear gas enveloped the campus as a combined force of some 100 anti-riot and regular police as well as local defence forces stormed the crowd. Dozens of students were injured. 

Announcing the dismissals and arrests, the University Council ordered the rioting students to report for classes or face expulsion.

"Those not reporting should regard themselves as having dismissed themselves from the university forthwith. Furthermore, any student who attempts to stop others from attending classes shall be dismissed forthwith," the council said.

Among the students dismissed were the guild president, Remmy Galogitho, and many of the student leadership.

The closure of Northcote Hall, at the beginning of the academic year early October, followed failure by the university to identify students who, in May, put pieces of broken glass into food meant for students in the nearby Africa and Livingstone halls.

A disciplinary committee chaired by a high court judge was instituted to investigate the matter but it failed to identify the culprits. Then, the university ordered the 720 students of the self-styled "military state" to become non-residents.

Though the university has been besieged by the police for a week, a large assembly of students eluded the security detail Wednesday to forcefully open the doors of Northcote Hall.

Doors and windows were flung open after students broke into the hall and later lit a bonfire in front of the hall. The university administration had declared the hall off limits to students.

Meanwhile, a strike by health workers in Uganda which started Tuesday over higher pay is slowly spreading.

Wards in Mulago Referral Hospital in Kampala were deserted by Friday except a skeleton staff handling emergencies. Strikers are demanding 900,000 Uganda shillings (900 U.S. dollars) monthly for doctors and 175,000 shillings (175 dollars) for support staff. Doctors currently earn 174,000 shillings (174 dollars) a month.

This is the second time in two years that health workers have gone on strike over higher pay. In September 1995, the government persuaded the striking workers to resume duty after promising to look into their grievances.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


397 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


Mozambique;
Mozambique To Have Internet In Six Months


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican and United States governments signed Thursday in Maputo an agreement that will give Mozambique access to the internet communications system.

According to the agreement, signed by Mozambican Transport Minister Paulo Muxanga and the director of the Maputo office of the United States Agency for International Development, George Wachtenheim, complete and quick access to internet will be available in Maputo within six months. 

The system will be available in other major Mozambican cities within a year.

The installation of internet in Mozambique is part of the 'Leland Initiative', launched by U.S. Vice President Al Gore in 1995. Mozambique is the 4th African country to enter the Worldwide Web through this initiative. According to Wachtenheim, eventually 20 African countries will benefit.

Under the agreement, USAID will provide a parabolic antenna and a direct link to the United States at a low cost.

Wacthenheim said that USAID will support all efforts to extend the internet to the largest possible number of users, be they individuals or groups.

"Over the months to come, we will provide technical assistance to identify and overcome hindrances to the quick expansion of the new technology, and will identify potential applications of the internet in the development of Mozambique," he said.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


398 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


Cameroon;
Biya On Bakassi, Boutros-Ghali's Re-election


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations, (PANA) - Cameroon is committed to a peaceful settlement of its dispute with Nigeria over the Bakassi Peninsula, President Paul Biya has told the United National General Assembly.

"From the beginning, we have given precedence to the approach of dialogue and a peaceful settlement of the dispute by bringing the matter before the OAU, the Security Council and the International Court of Justice at the Hague, " Biya said while addressing the assembly in New York Thursday.

He said that Cameroon would accept the decision of the court "as it is appropriate." Both neighbors have clashed repeatedly over the oil-rich peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea, since 1994. 

Biya, who is also the chairman of the OAU (Organization of African Unity), said the numerous conflicts in Africa -- in Somalia, Sudan, Liberia, Angola and Burundi, among others -- were having devastating consequences for the continent.

"Facing so many acute problems today, Africa has to see peace as an absolute requirement," he said.

Biya said although africa was moving along the road to democracy and to the construction of the state of law, poverty was posing the most serious threat to its efforts.

"Africa is indeed the least developed continent," he told the assembly," adding: "it is also the most affected by the disastrous effect of economic crisis."

The OAU chairman listed a number of measures which could help to change the fortunes of the continent, including an increase in the flow of private and public resources to the continent, debt reduction and facilitating access for Africa's exports to the world market.

He praised Boutros Boutros-Ghali, for his "tireless efforts" for the U.N. and for peace, and re-stated the position of the OAU that he should be re- elected for a second term.

"The heads of state and government of countries that are members of the OAU met last july in Yaounde and reconfirmed their trust in him.

"We trust that the members of our organization will thus enable Africa to hold two successive terms at the head of the U.N. just as in the past Asia, Europe and Latin America did," Biya added.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


399 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Countdown To 15th Pan African Film Festival


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina (PANA) - The countdown to the 15th Pan African Film and Television Festival in Ouagadougou (FESPACO) started Thursday with the inauguration of the national committee in charge of organizing the biennial event. 

The 15th FESPACO, slated from Feb. 22-March 1, 1997, will be managed by a National Organizing Committee (CNO) with 46 members.

According to FESPACO permanent general-secretary, Baba Hama, CNO members are resource persons selected on the grounds of competence, experience and devotion to work.

"FESPACO draws its fame from the quality of its organization and the promotion of African cinema," Hama explained.

The theme of the 15th FESPACO, which will also host the 6th congress of the Pan African Cinema Federation, is 'Cinema, Children and Youth'.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Uganda;
Some 30 University Students Arrested In Kampala

Africa News


October 25, 1996


Cameroon;
Biya On Bakassi, Boutros-Ghali's Re-election

SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words

He praised Boutros Boutros-Ghali, for his "tireless efforts" for the U.N. and for peace, and re-stated the position of the OAU that he should be re- elected for a second term.

"The heads of state and government of countries that are members of the OAU met last july in Yaounde and reconfirmed their trust in him.

"We trust that the members of our organization will thus enable Africa to hold two successive terms at the head of the U.N. just as in the past Asia, Europe and Latin America did," Biya added.

October 25, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Countdown To 15th Pan African Film Festival


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina (PANA) - The countdown to the 15th Pan African Film and Television Festival in Ouagadougou (FESPACO) started Thursday with the inauguration of the national committee in charge of organizing the biennial event. 

The 15th FESPACO, slated from Feb. 22-March 1, 1997, will be managed by a National Organizing Committee (CNO) with 46 members.

According to FESPACO permanent general-secretary, Baba Hama, CNO members are resource persons selected on the grounds of competence, experience and devotion to work.

"FESPACO draws its fame from the quality of its organization and the promotion of African cinema," Hama explained.

The theme of the 15th FESPACO, which will also host the 6th congress of the Pan African Cinema Federation, is 'Cinema, Children and Youth'.

Africa News


October 25, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
'Tonga' Museum Opens In Lusaka


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - President Chiluba today called for specialisation of museums in the country to attract more tourists.

In a speech read for him by tourism minister, Gabriel Maka at the commissioning of the museum, President Chiluba said it is only when museums start to specialise in the country's many existing cultural and natural heritage that tourists can begin to stay longer. 

The president suggested that the new Lusaka Museum should specialise in technology while another museum of mining and geology should be set up on the Copperbelt.

"This is a sure way of keeping tourists longer in the country because of the variety of attractions to show," the President said.

He said, however, that museums are a relatively new phenomenon in Zambia and perhaps in sub-saharan Africa and as such not many people appreciate the role of museums.

But Mr Chiluba said many countries in the ancient world including Europe, America, China and India have successfully used museums as major tourists attractions.

He said by their very nature, museums are a source of income to the nation and as such government will continue to support the sector for it to play a positive role in national development.

"To under play the role of museums in our national development is tantamount to denying ourselves our cultural identity,' he said.

And earlier, director of Lusaka museum Francis Musonda said the museum had taken long to be established due to lack of funding.

He called on government to fund the museum adequately for it to perate successfully.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Africa News


October 25, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zambian Farmers Get Help With Maize Sales


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The Agricultural Commodity Exchange (ACE) has finally come to the aid of farmers stuck with large quantities of grain in disadvantaged areas.

ACE is launching an exercise that will see the purchase of maize in these areas.

Peasant and Small scale Farmers Association chairman, Charles Zandala, in an interview yesterday, disclosed that the ACE had asked farmers to gather their grain in strategic points so as to ease the purchase exercise. 

"During my tour of the Kalomo and Mapanza areas, I was impressed to see that unlike the Food Reserve Agency delays to service the disadvantaged areas, ACE has come to the aid of farmers," Zandala said.

Zandala explained that ACE has advised farmers to gather their grain stocks jointly to enable them to sale attractive quantities of maize at fair prices.

"When the maize is grouped together, it will be easier for buyers to target these areas as they will be assured of sourcing large quantities of grain," Zandala explained.

According to the peasant farmers association, farmers in Mapanza area, where the exercise is set to kick off tomorrow, have already gathered 10, 000 bags of grain which will be purchased by ACE.

Zandala complained that the farmers in disadvantaged areas were being " ripped off " by unscrupulous grain traders who had been buying their grain at a meagre K5,000 or by other commodities such as second hand clothes.

But ACE is offering K13,500 per 90 kilogramme bag of maize.

Cavemont Merchant Bank has also followed suit and has set its offer at K14, 500 in all disadvantaged areas.

The government recently allocated K10 billion to the Food Reserve Agency to facilitate the purchase of grain from the remote areas usually shunned by grain traders.

The move was aimed at saving grain from going to waste as most of the farmers do not have proper storage facilities.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

October 25, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
New Recording Studio Opens


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - Lusaka-based music promotions outfit, Digital Network International (DNI), has opened a branch in Johannesburg, South Africa, called Afrogram Records.

The branch, which began operating some two months ago, is being managed by Zambia's theatre-cum-music export to South Africa, Kingsley "Kalicheli" Sinkala. 

"We have signed on eleven South African artistes so far," claimed Sinkala in an interview at the branch located on Market Street near the Carlton Centre. "Our aim is to fuse South African music with Zambian contemporary sound and come up with something unique."

Sinkala's debut album, Katinanga , which is expected to be released sometime next year will be the first LP to be released on the label.

Recorded at the Sound of Soweto studios, the album contains some moving tracks,among them Off To The City, Nka Fwila Mu Chila and the title track, which should appeal to many.

DNI, which is run by Chartered Accountant, Rodger Sombe, has extensive music interests in Zambian show business and has signed on nearly 70 per cent of Zambian artistes.

Business and Finance;
Citibank Scoops Banking Award


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - Citibank, the emerging markets, corporate and international banking institution, last year scooped the Euromoney Best Bank award under a tightly contested annual competition.

According to the latest leading financial periodical, Euromoney , the bank won the prestigious award after what they termed a striking good year which increased earnings to US$3.5 billion despite the returns on equity soaring to 20.8 per cent. 

"On the consumer side of the business, which made up 52 per cent of Citi's US$982 million first quarter core business earnings, the firm is building a strong brand image of efficient and convenient , high quality banking," the magazine read in part.

The banks operations is spread out in 98 countries with over 1,400 corporate client target market.

On the African scene the bank, in the Best Foreign Bank category, outclassed other domestic banks, which the magazine could not mention. Its rating was however demonstrated in the advisory role the bank played during the largest ever domestic share issue in the privatisation of Kenya Airways.

The bank is however growing and last year boasted of a total capital of US$27.7 billion. A further stock buy back programme estimated in excess of US$4.7 billion was announced.

Arts and Entertainment;
Zambian Artists Featured In New Exhibition


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - Out of Oblivion, an exhibition that was opened last Saturday, managed to bring out the thoughts of artists.

With most paintings depicting typical Zambian life, that went down to show how rich the Zambian culture is. 

With the exhibition taking place at a residential area, that was another part that added a whole different feel to the exhibition.

Black Star Liner owner Enock Banda who promoted the function said the venue was a deliberate choice which he knew would add colour to the whole exhibition that ran up to Sunday: "This exhibition was also organised by artists: Anne Legall and Zenab Abad," said Banda.

The exhibition had five big artists: Dominic Yombwe who has exhibited in many group exhibitions since 1991, Godfrey Yombwe who has organised joint exhibition with another reknowned artist Poto Kabwe.

Others were: Maurice Musonda who is currently exhibiting works in public and private collections, Mulenga Chafilwa - coordinator of an upcoming Artist weekend overnight workshop called Imiti Ikula at the Henry Tayali Centre and Evans Kabengele - a self taught artist.

Africa News


October 25, 1996


Zambia;
Amnesty International: MMD Government Manipulating Elections


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Grand Bay, Mauritius - Amnesty International (AI) has accused the Zambian government of manipulating the electoral process and denying popular participation so that it could remain in power.

The charge was made by AI legal adviser for Africa, Ahmed Motala, on Wednesday at the 20th Ordinary Session of the African Commission on Human rights and People's rights (ACHPR) in the Mauritian northern pleasure resort town of Grand Bay. 

Motala's charges on the MMD government were made in the presence of AFRONET president and Zambia's Committee for a Clean Campaign (CCC) chairman, Ngande Mwanajiti and NGO

Co-ordinating Committee board member Phosile Tracy Sichinga.

And AI cited Zambia as one of the three African countries that violates human rights and restricts free political activity.

Motala said despite the existence of multipartyism in Zambia, Kenya and Zimbabwe these countries had closed avenues for peaceful expression of political opposition to their governments.

"There are many African countries where the democratic process is in transition but most of these governments are not committed to respect human rights," Motala told the 20th Ordinary Session ACHPR which is also commemorating the 10th Anniversary of the African Charter.

One of the officials from the ACHPR said that while several governments had been represented, Zambia had not sent any official to the two-week meeting which ends on October 31.

The AI also criticised the serious attacks of the judiciary in Zambia and other countries by the executive, fearing that the criticism could lead to the judiciary being compromised.

The Commission was urged to advise erring countries to stick to last session's resolutions if the independence of the judiciary is to be achieved in African countries.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 25, 1996


Zambia;
EDITORIAL: A Timely And Correct Boycott


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - What's the political or moral justification for supporting fraudulent elections?

It is surprising that people who all along had been complaining that the political play field is not level and any elections held under these conditions will not be free and fair are today urging UNIP not to boycott clearly fraudulent polls.

We have carried many stories in which ZDC leaders were exposing serious flaws in the registration of voters and extensive irregularities in the voters' roll. Even this Wednesday voters' register irregularities were still surfacing. More than 4,000 people who had registered as voters in Livingstone, including High Court judge Christopher Mushabati, were omitted from the roll. 

The electoral arrangements which ZDC, other political parties and civic organisations had great concerns about have not been addressed by the government.

The question is what is the political or moral justification for participating in fraudulent elections?

Is the decision by ZDC and others not to boycott the polls a matter of principle or just expedience in the quest for political power ?

And the now over quoted comparison with what happened in Zimbabwe, Ghana or Cameroon when the opposition boycotted elections has been over generalised.

There are fundamental differences which have been over looked in these comparisons.

Those who boycotted in Zimbabwe, Ghana or Cameroon did not command substantial support as UNIP does. There is a big difference between ZANU- DONGA's size and quality of support and that of UNIP.

And can one imagine what would have happened if the threats which were made by the MMD in 1991 that if their demands for this or that were not met they would boycott elections was actually effected! We were lucky UNIP met all their demands and spared the nation veritable chaos.

And the consensus, which has existed for almost over a year, among opposition parties, NGOs , churches, donors, students and other stakeholders, over the unacceptable electoral arrangements put in place by the MMD government cannot be found in these countries.

Where is the assurance now coming from that these the same electoral arrangements, which have been condemned by the great majority of Zambians, including ZDC, can enable UNIP and other opposition parliamentary candidates to get to the National Assembly?

In fact the withdrawal of UNIP may compel the MMD to rig a few seats for opportunistic parties, like ZDC, which have helped through their participation to render some legitimacy to their fraud, as a reward.

And the fraudulent set up affects presidential and parliamentary candidates in the same way - after all there is only one voters' roll.

Therefore, we believe UNIP's boycott was timely and correct.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


415 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


Zambia;
7 Parties Join Polls Boycott


BYLINE: Mukalya Nampito and Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Lusaka - Seven other opposition parties under the opposition alliance have joined the boycott of next month's presidential and general elections.

But Zambia Civic Education Association (ZCEA) chairperson Lucy Sichone said the opposition parties should go further and disrupt this year's elections because they were fraudulent.

The seven alliance members made the decision on the boycott after a four hour meeting held in Lusaka yesterday afternoon.

They included National Party (NP) Liberal Progressive Front, (LPF) National Democratic Party (NDP), National Salvation Party, Grass Root People's Party, Independent Democratic Front and Labour Party,

UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda's press aide Muhabi Lungu said after the meeting that the alliance has unanimously agreed not to be part of the " confused electoral process". 

"Seven presidents who were present at the meeting have all agreed not to take part in the forthcoming elections," Lungu said.

This brings to eight the number of political parties boycotting the elections after UNIP's pull out on Wednesday.

But Sichone said the opposition should not only boycott elections but should also ensure that they are disrupted. She said the Chief Justice should soon take up the governance of the nation.

"I personally will campaign strongly to ensure that elections do not take place," Sichone said in an interview. "The Chief Justice is a capable man and he will take over the governance while the issues are being resolved."

She said people of Zambia will not sacrifice their "peace and patience for Chiluba to continue in power."

She said it was good that ZDC would field candidates against MMD so that Chiluba is not declared president unopposed after nominations today.

"The fact that they field candidates does not mean they are participating in an election. But a boycott on its own can not achieve anything, something more must be done," Sichone said.

NP, which was represented at the meeting by its president Humphrey Mulemba however gave conflicting statements about its stand.

Earlier in the morning its spokesman Sam Chipungu told The Post his party would take part in the elections in accordance with the demands of its members.

"National Party respects the decision of UNIP. It is an internal matter of the party. We feel National Party should help Zambians make a decision. If the people vote for the same party, then it will be them to blame and nobody else," Chipungu said.

NP vice-president and Lawyer Daniel Lisulo could also not help clarify the position.

"The best man to do that is the president himself who represented the party at the alliance talks this afternoon Lisulo said," adding he was himself ignorant of the party's position.

But NP president, Humphrey Mulemba, speaking in an interview at his Roma residence last night insisted that his party would only participate in the polls if all electoral flaws are addressed.

"As a party, we feel the best way forward is to take part in the elections but if nothing is done on the flaws in the electoral process, we will have no option but to pull out. We are only waiting to meet the Electoral Commission," said Mulemba

But the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC), the National Lima Party and the National Democratic Alliance say they would participate.

National Lima Party co-chairman, Ben Kapita, said his party would participate in the elections because they did not want to make President Chiluba and Kaunda indispensable.

He said his party once in Parliament will advocate for the change of unpopular laws.

LPF acting national secretary, Jennifer Phiri, however said her party would not participate because nothing has been done about the Constitution, Nikuv register, Public Order Act and the unfair coverage by the public media.

She said they would continue fighting for the changing of the Constitution before and after the elections. And she assured her party believes in peace and would not use violent means.

NADA president, Yona Phiri, who was the only opposition leader at the State House's 32nd independence anniversary celebrations, said in an interview yesterday that despite being a member of the inter-party alliance his party would participate in the elections.

"The inter-party alliance is there to reconcile the nation. Each party has its own identity and so NADA will participate in the elections if we have the necessary logistical capacity," Phiri said.

UNIP last Wednesday announced that it would boycott the 'sham' elections and mount a massive campaign to urge Zambians not to cast their votes.

And the Zambia Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) yesterday made a passionate appeal to UNIP to rescind its decision not to take part in the forth coming presidential and general election.

ZCTU secretary general, Alec Chirwa, said in a statement that the absence of UNIP in the elections was a disturbing issue.

Victory Ministeries Pastor Nevers Mumba said he was worried with the turn of events after UNIP announced that it was going to boycott the elections and called on the government to have dialogue with all the stake holders to avert possible violence in the country.

In diplomatic circles, Germany and French ambassadors to Zambia yesterday described as unfortunate the decision by the country's leading opposition, UNIP, to boycott the November 18 presidential and general elections.

Germany ambassador to Zambia Peter Schmidt, in an interview during celebrations to mark the 32nd anniversary of Zambia's independence at State House yesterday, said "UNIP's decision was a big blow to democracy".

"We respect the feelings of president Kaunda and his friends but they have not done a good thing for democracy in Zambia," Ambassador Schmidt said.

He advised that UNIP should have only boycotted the presidential race while fielding candidates in the parliamentary elections.

"The opposition could have made an impact in parliament which could have greatly contributed in the strengthening of the decision making process in the house," Ambassador Schmidt said. " I wish he could reverse his decision but we respect it."

French ambassador to Zambia Phillipe De La Bathie also said it was sad to note that "other people were boycotting elections".

"The decision by UNIP is an internal matter but it is always difficult to see some parts of the country boycotting elections," he said but refused to be drawn into further discussion.

Earlier President Frederick Chiluba, in his speech, accused Kaunda who he said had not even registered as a voter of inciting people not to vote for selfish interests.

"It is hypocritical and totally immoral for an individual who has not registered as a voter to contrive to deny registered voters their right to vote by invoking individual grievances," President Chiluba charged.

But president Kaunda during a press conference and national wide television broadcast on Wednesday, charged that the government of President Chiluba "had seemingly complicated, misrepresented and twisted through a web of deceit issues that were straight forward".

"The bottom line is that the doings of MMD over the Constitution and the elections are all aimed at perpetuating self interests," Kaunda charged on Wednesday. "It relates to the plunder and misappropriation of the country's wealth by a few, self interest as it relates to a few individuals who have so much enjoyed the trapping of political power and will hold on at all costs."


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
