Sports - General;
Zambia: Road Racing Champion To Be Honoured


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - The long-awaited "Meet the African Motor Rally King" braii to honour newly crowned 1996 FIA African Rally Champion, Satwant Singh, will finally take place tomorrow.

Zambia Motor Sports Association (ZMSA) treasurer, Aaron Chungu, said in an interview yesterday that the hurdles that had precluded the holding of the braii for the last two weeks have finally been over come. 

"Every thing is in place and the braii will be held this Saturday," Chungu said explaining that the braii will be preceeded by a march past commencing at 11:00 hours from the Mobile filling station along the Kabwe road, through Cha Cha Cha Road, Cairo road, the Great East Road up to the Lusaka Motor Club in the show grounds, where the braii shall be held.

"Satwant's winning car the Subaru Eprezza will be mounted on a trailer and all those wishing to see it should come," Chungu said.

Gate outlay for the braii is K2,000 for adults and K1000 children. Braii packs will be sold at a nominal fee and there will also be a cash bar.

Africa News


October 25, 1996


South Africa;
Truth Commission Says No Decision On Panel


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by Dr Wendy Orr from the Truth And Reconciliation Commission on October 24.

The statement by Dr Bernard Mandell, newly appointed President of the World Medical Association (WMA), that consensus had developed around the issue (of a separate truth commission for doctors) is premature in that it pre-empts the proceedings of a national consultative workshop on November 23 this year. He was quoted as saying that there is "consensus among his peers that it would therefore be unnecessary to have a separate truth commission."

Because there is still considerable debate and disagreement within the profession as to how best the past can be examined and a future human rights culture ensured within the profession, the TRC will be facilitating this workshop which aims to bring about a consensus amongst the various groupings as to what process should be implemented.

The outcome of this workshop is by no means a foregone conclusion, as Dr Mandell seems to imply.

Dr Orr, who is the deputy chairperson of the TRC's Reparation and Rehabilitation Committee, leaves this week for London where she was invited by the British Medical Association (BMA) to act as consultant on issues relating to the medical profession and human rights. She is also a member of the Medical Association of South Africa's ethics committee.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


418 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 25, 1996


East Africa;
Ogata Urges Rwandan Refugees To Consider Repatriation


BYLINE: UN High Commission for Refugees


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Geneva - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees today urged Rwandan refugees caught in fighting in eastern Zaire to consider returning to Rwanda.

High Commissioner Sadako Ogata, in a statement broadcast by local radio stations in the region, said she was "deeply saddened" that Burundi and Rwandan refugees are again fleeing for their lives.

"I am afraid this terrible situation may not stop immediately, and I would like you to know that we will do everything possible, in cooperation with the authorities, to help you where we can," Ogata said. 

"Because of your current ordeal, I am sure you will consider where you will be safer -- in Zaire or in Rwanda. That is a decision for you to make. However, I am sincerely asking you to remember that 80,000 refugees have recently returned home to Rwanda from Burundi, and UNHCR and UN human rights observers report that they are now busy resuming normal lives."

Noting the Rwandan government has renewed its offer to receive refugees in peace, Ogata said the international community is present in Rwanda to support repeated government assurances that refugees can return safely.

UNHCR Special Envoy Dessalegn Chefeke and Rwandan government representatives on Friday visited the Rwandan border town of Cyangugu in the southwest to look into facilities to receive potential returnees.

There are three reception centers in Cyangugu with a total capacity of 15, 000 per day. UNHCR and the International Organization for Migration have 120 trucks and buses available to transport returnees to their home communes.

UNHCR has stockpiled 50,000 blankets, 25,000 plastic sheets, 60,000 jerrycans, and 34,000 agricultural tools in southwestern Rwanda. It has stocks of non-food items for 300,000 people in Kampala, Uganda, and in Ngara, Tanzania, that can easily be moved overland to Rwanda to meet the needs of returnees. Two emergency teams, each composed of three persons, are prepared to fly to the region.

The World Food Program is providing a two-month food package to the returnees.

More than 300,000 Burundi and Rwandan refugees and displaced Zairians are on the move in the Uvira and Bukavu regions in eastern Zaire. They include the Burundi and Rwandan refugees who left the camps in Uvira and Rwandan refugees in Bukavu who have fled camps in the east to go to the western part of the region, fearing a Banyamulenge attack.

UNHCR has supplies in Bukavu for an estimated 80,000 refugees and displaced Zairians arriving in the area from Uvira, scene of heavy fighting between Zairian troops and the Banyamulenge.

Zaire hosts 1 million of the 1.7 million Rwandan refugees in the Great Lakes region. There also are 143,000 Burundi refugees in Zaire.

UNHCR has been having funding difficulties in its operations in the Great Lakes, which have forced the revision of its 1996 budget from $288 million to $253 million. So far, funds available total $201 million, of which $195 million has been committed.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


419 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 26, 1996


Zaire;
UN Rapporteur Tells of Executions, Arrests and Torture


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Geneva - The Special Rapporteur of the Commission on Human Rights on the situation of human rights in Zaire has received no testimony or other information indicating that there has been any improvement in the human rights situation in there, according to the preliminary observations issued by Special Rapporteur Roberto Garretsn last Saturday upon returning from his latest mission to Zaire.

During the 13 to 25 October mission, which took him to Kinshasa, the north Kivu city of Goma, and the south Kivu city of Bukavu, the Special Rapporteur met with representatives of the Zairian Government and with local authorities. In the three cities, he also heard from several non-governmental organizations and institutions representing civil society and from persons who had requested to meet with him. He was unable to go to Uvira due to the conflict raging there. 

The information Mr. Garretsn gathered told of extrajudicial, arbitrary or summary executions; arbitrary arrests and detention; and torture and ill- treatment of prisoners, all practices facilitated by the persistence of impunity. Moreover, the Special Rapporteur received no response concerning the dozens of cases of human rights violations brought to his knowledge by Zairian citizens and made known to the authorities beforehand.

With regard to the democratization process, the Special Rapporteur observed some progress, as reflected in, among other things, the establishment of a National Electoral Commission, the adoption of a text of a Constitution to be submitted to a referendum, and the adoption and promulgation of a law on referendums. But progress in that field has been accomplished slowly, while the time limits set for the institutions of the Third Republic to begin functioning are repeatedly pushed back; the Special Rapporteur fears another postponement.

Mr. Garretsn does not share the view of the authorities that pursuing the electoral process and the establishment of democratic institutions depended now on support from the international community. In effect, he observes, the establishment of the rule of law in a democratic State respectful of human rights and fundamental freedoms was an obligation, not a duty before presumed foreign pressure. International cooperation is certainly important for the realization of such a process, but the lack of it could not justify keeping in place an authoritarian regime. In addition, there are indispensable conditions for a transparent democratic process which did not depend on international cooperation, but which were not being fulfilled because of a lack of political will. Such is the case particularly in the failure to give effect to a real pluralism in the public media, as well as in the lack of effective guarantees for the exercise of the freedoms of expression, demonstration and assembly.

The visit of the Special Rapporteur took place as the armed conflict raged in Uvira, in the east of the country. A number of elements have contributed to the aggravation of tension and to the so-called "conflict of the Banyamulenge", a Tutsi community living in the high plateaus of the south Kivu region, writes the Special Rapporteur. He mentions in that regard the contribution, in the form of men and financial resources, of the Tutsis settled in Zaire to the war effort of the Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF).

While expressing concern over the question of the nationality of the Banyamulenge -- which he hopes the Zairian authorities would settle with equity and humanity -- the Special Rapporteur regrets that the Banyamulenge have chosen violence to claim their rights. That violence has already claimed a number of victims. The Special Rapporteur also condemns the recourse to foreign support. In that respect, the Zairian authorities have informed him of material evidence of the participation of armed Rwandan and Burundian citizens, with the consent of their respective Governments, in the violent actions and attacks perpetrated in Zairian territory.

The Special Rapporteur says he is also extremely concerned by incitations to hate and war on the part of the highest Rwandan authorities, as well as by the response of Zairian military and civilian authorities, whether at the national or regional level. Mr. Garretsn encourages the responsible and moderate attitude of the Prime Minister of Zaire, who has abstained until now from making inflammatory statements. He calls on the Rwandan, Burundian and Zairian authorities to refrain from any act or statement that could lead to an escalation in the murderous violence and confrontation that has already caused dozens of dead and wounded and led to the flight and dispersion of Rwandans, Burundians and local populations.

* *** *

Africa News


October 26, 1996


Zaire;
Pro-Hutu Group Says Refugee Periled in South Kivu


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Nairobi - (Note: The UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network (IRIN) does not usually distribute political statements, but given the current crisis, we feel it is useful for the humanitarian community to be aware of the widest range of information possible. IRIN's distribution of the item of course does imply endorsement in any way.)

Press Release from the RALLY FOR THE RETURN OF REFUGEES AND DEMOCRACY IN RWANDA October 25. Bruxelles Tel: 32-2-5348035 Fax: 32-2-5348053. Paris Tel/Fax: 33-41489987. 

Reliable reports reaching us from South KIVU indicate that thousands of Hutu refugees, particular the most vulnerable groups who include, women, the elderly, children pregnant women have died and are walking copses due to lack of water, food shelter, and medicine. Contrary to widely publicised reports, these refugees are not fleeing the fighting between Zairean troops and the Tutsi rebels(Banyamurenge), but because they have been direct targets of Banyamurenge militia and the RPF and Burundian troops, who are coordinating their action to drive Hutu refugees, like cattle, into Rwanda and Burundi. However instead of accepting to be forced into the hands of their attackers in Rwanda and Burundi, refugees have so far dodged the trap and are braving the hostile environment in the hills and forests of South Kivu, where they are likely to die a slow but sure death.

One should recall that this is a heavy rainy season and the area is not accessible to humanitarian assistance. In order to starve to death these refugees, the combined forces composed of Banyamurenge militia, RPF and Burundian troops have made sure to cut all the supply routes to refugee camps.

In North KIVU, a similar operation is taking place. The supply routes from Uganda were cut between BUNAGANA and GOMA and between KIBUMBA and Goma, and BUNIA and GOMA with the help of some elements from UGANDA.

In addition, the RPF troops are poised to attack the refugee camps of KIBUMBA, MUGUNGA, KATALE and KAHINDO, in order to escort at gun point the refugees back to Rwanda. The troops supposed to carry out the operation are from a well known position of the RPA army in MUTURA area, GISENYI prefecture.

Amid all these military raids by none other than RPF on rwandese refugee camps, the UNHCR is calling upon refugees to return home and has even embarked on a program of extending reception centres inside Rwanda. At the same time, in which looks like a coordinated strategy against Rwandese refugees, we are reliably informed that the Tanzanian minister of defense declared in a press conference on Wednesday October 16,1996, that his country was going very soon to forcefully send Rwandese refugees back home.

Much as refugees and understand the problems faced with the UNHCR in taking care of them under the present circumstances, refugees are nevertheless at loss to understand the rationale behind sending refugees to Rwanda whose regime is raiding their camps in neighbouring countries. This amounts to nothing but jumping from frying pan to fire. Moreover, the present chaos in Eastern Zaire, having been masterminded by the RPF and its brain child the BANYAMURENGE rebellion, purposely to corner and drive the refugees out by force of arms, coercing refugees to go home under any umbrella is giving in to RPF policy of annihilating refugees.

Refugees in these camps have gone without food, water and medicine for days and some have already died out of lack of care, a reminiscence of the cholera epidemic of July 94 which claimed tens of thousands of lives in Goma.

It is very sad that a human disaster of such magnitude leaves the international community, particular some human rights organisations and humanitarian agencies unmoved. It is inconceivable that some governments of civilised nations sacrifice millions of human beings allegedly to save 1 million dollar that is spent a day to feed refugees or, to impose on them regimes which they legitimately do not trust or to serve some hidden geopolitical interests.

RDR calls upon all civilised and peace loving people to get out of their indifference and come to the rescue of thousands of dying refugees particularly children, women and the elderly. Human rights organisations and humanitarian agencies should exert pressure on governments and relevant UN agencies so to bring Rwandan and Burundian governments to immediately open route supplies to refugee camps.

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

Africa News


October 27, 1996


Angola;
Children in UNITA Areas Said to be Unvaccinated


BYLINE: Kwacha Unita Press


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Huambo - Some 15,000 women and children in Mucusso, Rivungo and Luangundu, areas administered by UNITA in Kuando Kubango Province, have been unable to be inoculated against T.B., polio, whooping cough, tetanus and measles.

This is due to fuel shortages. According to Pedro Chindombe, the UNITA Director General for Health in Jamba (Kuando Kubango Province), a third of the vaccines have expired and another one third risks going to waste unless fuel for motor vehicles and refrigerators is found before November.

Pedro Chindombe has, meanwhile, thanked International Medical Corps (IMC), an American Non-governmental organisation, for recently donating a truck and medicine to the Jamba health services. He appealed to international non- governmental organisations operating in Angola to help resolve the fuel shortage.

Fifteen cases of polio have been identified in the Luangundo region of Kuando Kubango Province. A medical team from Jamba has left for the area to investigate the cases.

The International Action Against Hunger (IAH), an organisation based at Mavinga (Kuando Kubango Province), has inaugurated six health centers at Mavinga and Kueyo (Kuando Kubango Province) in a joint program with the UNITA Health Secretariat.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


422 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 27, 1996


Rwanda;
World Food Programme Prepositions Foodstocks


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Rome - The World Food Programme has begun prepositioning food supplies inside Rwanda along the border with Zaire amid reports that over 4,500 people fleeing armed clashes have crossed into the country. Thousands more are said to be massing at the border.

WFP staff report that on Sunday in the town of Gisenyi, about 4,500 people crossed over from Goma, Zaire. It's estimated that 3,000 of these are Zairians and the rest are Rwandan refugees who fled to Zaire in 1994. Nine of the Zairian refugees were wounded, five seriously. 

More than 10,000 people are estimated to have massed on the Goma side of the border where fighting continues north of the town. In Cyangugu, across the river from the Zairian town of Bukavu, an estimated 250 to 500 people have crossed into Rwanda.

WFP has already prepositioned 7,000 two-month rations in Gisenyi as well as 10,000 rations in Cyangugu. WFP plans to immediately preposition an additional 63,000 rations in the Rwandan capital Kigali. The agency is also readying 300,000 additional rations which can be in Rwanda within a week.

"We don't know if this sudden spurt of returnees will turn into a growing trend," said WFP spokesman Trevor Rowe. "But we don't want to be caught napping if it turns into a flood."

In response, WFP has decided to divert about 85 trucks bearing a cargo of food from the Uganda-Zaire border where they had been blocked for several days. The vehicles had initially been destined for Goma but could not cross the border because of worsened security conditions. The trucks, bearing a cargo of maize and split peas, have been redirected to Rwanda.

Overall, WFP estimates it has enough food in the region to feed the over 1. 2 million refugees in eastern Zaire as well as the 600,000 refugees in Tanzania for the next three months.

The United Nations World Food Programme is the largest international food- aid agency. Last year it helped feed over 50 million people, including half of the world's refugees and displaced people.

For further information, contact: Trevor Rowe WFP/Rome Chief Spokesman Tel: 39-6-5228-2602 679-6565.; Francis Mwanza WFP/Rome Information Officer Tel:39- 6-5228-2623 519-1569; Brenda Barton WFP/Nairobi Field Officer Tel:254-2- 622704.

(ENDS)

Africa News


October 28, 1996


United States and Africa;
Leon Sullivan and UNESCO Pledge To Assist Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

PHILADELPHIA, United States (PANA) - UNESCO Director-General, Federico Mayor, and the Rev. Leon Sullivan have signed a cooperation agreement calling for their organizations to work together in Africa and the United States in building a culture of peace through education, science, culture and communication.

The formal agreement between UNESCO and three organizations founded by Sullivan -- the International Foundation for Education and Self Help (IFESH), the African-African American summit and the Opportunities Industrialization Centers International (OICI) -- was signed Saturday at a ceremony attended by political, business and civic leaders, members of the clergy, and representatives of the African diplomatic community.

Reiterating that "education is the basis of freedom," Mayor said the agreement will "give a new message of hope to the children of the nations of Africa." 

Sullivan predicted his new "partnership with UNESCO will create a revolution in education and skills training for Sub-Saharan Africa. Education is essential for progress. If you can't read, you can't lead."

Stating that he will promote the UNESCO agreement at the fourth African- African American summit in Harare in July, 1997, he said he plans to launch a 'Help Africa Campaign' involving governments, civic organizations and the private sector. UNESCO will assist with the organization of the next summit.

The agreement calls for UNESCO and the three organizations to cooperate in the areas of basic education and literacy, including teacher training and curriculum development, higher education; promoting human rights and tolerance. Others are improving the status of women, science and technology development; and building communication capacities.

One of its main goals is to foster closer links between Africa and African Americans through educational and cultural exchanges, such as the establishment of UNESCO chairs at universities in Africa and in the United States, particularly at universities serving the African American community.

The organizations will participate in UNESCO's Culture of Peace Programme in Africa by helping to provide education and training to demobilized soldiers and training local non-government organizations in the management of development and self-help programmes.

Sullivan, long a key figure in the U.S. civil rights movement, was a leader in the battle against apartheid in South Africa. He is the author of the Sullivan Principles, a code of conduct for companies operating in South Africa during apartheid which advocated equal opportunity and an end to discrimination.

He founded OICI of America in 1964 to provide job and business training and five years later expanded the programme to Africa. IFESH was founded in the 1980s to involve American companies, institutions and individuals in education, health and economic development programs in Africa and now has numerous projects in over 30 countries in the continent and in Peru.

Since 1991, Sullivan has been organizing the African-African American summits to assist in development and influence policy decisions in economic and social development, democracy and peace.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


424 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Science and Health;
Author Revives Debate On AIDS, Accuses US Scientists


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - A renowned Nigerian author has revived the controversial debate on the origins of AIDS and accused United States scientists of inventing the incurable disease to reduce the Black population globally.

Known simply as Chinweizu, the author, who is a newspaper columnist famous for his fierce social commentary, said in a lecture Friday that the American scientists now link AIDS with the African green monkey as part of the conspiracy to discredit the Black race.

"In order to disguise its origin some people started the disinformation that it (AIDS) infected humanity through green monkeys in central Africa," he said in Lagos while delivering a lecture on "Black world collective security: Black redemption doctrines."

Chinweizu said the grand conspiracy by developed countries against Africa was "based on the model of too many men in a sinking the boat." 

To save the rest, " he said, "you cast one third overboard to the circling sharks."

"If the boat continues to sink," Chinweizu added, "you select another one- third of those in it, and cast them overboard too. And you repeat the process until you get rid of enough to keep the boat afloat."

The social critic said Americans and Europeans chose "Blacks as those to throw first to the sharks."

"Black Africa is a prime target for their population control squad despite its comparatively very low population density."

The controversy on the origin of AIDS first raged in the 1980s, with Western scientists arguing that AIDS originated in Africa. Other scientists argued that it originated in the experimental laboratories of Western scientists.

But the Nigerian author argued that in inventing the virus, the American scientists planned a systematic elimination of the "inhabitants of an allegedly overcrowded spaceship earth."

He said the plan was "to fashion a world in which a small minority can squander the earth's entire resources on themselves, and other minority are enslaved to serve them."

According to Chinweizu, the conspirators "intend for the Blacks exactly what the Nazis attempted on the Jews in Europe and what the Yankees inflicted on the native Americans and what Australians accomplished on the aboriginal Tasmanians, namely extermination and drastic depopulation."

"For rather than use the nuclear bomb for the planned extermination, they have started with the AIDS bomb," he added.

The Nigerian author also accused the United Nations of being privy to the recolonization of Africa, perpetrated through agencies such the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organisation.

"It is the UN's job to keep the Black countries maldeveloped, unindustrialized and economically strangulated, to erode their sovereignty and turn them into de facto trust territories as a prelude to their being openly recolonized," he added.

To stem the neocolonialism, Chinweizu said Black nations should "reappraise our geographical situation, and thereby clear our minds of all manner of obfuscation, delusion and diversions."

He said the Black world should see the "Eurocentric global order" as a source of "our strategic insecurity," hence the need for a "a collective security alliance for the Black world."

To this end, the author said Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, should host in 1997 a "Black redemption congress, to mobilize for the battle against recolonization."

He volunteered to convene the congress under the auspices of the "Black heritage and policy journal of the Black world."

Individuals, private organizations and governments of Black world are expected to attend the proposed meeting in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.

Chinweizu also suggested that Nigeria organize a "Black World League of Nations" conference in 1999, after an expert meeting to clarify the principles, goals and organizational form of the league.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 28, 1996


Burundi;
Red Cross Sets Conditions For Return To Burundi


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - The International Committee of the Red Cross says it will not return to Burundi until the killing of three of its personnel has been fully investigated, an official said.

"We asked for a thorough investigation immediately after the attack," Patrick Berner, the agency's representative in Bujumbura, said. 

"I have returned to Burundi precisely in order to relaunch the investigations prior to the resumption of our activities in the country," he added.

Berner, who arrived in the Burundian capital on Saturday, said the killings of its officials June 6 were the first in the agency's history. The officials were killed in Cibitoke province, in northwest Burundi, where they had gone to supply drinking water to locals.

He said the Red Cross was "extremely worried by the events" in eastern Zaire, where fighting between ethnic Tutsi rebels, known as the Banyamurenge, and the Zairian army has caused an exodus of hundreds of thousands of Hutu refugees from 12 camps.

Fearing reprisals from genocide against the Tutsi, these refugees fled Rwanda in 1994, following the victory of a largely Tutsi guerrilla force over a Hutu dominated government army.

At least one million people were killed and about two million others fled into exile, mostly to eastern Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


426 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Mozambique;
Chissano Admits Corruption In State Institutions


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano said Monday that crime and corruption in state institutions had reached alarming proportions but that he would halt the practices.

During a meeting with visiting South African Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, he said the police would be retrained and reorganized. This should have occurred two years ago but has been delayed by a lack of funds.

Holland, Italy and Spain have said they will help retrain the police. However, these countries have not publicly revealed the amounts they will make available for the job.

Tutu has been visiting Mozambique since Saturday. He is accompanied by 11 members of the Association of European Parliamentarians for Southern Africa and of the Africa-Europe Institute. These bodies are designed to promote peace, democracy, reconciliation, development and training for parliamentarians.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


427 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Nigerian Star Player Can Sue Italian Doctors


BYLINE: Comfort Coleman, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's troubled international soccer star, Nwankwo Kanu, alleged by Italian cardiologist to have a heart problem, can sue the doctors for breach of confidence, a leading Nigerian constitutional lawyer said.

Mike Ozekhome, also a human rights activist, told PANA in Lagos that "the manner of disclosure" of the star's alleged ailment was in breach of the patient/doctor relationship and smacked of a grand conspiracy.

In legal parlance, the offense is known as "Uberima Fidei" or breach of fiduciary relationship.

Ozekhome said medical doctors are ethically prohibited by the Hippocratic oath to keep personal issues concerning their client's health strictly confidential unless they had the full consent of the patient. 

"Kanu can sue them and his new club Inter Milan," Ozekhome said. There could, he added, even be greater grounds for damages if an independent examination reveals that Kanu is healthy.

In September, Western media reported on to the allegations of Kanu's ill- health based on the Italian doctors' diagnosis.

The doctors ruled Kanu unfit for future professional soccer, thereby provoking a huge controversy.

After a brilliant stint with European champions Ajax of Amsterdam, Kanu, 20, began moves to switch clubs just before the centennial Olympic in Atlanta '96, where he led Nigeria's under-23 team to win the soccer gold.

He was obliged to take Ajax to court to obtain his release to the Italian club, Inter Milan, on slightly over a two-million-U.S.-dollar contract.

It was the fitness test by the doctors for Inter Milan that triggered the controversy.

Ezekhome said that even if Kanu was finally confirmed to have a weak aorta valve, he could still sue Ajax for negligence.

Ezekhome said that the disclosures by the doctors for Inter Milan were the most damaging on Kanu. Ezekhome said that an independent assessment should have been conducted before the announcement was made public.

Premature disclosure, he said, amounted "to killing Kanu's entire football career, thereby rendering him unmarketable and useless, and even denting his family's image, since heart ailment can be hereditary."

Ezekhome said, "it could make any reasonable club shun him and his marketability will plummet."

Independent medical opinion has also faulted the claims by the doctors for Inter Milan, saying that a surgery could rectify such an ailment, assuming Kanu has one.

"It is a pretty standard operation," said Dr. Michael Debakey, of the Baylor Medical Center in Houston, Texas, the United States.

Speaking in an interview, Debakey said: "Kanu should have a good result (after the operation), depending on his overall physical condition and his age."

Debakey, a renowned cardiologist, said Kanu "should be able to resume normal activities."

Another American heart specialist, Dr. Adolph Hutter, said it was important to take a look at the player to evaluate the problem, adding "the question is how bad it is."

The doctors are agreed that an independent opinion from that of the Italian doctors was needed.

In Nigeria, the government has pledged to underwrite Kanu's medical expenses to ascertain his true state of health.

Youth and Sports Minister Jim Nwobodo, who lambasted the local press for " exaggerating the player's predicament," supports an independent examination, preferably in the United States.

Meanwhile, the Nigerian Football Association has detailed a member of its medical team, Dr. Mohammed Muazu, to liaise with Inter Milan for a comprehensive report on the situation.

At the moment Kanu is saying very little. In his first press interview granted to a privately owned Nigerian radio he said "there is nothing spectacular about my health."

Accusing the media of blowing the issue out of proportion, Kanu said "the stories written about my heart problem have been over blown. They (media) kept on writing about me as if there was no other thing to write."

"I am alright. There is no problem with me. Inter Milan has not dropped me," Kanu said.

His parents have also expressed concern, dismissing the alleged health problem as an orchestrated campaign by those who do not wish Nigeria and their son well.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


428 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Zaire;
Red Cross: Kivu a 'Major Human Tragedy In The Making'


BYLINE: International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Geneva - The situation in the Kivu province of Zaire has deteriorated even further. Apart from the actual fighting, excesses resulting from undisciplined behaviour on the part of those bearing weapons, intolerance and terror are giving rise to the worst fears for the Zairian civilian population and the hundreds of thousands of refugees in the area. Now that the humanitarian organizations have withdrawn from South Kivu, there is no way of knowing what is happening to the Zairian civilians and the refugees, who are left without any humanitarian presence. 

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), which was forced to suspend its activities in Uvira on 22 October, today withdrew its last two delegates from Bukavu, where they were trying to bring medical aid to the wounded. Security conditions in the town have degenerated to the point where any movement is extremely dangerous. In the last few days several hospitals have been attacked and looted, Red Cross vehicles have been stolen and humanitarian workers harassed.

Near Goma (North Kivu), where seven delegates are still working, the ICRC has managed to distribute emergency aid to some 12,000 Zairians who fled their villages to escape the recent days' fighting. Hospitals in Goma which are treating casualties received medicines and other medical supplies on 27 October. The ICRC also delivered assistance to the dispensary in Mugunga, where more than 150,000 refugees from the Kibumba camp have now arrived.

The ICRC calls once again on all political and military leaders to respect and ensure respect for the basic and universally recognized rules which protect civilians, the wounded and captured combatants, as well as the staff of humanitarian organizations, the ICRC in particular.

(ENDS)

Africa News


October 28, 1996


Western Sahara;
UN Committee Urges Talks Between Morocco and Polisario


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

United Nations - The General Assembly would encourage the resumption of direct talks between Morocco and the Frente Popular para la Liberacion de Saguia el-Hamra y de Rio de Oro (POLISARIO) to relaunch the peace process in Western Sahara, by the terms of an orally-revised draft resolution approved without a vote by the Fourth Committee (Special Political and Decolonization) this afternoon.

The Assembly would also express serious concern about obstacles to the settlement plan, and reaffirm the Organization's responsibility to the people of Western Sahara, as well as its commitment to a free, fair and impartial referendum for self-determination. The text stresses the importance of the cease-fire as an integral part of the settlement plan.

In introducing the draft and oral amendments, the representative of the United Republic of Tanzania said the international community should persist in the decolonization of Western Sahara and make it possible for the Saharawi people to exercise their right to self-determination. The representative of Morocco said the question of Sahara could be dealt with only in the context of his country's territory. It was not a matter of decolonization. The representatives of Angola and Ireland (on behalf of other countries) also made statements.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


430 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Gabon;
UN Human Rights Committee Takes Up Initial Gabon Report


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Geneva - A Government delegation presented the Human Rights Committee this morning with Gabon's first report on implementation of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, stating that such rights were receiving greater emphasis as the country moved from single-party rule to multi-party democracy.

Committee members, noting that the report arrived 13 years after Gabon's ratification of the Covenant and seemed thin on detail, asked numerous questions about legal protections for citizens, the actual state of women's rights, the independence of the judiciary, and limits on pre-trial detention.

Sebastien Mamboundou Mouyama, Minister of State for Communication, Culture, Arts, Education, and Human Rights, and head of the seven-member delegation, introduced the report by saying that despite the problems experienced by a developing country, the Government in its new multi-party form was basing its activities on respect for human rights.

Gabon is one of 134 States parties to the Covenant, and under the terms of the treaty is obligated to present periodic reports to the Committee. 

The Committee will reconvene at 3 p.m. to continue its discussion with the Gabonese delegation.

Report of Gabon

The initial report of Gabon on efforts to implement the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (document CCPR/C/31/Add.4) reviews the status of the treaty in the country on an article-by-article basis. An introduction places the human-rights situation in historical context, tracing the process under which the nation achieved independence in 1960, struggled under a military coup and one-party rule, and then, in 1990, during a national conference, adopted a programme of transition to multi-party democracy. The conclusion of the report remarks that while the country has strived to respect international human-rights agreements, it has had to cope with internal economic and political difficulties, and with the overall problems of a developing country.

Introduction of Report

SEBASTIEN MAMBOUNDOU MOUYAMA, Minister of State for Communication, Culture, Arts, Education, and Human Rights, said that major changes were under way in the country aimed at establishing multi-party democracy, restoring public order, and fostering human rights. A new Constitution dedicated to political pluralism would be adopted; free legislative elections would be organized and a national assembly with representatives of opposition parties would be formed. The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights had recently visited Gabon, and a mission of the Centre for Human Rights would soon arrive in Libreville to evaluate the needs of Gabon so that a technical-assistance programme could be established.

Consideration of Report

The delegation of Gabon began by providing answers to a list of questions prepared in advance by the Committee. These dealt with such topics as the status of the Covenant in the country; the drafting of a new Constitution; the duties of national human-rights bodies; equality of the sexes; and police procedures.

A human-rights commission that was entirely autonomous -- outside the Government -- was envisaged soon, Mr. MAMBOUNDOU MOUYAMA said. That would be accomplished following a visit from the Centre for Human Rights; advice was needed on how to do this, and it also was necessary to have the new democratic Government in place and the legislature seated to analyze and approved the arrangement.

Discrimination against women was not a serious problem in Gabon, Mr. MAMBOUNDOU MOUYAMA said; women had equal rights to education and functioned in general as equal member of society; although currently they were underrepresented in Government and elected positions, that should change rapidly as the new democratic system took hold. The country's Constitutional Court was headed by a woman.

Extra-judicial executions and involuntary disappearances had not been a problem in the country, the Minister said. Under the previous regime there occasionally had been acts not in line with human-rights standards, said Lieutenant-Colonel Major HILAIRE NDJOYE, of the Ministry of National Defense, in response to a question about torture; the new Government was changing perceptions among police and security personnel. Confessions that were obtained through torture were not accepted in court. Training of police was in the process of being improved.

Length of pre-trial detention and detention conditions were governed by law, said JEAN BAPTISTE RAZINGUE, Counsellor to the Minister of Justice. The length of pre-trial detention for criminal charges was a maximum of 12 months, which could be extended to a maximum of another 12 months. Detainees had to be released if not brought to trial within those time limits. In criminal cases, police custody could be extended to a maximum of eight days.

In comments from the floor, Committee members said the report lacked detail; they sought further information on a state of emergency in the early 1990s, which under the Covenant should have been reported to the UN Secretary- General, along with a summary of the rights affected by the procedure; they asked, among other things, what specific laws prohibited discrimination and what recourses were provided for those discriminated against; if old discriminatory laws against women had been eliminated, including prohibitions against contraception; what the mortality rates were for men and women; if traditions and customs in Gabonese society sometimes hindered equality between the sexes; if the judiciary was sufficiently independent of the national administration; if the military was responsible for the tasks of the police, or if a civil police force existed; how many death sentences had been pronounced, and for what offenses; what were considered proper grounds for arrest and detention; what were the rates of school attendance; and if there were problems with bonded labour and child labour in Gabon.

Africa News


October 28, 1996


United States and Africa;
Leon Sullivan and UNESCO Pledge To Assist Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

PHILADELPHIA, United States (PANA) - UNESCO Director-General, Federico Mayor, and the Rev. Leon Sullivan have signed a cooperation agreement calling for their organizations to work together in Africa and the United States in building a culture of peace through education, science, culture and communication.

The formal agreement between UNESCO and three organizations founded by Sullivan -- the International Foundation for Education and Self Help (IFESH), the African-African American summit and the Opportunities Industrialization Centers International (OICI) -- was signed Saturday at a ceremony attended by political, business and civic leaders, members of the clergy, and representatives of the African diplomatic community.

Reiterating that "education is the basis of freedom," Mayor said the agreement will "give a new message of hope to the children of the nations of Africa." 

Sullivan predicted his new "partnership with UNESCO will create a revolution in education and skills training for Sub-Saharan Africa. Education is essential for progress. If you can't read, you can't lead."

Stating that he will promote the UNESCO agreement at the fourth African- African American summit in Harare in July, 1997, he said he plans to launch a 'Help Africa Campaign' involving governments, civic organizations and the private sector. UNESCO will assist with the organization of the next summit.

The agreement calls for UNESCO and the three organizations to cooperate in the areas of basic education and literacy, including teacher training and curriculum development, higher education; promoting human rights and tolerance. Others are improving the status of women, science and technology development; and building communication capacities.

One of its main goals is to foster closer links between Africa and African Americans through educational and cultural exchanges, such as the establishment of UNESCO chairs at universities in Africa and in the United States, particularly at universities serving the African American community.

The organizations will participate in UNESCO's Culture of Peace Programme in Africa by helping to provide education and training to demobilized soldiers and training local non-government organizations in the management of development and self-help programmes.

Sullivan, long a key figure in the U.S. civil rights movement, was a leader in the battle against apartheid in South Africa. He is the author of the Sullivan Principles, a code of conduct for companies operating in South Africa during apartheid which advocated equal opportunity and an end to discrimination.

He founded OICI of America in 1964 to provide job and business training and five years later expanded the programme to Africa. IFESH was founded in the 1980s to involve American companies, institutions and individuals in education, health and economic development programs in Africa and now has numerous projects in over 30 countries in the continent and in Peru.

Since 1991, Sullivan has been organizing the African-African American summits to assist in development and influence policy decisions in economic and social development, democracy and peace.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 28, 1996


Science and Health;
Author Revives Debate On AIDS, Accuses US Scientists


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - A renowned Nigerian author has revived the controversial debate on the origins of AIDS and accused United States scientists of inventing the incurable disease to reduce the Black population globally.

Known simply as Chinweizu, the author, who is a newspaper columnist famous for his fierce social commentary, said in a lecture Friday that the American scientists now link AIDS with the African green monkey as part of the conspiracy to discredit the Black race.

"In order to disguise its origin some people started the disinformation that it (AIDS) infected humanity through green monkeys in central Africa," he said in Lagos while delivering a lecture on "Black world collective security: Black redemption doctrines."

Chinweizu said the grand conspiracy by developed countries against Africa was "based on the model of too many men in a sinking the boat." 

To save the rest, " he said, "you cast one third overboard to the circling sharks."

"If the boat continues to sink," Chinweizu added, "you select another one- third of those in it, and cast them overboard too. And you repeat the process until you get rid of enough to keep the boat afloat."

The social critic said Americans and Europeans chose "Blacks as those to throw first to the sharks."

"Black Africa is a prime target for their population control squad despite its comparatively very low population density."

The controversy on the origin of AIDS first raged in the 1980s, with Western scientists arguing that AIDS originated in Africa. Other scientists argued that it originated in the experimental laboratories of Western scientists.

But the Nigerian author argued that in inventing the virus, the American scientists planned a systematic elimination of the "inhabitants of an allegedly overcrowded spaceship earth."

He said the plan was "to fashion a world in which a small minority can squander the earth's entire resources on themselves, and other minority are enslaved to serve them."

According to Chinweizu, the conspirators "intend for the Blacks exactly what the Nazis attempted on the Jews in Europe and what the Yankees inflicted on the native Americans and what Australians accomplished on the aboriginal Tasmanians, namely extermination and drastic depopulation."

"For rather than use the nuclear bomb for the planned extermination, they have started with the AIDS bomb," he added.

The Nigerian author also accused the United Nations of being privy to the recolonization of Africa, perpetrated through agencies such the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organisation.

"It is the UN's job to keep the Black countries maldeveloped, unindustrialized and economically strangulated, to erode their sovereignty and turn them into de facto trust territories as a prelude to their being openly recolonized," he added.

To stem the neocolonialism, Chinweizu said Black nations should "reappraise our geographical situation, and thereby clear our minds of all manner of obfuscation, delusion and diversions."

He said the Black world should see the "Eurocentric global order" as a source of "our strategic insecurity," hence the need for a "a collective security alliance for the Black world."

To this end, the author said Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, should host in 1997 a "Black redemption congress, to mobilize for the battle against recolonization."

He volunteered to convene the congress under the auspices of the "Black heritage and policy journal of the Black world."

Individuals, private organizations and governments of Black world are expected to attend the proposed meeting in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.

Chinweizu also suggested that Nigeria organize a "Black World League of Nations" conference in 1999, after an expert meeting to clarify the principles, goals and organizational form of the league.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 28, 1996


Burundi;
Red Cross Sets Conditions For Return To Burundi


BYLINE: Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - The International Committee of the Red Cross says it will not return to Burundi until the killing of three of its personnel has been fully investigated, an official said.

"We asked for a thorough investigation immediately after the attack," Patrick Berner, the agency's representative in Bujumbura, said. 

"I have returned to Burundi precisely in order to relaunch the investigations prior to the resumption of our activities in the country," he added.

Berner, who arrived in the Burundian capital on Saturday, said the killings of its officials June 6 were the first in the agency's history. The officials were killed in Cibitoke province, in northwest Burundi, where they had gone to supply drinking water to locals.

He said the Red Cross was "extremely worried by the events" in eastern Zaire, where fighting between ethnic Tutsi rebels, known as the Banyamurenge, and the Zairian army has caused an exodus of hundreds of thousands of Hutu refugees from 12 camps.

Fearing reprisals from genocide against the Tutsi, these refugees fled Rwanda in 1994, following the victory of a largely Tutsi guerrilla force over a Hutu dominated government army.

At least one million people were killed and about two million others fled into exile, mostly to eastern Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 28, 1996


Mozambique;
Chissano Admits Corruption In State Institutions


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano said Monday that crime and corruption in state institutions had reached alarming proportions but that he would halt the practices.

During a meeting with visiting South African Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, he said the police would be retrained and reorganized. This should have occurred two years ago but has been delayed by a lack of funds.

Holland, Italy and Spain have said they will help retrain the police. However, these countries have not publicly revealed the amounts they will make available for the job.

Tutu has been visiting Mozambique since Saturday. He is accompanied by 11 members of the Association of European Parliamentarians for Southern Africa and of the Africa-Europe Institute. These bodies are designed to promote peace, democracy, reconciliation, development and training for parliamentarians.
