LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


435 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Nigerian Star Player Can Sue Italian Doctors


BYLINE: Comfort Coleman, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's troubled international soccer star, Nwankwo Kanu, alleged by Italian cardiologist to have a heart problem, can sue the doctors for breach of confidence, a leading Nigerian constitutional lawyer said.

Mike Ozekhome, also a human rights activist, told PANA in Lagos that "the manner of disclosure" of the star's alleged ailment was in breach of the patient/doctor relationship and smacked of a grand conspiracy.

In legal parlance, the offense is known as "Uberima Fidei" or breach of fiduciary relationship.

Ozekhome said medical doctors are ethically prohibited by the Hippocratic oath to keep personal issues concerning their client's health strictly confidential unless they had the full consent of the patient. 

"Kanu can sue them and his new club Inter Milan," Ozekhome said. There could, he added, even be greater grounds for damages if an independent examination reveals that Kanu is healthy.

In September, Western media reported on to the allegations of Kanu's ill- health based on the Italian doctors' diagnosis.

The doctors ruled Kanu unfit for future professional soccer, thereby provoking a huge controversy.

After a brilliant stint with European champions Ajax of Amsterdam, Kanu, 20, began moves to switch clubs just before the centennial Olympic in Atlanta '96, where he led Nigeria's under-23 team to win the soccer gold.

He was obliged to take Ajax to court to obtain his release to the Italian club, Inter Milan, on slightly over a two-million-U.S.-dollar contract.

It was the fitness test by the doctors for Inter Milan that triggered the controversy.

Ezekhome said that even if Kanu was finally confirmed to have a weak aorta valve, he could still sue Ajax for negligence.

Ezekhome said that the disclosures by the doctors for Inter Milan were the most damaging on Kanu. Ezekhome said that an independent assessment should have been conducted before the announcement was made public.

Premature disclosure, he said, amounted "to killing Kanu's entire football career, thereby rendering him unmarketable and useless, and even denting his family's image, since heart ailment can be hereditary."

Ezekhome said, "it could make any reasonable club shun him and his marketability will plummet."

Independent medical opinion has also faulted the claims by the doctors for Inter Milan, saying that a surgery could rectify such an ailment, assuming Kanu has one.

"It is a pretty standard operation," said Dr. Michael Debakey, of the Baylor Medical Center in Houston, Texas, the United States.

Speaking in an interview, Debakey said: "Kanu should have a good result (after the operation), depending on his overall physical condition and his age."

Debakey, a renowned cardiologist, said Kanu "should be able to resume normal activities."

Another American heart specialist, Dr. Adolph Hutter, said it was important to take a look at the player to evaluate the problem, adding "the question is how bad it is."

The doctors are agreed that an independent opinion from that of the Italian doctors was needed.

In Nigeria, the government has pledged to underwrite Kanu's medical expenses to ascertain his true state of health.

Youth and Sports Minister Jim Nwobodo, who lambasted the local press for " exaggerating the player's predicament," supports an independent examination, preferably in the United States.

Meanwhile, the Nigerian Football Association has detailed a member of its medical team, Dr. Mohammed Muazu, to liaise with Inter Milan for a comprehensive report on the situation.

At the moment Kanu is saying very little. In his first press interview granted to a privately owned Nigerian radio he said "there is nothing spectacular about my health."

Accusing the media of blowing the issue out of proportion, Kanu said "the stories written about my heart problem have been over blown. They (media) kept on writing about me as if there was no other thing to write."

"I am alright. There is no problem with me. Inter Milan has not dropped me," Kanu said.

His parents have also expressed concern, dismissing the alleged health problem as an orchestrated campaign by those who do not wish Nigeria and their son well.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


436 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Science and Health;
Where Is The Aesthetic Sense In Female Circumcision?


BYLINE: Florence Bamanyaki, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

Nairobi - The pain is simply excruciating! There is the risk of death from excessive bleeding or from tetanus or some strange infection. There are even risks in child birth on account of the scar from the operation.

Others from societies in which the practice does not exist can only express horror at the details of the operation. Those who have been through the operation speak of the trauma of the whole experience and how they would not want to inflict such misery on their own daughters. 

This operation otherwise seen as sheer misery is none other but female circumcision (excision, clitoridectomy, infibulation) -- give it any name, but the fact remains, according to women's rights activists and medical personnel, it is female genital mutilation (FGM). They argue that when external genitals are normal, there can be no reasons, medical, moral or aesthetic for removing all or any of them.

John Kanga, a history teacher in Nairobi says it is wrong to fully discredit the cultural reasons for female circumcision because, he argues, " these women, though uneducated, are highly intelligent, creative individuals who are just as aware of the inevitability of social change."

Apparently for female circumcision, men on the other hand generally speak of the elimination of the sexual urge and preservation of chastity in women. But then, one wonders why there is never need to curb the sexual urge in men.

Finda Mbriwa (not her real name) from Sierra Leone, who has undergone circumcision and says she can perform the operation by virtue of her age and experience as an elder, defends the practice, saying it is a rite of passage from childhood to womanhood and that it is directly linked to fertility.

But one interesting argument Mbriwa puts across is that if the baby's head touched the clitoris during child birth, it would die. The question is, says who?

The biological facts of reproduction continue to be the best kept secrets in many parts of Africa, often distorted by damaging myths, taboos and fears that threaten and debase the lives and dignity of women.

The failure to learn about the natural biological process of giving life or how a baby is made, are still the cause of great suffering, pain and tragedy - quite needlessly.

One Christine from Kenya's Maasai tribe where female circumcision is practised widely, says she feels "more of a woman" and that she is respected in her society as a full grown woman.

Well, it is often difficult, even impossible for those who do not belong to a given culture, to fully appreciate the implications as well as the significance of aspects of that culture, and understand why even enlightened members of that society choose to conform against the judgement that female circumcision is obviously a painful and dangerous experience.

Miss Jane Auko, a sales girl in Nairobi, is disturbed by the argument that female circumcision is meant to preserve chastity in women. Obviously irritated, she asks why women should on the overall continue to succumb to the whims of men who are naturally the decision makers in matters pertaining to culture and traditional practices under which female circumcision falls.

A mid-wife at one of Kenya's leading hospitals says that the female external reproductive organs are "normal, healthy organs" and each has its own function to perform either during sexual relations, labour, child birth and post-partum, therefore none of them is a mistake.

Talk about reproduction, millions of women and girls continue to live in fear and ignorance of their own bodies and life-giving functions. A recent World Health Organization (WHO) report indicates that every year about 2 million females are at risk of being mutilated. The report says that Sierra Leone and Liberia still widely incorporate female circumcision in their secret societies.

A research carried out in Kenya by the Programme for Appropriate Technology in Health (PATH) last August revealed that the practice is still emphasised among the Kisii, Maasai, Samburu and Meru. Up to nearly 50 per cent of the women in this East African state are circumcised.

A programme officer for PATH, Mr. Samson Radeny says that even the educated, including medical personnel, are involved in the practice.

Radeny says that parents send their daughters to the village at the age of seven for circumcision whether they are in school or not. He notes however, that some tribes like the Kikuyu had abandoned the practice because the church stepped in with threats to excommunicate those Christians involved in circumcision and also following the ban on female circumcision by President Daniel arap Moi in 1983.

PATH is a non-governmental organization (NGO) dedicated to offering technical assistance in improving the reproductive health of women. The programme has been very active in anti-female circumcision campaigns.

Explaining the medical dangers of female circumcision, Dr. Gerald Aine, a private practising gynaecologist, says after the operation, the external reproductive organs heal with a scar which consists of fibrous, non-elastic tissues which does not yield during child birth, thus making labour prolonged and sometimes obstructed.

According to Dr. Aine, during this period, referred to as the second stage of labour, the head of the baby is already in the vagina, but the opening of the birth canal is closed by the unyielding scar tissue of circumcision.

Dr. Aine says the constant prolonged grinding of the baby's head on the mother's urinary bladder on top and the rectum behind causes fistula (uncontrollable passing out of urine and faeces). This is not bed wetting which occurs in boys and girls up to the age of nine to ten years.

Dr. Aine adds that fistula is common in adolescent girls and it is extremely difficult for some of these women to give birth to a live child if the fistula is not repaired. If by chance they become pregnant, urine poisons the foetus, causing frequent miscarriages.

"But not all circumcised women end up with fistula," stresses Dr. Aine. But many still wonder why womanhood training including family education, sex education and child rearing should not be continued and made the most valuable aspects of female initiation. One would imagine the pangs of child birth alone would suffice the ability to endure pain and the qualification of "being a woman."


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


437 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Lay Centres' Association Celebrates 25 Years In Africa


BYLINE: Osman Njuguna, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Ndola, Zambia - The names of founders of the Association of Christian Lay Centres in Africa (ACLCA) read out during silver jubilee celebrations held in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare, from October 6 to 13 read like who is who in an ecumenical book of records.

They include Mrs. Winnifred Sibusisiwe, the widow of South African church minister, the late Rev. Enos Sikakane; former general secretary of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), Rev. Dr. Maxime Rafransoa from Madagascar, Nigerian clergy Rt. Rev. Adeolu Adegbola; Ugandan Rev. Erastus Bitarabeho; Zambian Canon Jason Mfula; South African Rev. Dale White; and Egyptian Rev. Dr. Samuel Habib.

"These were the people, who planted the first seeds of the current ACLCA, whose 25 years of pastoral service among the laity in Africa we are celebrating today," remarked the association's Executive Secretary Rev. Jonah Katoneene, as he read out the names for recognition and awards-giving.

Under the challenging theme, Celebrating in Hope: Restoring Just Relationships, the 200 delegates, drawn mainly from member centres of the association and invited guests from the ecumenical church partners and regional lay associations both from Africa and Europe, met in Harare for the week-long silver jubilee celebrations.

But contrary to what one would have expected -- continuous merry- making, the occasion created a forum for delegates to look back and plan for the future, among other deliberations. Nevertheless, they dedicated one evening to cultural activities. 

The issues at hand for deliberations were as wide and central for both the African continent and its people as they were for the church and its pastoral mission among the African people. They covered such spheres as human rights, implication of global disintegration, drug trafficking and abuse, gospel and culture, inter-religious dialogue, church as a healing ministry to the vulnerable, ethnicity and conflict resolution skills.

Other items included on the ACLCA agenda were street children, rape, landlessness, and homelessness; the position of women and youth; the effects of HIV/ Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (HIV/AIDS), liberalization of economies and their effects, militarisation, destabilisation, overcoming a culture of violence, confrontation and structural adjustment programmes and their effects.

"Definitely we would have done alot of disservice to ourselves if we simply met here to make merry without taking stock of what God has helped us achieve so far, and at the same time focus on the challenges ahead of us," noted the ACLCA president Rev. Sipho Masemola from South Africa.

In an interview with APS, Rev. Masemola talked of the diversified issues facing the lay person in the church, key among them lack of recognition as a " powerful tool" within some church hierarchies. He cited destitution, civil strife, famine, up-rootedness and economic hardships, as odds that must be addressed by the ACLCA celebration programme, otherwise "we would not have accomplished our mission of celebrating in hope and restoring just relationships."

And true to their commitment, delegates, who also included representatives of ecumenical partners, such as the World Council of Churches (WCC), the AACC and a number of regional Christian lay associations in Africa and Europe, proposed the way forward for ACLCA's commitment in the laity's pastoral ministry.

A significant resolution was the launching of a trust fund, which will help the association raise money locally for its financial requirements.

"The launching of this fund is in line with our long thinking that in future things will not be as they are today. We shall be forced to stand on ourselves in terms of financial commitment for our pastoral programmes. Our financial wells are slowly drying up in Europe and we must start thinking seriously on how to effectively stand on our two feet," emphasised Rev. Masemola, while launching the ACLCA Trust Fund.

At the end of the week-long celebrations, participants instituted a covenant of commitment which raised several concerns that ACLCA should commit itself to.

The ACLCA covenant of commitment included 26 items, among them the urgent need to define and articulate a new multi-faith environmental ethic derived from traditional African concepts, principles and practices, which provide for peaceful co-existence between man and nature.

The delegates recommended that ACLCA member centres should be models of communities which are inclusive, tolerant and safe with one another. According to the covenant, centres should incorporate civil society in the training curricula. The delegates lamented that recent events in Africa have shown that an active and informed civil society is crucial for managing power transfers from authoritarian to more accountable models of governance.

The ACLCA covenant noted with concern that Africa is becoming "rich and has plentiful" supply of cheap sex for tourists, who generally prey on the vulnerable girls, boys and women and intensify unnatural relationships in the name of human rights.

"We categorically say that we are not poor. We must forever banish the demon of poverty and work hard to prosper and make others prosper," said the ACLCA delegates in their statement of commitment.

Observing that globalisation of world economies has undermined national sovereignty and the power of leaders to take charge of their economies, the ACLCA covenant pointed out; "This makes a mockery of accountability for leaders who lose their role of planners and implementers of development policies."

The delegates called on centres to encourage debate on globalisation and seek to educate people on its effects.

The ACLCA meeting also raised concern on the family which it classified as " under attack," saying its centrality as a basic building block of society is being undermined. There is need to insist on the sanctity and role of family as an institution for socialization in its fuller sense, participants noted in the covenant.

The lay centres were also called upon to be steadfast in ensuring that the church defines and redefines the methods of its mission, noting that the purpose of mission is un-changing. A church which lacks a clear identity and sense of mission has no business engaging in dialogue of any kind, the delegates stressed.

Saying that the process of democratization which gained momentum in the early 1990s has given hope to millions in Africa, the ACLCA meeting called for the institution of a large scale civic education programme if a similar pace is to be maintained.

Emphasizing that in the past 25 years, ACLCA has worked to empower the laity, the delegates noted; "We have now come of age and need to proceed further to tackle civil and economic issues. A greater and more decisive mandate from the church is needed by the centres for greater autonomy to get on with the job of laity formation. We regard the mission of the laity as being an integral part of the mission of the church."

Delivering her key-note speech, Rev. Dr. Eunice Santana, a president of the World Council of Churches, challenged the church in Africa to accommodate Christian organizations such as ACLCA as part of the pastoral mission.

Such organizations like ACLCA are vital, especially where they come in as empowering agents for the lay people, she observed.

Rev. Santana also challenged ACLCA to strive to work harder for the lay people on the African continent, cautioning that in the future, issues and duties will hardly be minimized but on the contrary will increase, hence the need to redouble efforts.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


438 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


East Africa;
Lift Sanctions, Then We Can Talk, Says Burundi's Junta


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1960 words


 

Nairobi - A showdown appears to be in the offing between Burundi's military junta and East African regional leaders following the junta's call on October 14 for the lifting of an economic embargo imposed on the war-torn central African nation last July, as a precondition for talks with extremist rebels from the Hutu majority.

On October 12, a regional summit gave Burundi's warring Tutsi minority and the Hutu majority one month to start peace talks and expressed its readiness to take "appropriate measures" against any group refusing to participate.

The call by the summit which grouped the presidents of Tanzania, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, and Zambia, the prime ministers of Zaire and Ethiopia, the foreign minister of Cameroon, the secretary general of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and mediator Julius Nyerere, Tanzania's founding president, came as Tutsi strongman Pierre Buyoya and former Interior Minister Leonard Nyangoma, the main guerrilla leader, both offered to enter into such talks.

The regional leaders also said they wanted a full return to constitutional order and said that Nyerere had received a written assurance from Buyoya, saying he was ready to negotiate with Nyangoma's group, the National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), and all other armed factions in the three-year-old civil war, which has already left 150,000 people dead, most of them civilians. 

A letter from Nyangoma to the summit said: "I solemnly declared herewith that despite all odds, the CNDD is ready to enter into open negotiations with the Burundi military junta immediately."

The regional leaders maintained Burundi's economic blockade imposed a week after a July 25 military coup by the Tutsi-dominated army which ousted Hutu president Sylvestre Ntibatunganya and installed Major Buyoya in his place.

The final communique read out before the assembled heads of state and government in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha said the regional countries would send a ministerial delegation to the Burundian capital, Bujumbura, to evaluate the situation "and take appropriate action," and called for preliminary talks to start immediately.

But on October 14, the head of the government formed after the July 25 military coup, Prime Minister Pascal-Firmin Ndimira, said they would not talk to the rebels "so long as the blockade has not been lifted."

"We are predisposed and still determined to enter negotiations, but not in the framework of a blockade," Ndimira said, pointing out that the embargo " endangered the peace process and encouraged the (rebel) armed factions, while the government's hands are tied."

"The government denounces a plot by those, who in the name of democracy, continued to serve their own interests. Some countries are seeking to stifle the Burundian people," he added.

Ndimira described the embargo as "illegal, unjust and biased" and said it had already cost one of the world's poorest countries "a loss of income of more than 162 million dollars."

Regional heads of state decided on October 12 at the Arusha summit to maintain the embargo and gave the parties to the conflict between the army and the rebels, one month to open peace talks.

But United States Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who visited Arusha a day earlier, had made it clear that the United States favoured easing the sanctions, and praised a recent decision by Buyoya to lift his suspension of political parties and parliament. "When we see progress, we must be ready to recognise it," Christopher pointed out.

In Bujumbura, former Burundian president Jean-Baptiste Bagaza said the decision to maintain the sanctions was a "disaster" which would widen the breach between Hutus and Tutsis and could spark riots.

"The embargo is hitting the most disadvantaged, poorest and weakest people in society. Normally, such measures are taken against belligerent states. This is not the case in Burundi," said Bagaza, who was president from 1976 to 1987.

Hutus make up 85 per cent of Burundi's population of 5.5 million people, but are mostly peasant farmers, while the Tutsis, at 14 per cent, control the armed forces, big business and political decisions.

The sanctions, crippling an already war-battered economy, have been hitting the urbanized Tutsis harder than most Hutus, who have always lived at subsistence level.

Ndimira's support for the lifting of sanctions came amid reports of further raids blamed on rebels and fighting in several parts of the central African highland nation.

On October 13, a grenade attack killed two people and injured 29 in a crowded market in the south-eastern Rutana province of Burundi, which is fraught with ethnic violence, the national radio reported. It quoted a member of the military general staff as blaming the attack on the Hutu rebels fighting the Tutsi-dominated army.

The radio, quoting a local correspondent, also said that Hutu rebels killed 23 villagers at Burambi in the south-west on October 11, bringing down the death toll in the massacre from 40 as originally reported. Six children have disappeared but 28 other people who had gone missing have been found, it reported.

On October 14, soldiers were also exchanging fire with Hutu rebels on the hills overlooking the capital Bujumbura, military spokesman Lt.Col. Isaie Nibizi said.

Nibizi said that a new battalion of more than 400 men was taking up positions in the Nyambuye district, about 15 kilometres east of the capital, where rebel bands were shooting to harass them. He also confirmed that a local administrator was killed last October 9 at Kibuye in the northern Kayanza province. His death was first reported on the night of October 13 by the national radio.

The army is pursuing an operation against the rebels in the Kibira mountains, close to Kayanza, where the latter have set up several bases, and troops are also moving against the rebels at Murambi in the south-western Bururi province, which has led to the displacement of large numbers of civilians.

The developments on the long-drawn ethnic conflict in Burundi came as Christopher was about to complete a week-long tour of Africa aimed at enhancing Washington's role in the continent, but which was largely seen as a failure after the attempts failed to win over African leaders.

Christopher visited five countries on his tour, beginning with former French West Africa in what was seen as a deliberate challenge to the former colonial power, and ending in war-torn Angola, a former Portuguese colony.

Christopher's efforts to win support for a US-sponsored African peace force, a successor to Boutros Boutros-Ghali as United Nations leader, an easing of sanctions against Burundi or sanctions against Nigeria, met with a cool response or even outright sceptism.

Most leaders showed polite interest when Christopher asked them to take part in an African Crisis Response Force - a standing peacekeeping force made up of 10,000 African troops which would protect civilians in areas of conflict. But only Mali and Ethiopia appeared inclined to join.

Mali, the first country on Christopher's itinerary, gave its agreement in principle but made no formal commitment. Christopher lavished praise on Mali's fledgling democracy and pledged financial aid to finance elections next year and the resettlement of former Tuareg rebels in the north.

His visit to Bamako was taken as a signal to France that Washington now felt free to stake its claim to countries which traditionally fell within the French "sphere of influence."

A US diplomat in Bamako said that in Mali, "France is the first wife, the one they did not choose. We are the second, who is often the favourite."

In Ethiopia where he outlined the peace force plan, leaders of the continental body said the plan needed further consultations and clarifications, notably about who would command the force.

OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim objected to Washington's insistence that only countries "with an experience of democracy" should take part in the force, saying it should be a pan-African force and it was not up to the Americans to decide which countries could join.

In talks with African leaders in Arusha on Burundi, Christopher pressed for an easing of sanctions against Burundi's military junta to reward Buyoya for political concessions, but Burundi's neighbours ruled the sanctions should stay and set an ultimatum for Buyoya to open talks with Hutu rebels.

In South Africa, President Nelson Mandela was unenthusiastic about a Washington-sponsored peace force, saying such a force should be convened by the United Nations or the OAU rather than the United States. "I would like the whole process to come through the UN," Mandela said.

The South African president appeared to give Christopher a cool reception and the peace force issue was not the only one on which they disagreed.

Mandela told the US Secretary of State that South Africa was joining many other African leaders in supporting UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros- Ghali's re-election at the UN, despite strong US opposition.

Christopher was thought to be seeking another African candidate during his tour. Salim Ahmed Salim was mentioned as a possibility, but turned it down.

African leaders said they would not budge on that issue before Washington formally vetoed Boutros-Ghali's re-election.

Christopher's efforts to muster support for sanctions against Nigeria's military regime for its alleged human rights abuses also encountered a muted response, forcing him to sound a warning in Johannesburg that Washington would take "appropriate" steps against Nigeria if that country failed to restore democracy.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


439 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Benin;
Benin's "Water People" Whose Problems Won't Go Away


BYLINE: Robert N. Kizito, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

Ganvie, Benin - Thanks to profound democratic reforms and economic liberalization, the West African state of Benin, formerly a Marxist military dictatorship, boasts of a new reputation today.

However, the inhabitants of a unique village, Ganvie, as elsewhere in Africa and like the majority of the 5 million Beninois in general, have nothing to show for these changes especially in economic terms and the infrastructure.

Popularly known as the capital city of the "people of the water", Ganvie village is located in the north-western end of Lake Nokoue, a few kilometres from Cotonou, the commercial capital of the tiny Republic of Benin.

With a population of about 23,000 inhabitants, Ganvie is the largest lake of the Toffini, locally referred to as people of the water. It is believed to be among the biggest and better known water- villages in the world. 

Jean-Claude Gnouloufoun (read Nyolofoo), 50 was born and raised in Ganvie village. In his lifetime he has witnessed some significant progress in the village.

These include among others, a primary and subsequently secondary school and more recently a dispensary and clinic. All these are, however, church- sponsored developments.

A steady, but still relatively small number of tourist visitors, is one of the more visible developments since Benin acquired the reputation as the " cradle of the African democratic reform movement," following the 1991 multiparty elections that saw a peaceful transition from one-party rule. Carvers and other handicrafters are beginning to cash-in on this flow of visitors as is, and perhaps even more so, the government.

As part of the move to promote tourism further, the government constructed a new guest house in the village as it prepared to host the sixth summit of the French-speaking countries of the world in December, 1995.

It is significant that the event was successful. Among prominent participants were Jacques Chirac, President of France and the Prime Minister of Canada, Jean Chretien, who is from the French province of Quebec.

It takes about one hour to travel to the village by a dug-out canoe, boat or craft from Abomey-Calavi, 19 kilometres from Cotonou, where the government has built a wooden loading platform. By motorized boat, the ride takes about 30 minutes.

Both the old and young from the age of six are expert canoeists. Sole women canoeists with children on their backs and their canoes fully loaded, can be seen steering their "vehicles" with rare expertise, especially in the " highway" to the village.

Canoes carrying merchandise to or from the village are so heavily loaded that their edges touch the level of the water. In the hands of an ordinary operator, these canoes would certainly tip over.

Within the village itself, hawkers carry on their house-to-house business in canoes. And as would be expected, school children roar to and from their schools daily without any assistance.

Documents at the Department of Tourism indicate that the Toffini led by their Chief Agbogbre, first founded Ganvie in the 18th century as a hideout from the wars of succession in the Kingdom of Allada and Dan-Home.

Because of religious beliefs, their pursuers could not go after them in or beyond the lake. The Toffini, it is said, were also the victims of demographic explosion.

Initially they hid in the outlying forests in the swamps whose arrangement of trees and branches provided them with a natural habitat. Erosion and deforestation, however, soon forced them to adopt man-made structures suitable to their environment.

The meaning of the name Ganvie supports this theory. Gan expresses relief and can be interpreted to mean "we are saved," while Vie means community. Hence "we are the saved community."

Fishing comes to the Toffini naturally. They have also acquired a rare skill in breeding fish, a profession that may start as early as at the age of six. The fish farms are to be found in natural breeding grounds which are skillfully turned into farms to trap and retain more fish than would otherwise breed in the natural setting.

Apart from tourism, fishing is the other activity that has expanded during this new era that has given Benin a new more liberal disposition. The fishing farms are now larger and most households have more than one such farm.

Household incomes have, as a result, improved slightly; more people have radio sets while a few have television sets, Jean Claude Gnouloufoun told APS. A lady dealer lights her handicrafts' shop using solar energy. There is also engine generated power in some houses.

But despite these developments, the overwhelming majority of people live in abject poverty, in houses laid on hard teak-wood poles planted in the muddy bottom of the lake. The homes hardly have any household property to speak of.

As for canoes, these are items of absolute necessity. And since individual errands do not always coincide, it is important for each household to have more than one canoe.

The houses are built with bamboo walls and floors and roofed with palm leaves. The teak is rot-proof though poles may be replaced alternatively after several years.

Sanitation as has always been, remains a major problem with raw sewage and refuse from the houses draining in the water. With growing population, the lake and the air is increasingly becoming more polluted.

Water is another problem that has refused to go away. The village has one source of water that was constructed during colonial times when the population was much smaller.

Gnouloufoun, a dealer in handicrafts, believes the population is still set to increase. "Fewer and fewer people are migrating from the village because land is less available elsewhere in the country," he says.

The village is dotted with a few tiny and medium-sized patches of land and swampy grass fields that are not navigable. The Toffini have taken full advantage of these patches to construct some of their houses partly on land, partly in water.

The houses are approached from ladders suspended from the entrance into the mud. Some houses, despite their simplicity, have beautiful balconies overlooking the "streets" of the village of which "Lovers Lane" is the most famous.

The swamps provide a natural breeding place for mosquitoes, but which are only a nuisance at night. The villagers claim to be immune to mosquito bites.

Nevertheless this is one of the "many, many inherent problems of living on water" that inhabitants say "government should address using income earned from tourism."

One advantage of this habitat, however, says a handicrafts' dealer, is that thefts are rare while street muggers are unknown. "Here, it is not easy to make a quick escape or hasty retreat."


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


440 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Angola;
Regional Leaders Call For More Peace Efforts In Angola


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1640 words


 

Luanda - Fears of possible resumption of war in Angola have prompted Southern African regional leaders to urge former Angolan rebel chief Jonas Savimbi to help move forward the peace process by coming to the Angolan capital, Luanda.

The call came on October 2 after Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos told a Southern African Development Community (SADC) heads of state summit in Luanda, that his country was still between war and peace.

The one-day SADC summit, held under the chairmanship of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, and included Nelson Mandela of South Africa, Fredrick Chiluba of Zambia and Joachim Chissano of Mozambique, another former Portuguese colony in southern Africa ravaged by a long civil war that finally ended with a military and political settlement in 1992, issued a statement expressing concern at the slow pace of the peace process.

Savimbi, head of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA), which fought the ruling People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) from independence in 1975, did not take up an invitation to attend.

Opening the summit, Dos Santos said Angola was "at the crossroads between war and peace" following the signing of political and military protocols by the two rival sides in Lusaka, Zambia, in November 1994. 

"We're going through a crisis of confidence because of the systematic delays in the implementation of the peace pact. This summit will be decisive for our interlocutors to realise that they have everything to gain from honest and constructive cooperation," Dos Santos said.

Tight security was laid on for the summit, where Mugabe made no secret of his disappointment at Savimbi's failure to come. But the central Angola-based ex-guerrilla chief, who has expressed fears for his safety in Luanda, has not visited the capital since renewed civil war broke out after UNITA lost elections to the MPLA in 1992, and he has turned down a proposal by the government that he should become vice-president.

Portuguese Defence Minister Antonio Victorino, who is visiting Angola to discuss military cooperation, said Savimbi had missed a "unique opportunity" to help speed up the peace process.

The Angolan government and UNITA are still struggling to reach agreement on the formation of a government of national unity after Savimbi refused to become vice-president.

In Lusaka, negotiators spelt out in detail the steps for encamping and disarming troops of the rival sides and the formation of a new joint army, as well as of UNITA's participation in government and the administration.

However, they left Savimbi's role to one side to press ahead with a peace settlement and simply provided for him to have "special status", but Savimbi still reckons that "the moment is not right" to go to Luanda.

The SADC leaders could thus only make recommendations to encourage the two sides to find a way of working together until new elections can be held. In all, 70 UNITA deputies were elected in September 1992 for a four-year term. They were heavily outnumbered by MPLA deputies.

Dos Santos beat Savimbi in a first round of presidential elections but just failed to win the 50 per cent majority needed to avoid a run-off round, which has never been held.

The United Nations, which has sent some 7,000 troops to Angola to oversee the application of the 1994 peace accords, has repeatedly denounced the slow pace of the peace process.

On October 2, UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali criticised Savimbi's apparent boycott of the SADC summit, noting that had the latter come to Luanda for the meeting which would have been his first with Dos Santos on Angolan territory, the implementation of the 1994 peace pacts would have been accelerated.

However, all 63,000 soldiers of the former rebel UNITA movement have finally been registered in camps across Angola as a key stage in the demobilization process, the UN's special representative in Angola, Alioune Blondin Beye announced on September 26.

And reporting on October 7 to the UN Security Council in New York, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said he planned to begin reducing the number of UN peacekeepers in Angola by the end of 1996 despite "considerable delays."

The process of encampment began in November 1995, and by September 26, 63, 006 former UNITA guerrillas had been registered in 15 UN- supervised camps across the country.

More than 11,000 former UNITA soldiers have left the camps, complaining of intolerable conditions, but according to the UN Unit for Coordination of Humanitarian Aid, hundreds are returning to claim the 646 US dollars that will be granted to every demobilised soldier.

The demobilisation process began on September 24, despite the delay in completing the encampment, with the return of a group of 466 soldiers aged under 18 years to their native regions. Around 6,000 soldiers aged less than 18 fought with UNITA. Some 37,000 UNITA troops are due to be demobilised in all.

Some 5,000 soldiers were also selected to join a 90,000-strong Angolan defence force which will eventually include 26,300 UNITA soldiers and 63,700 government troops.

According to the military plan, the next step will involve formal establishment of the new army and the creation of its general staff, which is set to include 10 generals from UNITA ranks.

However, UNITA has so far failed to keep a promise to send the 10 to Luanda. Only five of them, including UNITA chief of staff General Arlindo Chenda Pena, known as "Ben Ben," are currently in the capital. The later is to become deputy commander of the joint defence force.

The mandate of the UN Angola Verification Mission (UNAVEM III) is scheduled to end next February, but problems in implementing the Lusaka peace protocol, signed in Zambia in November 1994, persist also on the political front.

The implementation of the military aspects of the Lusaka protocols is well under way, but some UNITA troops still have to be disarmed and the former rebels must hand in all their heavy weaponry to the UN mission.

On the political front, the Lusaka pact gave UNITA four cabinet portfolios in the government and seven deputy ministerial posts, as well as diplomatic positions. UNITA deputies elected to parliament late in 1992 under a first peace deal have to take up their seats there.

But the UN mission has been dissatisfied with the quantity of arms turned in by UNITA, saying that it found the numbers totally insufficient.

On September 16, UNITA gave the UNAVEM III 14 tonnes of shells, seven artillery pieces, including obsolete anti-aircraft batteries, two rocket launchers and a heavy machine-gun, with a local UNITA commander, General Numa Kamalata saying: "Our men did not have modern weapons. All that we have are weapons captured from our enemies of yesterday, our brothers today."

Kamalata, who headed UNITA troops in the four provinces of the north, Bengo, Kwanza-Norte, Uije and Zaire, said that soldiers there only possessed a total of two tanks, 42 heavy artillery pieces and 50 tonnes of shells.

The commander of UN peacekeeping troops in the southern African country, Zimbabwean General Philip Sibanda, urged UNITA to hand over considerable quantities of weapons during the next disarmament operation in the north-east.

"I am hoping to see more weapons and tanks," he said during the hand-over at Ntuku, which was not attended by representatives of the Luanda government, which has criticised the small amounts and poor quality of the arms so far surrendered by the ex-guerrillas.

Kamalata led UNITA forces when the civil war resumed at the end of 1992 after Jonas Savimbi's movement lost general elections to the ruling People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos.

The UNITA general seized control of almost all of Bengo province, north of Luanda. During government offences that preceded the Lusaka peace settlement, the rebels were forced out of the provincial capital, but they still control about 40 per cent of the province.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


441 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Inculturation And The 21st Century Church In Africa


BYLINE: Osman Njuguna, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1720 words


 

Nairobi - Is the African church well equipped for its enormous pastoral challenges as it bids farewell to the 20th century and welcomes the next millennium? What issues are likely to set the agenda for the 21st century African church as it endeavours to evangelise to people overwhelmed with social economic, political and even religious problems?

For the Catholic church, the goal seems set --how to effectively " inculturate" the Christian message to reflect the social, economic, religious and cultural needs of the African people.

In a recently published book, Ecclesia (the church) in Africa, under the sub-title, Urgent Need for Inculturation, Pope John Paul I I, referring to the recommendations reached at the first ever synodal assembly for African bishops, says; "On several occasions, the synod Fathers stressed the particular importance for evangelisation of inculturation, the process by which catechists take flesh in the various cultures."

The Catholic pontiff explains inculturation in two dimensions -- the intimate transformation of authentic cultural values through their integration in Christianity, and the insertion of Christianity in the various human cultures.

The historic special assembly for the African Catholic bishops considers inculturation an urgent priority in the life of the particular churches for a firm rooting of the gospel in Africa, notes the Pope. 

Ecclesia in Africa singles out inculturation as a requirement for evangelisation, terming it one of the greatest challenges for the church on the continent on the eve of the next millennium. Contents of his recent book form part of the recommendations and key issues raised by the historic assembly for the African synod held in Rome from April 10 to May 8, 1994.

Bishop Njeru Wambugu, a Kenyan and leader of a local independent church, commenting on the book by the Catholic pontiff told APS in an interview; "I agree with the Catholic pontiff and the entire Catholic hierarchy on the African continent that inculturation of the gospel message in respect of the African traditional values is one of the most effective ways to evangelise the people."

But Bishop Wambugu, who is also the General Secretary of the Organization of African Instituted Churches (OAIC) says "the (Catholic) church might have come out a bit late on the issue, however it is better late than never."

He is hopeful that through inculturation, the Catholic church as well as the mainline churches, will come face to face with African realities like celibacy and polygamy.

In the past, most of the mainline churches have tended to either downplay or ignore some central issues that govern the life of the African, both inside and outside their religious faith, Bishop Wambugu says.

A senior lecturer in religious studies at the Nairobi University, Kenya, Dr. Hannah Kinoti in an article published in a recent publication, Violence against Women: Reflections by Kenyan Women Theologians, says early Christian missionaries among Kenya's Kikuyu community, held the general outlook of the 19th century missionaries that everything in non-Christian religions and cultures was evil.

"It was an outlook which particularly denied any culture of value in Africa. " In their perceived double mission to evangelise and civilize the African, the missionaries believed that it was their duty to overhaul African culture, observes Dr. Kinoti who is a member of the Circle of Concerned African Women Theologians (CCAWT).

Individual missions and missionaries who worked among the Kikuyu (Kenya's largest ethnic group, mainly inhabitants of the Central Province) may have differed in the degree to which they condemned the local culture, but this general attitude dominated their activities, Dr. Kinoti argues in her article.

The Catholic bishops in Malawi have focussed on incluturation in their latest pastoral letter dated September 14 under the title, Walking Together in Faith; Our Journey Towards the Year 2000.

The Malawian Catholic clergy point out that "our Christianity was taught and we received it through the European and American missionaries, many of whom found little to be admired in our Malawian, African cultures."

They (missionaries) could not see Malawian cultures as a medium for Christianity, therefore their preaching could not avoid wholesale condemnations of local customs and institutions, the bishops lament, saying this made many Christians to feel like strangers in their own culture.

Stating that the process of inculturation involves and touches the whole of life -- customs, values, liturgy, theology and church structures among others, the bishops challenge the local hierarchy and the faithful to do more than talk about it. They ask them to be "actually living, praying, and worshipping following our cultures, while allowing the same cultures to be purified and inspired by gospel values."

The Malawian bishops recommend an intensive research and study, which they point out, would contribute towards discovering direction and guidance in inculturating the faith and gospel.

"We, as a conference and as individuals will encourage and oversee this work at national and diocesan levels according to our competence," the bishops elaborate. They have also requested experts in liturgy, theology and other disciplines to be resourceful, daring and respectful of authentic Christian and cultural values.

"We must heed the exhortation of the Holy Father who reminds us that inculturation is essential for evangelisation," the bishops add.

During his pastoral visit to Kenya in 1994, the spiritual leader of the worldwide Anglican community, the Archbishop of Canterbury Dr. George Carey, touched on incorporating culture but from a different perspective.

His was an apology to the African Anglicans for having been evangelized through the English culture by the early missionaries. "I do apologise to Africans over the way the Anglican church imposed English traditions on the continent, while ignoring the African culture," said Dr. Carey, late 1994, then a guest of the (Anglican) Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) in celebrations marking its 150 years in this East African country.

Speaking on the subject, The Mission of the Anglican Community in the 21st Century, the Anglican Archbishop noted that the mistake was made somehow out of ignorance by honourable people who were not only committed to evangelising the continent but ready to die for their faith.

Dr.Carey, however, noted that the early missionaries may not have been as informed and aware as we ar today on the riches of African cultures and traditional values.

And writing on Contextual Theology: A Basic Need Within the Churches in Africa Today the African Ecclesial Review -, published by the Catholic bishops in Central and Eastern Africa, Victor Chendekemen Yakubu, a Nigerian seminarian offers advice on how to accomplish the inculturation of the Christian message in Africa.

Instead of lamenting about the Euro-American cultural models used by the early missionaries when evangelising Africa, the main concern should be to rediscover through these cultures what the gospel proclaimed."

Yakubu argues that churches ought to strive to develop new trends in teaching their peoples the essence of Christianity within the local context by using the structure, personnel and policies already existing in the church.

The Nigerian seminarian advocates for detachment from "the North Atlantic captivity of the Church" to an African theological model in doctrine, liturgy, theology, personnel and even name.

"No theology is taken seriously if it ignores the surrounding social misery. The African bishops rejected the theology of adaptation (the attempt to adapt traditional Western theology to other cultures) and accepted the theology of incarnation (the attempt to explain the Christian religion in traditional thought patterns in the light of the "word became flesh and dwelt among us" (John 1:14)), he said.

The Nigerian ends his paper by evoking the sentiments of Pope John VI and Pope John Paul II on inculturation of the Christian message.

Quoting Pope John Paul II, he says; "A faith that does not become culture is a faith that is not fully accepted, completely thought on, and truly lived on."

From Pope Paul VI, he adds; "The gospel is an incarnation of the Christian life and message in an actual cultural area in such a way that this experience can be expressed not only in the elements of the cultures in question, but it becomes the inspiring, normative and unifying principle that transforms and recreates this culture, giving rise to a new creation."


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


442 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Africa's Churches Asked To Give Hope, Food, Shelter


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

HARARE (APS) OCTOBER 14 - The Church in Africa has a duty to continue giving hope, where hopelessness has reigned; feed, where hunger has prevailed, clothe, where nakedness is affecting people, shelter where people have been shelterless and heal, where diseases have become the order of the day, a president of the World Council of Churches (WCC) has said here.

Delivering a key-note speech during the Silver Jubilee celebrations of the Association of Lay Christian Centres in Africa (ACLCA), held here from October 6 to 13, Dr. Eunice Santana, said some of the social, economic and political issues prevailing on the Africa continent, had made many of the African people to become hopeless.

It was therefore the duty of the church on the continent to continue to instill hope where destitution among other sufferings, have prevailed, she stressed.

Like in Caribbean and Latin American countries, the African continent is affected by many odds such as hunger and violation of human rights, and churches should chip in their contribution to eradicate them, she further told the huge gathering of nearly 200 delegates, who attended the occasion. 

Citing women and youth as an example, the WCC president, who hails from Puerto Rico said, "there were numerous odds that militated against women and youth and the church should direct its pastoral attention to them."

Turning to UN statistics, Rev. Dr. Santana noted there are currently about 26 million African girls who are out of school due to divergent reasons, chief among them lack of school fees or early pregnancy.

"The figure is expected to rise to 36 million by the turn of the century," she further told the ACLCA meeting.

The delegates included national coordinators and directors of the member lay Christian centres of the ACLCA, the founders of the ACLCA and invited fraternal guests from various parts of the world.

The Silver Jubilee celebrations, which also coincided with the general assembly of the pan-African Christian Association, were celebrated under the theme: Celebrating in Hope; Restoring Just Relationships.

The Silver Jubilee celebrations, which also coincided with the general assembly of the pan-African Christian Association, were celebrated under the theme: Celebrating in Hope; Restoring Just Relationships.

Saying that the church has always tried its best to alleviate people's sufferings, Rev. Dr. Santana regretted that "sometimes, lack of political will to accompany this, has failed the church in reaching its goal."

The fact that WCC has decided to hold its 8th General Assembly in Zimbabwe in 1998, was a clear sign that the global ecumenical organization was trying to come closer to the African Christians. "We must respond to this gesture by playing a vital role before and during the general assembly," she added.

According to Rev. Santana the church would lose a lot if she failed to be a community based institution. "The church needs the faithful's support, much as they (the faithful) need the church's support," she emphasized.

Addressing the same gathering, General Secretary of the Zimbabwe Council of Churches (ZCC) Rev. Murombedzi Chikanga Kuchera said of the ACLCA; "25 years is a long time and reaching this milestone meant hard work, patience and persistence." However, he added, the next 25 years leading to the golden jubilee, will not be simple considering the speed and space at which the technological world is flying.

Emphasizing the need to be sensitive to the plight of women, youth and the marginalized, Rev. Kuchera said it was no use talking about the rights of women without arming and equipping them with the necessary tools such as education, which they can use to develop the world.

Delivering a sermon during the official opening of the celebrations, Lt. Colonel Stuart Mungate said "Africa needs to sing a new song which brings in the new heaven and the new earth with the holy city of God."

He lamented that people's minds are obsessed with greed, thinking only about self while caring little about the suffering of others.

Lt. Colonel Mungate of the Salvation Army Church (Zimbabwe), listed disease, hunger, the up-rooted, economic hardships, women and child suffering, and all forms of abusive systems as causes of sorrow on the African continent.

The Salvation Army church minister paid glowing tribute to celebrated Catholic nun-Mother Teresa of Calcutta, India, for her excellent work and concern among the poor in India. "She has become a household name through human contact," he added.

And he challenged fellow African Christians; "Let us become Christians that are involved totally. Let's wash the wounds, bandage them and care to prove that we love."

In his brief address to delegates, ACLCA president, South African church minister, Rev. Sipho Masemola challenged churches and Christians in general to journey together with ACLCA for greater participation in the future, even as they joined the organization during its Silver Jubilee celebrations.

Instituted in 1970, the ACLCA which currently enjoys a membership of 67 lay Christian training centres in 24 African countries, is a fellowship of African lay centres, academies and movements of social concern, whose common mission is leadership training, laity formation and ecumenical learning.

"The centres which associate themselves in this fellowship seek to share ideas and adopt common strategies for action, to fulfill together their common vision to the glory of one Father, Son and Holy Spirit," remarked the association's Executive Secretary, Rev. Jonah Katoneene, in an interview with APS during the Silver Jubilee celebrations in the Zimbabwean capital.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


443 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Madagascar;
Candidates Galore For Madagascar's Presidential Polls


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

ANTANANARIVO (APS) OCTOBER 14 - At least 17 candidates, including two former presidents, will be vying for the top posts during the coming Malagasy presidential elections scheduled for November 3.

Leading the field will be two former presidents, the recently impeached former president Albert Zafy and the man he defeated in the last poll in February 1993, Admiral Didier Ratsiraka, the current acting President Norbert Ratsirahonana, and the outgoing national assembly president Pastor Richard Andriamanjato, a past chairman of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC).

Also standing is former prime minister Guy Razanamasy and opposition politician Herizo Razafimahaleo. 

The list was compiled by the Indian Ocean island republic's election officials at the deadline for handing over nomination papers on October 5.

Malagasies will vote for a new head of state on November 3, following the destitution of president Albert Zafy by the high constitutional court of Madagascar, officials said here.

The October 5 deadline date was set by the government of the large Indian Ocean island republic, where Ratsirahonana was named interim president by the country's constitutional court on September 5, after upholding a decision by the general assembly taken in July to impeach Zafy, whom parliamentarians accused of failing to enact plans to form a senate, or upper house of parliament, and to reform the judiciary.

Elected three years ago with a large majority, Zafy had been bracing himself for the court's ruling after the vote at the end of July, in which 99 of the 138 members of the lower house of parliament wanted him impeached.

Once elected to a presidency with diminished powers, Zafy had pledged to be the guardian of the new constitution of Madagascar's Third Republic.

Emmanuel Rakotovahiny resigned as prime minister in May after his government received a no-confidence vote in the national assembly, but his replacement by the president of the constitutional court, Norbert Ratsirahonana, failed to dispel the government's unpopularity.

Zafy, a former professor of medicine and health minister, was a key figure in the pro-democracy movement that eventually ended the 17- year rule of former military strongman, Didier Ratsiraka.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


444 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Nigeria;
Human Rights Violation A Major Concern In Nigeria


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

NEW YORK (APS) OCTOBER 14 - Despite its stated commitment to return Nigeria to civilian rule by October 1, 1998, the Nigerian government continues to violate the rights of Nigerian citizens to freely engage in political activity.

Permanent Transition, a report released on September 26 by Human Rights Watch/Africa, assesses the transition programme and the steps that have been taken toward its implementation to date, including an examination of the seriously flawed local government elections of March 1996.

The 52-page report identifies the impediments to free political activity that destroy the credibility of the transition programme, including the detention and imprisonment of opposition politicians, human rights and pro- democracy activists, trade unionists and journalists, as well as restrictions on freedom of expression, assembly, association and movement.

In a press release here, Human Rights Watch charges that recent reforms announced by the government including the restoration of a right to appeal in some cases where it had been denied, the repeal of a decree preventing the courts from granting writs of habeas corpus in favour of detainees held without charge, and the creation of a human rights commission are purely cosmetic, and do not begin to address the need for fundamental reform and renewal. 

As a result, Human Rights Watch calls for the imposition of additional international sanctions including freezing the foreign assets of members of the Nigerian military government to ensure that the West African nation is returned to civilian rule by a freely elected government as soon as possible.

Repression continues in Ogoniland, birthplace of executed minority rights activist Ken Saro-Wiwa. Nineteen Ogonis still await trial before the same Civil Disturbances Special Tribunal that convicted Saro-Wiwa and eight others and sentenced them to death in October 1995, executions later described by British Prime Minister John Major as "judicial murder."

Other suspected sympathizers of Saro-Wiwa's organization, the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP), were detained after demonstrations on January 4, 1996, celebrated as "Ogoni Day" since January 1993.

Still more Ogonis were detained before or during the April visit of a fact- finding team sent to Nigeria by the United Nations Secretary General, despite assurances by the Nigerian government that nobody would be penalized for attempting to speak to the team.

While the Nigerian government has put in place token efforts at " reconciliation" in Ogoniland, it has not made any move to pay compensation to the families of the executed activists, as recommended by the UN fact-finding team.

International attention has shifted from Nigeria during 1996, after an outcry following the November 1995 executions of the Ogoni Nine.

Although sanctions imposed following the executions remain in force, as well as those put in place in 1993, no further measures have been imposed, despite the lack of genuine progress in returning the country to an elected government.

The Commonwealth, which suspended Nigeria's membership in November 1995, has halted the implementation of additional sanctions recommended in April 1996 by the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group (CMAG), pending further discussions with the Nigerian government.

The Organization of African Unity (OAU) has failed to take any measures against Nigeria, and the African Commission on Human and People's Rights, which held an extraordinary session on Nigeria in December 1995, has yet to follow this up with further action or recommendations.

Human Rights Watch calls for international pressure to be maintained and intensified to ensure that the Nigerian government takes meaningful steps to improve the human rights situation. Detainees must be released and free expression and assembly restored in order to ensure a genuine transition to civilian rule.

In particular, Human Rights Watch urges the imposition of a total arms embargo on Nigeria, and the freezing of assets held in other countries by members of the Nigerian armed forces or senior members of the government and their families.

Human Rights Watch was also concerned that the CMAG which met on September 28 to 29, would urge the Commonwealth member states to implement the sanctions recommended last April, and also adopt an asset freeze and arms embargo.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 28, 1996


United States and Africa;
Mali Commits Troops To Africa Crisis Response Force


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

BAMAKO (APS) OCTOBER 14 - The West African nation of Mali, one of the poorest countries in the world, has become the first in Africa to confirm it will commit troops to the proposed Africa Crisis Response Force.

Malian President Alpha Oumar Konare, told visiting American Secretary of State Warren Christopher here on October 8 that Mali was ready to participate in the Crisis Force.

Mr. Christopher was in Bamako on the first leg of a five-nation tour of Africa, the first time he has visited sub-Saharan Africa. Christopher commended Mali for its contribution of troops during the Gulf War crisis in the early 90's. 

For many years the Organization of African Unity (OAU) has been trying to organize such a force to intervene in conflicts or natural disasters on the continent but was unable to win donor support or commitment to fund it.

However, in the face of crises in Burundi, Liberia and the potentially explosive situation in eastern Zaire, the United States said it would contribute a substantial portion of the estimated $40 million required to train and equip the force.

The United States State Department Under Secretary for African Affairs George Moose said the primary purpose of the crisis intervention force was to impose peace on warring factions. Moose believes such a force could be created quickly and deployed as a preventive force or in explosive locations like Burundi in the event of a Rwanda-style genocide scenario becoming a reality.

The Secretary of State told his hosts in Bamako that he will consolidate the idea of the Crisis Force in Ethiopia - his second stop over in Africa.

In Addis Ababa he will meet officials of the OAU before travelling to Tanzania where his arrival on October 11, will coincide with the Eastern Africa regional meeting to review the situation in the troubled Central African nation of Burundi. Christopher will then travel to South Africa and Angola.

In Bamako, Christopher, who has been accused of neglecting Africa since he took office in 1992, choosing instead to concentrate on the Arab-Israel conflict, was met by jubilant dancers and found time to tour a number of American supported projects run by the 160-strong peace corps in the West African nation. He pledged $700,000 to Malis' General Election due next year.

He suggested that African nations should search quickly for a candidate to take over the post of United Nations Secretary General since America would not support the incumbent Boutros Boutros-Ghali whose term expires later this year.

Christopher said America had made up its mind that Boutros Ghali must relinquish his post, charging that the Egyptian born Secretary General had failed to deliver over the last five years that he has been head of the cash- strapped UN. Ironically the United States is the UN's biggest debtor nation.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
