Africa News


October 28, 1996


Uganda;
Ugandan Women In Aggressive Search For Peace


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

KAMPALA (APS) OCTOBER 14 - A meeting convened by the Uganda Women's Network resolved on October 7 to form a pressure or lobby group to work for a peaceful resolution to the insurgency in the North of the country, particularly West Nile, Gulu and Kitgum districts.

The stormy meeting comes in the wake of reports that the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) led by a one time Catholic catechist, Joseph Kony, had murdered 70 people in Gulu and Kitgum districts in the month of September alone.

The meeting by the Uganda Women Network (UWONET) which combines all national non-governmental women's organizations, criticised the government of Uganda for its failure to involve women from the onset in making decisions about the war in the North. 

The women said they will hold "highly publicized" demonstrations demanding peace as a way of putting pressure on both government and rebels to end the suffering of the people in northern Uganda.

The UWONET meeting was chaired by Ms. Rebecca Kadaga, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs in charge of Regional Affairs. It was attended by politicians, diplomats and people from the affected districts in the north.

The keynote address was delivered by Ms. Winnie Byanyima, a Member of Parliament from south-western Uganda, who said the war was fanned by selfish individuals both on the government side as well as Acholi tribes people from the north "who are using ethnicity to pursue their narrow agenda."

"All of us politicians in Uganda are guilty of tribalising the war in the North to pursue our own personal agenda," she lamented.

She said the origins of the northern conflict was economic imbalance in Uganda created in the period of colonial rule, when the colonial administration formulated stereotype roles for Uganda's various tribalcommunities.

The current insurgency in the North began in 1986 when President Yoweri Museveni's National Resistance Movement/Army (NRM/A)came to power. Soldiers of the defeated former regime combined with the "Holy Spirit" movement of the mystic Alice Lakwena had returned from Sudan to wage war on the new regime. She was defeated in 1988.

Subsequently, Joseph Kony a former catechist of the Catholic church formed a splinter fighting group called the Lord's Resistance Army which initially sought to have Uganda ran as a fundamentalist Christian state.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


447 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Ethiopia;
Genocide Trial Resumes In Ethiopian Capital


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (APS) OCTOBER 14 - The genocide trial of Ethiopia's former dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam and his aides resumed in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa on October 1, with the arraigning in court of 46 defendants.

A total of 120 people, all former soldiers, including Lieutenant- Colonel Mengistu himself, face charges of genocide and crimes against humanity under his Marxist regime between 1974 and 1991.

On the first day of the hearings on October 1, which lasted only two hours, witnesses told how family members disappeared under the "Red Terror" regime of Mengistu, with the 40th witness in the trial taking the stand and describing how his younger brother, a student, Malo Salai, was arrested in 1976 and was never seen again.

"His classmates were arrested because they distributed opposition tracts. I wanted to protect him by forbidding him from leaving the house, but he managed to get out. You know how young people are," said the witness, a retired colonel. 

The family finally learnt that the youth was in the central prison. Police later gave them back his clothes and simply said that he was no longer in jail. "After that, we mourned him. We don't know how he was killed."

Two other witnesses described how they lost relatives in similar circumstances. One woman's husband was arrested while she was in hospital. When she was discharged, she found that prison authorities had given back his jersey and a towel.

On October 8, six other witnesses took the stand and told of atrocities committed by Mengistu's Marxist military regime.

One witness took off his jacket and shirt and showed the court a long scar which he said came from a wound caused by three bullets the day soldiers killed his mother and arrested his father.

His sister, today an elected local government official, also gave evidence before the court, where 46 of the accused were present in the dock.

A police officer said he had been ordered to escort prisoners to the central jail, which was known as "Alem Bekagn" (The world is over), and disclosed that some of them never got there.

Mengistu, who is in exile in Zimbabwe, and 24 other defendants are being tried in their absence, while others among the accused are dead, either eliminated during purges of the junta or killed trying to flee the country when allied rebel armies toppled his regime in May 1991.

The trial, known as "Africa's Nuremberg", began in December 1994 and has been held up by procedural questions and adjournments, the last of them in July, to allow for holidays and the rainy season.

The indictments, totalling almost 500 pages, accuse members of the regime known as the Derg, of the murder of 1,825 people, torturing about 100 others and other crimes against humanity.

In previous hearings, 39 women related to the victims of mass murder gave evidence, together with former soldiers and the chamberlains of the late emperor Haile Selassie, who was suffocated in his bed at the age of 83 with an ether-soaked pillow in 1975, the year after Mengistu seized power.

The accused face the death sentence on conviction. Three of those being tried in their absence are holed up in the Italian embassy here and Rome is reluctant to extradite them because they face capital punishment.

Others accused of war crimes, forcibly displacing whole populations and other acts while serving the junta are due to be tried by other courts.

A document released by special prosecutor Guirma Wakjira's office in August 1994, indicates that 1,315 suspected of taking part in massacres are in prison, but other sources say the total number of detainees is closer to 2, 000.

Human rights groups and opponents of the government headed by Meles Zenawi, former leader of the Tigre People's Liberation Front (TPLF) rebels who were allied with Eritrean forces, have accused it of violating the rights of the defendants by holding them for more than four years awaiting trial.

But the government maintains that the legal system and the financial resources at the disposal of the prosecution have made it impossible to move any faster.

The state's case has been helped by the bureaucratic practices of Mengistu's brand of Marxism, which produced 300,000 pages of incriminating documents as well as films and videos. Estimates of the number of killings under Mengistu range from 50,000 to 200,000.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


448 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Journalists Discuss Media Role In Conflict Resolution


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) OCTOBER 14 - A journalism programme here recently organized a workshop to discuss the role of media in conflict prevention and resolution.

The eighth in a series, the seminar which was facilitated by the United States International University - African (USIU-A) ran from September 25 to 27.

The programme which began on February 1995 has trained more than 200 practitioners in various fields of specialization including the coverage of elections, feature writing, gender issues, interpretative reporting and investigative journalism.

At the latest seminar, participants observed that conflicts worldwide, in Africa or Kenya, will always be a source of news and good copy for journalists everywhere, but whenever journalists write about conflicts they probably make situations worse than they already are. 

Wars, bloodshed and death are the very substance which dominate front pages and news bulletins in both print and electronic media the world over, the meeting noted.

Conflicts make an important part of human interest stories, they will continue to dominate both space and time in all the news media, participants agreed.

In a stimulated contribution Mr. Joe Kadhi, former managing editor of Kenya's leading mass circulation daily, the Daily Nation, who is currently the journalism programme coordinator at the USIU-A, challenged journalists to become more involved in efforts to ensure that Kenya will never degenerate into a state of bloody civil war similar to what has been experienced elsewhere in Africa.

Referring to bloodshed during the 1991-93 political/ethnic land clashes in parts of the country, Mr Kadhi underscored the need for journalists to be exposed to professional ethics of covering conflicts and peace efforts.

The role played by media in stirring up ill feelings among people can clearly be seen in Rwanda, where radio effectively built up hatred among nationals of the same country, although from different ethnic background, Mr. Kadhi emphasized

Saying journalists could be agents of peace and understanding, the USIU-A journalism programme coordinator called for deliberate efforts to make media practitioners change the style, language and presentation of ethnic clashes, with a view to highlighting positive and responsible journalism without hiding any facts or muzzling the press.

Mr. Polycarp Ochilo, a lecturer at the University of Nairobi School of Journalism, who is also a communication consultant at the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) Communication Training Centre (CTC), challenged the media to seek the root causes of conflict as a way of finding solutions and promoting peace.

The AACC communication consultant also called for research activities in areas where conflicts exist.

The media , he said, should encourage social and cultural promotion of dialogue where conflicts arise and construct an international order to promote democracy. "You cannot solve the conflict if you don't understand the value of the conflict," added Ochilo.

Speaking on the Western misconception about Africa, a veteran cameraman Mohammed Amin said the Western world is assumed to be unprepared to relish any story from the rest of the world, especially from the Third World, unless such a story is "juicy" because of its negative highlights.

The cameraman cited famines, volcanoes, earthquakes, floods, political upheavals as some of the disasters with which the Western world and media identify Africa and Third World in general.

Editors and "gatekeepers" in the Western newsrooms are usually men and women who have never "left their editorial armchairs" to see for themselves at firsthand - the real situation in Africa, so as to be able to give a correct and more sympathetic account of why Africa is besieged by such calamities, noted Mr. Amin.

The seminar, jointly conducted by a team of professional experts and academicians who have either worked as journalists in high ranking positions or have taught journalism for a long time, brought together more than 50 participants drawn from local newspapers and other media in Kenya.

The participants called for an independent information body which would be responsible for African news only.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Kenya;
Lucrative Bicycle-Taxi Industry Losing Its Lustre


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Nairobi - For the past four or so years, Ochieng' Okelo has been earning an honest, if a little too energy-sapping, livelihood as a bicycle taxi operator in Kisumu, Kenya's third largest town with a population of about 300,000, and situated about 500 kilometres west of the capital, Nairobi.

Although rather menial-looking and probably looked down upon, Okelo's occupation has improved his life from below the poverty line to reasonably comfortable levels.

But not any more. For the life line of Ochieng' Okelo, 38, and his 1,000 colleagues in the Lake Victoria port town, is threatened by forces beyond their control. "I don't know what I will do should this business collapse," lamented Okelo during an interview with APS. 

In the first place, a controversy has been stirred by bicycle operators in Busia District, about 140 kilometres north-west of Kisumu, where the pedal- powered vehicles are called boda-boda, an onomatopoeic term referring to the area of operation--across the Kenya-Uganda border.

Here the bikemen ferry small-scale traders from the Busia border town to various destinations in the district and its environs. According to recent press reports, the spouses of the men who ride these bicycles are complaining rather loudly that their partners do not perform their husbandly duties to their wives' satisfaction after a day's hard slogging.

"When he comes home in the evening, my man is so tired that my conjugal rights are not met," the local press quoted one woman as griping.

But health experts disagree with the women, arguing that bicycle riding does not cause impotence. Says Dr. John Owiyo, a Kisumu- based physician: " Riding a bicycle for long hours per se does not reduce a man's libido, or his sexual performance. The effect is merely physical and psychological. The women should know better and feed their men properly."

Dr. Opondo Wakhungu, a clinical psychologist argues that the economic pressures, especially on the men, are not conducive to good sexual performance. Like all the other men in the business and the salaried sectors, he says, the pressure to work harder and meet the family's cash obligations reduces the man's libido. "The bikemen, by virtue of their very energy- sapping calling, bear the brunt of this inadequacy more than many other cadres of men," Dr. Wakhungu says.

This complaint by the Busia women in general has spread to Kisumu town and its environs where the pedal-powered bike has become a popular mode of commuter transport.

After several sleepless nights caused by quarrels from a neighbour's house, this writer accosted the man of the house who summarised his situation thus: " It is not my fault, it is my wife's. She keeps moaning about my inability to do this and that, and sometimes this altercation ends up in a fight."

"You are a fellow man, I may confide in you. This woman says that since I started operating my bike taxi, my sexual performance has not been up to the required standards. She says that the situation is going from bad to worse," the neighbour who is also a bicycle taxi operator told this writer.

His 35 year-old wife had this to say: "In matters of marriage and procreation I cannot be shy," she bellowed. "You see, Baba Toto, (father of children) I took quite sometime having children and I have only three to show for my age. When this man comes home he's so tired he's no good to any woman. If this situation continues, I may not be able to have any more children while my co-wife has eight. Much as I need the money, I am entitled to my conjugal rights and to children."

Another raw point in the bikemen's business is how to keep their customers satisfied. Says Ochieng' Okelo: "My customers keep complaining about either the hot sun or the rain. At such times my earnings are drastically reduced as the would-be customers are forced to travel by other means."

Although the Kisumu bicycle taxi operators are organising themselves into a co-operative society, with a view to fixing hoods on their bikes, like the rickshaws of India, this may take quite a bit of time, subjecting their business to further problems beyond their individual control.

The evolution of the biycle as an alternative means of commuter transport in Kisumu town may be ascribed to the town's general level of poverty. The ramshackle saloon cars that ply the town's routes are few and far between, and the Government-owned Nyayo Bus Corporation which used to ease the situation somewhat, has gone under and is in the process of being sold.

Private cars are even fewer and mostly owned by the more affluent Asian community who continue to dominate the town's business life. Although the Luo, who dominate the town blame this state of affairs on state marginalisation, they bear part of the blame owing to their combative politics and inconsolable opposition to the establishment.

Thus, in answer to the residents' call for a cheaper and more readily available means of commuter transport, came the bicycle taxis which have proved very popular, especially with the low-income workers.

The bikemen charge an average of shillings 10 (less than 20 US cents) per trip covering distances between the town centre and the suburbs. And since an ambitious operator can make up to 30 trips a day, a monthly earning of Sh.9, 000 (about $160) is not out of question.

Thus, although the hike-on-a-bike business is greatly threatened, it remains a lucrative means of livelihood for many Kisumu residents who cannot make good elsewhere. Besides, the many commuters who cannot afford the exorbitant fares charged by matatus (communal taxis) and buses, will continue to depend on it and take sides with the men operators, even when the debate touches on that crucial male factor.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


450 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Algeria;
Algeria In Race To Quash Extremists As War Intensifies


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Nairobi - According to political activists, Algerian President Liamine Zeroual has embarked on an apparent race to undermine hardline Islamic movements in Algeria by making Islam the official language in this north African country, while at the same time pushing through with democratic reforms.

In an announcement made in the Algerian capital, Algiers, on October 14, Zeroual said he would put the issue of religion to a referendum on November 28, a move that was clearly aimed at preventing the outlawed Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) from gaining ground and reclaiming its position as a major political power.

Zeroual, who embarked on a week-long tour of Gulf and Asian countries on October 15, has also been trying to bring various political parties into talks aimed at convincing them of his willingness to implement democratic changes.

The proposed amendment has, however, stopped short of making a unilateral declaration on the vexing issue of separation of church from state, as has been demanded by several democratic and secular parties, such as the former communist Ettahaddi Movement, although stressing that "Islam is our religion and our foundation since the message was delivered" by the prophet Mohamed. 

During his address to the nation, Zeroual called on Algerians to decide on the issue of religion and state, while taking into account that Islam, Arab and Berber were the three main components of national identity.

His proposed constitutional reforms, however, do not deal with the issue of Berber becoming the official language along with Arabic, as called for by various Berber parties and opposition groups who have threatened to boycott the referendum vote.

He told voters in his televised speech that his proposed reforms would ensure that Islam and the Berber language would no longer be used as political weapons.

"You are being asked to decide on what criteria should be used for the creation (of parties) that will operate without being manipulated by religious and language" issues, he said, adding that such parties would have to avoid being influenced by foreign powers and refrain from violence, a reference to the armed campaign by Islamic fundamentalists to topple the government since January 1992.

The violence has left tens of thousand of people dead and severely crippled the country's economic and political standing.

Zeroual said that his government was doing all it could to eliminate terrorism in the country and that his decision to be lenient with "lost" citizens had allowed us "to save numerous of our youngsters" who had joined armed groups.

Amendments to the constitution will also be designed to limit the powers of the president in favour of parliament, which will be given a second chamber to "give more stability to the institutions of the state," Zeroual said.

Zeroual said the referendum would also cover the creation of a council of state to "strengthen justice and administration," and the introduction of a state high court which would be given powers to try the president "should he no longer be worthy of the confidence placed in him by the people."

"I am committing myself, today, before you, to respect your sovereign decision. Your choice will be the substance of a move towards the revision of laws on the parties and on the electoral code, as well as legislative and local elections," Zeroual said.

The President also confirmed that general elections would be held before mid-next year, and local elections before the end of 1997.

The Algerian Head of State last month announced the establishment of a national commission, to be chaired by Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia, to organise the referendum in the strife-torn country.

The 700,000 Algerians living abroad will also be entitled to vote. Algeria has been in the throes of a savage civil war since 1992, pitting the military- backed government against Islamic fundamentalist insurgents who claim to have won parliamentary elections in January of that year.

The government annulled the elections, sparking a conflict which has so far cost an estimated 50,000 lives. The new developments come in the wake of an escalation of bloody attacks by the Islamic extremists throughout the country.

On October 11, a 25-strong gang of armed Islamic extremists burned down a professional training centre for some 300 young women in western Algiers after overpowering guards, the daily El Watan newspaper reported on October 16.

It said the attackers stayed in the building in the Bainem quarter of the capital for an hour to make sure it had caught fire, before fleeing into a nearby wood.

Last year, 815 schools and 34 training centres were hit in attacks blamed on Islamic extremists fighting the Algerian government. The armed fundamentalists consider aspects of education to be un- Islamic. Teachers and pupils have been murdered in the country's bitter conflict.

Since the October 11 attack on the professional training centre, two more bombs have rocked Algeria, killing seven people and injuring a further 26 in the town of Blida, 50 kilometres south of Algiers, and bringing the death toll since the beginning of September to over 80, according to press reports.

The first bomb on October 16, which ripped through a passing train, killing three and wounding 10 more, had been placed on a railway line outside the town, the daily Liberte said on October 19.

A second blast occurred on the afternoon of October 17 in a working class district of the town, leaving four dead and 16 injured, according Liberte. Both bombings were attributed to the Islamic fundamentalists' bloody campaign of violence aimed at destabilising Algeria's military-backed government.

In one of the worst incidents recently, a car bomb which exploded in a crowded market place in nearby Boufarik killed 27 and left more than 80 injured on September 27.

Thirty eight people were on October 8 slaughtered at a false checkpoint near a gas field in the south of the country, while on October 15, the Islamic extremists killed four people and injured 13 others in two separate incidents, security services said.

They said three people were killed overnight and 13 injured, two of them seriously, when a homemade bomb exploded in the Lakhdaria district south-east of the capital, while the fourth person killed was the business manager of the Arabic language weekly Echuruk who was shot while driving his car in the capital early the same day.

The security services communique said Hamoui Mokrane, 43, was gunned down by a "group of terrorists", the official term used for armed Islamic extremists. The Echuruk magazine has one of the biggest circulations in the Algerian press and is usually aimed at female readership.

Journalists became prime targets in 1993, and 54 have since been killed as well as another 20 or so people working as drivers or in other press-related jobs, whom the fundamentalists accused of "collaborating" with the government.

The fatal attack on the manager was the third on an Echuruk employee. In May last year, journalist Malika Sabour, 22, had her throat cut by an armed gang, while in November, Khadidja Dahmani, 28, was shot dead.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


451 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Church and Society Blamed For Violence Against Women


BYLINE: Osman Njuguna, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2000 words


 

Nairobi - Voicing their concern in a recently published book, "Violence Against Women," a group of Kenyan women theologians blame the violence against their lot squarely on the church as an institution as well as on cultural values, which they say demean the African womanhood.

And because of the diversity of the subject matter, the ten women theologians have dealt with the rather controversial issue under ten papers which include among others, Feminist Theology and African Culture; Rape as a Tool of Violence against Women; Theological Reflection on Economic Violence against Women; The Church in Africa and Violence against Women and the Status of Women in African Naming Systems.

In their introductory remarks, Grace Wamue and Mary Getui who edited the 85- page volume say; "The violence is many faceted -- cultural, social, religious and economic. Each of the voices in this book is crying out to society and to the church for recognition, attention and action."

In particular, say the editors, women are wondering why the church, the body of Christ does not seem to curb, address or even realise that women are getting a raw deal. The theme that runs through all the papers is that violence against women is not warranted and should be eliminated. 

In her paper, Feminist Theology and African Culture, Dr. Musimbi Kanyoro appreciates the efforts taken by fellow women to speak out, saying; "If today African women are able to name the oppressive aspects of our cultures, it has not come easily. For centuries, African women have gone so far along with cultural prescriptions, that we came to believe that our lives were to be managed by commands of our cultures. The fear of breaking taboos silenced us into a state where we act without questioning what we do."

Dr. Kanyoro, currently Secretary for Women in Church and Society in the department of Mission and Development of the Geneva-based Lutheran World Federation (LWF), describes the study of theology from the women's perspective as a gift to the church and to women.

She says the study of theology has opened the eyes of many women to the gospel of Jesus Christ the Redeemer, and goes on to refer to women's theological reflections as an oasis in a desert, a pearl of great price, a treasure long hidden and just discovered.

A strong believer in feminist theology, Dr. Kanyoro explains that feminist theology springs out of women's experiences in church and society. It gives women an imperative call to remember and to name their experiences by articulating their stories of faith and life. By telling their day to day stories, the church will be forced to listen to their day to day struggles and the way in which women have maintained their faith in God, says the Kenyan theologian.

On the composition of its members and leadership Dr. Kanyoro observes: "The church will need to come to grips with the fact that 80 per cent of the church membership in Africa is made up of women and not even 5 per cent of the leadership of the church is women."

Cautioning that women's stories should not be told as individual stories of endless suffering, the Kenyan theologian proposes that these "must be told collectively as corporate stories of a community of God's people moving forward in faith and hope in order to bring renewal to the Church of Christ."

Writing on Violence Against Women in African Oral Literature as portrayed in proverbs, Hazel Ayanga says cases of violence against women include rape or attempted rape, physical assault like battering and sometimes actual murder and killing.

But violence against women seems to have some deep rooted causes, she points out. In other words, she elaborates that causes of general violence in society are not adequate explanations for violence against women. There appears to be some religious cultural roots of violence against African women, she observes, adding; "the place of women in traditional and to a large extent in modern African societies is determined by cultural norms and attitudes."

These norms and values have been passed on orally. They have been preserved and propagated from generation to generation through different forms of the spoken word -- mainly stories, proverbs, songs, myths and rituals, Ayanga explains.

The Kenyan scholar recommends that the negative and prejudicial proverbs should be discarded as new evidence and new challenges are identified and addressed. There may be a need of continued reformation of proverbs if they are to remain current and useful in the society. In this way, "we can identify with and put in practice Christ's parable, 'And no one pours the new wine into old wineskin. If he does, the wineskin will be ruined," (Luke 5:37: 38) she stresses.

Addressing the subject Theological Reflection on Economic Violence Against Women, Constance Shisanya, suggests that Kenyan women should put pressure on the government to punish all those individuals who misuse child labour and force young girls into early marriages.

And hopefully, she says, this would provide girls with equal education opportunities to compete with boys, thereby eliminating the existing gender disparities.

Shisanya adds, however, she would be acting on faith by attempting to enforce the suggested proposals on the Christian Community. The effort, she explains, would be in line with the biblical teaching on caring for the under privileged in the community.

On the Church in Africa and Violence Against Women Ruth Muthei James, revisits the controversial subject of ordination of women into priesthood. With regard to theological education, she suggests that all churches open up ordained ministry for women. Church leaders should encourage and be supportive to young women who desire to be trained as ordained ministers and theologians, she recommends.

She challenges women to stand up and tell church authorities boldly that they are discriminated against, while stressing the need for churches to re- evaluate their practices with the aim to remove negative cultural influences that are oppressive to women.

On Rape as a Tool of Violence Against Women, Margaret Gecaga says the church should play the role of condemning all violations of human dignity and personal rights and help rehabilitate the victims of sexual abuse and violence.

At the community level, the local churches should alert their communities about manifestations of violence including rape, marital violence, child abuse, domination and submission of women and images of women as sex objects in the media, she suggests.

And basing her argument on several biblical verses to show the dignity of women from God's point of view, Gecaga says sexual violence tends to be seen in isolation as the act of a few perverted sex monsters. "But we have to see its connection with more widespread male behaviour towards women," she stresses.

In political conflicts, rape is committed by the victorious troops against women of the defeated side or considered as an act of aggression during the progress of the fighting, she further says, adding, "this was the case in Bosnia, where Muslim women were raped by government soldiers."

On Nguiko: A Tempering of Sexual Assault Against Women, Dr. Hannah Kinoti, laments that the early Christian missionaries among the Kikuyu community held the general outlook of the 19th century missionaries that "everything in non- Christian religions and cultures was evil. It was an outlook, which particularly denied any culture of value in Africa. In their perceived double mission to evangelise and civilize the African, missionaries believed that it was their duty to overhaul African culture," she argues.

Grace Wamue in her paper, Gender Violence and Exploitation: The Widow's Dilemma says the general view of widowhood in Kenya today, portrays negative stereotyping and stigmatization. She defines the attitude towards widowhood as an abuse of human dignity which perpetuates further psychological violence to a person who is grieved.

Wamue further describes a widow's dilemma as a form of sexist oppression because, a widower seems protected by the society from any stereotype and social stigma.

The lengthy burial preparations and complications, financial and property disposition, all turn a widow into a pauper, says Wamue. She recommends that theologians should tell the church when it goes wrong and educate widows on their rights.

And on the Status of Women in African Naming Systems, Dr. Mary Getui argues that the woman's role and place in the naming of her child should be appreciated. As it is now, she explains, the woman goes through a lot of physical, emotional and psychological trauma, which, she adds, affects her well-being and sometimes that of the child.

She recommends that women should not allow themselves to be pushed too far. They should be alert and ready to combat any attempts that may be made to violate them because of names and naming, and anything else for that matter, she further recommends.

In her presentation Hannah, Why Do You Weep?: (1 Samuel and 2:1-21), Dr. Nyambura Njoroge says while quoting the biblical words, "Hannah's words to Eli, the priest, could be or have been uttered by many African women in her situation. No. my Lord, I am a woman deeply troubled; I have drunk neither wine nor strong drink, but I have been pouring out my soul before the Lord. Do not regard your servant as a worthless woman, for I have been speaking out of my great anxiety and vexation all this time."

Like Hannah, women are capable of making decisions, acting and encountering God without a male intermediary because, like men, they are endowed with many gifts by the Holy Spirit and are empowered by the grace of God to participate fully in God's household, says Njoroge, the executive secretary, Department of Women and Men in Partnership at the Geneva-based World Alliance of Reformed Churches (WARC).


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Zimbabweans Raise Funds to Host Church Assembly


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

HARARE (APS) October 25 - Christians in Zimbabwe are set to raise Zimbabwe dollars 4 million (US$400,000) towards the 8th General Assembly of the World Council of Churches (WCC), which this Southern African country will host from September 10 to 21, 1998.

According to the assembly's local coordinator, Rosemary Siyachitema, the WCC Geneva secretariat will contribute Z$6 million (US$600,000) towards the assembly budget bringing the estimated total expenditure to Z$10 million (US$ one million).

In an interview with APS here on October 10, Siyachitema said the money will be raised mainly from the 20 member churches of the Zimbabwe Council of Churches, the host organization for the assembly.

"The idea here is to mobilise each and every Christian in the country to help raise the targeted amount, but with special emphasis on the ZCC member churches," she explained. 

On preparations already underway, Siyachitema informed that they had already instituted a local secretariat and set up operational, theological school, liaison, fund-raising and policy-making committees.

More committees are yet to be set up to cover such areas as communication (media) and accomodation.

The assembly, to be held at the University of Zimbabwe, will bring together between 3,000 to 4,000 delegates representing the 330 WCC member churches in more than 100 countries all over the world.

The 8th assembly which will also coincide with WCC's 50th anniversary, will deliberate on the theme, Turn to God-Rejoice in Hope, derived from the Book of Leviticus.

Siyachitema, told APS of the organising committees' commitment to sell the name of the assembly to the local churches and Christians, in the hope that most of the activities will have taken shape in 1997, a year before the assembly is held.

Rev. Murombedzi Chikanga Kuchera, the ZCC General Secretary, described Zimbabwe's hosting of the assembly as a great honour accorded to the church in Africa and particularly to this Southern African country.

"It is a challenge we would like to face squarely. We expect the entire church in Africa and more so the church here to join us in this venture," he told APS in an interview.

Asked to comment on the debate of homosexuals in the church, a controversial subject that has featured in previous WCC decision making fora such as the Central Committee, Siyachitema referred to WCC General Secretary Konrad Raiser's visit to Zimbabwe last August, and his talks with Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe over the matter.

In an earlier story carried in the APS Bulletin (See APS No.39/96) Dr. Raiser was reported assuring the WCC Central Committee members meeting in Geneva from September 12 to 20, that President Mugabe promised to protect the participants at the WCC assembly, allowing them freedom of association and expression of opinion.

The debate on homosexuality has become particularly sensitive within the WCC in view of Harare as the venue for the 8th Assembly, because of President Mugabe's publicly declared distaste of homosexuals whom he has likened to " beasts", threatening to jail them. On the other hand, WCC's 330 member churches meeting in Harare in 1998 have widely differing views on homosexuality.

And a WCC president, Rev. Dr. Eunice Santana, who was attending the General Assembly of the Association of Christian Lay Centres in Africa (ACLCA) held here from October 6 to 13, had this to say of the continent playing host to the WCC event; "The fact that Africa will host yet another WCC assembly (the 5th WCC assembly took place in Nairobi in 1975) is an indication that the African church is still within the heart beat of the WCC. We should therefore pray hard that things go as scheduled."

She singled out the forthcoming assembly as special, in that it will mark the end of the WCC-sponsored Ecumenical Decade in Solidarity with Women (1989- 1998).

The highest governing body of the World Council of Churches, the Assembly meets approximately every seven years.

With the first at inauguration in Amsterdam, Netherlands in 1948, other assemblies have taken place as follows; Evanson, United States of America (1954); New Delhi, India (1961); Uppsala, Sweden (1968); Nairobi, Kenya (1975) ; Vancouver, Canada (1983) and Canberra, Australia in 1991.

The WCC staff is currently headed by General Secretary Konrad Raiser, from the Evangelical Church in Germany (EKD).

Raiser, reappointed by the last (September 12 to 20) WCC central committee to a second five-year term of office, was elected to his present position by the 1992 central committee, and took up his duties in Geneva in January 1993. His first term of office expires at the end of 1997.

His reappointment on September 18 means the German theologian will hold office until the end of the year 2002.

Currently, WCC faces major challenges including financial difficulties which call for reorganization and re-thinking of the role of the ecumenical body.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 28, 1996


United States and Africa;
Nigerian Women Linked With Major U.S. Drug Syndicate


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

WASHINGTON DC (APS) October 25 - The United States Drug Enforcement Agency has claimed a major victory following the smashing last September of a major international drug smuggling ring led by Nigerian women. Of the 34 people arrested worldwide 15 are women.

Drug enforcement agents said some 55 tonnes of heroin worth $25 million was seized worldwide. "Their operations were on such a scale they rivalled that of the Colombian Medelin drug barons," observed Jim Milford, head of the Drug Enforcement Agency here. 

Milford said the head of the syndicate was a Nigerian woman based in the city of Chicago, United States. She used her boutique business in Chicago as the nerve centre in a global smuggling operation that relied on an elaborate exercise in deception.

One strategy the smuggling ring used all the time was to constantly vary their routes in order to confuse anti-narcotics officials in Asia, Europe and America. One of the seven main routes traced from Bangkok, Thailand to Europe, California, Mexico and then into Texas for onward distribution through the mid-western states of the United States.

The Chicago Tribune reported early October that the anti-narcotics officials made their first break through against the syndicate more than a year ago when their officials learnt about the Nigerian's boutique in Chicago. Quietly they pieced together intelligence reports over a period of one year before moving in to arrest the culprits. Telephone conversations conducted in Nigerian ethnic language were taped and translated to obtain vital leads that helped police to crack the syndicate.

Mr. Milford praised police and drug enforcement agencies in the United Kingdom, Switzerland, Mexico, New York, Thailand and Singapore for the coordinated surveillance that made the arrests possible.

Observers fear that the involvement of African women as key players in the drug syndicate's operations will heighten the survailance of African women travellers particularly those on business trips to Far Eastern countries like Thailand, and Singapore.

Already, Nigerian women comprise a large proportion of female prisoners in British penal institution. Most of these women were on drug courier missions when they were arrested.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 28, 1996


Uganda;
Uganda's Catholic Archbishop Visits War-Torn North


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

KAMPALA (APS) October 25 - The head of the Catholic church in Uganda, Emmanuel Cardinal Wamala spent three days in war-torn Gulu district of northern Uganda, in what was described as a "pastoral visit".

"The Cardinal went on a pastoral visit mainly to address seminarians at Alokolum Seminary," a statement from the Archbishop's office in Lubaga, Kampala, said of the October 21 to 23 visit.

Seminarians at Alokolum were recently reported to have demanded weapons training for self protection after the abduction of more than 100 girls by the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels who are fighting the regime of President Yoweri Museveni. Coincidentally President Museveni is in Gulu on an indefinite stay. 

Cardinal Wamala and the Catholic Bishops of Uganda have consistently advocated peace talks between the government and the LRA rebels who the government says are armed by neighbouring Sudan.

Three months ago, the Episcopal Conference of Uganda sent a three- man delegation led by Bishop Kalanda of Fort Portal to sound out prospects for a peace initiative. However, unconfirmed reports claimed that Joseph Kony, the leader of the LRA said he would await a "signal from God" before entering into any negotiations with President Museveni's government.

While the Cardinal was in Gulu, the Parliamentary Select Committee on the rebellion in the North was also in Gulu and took evidence from all interested parties on how to end the conflict.

Among witnesses was the Bishop of Gulu Catholic Diocese, Martin Luluga, who called on the government to extend a blanket amnesty to rebel leader Joseph Kony and his commanders like Colonel Otti Lagony and Oti Vincent.

President Museveni says Kony and his commanders are war criminals but Bishop Luluga and scores of other witnesses insisted that the only way to end the rebellion is to pardon the rebels and their leaders without any pre- conditions.

Museveni should swallow his pride and talk to Kony and others elsewhere, said Rev. George Odwong, a former military chaplain.

But a former state minister in charge of the North Mrs. Betty Bigombe who is now at Harvard University, characterised the select parliamentary probe committee on the rebellion in the North "as a waste of money."

She said the committee had only availed rebel sympathisers a platform to attack the government. Mrs. Bigombe warned that Joseph Kony's rebels are now confident they have strong backing from Sudan, "they see no reason to enter into negotiations with the government."

Meanwhile, the London-based Amnesty International has accused the Lord's Resistance Army of massive abuses of human rights, particularly rape and deliberate killings of civilians.

In its 1996 report, Amnesty says in April 1996 alone, as many as 200 civilians in the North were deliberately killed by the LRA.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 28, 1996


Zaire;
Refugees In Eastern Zaire Leave As Fighting Intensifies


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 960 words


 

BUKAVU-EASTERN ZAIRE (APS) October 25 - Thousands of Hutu refugees from Rwanda and Burundi are streaming north to the Bukavu high plateau in eastern Zaire, after fleeing fighting further south and triggering fears of a new humanitarian disaster.

Almost 300,000 refugees have left their camps around Uvira, near the border with Burundi and fled to the Bukavu high plateau for fear of getting caught up in fighting between Zairean troops and ethnic Tutsis, which has already made relief operations impossible, according to United Nations staff.

Zairean officials have accused the Tutsi-dominated Rwandan and Burundian governments of backing armed groups of ethnic Tutsis, known as Banyamulenge, who have lived in eastern Zaire for nearly two centuries and are now demanding Zairean citizenship.

But the Zairean authorities want both the Banyamulenge and some 1.2 million Hutu refugees to leave the country, and have at the same time accused the Burundian and Rwandan army of supporting the Banyamulenge in their struggle against the Zairean government. 

Other Hutu groups have also accused Burundian and Rwandan armies of being behind the attack by the Banyamulenge in their current fighting against Zairean forces in an effort to realise a Tutsi-Hima empire that would involve Tutsis in Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda, charges strongly denied by both Bujumbura and Kigali.

But as the situation in eastern Zaire was fast moving towards a humanitarian catastrophe, Burundi's army, which like Rwanda denied supporting the Banyamulenge, said on October 22 that exiled Hutu rebels from Zaire had carried out a raid over the border, attacking the town of Cibitoke for 90 minutes in the morning.

Burundian army spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Isaie Nibizi said he did not know how many people were killed in the rebel attack on Cibitoke, which is less than five kilometres from the easily- crossed Rusizi river on the border.

However, he stated that four rebels were killed and a soldier wounded on October 21 in the Burarana district of Burundi's central western Muramvya province.

In Geneva, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) spokesman Ron Redmond warned that the situation "has now deteriorated to such an extent that we are almost back to an emergency phase like in 1994," a reference to the flow to Zaire of hundreds of thousands of Rwandans during their country's genocidal civil war, when Hutu extremists killed between 500,000 and one million Tutsis and moderate Hutus before Tutsi Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) rebels seized power.

"We appeal to all sides to step back from the brink of what now threatens to become a very real humanitarian disaster in a region that has suffered enough," the UNHCR spokesman added.

Bukavu and Goma, on the northern and southern shores of Lake Kivu, close to the border with Rwanda, are both already centres for camps housing more than a million mainly Rwandan Hutu refugees.

The fighting between Zairean troops and the Banyamulenge also involves indigenous local tribes opposed to the presence of the ethnic Tutsis who have not been recognised by Zaireans, and had claimed at least 83 lives by the end of the third week of October, according to relief staff.

The UNHCR said that 3,000 Rwandans had appeared in the Bukavu region on Monday evening and had gone to the Nyengezi-Mulwa camp, where aid workers were to assess their health and food needs. Thousands more were arriving the following day.

Witnesses said troops had stopped the refugees getting any nearer Bukavu, 26 kilometres from Nyegezi. Relief officials said about 100 refugees had reached the town itself.

But most of the refugees were still hiding out in the hills and banana plantations around Uvira, which also form ideal terrain for guerrilla activity.

"They and we are at the mercy of a security situation that is so dangerous and chaotic that it is impossible at this time to predict the outcome," Redmond said.

Fighting is also taking place around refugee camps north of Bukavu, near the town of Goma, according to aid workers. This region is home to ethnic Rwandan Hutus and Tutsis, known as the Banyarwanda, as well as indigenous people and refugees.

The disastrous situation in the region, long prone to strife between traditionally dominant Tutsis and the farming Hutu majority, blew up with the Rwandan civil war of 1994 and mass bloodshed in Burundi, where an estimated 150,000 people have died in an escalating conflict since the assassination of that country's first Hutu president Melchior Ndadaye in October 1993.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


456 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Zambia;
Zambians Go To Polls On November 18


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

LUSAKA (APS) October 25 - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba has bowed to immense political pressure and announced that his country would go to the polls on November 18.

"I am happy to announce that both presidential and parliamentary elections should be held on November 18, 1996," Chiluba said at a campaign rally in the central Kabwe town, some 130 kilometres north of here, on October 19.

He told cheering supporters of his governing Movement for Multi- party Democracy (MMD) that elections would be held under the newly- amended controversial 1996 constitution.

Chiluba, who also announced the dissolution of parliament, maintained there would be no vacuum in the political leadership of the country. 

"There will be no vacuum ... there will only be a government. There will be no single day when there will be no president," Chiluba said.

"I remain president before, during and after elections, until I hand over the presidency either to myself or somebody."

Chiluba had remained silent on the election date, hence brewing widespread anxiety among Zambians as the end of his mandate drew closer on October 31.

President Chiluba's silence had infuriated opposition parties which accused him of trying to extend his term of office illegally, adding they would not recognise him after October 31.

Legal experts here argued that by dissolving parliament, Chiluba also dissolved his office because the presidency is tied to the life of the national assembly, but Chiluba said his MMD party would not be intimidated by anyone at all, stressing "We are in government, we intend to be in government and maintain law and order."

The coming elections could, however, be the bloodiest in Zambia's history, political pundits said, after riots broke out in the country the same day Chiluba was announcing the new election date.

The violence erupted after Chiluba announced the nomination of a junior minister, Paul Tembo, to stand in the Kabwe constituency, instead of a popular local businessman, Austin Chewe.

Police used batons against youths after hundreds went on the rampage, stoning local shops and cars. Police were acting on the orders of the president who told officers to "sort them out," state- run television reported.

Former President Kenneth Kaunda also announced on October 23 that his party will boycott the November 18 general elections and predicted that Chiluba's government would fall within six months after the polls through demonstrations and strikes.

"In three to six months this government will fall; that is, if there will be elections at all," he told a news conference, and pledged: "We are determined to keep the peace as we fight for our rights and rights of fellow Zambians against the evil perpetrated by (the government) through its manipulation of the constitution and the electoral process."

Kaunda, who ruled Zambia for 27 years, was effectively barred from running for president by a constitutional amendment passed by Chiluba's government earlier this year.

His United National Independence Party (UNIP) is the biggest opposition party in the Zambian parliament, holding 26 of the 150 seats, and apart from refusing to put up an alternative candidate, it now appears prepared to sacrifice its parliamentary seats.

The new law says the president must be at least a second-generation Zambian. Kaunda was born in Zambia but his parents immigrated from Malawi around the turn of the century.

Kaunda was also ruled out by another amendment which limits the president to two terms in office -- a move which he said should not be made retroactive.

The barring of Kaunda, just five years after he introduced the multiparty democracy which swept him from power, was widely criticised by Western donor nations, some of which suspended millions of dollars in aid.

He said officials from his party would tour the country to campaign against Chiluba's government, which he accused of "subverting the legislative process so as to prevent any alternative government from contesting and winning."

While he would not lead the country into violence, he said, "I will fight them through demonstrations." Kaunda also condemned the voter registration exercise carried out by an Israeli firm, Nikuv, saying that of 4.6 million eligible voters just 2.2 million had been registered.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


457 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Egypt;
Iran Denies Links With Arrested Shiites In Egypt


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

CAIRO (APS) October 25 - Egyptian security forces have arrested 56 Shiite Muslims accused of belonging to an underground group linked to Iran, but the Iranian government immediately denied it had any links with the group.

According to an announcement by Egypt's Interior Ministry here on October 21, the suspects, arrested in five provinces, "had begun implementing a plan to flood Egypt with publications and cassettes to spread Shiite thinking.

"The organization's leaders have visited Iran where they made contacts with both Iranian and Arab Shiite religious leaders," the ministry statement added. 

The police had seized 100,000 Egyptian pounds (29,500 US dollars) that was to finance the group and came "from internal and external sources," while computers, printing machines, various publications and cassette tapes made by Shiite Muslim leaders were also confiscated, the statement said.

The arrests were made in the provinces of Cairo, Giza, Shargiya, Dakhalia and Gharbia, the statement said, without indicating over what time-frame they had been carried out.

It said those arrested "were recruited after they were inculcated with Shiite ideas with a view toward sending them to Iran."

In Iran, they "would be trained in anticipation of the unification of underground Shiite groups through something known as the Supreme Shiite Council in Egypt," the statement added.

The members of the network are "expected to infiltrate some political parties and use them to spread Iranian objectives and extremist plans," the statement said.

The Interior Ministry gave the names of eight "leaders" of the clandestine organization -- two merchants, two civil servants, a teacher, a doctor, a driver and a man with no profession, saying they had visited Iran and been in contact with Iranian Shiite leaders.

The preacher Mohammed Hassan Shehata, arrested recently in Cairo for alleged Shiite preaching, "played a vital role in the execution of the Shiite plan," the ministry said.

"Since the beginning of the year, the state security services have infiltrated this underground Shiite organization and observed its leaders and members, who formed cells and recruited extremists with the goal of making Egypt into another Iran," the statement said.

The 56 arrested individuals will be brought before the state security prosecutor, who has begun an inquiry, it added.

But on October 23, Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati said a statement strongly denied any link between Iran and an undeground Shiite Muslim group in Egypt, saying Cairo was trying to shift the blame for unrest at home.

"We regret Egypt's having to accuse other countries from time to time in a bid to justify its inability to run the country. It is a proven fact that Egypt's troubles are a doment affair," Velayati said in a statement released in Tehran.

"Iran has repeatedly stated that it in no way interferes in the internal affairs of other countries," Velayati added.

Diplomatic relations with Egypt have been severed since Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution. Tehran denies involvement in the Islamic militant violence in Egypt that has killed more than 1,000 people since 1992.

Egypt, home to 60 million predominantly Sunni Muslim inhabitants, counts 500,000 Shiites among the population, according to Shiite sources, but police sources put the community' number at only a few thousands strong. Egypt was a bastion of the Shiite sect during the Fatimid era (909-1171) before turning to Suni Islam.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


458 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Sudan;
Sudanese Christians Celebrate Blessed Comboni Feast


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

NZARA-SOUTHERN SUDAN (APS) October 25 - Thousands of Sudanese Catholics and other faithful on October 20 commemorated the death of Bishop Daniel Comboni, the founder of the Christian faith in the Sudan.

Bishop Comboni died in 1881 at the age of 51. He was proclaimed Blessed by Pope John Paul II in March 1996. 

The day-long ceremony, led by Fr. David Glenday, the Superior General of the Comboni Missionaries took place in the south-western Sudanese town of Nzara, about 1,170 kilometres from the capital Khartoum.

It attracted delegations from Rome, Zaire, Sudan and Uganda. Father Peter Lwaminda of the Nairobi-based Association of Member Episcopal Conferences for Eastern Africa (AMECEA) was also among those who attended.

The holy mass which was conducted in English, Arabic, Dinka and the local Azande language was led by host Bishop Joseph Gasi of Tambura Yambio Diocese. The Apostolic Administrator of Rumbek Diocese, Monsignor Caesar Mazzolari and Max Macram Gassis of El-Obeid,all in southern Sudan, were also present.

Fr. Glenday had earlier presided over similar ceremonies in Khartoum on October 10, El Obeid on October 13 and at Dilling on October 14.

The late Bishop Daniel Comboni, an Italian, born at Limone on Lake Garda (Brescia, Italy), began his missionary work in Africa at the tender age of 26. Moved by the situation of human suffering in the region, he embarked on a mission to make Africa a better place to live in and was to spend the rest of his life shuttling between Europe and Africa in pursuit of his goal.

Keeping to his motto Africa or Death, the late Comboni presented an appeal, Postulatum pro Nigris, to the Fathers of the first Vatican Council in 1870, founded two missionary institutes and was made the head of the Apostolic Vicariate of Central Africa, first as Pro-vicar in 1872, then as Vicar Apostolic and Bishop in 1877.

Today the congregation of Comboni Missionaries has 1,800 priests and over 2, 000 nuns. There are 14 provinces of the Comboni Missionaries in Africa, two of which are in the Sudan. Others are in Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, Malawi, Zambia, Mozambique and South Africa.

Besides spreading the gospel and participating in relief work, the Comboni Missionaries have established and are responsible for the running of several development projects particularly in Africa's troubled spots. They have also set up and run schools and health institutions in different parts of the world.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


459 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Vatican Official Cautions Africans Against Ethnic Strife


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Nairobi (APS) October 25 - An official of the Vatican Embassy here has cautioned the African people to guard against divisions on ethnic lines.

Ethnic identity must not become an instrument of hatred, he said, stressing that "those who are guilty of this crime in Africa, exploit ethnic identity in their struggle for power and wealth."

Monsignor Edgar Pena-Parra made these remarks, here on October 20 when he presided over a colourful mass to mark the 18th anniversary of the inauguration of the pontifical reign of the incumbent Catholic pontiff, Pope John Paul II.

"Although the day falls on October 22, we decided to mark it today (Sunday October 20) to coincide with the church's Mission Sunday," Monsignor Pena- Parra told members of the press at the end of the Eucharist Mass. 

According to the Vatican official, who represented the Vatican Ambassador to Kenya Archbishop Giovanni Tonucci, "no ethnic group may take for itself the privilege of being in the right and having power," for, he stressed..." every individual, every cultural group, is unique and has the right to exist."

In some African countries, the issue of ethnic differences, has led to ethnic clashes between and among tribes and communities, resulting in bloodshed. Such countries include Rwanda and Burundi, where large scale ethnic differences between Tutsis and Hutus in both countries respectively, have led to massive loss of lives.

Monsignor Pena-Parra urged the rich countries in the North to continue supporting African countries in the latter's efforts to battle with the problems of refugees, poverty, economic and cultural under development.

The continuing gap between the rich and poor regions of the world is a serious threat to global stability, said Monsignor Pena-Parra.

The moral imperative of solidarity is fundamentally linked to human nature itself and to the absolute need which human beings have for one another. This need must be met at the level of nations and continents, otherwise living together in harmony becomes impossible, the Vatican representative told hundreds of faithful attending the mass.

Stressing that Africa is at cross-roads, Monsignor Pena-Parra urged the African people and their leaders to exercise all their wisdom in the difficult and urgent task of promoting a development which is not just economic and material, but one that would involve building a civilisation of respect for all members of society.

The mission of the church is not normally seen in the real way especially when speaking out on social issues such as the dignity of the human person, human rights, justice and peace among other issues, Monsignor Pena-Parra told the congregation at the Holy Family Basilica here.

According to a text prepared to mark the event, people often ask the question why the Pope visits Africa so often. This is explained in the understanding that Africa is the continent of the family, and the future of the church's evangelisation mission passes through the family.

Born Karol Wojtyla on May 18, 1920, the incumbent Catholic Pontiff is the son of a Polish sub-lieutenant in the army. He lost his mother at the age of 9 years.

Wojtyla was brilliant at school and excelled at sports such as football, swimming, walking, canoeing and skiing. He entered the University of Cracow in 1938 and worked in a quarry, cutting stones at Slovak Chemical Works in 1940, while continuing his studies by himself.

The young Polish joined an underground Catholic seminary in 1942 and was ordained priest in 1946. He became a bishop in 1958 at the age of 36 years.

Pope John Paul II was created pope on October 18, 1978' while his pontifical throne was inaugurated on October 22, the same year.

The first Catholic pontiff to come from the then Eastern Bloc, John Paul II succeeded Pope John Paul I (Albino Luciani), who died 33 days after his papal election. Before Paul I, was Pope John Paul VI, best remembered by African Christians as having visited Uganda in 1969, where he canonized the famous Ugandan Martyrs.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


460 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 28, 1996


South Africa;
Statement On Buthelezi And Affirmative Action


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC in KwaZulu Natal finds the attack of Chief MG Buthelezi, Minister of Home Affairs, on the government policy of affirmative action as an affront to the intelligence of Africans, Indians, Coloureds and women if the newspaper reports are correct. That Chief Buthelezi uttered these unfortunate words in the Conference of the IFP Women's Brigade is an insult to the very motherhood and the Titans of our nation. 

Even the forces of apartheid no longer have the temerity to utter such words in the public. Chief Buthelezi's statement begs a question whether the IFP is still honest to its founding principle of freedom for the oppressed or it has become a front of the extreme white right- wing. Only the extreme white right-wing can be expected to find a fault with affirmative action. Chief Buthelezi's statement is not surprising if one takes into account the IFP's recent history of its members being trained, armed and deployed by the fascist elements within the apartheid security forces.

Perhaps for Chief Buthelezi to be efficient you must be a lawyer, male, white, Italian and foreign. The ANC calls upon the Government of National Unity and the private sector to ensure that the programmes to uplift those sections of our society whom apartheid discriminated against are accelerated. In fact, if there is anything to bemoan, it is that affirmative action is not yet being fully implemented. Most Africans, Indians, Coloureds and women recently promoted to higher positions were not promoted because of affirmative action. They qualify to those positions on their own merit. They were only discriminated against by apartheid.

Issued by the ANC KZN Dpt of Information and Publicity

Date: 27 October, 1996. Contact Dumisani Makhaye at 031-4006416 or 031 - 307 5460.


LOAD-DATE: October 30, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 28, 1996


South Africa;
ANC Questions Adviser Role in KwaZulu


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC in KwaZulu Natal is surprised that the problem around the employment of Mario Ambrosini, the Italian foreign adviser of the Minister of Home Affairs, is not resolved as yet even though there is a government resolution not to employ foreigners. That it is alleged that Ambrossini has incurred expenses of about R1/2 million in two years on top of his R28 000 per month salary and the claim by the Director- General of Home Affairs that Ambrosini had done no work of the department, shows that the decision to call Ambrosini to appear before the Home Affairs Committee is too little and too late. 

The taxpayers can no longer afford to pay for advisers who seemingly are not doing their work but instead act as advisers of political parties. The taxpayers cannot fund the IFP under apartheid and again in the new political dispensation.

The ANC in KwaZulu Natal calls upon the GNU to implement its decision not to employ foreigners. The continued employment of Ambrosini betrays political indecision and chicanery.

Issued by the KZN Dpt of Information and Publicity.

Date: 27 October 1996. Contact: Dumisani Makhaye - at 031 - 307 5460 or 031 4006416.
