Africa News


October 29, 1996


Zambia;
Ruling Party Challenged By Rebellious Members


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) is facing a rebellion around the country where some members aspiring for parliamentary seats have decided to challenge party nominees for the Nov. 18 elections.

The rebels include former Commerce Minister Dipak Patel, who is contesting his former Lusaka central constituency, pitting himself against the party's official candidate, MMD deputy national treasurer Sylvia Masebo. 

Patel had resigned his cabinet portfolio along with former Works and Supply Minister Simon Zukas in protest against the constitutional amendments that bar second-generation Zambians from contesting presidential elections.

The amendment has also affected former President Kenneth Kaunda because his parents were from neighboring Malawi. His leading opposition party, UNIP, is boycotting the polls.

Another prominent member, Austin Chewe, is challenging MMD deputy national secretary Paul Tembo, for the midlands town of Kabwe constituency. Tembo held the seat in the outgoing parliament.

Two weeks ago, Chewe's supporters sparked off a riot at an MMD national rally addressed by President Frederick Chiluba at which he announced names of party candidates for the November elections. They were protesting Chewe's omission from the list.

Zambia's former high commissioner to Zimbabwe, Roger Sakuhuka, on Monday resigned from the ruling party and was expected to stand for his old seat in Zambezi, north-western Zambia, on the ticket of the opposition National Party.

Sakuhuka had served as minister of tourism in Kaunda's last cabinet, voted out of power during the country's first multiparty elections in 1991.

Meanwhile, Zambia's Lands Minister Peter Machungwa has been declared unopposed for the Luapula parliamentary constituency, in northern Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 29, 1996


South Africa;
More European Union Assistance For South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The European Union is providing another 6 million U.S. dollars to finance rural water supply projects in South Africa.

In an announcement in Pretoria on Monday, the EU said the programme -- which is expected to fund about 100 water and sanitation projects during the next two years -- will be aimed at rural areas which do not yet have any such facilities. 

It is part of the Mvula Trust, which is South Africa's largest non- government organisation financing water supply and sanitation projects. The latest EU contribution lifts total aid by the Union to the Mvula Trust beyond the 13 million dollars. It forms part of the EU's total annual contribution of 130 million dollars to South Africa's Reconstruction and Development Programme.

The EU's Ambassador to South Africa, Erwan Fouere, said the programme would concentrate on development of infrastructure. It would also intensify the development of local community involvement in addressing their own needs.

"The empowerment of those communities will ensure a sustainable development process," he added, "and will enable the people to stand tall with a dignity that was denied them in the past."


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


490 of 541 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 29, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigerian Universities Resume Classes After Strike


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Teaching has resumed in Nigerian universities after a seven-month strike by lecturers.

Reports from across the country indicate a return to normalcy in most of the country's universities, which number about 40. 

At the University of Lagos, normal lectures resumed Monday with students expressing greater confidence that they will finish the semester and take their examinations.

Some lecturers had been teaching a handful of students during the period of the strike launched April 9 by the banned Academic Staff Union of Universities.

But yielding to public appeal, the union suspended the strike last week. It had been pressing for adequate funding of Nigerian universities and better pay for its members.

The Ahmadu Bello University in the northern city of Zaria, closed for about one year over a student crisis, is expected to reopen Nov. 2.

Students of the Northern University of Ilorin are quarrelling over the examination timetable, set for Dec. 9 which they describe as "unrealistic."

They have also accused some of their lecturers of selling their lesson handouts at "exorbitant prices."

Some lecturers often resort to lesson handouts because of the dearth of text books in the country.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Zaire;
Hundreds of Zairians Flee Into Uganda


BYLINE: Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Hundreds of Zairian refugees have entered Uganda, fleeing the war raging in eastern Zaire.

The refugees have been entering Uganda through Ishasha border post but most of them have re-entered Zaire through another border post at Mpondwe, state- owned daily, The New Vision, has reported. 

"We are fleeing to north Kivu. The road to Beni from Bukavu and Goma is not safe. There is too much fighting at home, " the refugees told the paper.

The refugees, who include Zairian government officials, are travelling in vehicles including trailers, pick-ups and saloon cars.

"Thousands are walking, fleeing the war in south Kivu. Others may die on the way," the refugees said.

They told Ugandan security officials in Bushenyi and Kasese border districts that they were going to settle in Beni, Mutwanga and other areas considered to be safe in north Kivu province.

Only heads of families of the refugees are being registered at Mpondwe customs post by Ugandan security officials.

"But they are not yet in thousands. You can say hundreds," police commander Richard Edyegu said.

Meanwhile, United Nations and other expatriate workers from the eastern Zairian town of Bukavu were on Sunday evacuated to Uganda by two U.N. buffalo aircraft.

The 128 aid workers have been put in a temporary base at the old Entebbe airport, 34 kilometres south of Kampala where a communications center has been installed.

The airport was used as a supply base for American troops delivering aid to Rwanda refugees in Goma, Zaire, in 1994.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Sudan;
Khartoum Rules Out Peace Talks With Rebels


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Sudanese government has ruled out peace talks with the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), which is fighting in southern Sudan against the Khartoum government.

Foreign Minister Ali Asman Mohammed Taha said in an interview carried by the government daily, El Sudan El Hadith, on Tuesday that the government believes such talks could be aborted through intervention of third parties who have influence on SPLA, led by John Garang. 

"The government has no intention at the moment to hold any direct talks with the SPLA because the SPLA is now under pressure from the northern Sudanese opposition represented in the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) and foreign powers that prevent it to talk independently."

Taha added that the SPLA was also plagued with internal conflicts that make it unable to come forward for a useful meeting with the government.

He further belittled the recent alliance declared between the SPLA and other armed opposition groups belonging to the NDA as "an indication of the failure of the opposition."

Representatives of the political parties outlawed by Gen. Omar Bashir when he seized power in 1989, the SPLA, and defecting army officers reportedly met in Asmara, Eritrea, last week and unified their armed forces under the command of the SPLA.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Business and Finance;
No Dividends For Kenya Airways Shareholders


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Kenya Airways will not pay dividends to shareholders in 1996, in spite of a record operating profit of 2 billion shillings (56 shillings = 1 USD) earned on a turnover of 10 billion shillings.

According to the national carrier's annual report for the year ended March 31 1996, the management, however, hopes to pay shareholders a dividend during the next financial year.

The company made an after-tax profit of 1.42 billion shillings compared to the previous year's profit of 2.1 billion shillings. 

But the profit was affected by the settlement of a labor dispute between the airline and its pilots resulting in a payment of 411 million shillings, reflected in the report as an exceptional expenditure.

During the period under review, the airline paid a tax of 169.6 million shillings compared to nothing the previous year. The earnings per share after taxation and sundry expenditures stood at 3.07 per share compared to the previous year's 4.63 million shillings.

The Kenya Airways Chairman, Isaac Omolo Okero, says the year was the most significant in the carrier's history, when the government divested its 51 percent shareholding, and the purchase of a 26-percent stake by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.

"The partnership with KLM will prove to be a good investment due to the experience the latter has in international routes", Okero said, adding that KLM's investment has brought with it the experience of one of the world's leading airlines. Kenya Airways was already benefitting from joint initiatives designed to improve the quality of service offered to passengers, he added.

The Airways Managing Director, Brian Davies, said in the report published last week, that the carrier's current profit margin were among the best in the industry worldwide, when measured against return on capital employed which stood at 25.3 percent or against net margin on sales of 13.8 percent.

The first half of 1990s saw airlines recover from the effects of the Gulf War, and by 1994/95, operating benefits were recorded by major international carriers.

The report says the International Air Transport Association forecasts for Sub-Saharan Africa show an annual growth potential of 7 percent over the next five years.

"As one of the few privatized flag carriers in Africa, we are uniquely placed to play a leading role in developing air transport links within the region," Davies said.

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Zaire;
Humanitarian Agencies Say Security Needed For Relief Aid


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Nairobi - The following statement reflects the views of participants from UN agencies and NGOs present at a meeting in Nairobi on 28 and 29 October 1996 which convened in order to agree on actions required in North and South Kivu, Zaire. The UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs (DHA) called the meeting to review the present crisis and share information on humanitarian strategies, operational plans and constraints.

As the UN Secretary-General noted in his 24 October letter to the Security Council, the situation in North and South Kivu is already a grave political and humanitarian crisis for both Zaireans and refugee populations in the area, as well as for the stability of the region. During the last week, military activity in border areas has escalated, and an estimated 500,000 people are on the move throughout the Kivu sub-region. 

The major effects of the conflict have been to disperse refugee populations, as well as to displace large numbers of Zaireans from their homes. At present it appears that the majority of refugees are remaining within Zaire, as large return movements to Rwanda and Burundi have not occurred.

Certain areas of North and South Kivu are war zones, and conflict and insecurity make the delivery of humanitarian assistance virtually impossible. Humanitarian personnel seeking to work in the area have been subjected to death threats, have experienced acts of violence against their staff, had their vehicles stolen and property taken. Humanitarian organizations have had no positive responses to their demands for guarantees of security and access to vulnerable populations.

Despite these constraints, humanitarian organizations are ready to return to the region as soon as practically possible. The major constraints of lack of security and access must be addressed by discussions with the authorities in Kinshasa as well as local leaders. In order for humanitarian organizations to recommence work in Uvira, negotiations with local leaders will be necessary, while at the national level it must be made clear that these are for the purposes of humanitarian access only, and do not amount to political recognition of any local forces or put into question the territorial integrity of Zaire.

It may also be necessary to undertake negotiations in areas held by rebel forces to allow safe passage for those refugees seeking to return to their country of origin. Discussions with other regional governments will also be needed to allow aid to be transported to these affected areas in Zaire, when that becomes possible. Humanitarian agencies will do all they can to impartially assist members of all vulnerable groups. Humanitarian organizations will also send the unequivocal message to the international community that a lasting political solution is vital, and will only be achieved once the nationality question, and other underlying issues including the presence of refugees, are addressed.

The following agencies attended the meeting. Those in brackets were not present when this document was finalized: ACTIONAID; CARE INTERNATIONAL; (CHRISTIAN AID); MSF; (MDM); (NORWEGIAN CHURCH AID); (OXFAM UK AND IRELAND); SAVE THE CHILDREN UK; (UMCOR); (ICRC); (IFRC); DHA; UNICEF; WFP; (WHO).

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996

October 29, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Algerian Film Wins Top Award at Carthage Film Festival


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Tunis - "Salut Cousin" by Algerian filmmaker Merzak Allouache was awarded the Golden Tanit, the top prize of the Carthage Film Festival. The Silver and Bronze prizes were awarded respectively to "Po Di Sangui" (Tree of Blood) by Flora Gomes from Guinee Bissau, and "Haifa" by Palestinian filmmaker Rachid Mashrawi. 

The Golden Tanit was Allouache's second, after his 1978 film "Les aventures d'un hero" (Adventures of a Hero). "Salut Cousin" is the story of Algerian immigrants living in France who are torn between the difficulty of adjusting to life in France and the equally difficult situation in their home country. In awarding the Golden Tanit to "Salut cousin", the festival's international jury cited the "maturity of its cinematogrphic language" and for "describing with lucidity and courage the life of Algerian immigrant communities."

The Best Actress prize was awarded to Ilhem Chahine from Egypt for her role in "La vie, ma passion", and the prize for Best Actor was awarded to Mustapha Adouani from Tunisia for his role in "Et=E9 a la Goulette" (Summer in La Goulette). In the short features category, the Golden Tanit was awarded to " Un taxi pour Aouzou" from Chad.

Nineteen films and 17 short features from 14 Arab and African countries competed in the week-long film festival which gathered a large number of Arab and African film professionals, enthusiasts, and officials.

This year's edition marks the 30th anniversary of the Carthage Film =46estival. The event, which is organized every two years, is a forum of competition and exchange for Arab and African cinema.

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Tunisian Mosaic To Decorate Court Halls


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Tunis - A replica of an ancient mosaic depicting a sea landscape (Neptune and the =46our Seasons) was offered by President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali to the newly-created International Law of the Sea Court (ILSC) in Hamburg, Germany on Friday, October 18, 1996.

The mosaic was presented by Tunisian Health Minister Dr. Hedi Mhenni to the president of the Court during an inaugural ceremony of the ILSC, attended by United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros Ghali and Germany's Minister of Justice. 

A Tunisian judge, Mr. Mouldi Marsit, was among the 21 international judges who were installed during the inaugural ceremony.

Tunisia, which was a province of the Roman Empire for nearly 7 centuries (2nd century BC to 500 AD), has the largest collection of Roman mosaics in the world, most of them housed in the Bardo Museum in Tunis.

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Business and Finance;
Tunisia Symposium ExaminesBroadcasting In Digital Era


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Tunis - The implications of new communications technologies on Arab broadcasting is the topic of an international symposium organized by the Tunis-based Arab States Broadcasting Union (ASBU), the International Telecommunications Union (ITU), and the Friedrich Ebert Stifting Foundation, October 23-25, 1996, in the resort town of Hammamet.

About 150 participants representing 20 broadcasting organizations will discuss the ramifications of the advent of digital broadcasting on cable television, satellite broadcasting, production, and programming. Legal, cultural, and social implications are also part of the presentations by the various panels of Arab and international broadcasting experts and academics. A final session will cover Arab cooperation in broadcasting with regard to the new communications technologies.

According to Raouf Basti, ASBU secretary general, the symposium is the culmination of nine years of discussion among ASBU members about the best ways to plan and implementthe future development of Arab broadcasting and the use of new technologies. ASBU, an arm of the League of Arab States, is a cooperative of all Arab public radio and television organizations.

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Business and Finance;
Tunisia Expects A Record Olive Harvest


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Tunis - Tunisian farmers are gearing up to a record harvest of olives and olive oil, two essential staples of Tunisian agriculture. According to Mohamed Ben Rejeb, Minister of Agriculture, the total production of olive oil this fall season is expected to reach 200,000. Production during the previous two years was 70,000 (1994) and 60,000 (1995), a low output because of poor rainfalls.

The minister of agriculture told a press gathering October 25, that the best conditions for the processing, storage and transportation of olive oil will be made available in order to ensure an excellent olive harvest season and a top quality olive oil.

About 1.7 million tons of olives are expected to be processed in 1,300 olive oil treatment plants throughout the country. The olive groves in the central and southern regions produce most of Tunisia's olive oil.

Total national consumption of olive oil is estimated at 50,000 tons annually. Olives and olive oil are essential ingredients in Tunisian cooking and diet.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Tunisia;
Presidents Ben Ali and Chirac Exchange Views by Phone


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Tunis - Relations between Tunisia and France and developments in the Middle East were the main topics of a telephone conversation between Tunisian president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali and French president Jacques Chirac on Saturday, October 26, 1996.

President Ben Ali and president Chirac reviewed the situation in the Middle East following the French president's tour in several countries of the region. According to Tunisian news Agency TAP, both leaders agreed on "the need for all concerned parties (in the Middle East) to respect their commitments, according to the agreements and resolutions of the United Nations."

The phone conversation between presidents Ben Ali and Chirac was the second in less than six weeks. When President Chirac visited Tunisia on October 5 and 6, 1995, both leaders agreed to maintain contact by telephone and to consult each other on important bi-lateral and international matters.

Africa News


October 29, 1996


Tunisia;
International Cooperation on Cultural Heritage


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Tunis - Minister of Culture Abdelbaki Hermessi discussed with Mr. Miguel- Angel Corzo, representative of the Paul Getty Foundation, the ways and means of boosting cooperation between Tunisia and the foundation. The two parties also examined the prospects of the Foundation's participation in the 1997 UNESCO-sponsored event: "Tunis, Regional Cultural Capital".

The Paul Getty Foundation is an institution interested in research, education and the safeguard of cultural heritage.

The Minister also met with Mr. Marc Laenen, director of the Center for International Studies on Cultural Property and Preservation, and discussed cooperation in organizing conferences, training experts, and consolidating the newly established training program for the study and preservation of national heritage in the Maghreb region.
